Information requested by The Minister regarding letter of June 13, 1952, from Right Reverend Robert Jefferson, Bishop of Ottawa.

1. Re last paragraph, page 2, and first paragraph on page 3:

It is regretted that the Church of England sees fit to adopt the attitude expressed in paragraphs mentioned. Each disputed case has been considered on its merits and it is understood that the decision given was in accordance with departmental interpretation of Section 117.

2. It would appear that the cases mentioned in the last three paragraphs of page 3, also the information contained on page 4 as well as the top portion of page 5 have been reviewed in this letter for the purpose of directing attention to the paragraph marked "Note" on page 5.

It would be extremely difficult, if not impossible, to carry out the procedure requested without the fullest cooperation of the Churches. Otherwise the only possible action that an Indian Superintendent can take is to accept the parent's statement regarding his religion and the school in which he wishes his child placed.

3. In paragraph 6 on page 3 and in some other places in the communication, there is reference to the delay in dealing with correspondence and making decisions.

Religious cases cannot be settled quickly. Complete information must be obtained from field officers, and the interchange of correspondence in order to obtain the very definite information required causes a considerable time lag. In addition, during the period about which the complaint is particularly made, the Education Division staff was depleted owing to resignations and has only been brought to full strength during the past few weeks. As a result, it was physically impossible to give immediate attention to the large volume of correspondence which the Education Division receives daily.

4. Paragraph 4 or letter of February 7, 1952, mentioned on page 4 presumably refers to the request of the Church of England for the Department to purchase the present Fort George Church of England Residential School and enlarge its accommodation. This cannot be definitely considered until the church of England is able to produce satisfactory title to the land on which the present school is situated. It is our understanding that the church of England is now negotiating with the Quebec Provincial Government with a view to obtaining a proper title.
5. Paragraph 5 of page 4 refers to an interview that Canon Cook had with the Minister. In regard to this interview Canon Cook states that Mr. Harris assured him that in such cases "the final decision rested with the Director or the Minister".

Since the new Indian Act was issued in September, 1951, there have been placed before the branch approximately 57 so-called religious cases. Some of these have been requests for placing children of Roman Catholic antecedents in Protestant schools and others have been requests to transfer children of Protestant antecedents to Roman Catholic schools. With the exception of two cases, which will be dealt with later in this memorandum, none of the other religious cases have been decided by the Director or other official of the Indian Affairs Branch. The information in each case has been submitted for direction and instructions issued have been followed.

6. The latter part of page 5 refers to the case of the James children.

This family is from the Stikine Agency in the Province of British Columbia and both parents are living. The father requested by application the admission of his children, Albert age 7, Jimmy age 12 and Paddy age 10, to the Carcross Church of England Residential School. On the application form the religion was not mentioned, but a separate statement attached to the forms read as follows: "I do fully understand that this is a Protestant school and not a Roman Catholic." He made no further commitment regarding his religious denomination, other than the statement mentioned.

Superintendent Clark stated that it is his understanding that the family is of the Roman Catholic faith. However, Mr. Clark recommended the admission of the children to the Carcross School. The decision made in this particular instance was as follows: "Applicant being Roman Catholic, children should attend Roman Catholic school". Instructions were issued accordingly but the Church of England was advised that these children could remain in the Carcross School until the end of the academic year, namely June 30, 1952, and per capita grant would be allowed for them to that date, in order that their academic work might not suffer any interference. At the end of June, the Carcross School has been directed to return the children to their parents.

7. At the bottom of page 6 the case of "Kenneth Johnson" is mentioned. The application for this boy was forwarded to the Department by Superintendent Meek. The application form stated that the boy's religion is Roman Catholic and no reason was given for wishing him admitted to the Carcross School, which is conducted under Church of England auspices. Consequently, Superintendent Meek was written in the manner mentioned in the last paragraph on page 6. The letter mentions that no grant is being allowed for him. This is correct because the circumstances were different. While the correspondence regarding his admission was proceeding the boy was not in the school and consequently the Church of England was not expending any funds on his behalf. It was for this reason that no grant was allowed. This is a different case from the James children, who were in the school while the correspondence regarding
their admission was being considered and, of course, were being maintained during that period by the school. This is one of the cases referred to in paragraph 5.

8. Re: Clyde Blackjack - The first information that the Branch received regarding this boy was contained in a letter from Bishop Goudert (R.C. Bishop of the Yukon), dated January 30, 1952. In this letter Bishop Goudert states that this boy is an orphan. The Bishop further stated that he was well acquainted with the whole family - that all had joined the Catholic Church nearly 10 years previously - that two of the other children in the family had attended the Grouard (R.C.) Residential School - that the father had died some years previously and that the mother, together with four of her other children, was in the Cassell Hospital and as a result of the mother's condition, the Bishop stated that the boy Clyde was being neglected, and he therefore requested that Clyde be placed in the Lower Post Residential School. One sentence in Bishop Goudert's letter read as follows: "I was amazed to hear that Agent Meek, far from showing any interest in the educational welfare of the boy, looked for every possible excuse to discourage the local Missionary, Father Turenne, to have the boy admitted to the Lower Post School".

In view of the information contained in Bishop Goudert's letter, Superintendent Meek was written on February 7th and informed of the contents of Bishop Goudert's letter. He was instructed to have the boy placed in the Lower Post School, provided the boy was physically fit.

Subsequently, we received a letter from Superintendent Meek, stating that one of the boy's brothers thought he should be placed in the Carcross School. However, we felt that the information contained in Bishop Goudert's letter, as quoted above, definitely indicated that the religion of this boy should be considered as Roman Catholic. Later, Mr. Meek forwarded to us an application form signed by his brother, Roddy Blackjack. This form stated that the boy's religion was Roman Catholic.

You will note that the action in connection with this boy was taken previous to Archdeacon Clough's interview with the mother in the Charles Cassell Indian Hospital. It is noted that Archdeacon Clough states that the religion of the mother is recorded in the Charles Cassell Indian Hospital as Roman Catholic. This is the second of the cases mentioned in paragraph 5.

9. Re Dreaer children mentioned at the bottom of page 9, the information we received regarding this family from the Indian Superintendent was to the effect that the family resided in the Meadow Lake Agency and that both parents were living. The application forms which were forwarded and approved by the Indian Agent stated that their religion was Roman Catholic, although the parents applied for their admission to the Lac la Ronge Church of England Residential School. The ruling given in this case was as follows: "Applicant being Roman Catholic, children should attend Roman Catholic school." However, as the children had been placed in the Lac la Ronge School without our authority and in order that we would not interfere with their academic year, it was
decided to allow them to remain in that school to the end of
the current academic year, June 30, 1952, and pay the usual per
capita grant for their maintenance. Instructions were also
issued to have them discharged from the Lac la Monge School at
the end of June this year and returned to their parents.

10. At the bottom of page 9 and the top of page 10, there
is a reference to Anna and Dora Heather (Heather) who, it is stated,
are members of the Church of England, but the father placed them
in the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

The applications for these children were very carefully
considered and the ruling made was as follows: "Except if the
mother is of the Roman Catholic faith, the children who, it is
assumed, are of the same religion as their father, should attend a
Protestant school." Subsequently it was ascertained that the mother
is a Protestant and consequently instructions were issued to the
effect that the Department was not prepared to approve their admis-
sion to the Onion Lake R.C. School but in order not to interfere
with their academic work they could remain in the school until the
end of the current academic year, namely June 30, 1952, at which
time they should be returned to their parents.

James Bay (page 10)

This refers to the admission of George and Bertie Andrew
Wesley to the Albany R.C. Residential School.

At the time the application forms were received last fall,
the forms stated that these children were Roman Catholic and their
application for admission to the Albany School was signed by the
father and approved by Superintendent Allan. As the application
forms appeared to be in order, their admission to the Albany School
was approved.

At the end of March, Bishop Clarke advised the Superintendent
of Education that these children were members of the Church of
England. Indian Superintendent Allan was immediately written in
regard to the matter but there has been considerable delay in re-
ceiving his reply as he stated he could not obtain access to the
Church records owing to the absence of Bishop Clarke. Recently we
received complete information regarding these children and a memo-
randum regarding the matter is going forward to the Deputy Minister's
office for decision.

12. Old Sun School - pages 10, 11, 12, and 13 refer to
requests for transfer of certain pupils from the Old Sun (C. of E.)
Residential School to the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School -
both of which are located in the Blackfoot Indian Agency in the
Province of Alberta.
Mayfield children -

Phyllis,
Bert Nelson,
Walter.

The first two mentioned children attended the Old Sun Residential School until June 30, 1951. As far as we know, Walter had not attended any school.

The information we received was as follows:

"The father is deceased and the mother is responsible for her children. Mrs. Mayfield has taken out a statutory declaration stating that she has been baptized a Catholic and is a member of the Roman Catholic church and that she wants her children to be placed in the Roman Catholic Residential School."

In making the above statement, she requested the transfer of Phyllis and Bert Nelson from the Old Sun's to the Crowfoot School and the admission of Walter, who had not previously attended school, to the Crowfoot School. The decision in this instance was as follows: "The Mother being the responsible parent, is Roman Catholic and the children should attend Roman Catholic school.

Yellowhorse children -

David,
Percy,
Marie,
Silvia.

All of these children had been in the Old Sun's School until June 30, 1951, but the following information was received from the Indian Superintendent:

"The Yellowhorse family is from the Blackfoot Indian Agency and both parents are living. The father has taken out a statutory declaration stating that he has severed any connection with the Anglican Church and that after the transfer of his children to the Roman Catholic School he will have no further connection with the Anglican faith. He further stated that he had been baptized a Catholic and is a member of the Roman Catholic Church and he requested the transfer of these children to the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School."

The decision in this case was as follows:

"In view of the father's declaration, the children should attend the Crowfoot R.C. School".

The information contained at the top of page 12, to the effect that these children are now in the Old Sun's School, is in accordance with instructions given from this office, that in order that there might be no undue interference with their academic work they could remain in the Old Sun's C.E. School to the end of the academic year, June 30, 1952, and that per capita grant would be allowed Old Sun's School for them.
Royal children -

Floyd,
Romana,
Francis.

The two first mentioned children were enrolled at the Old Sun's School to June 30, 1951. They did not return to this school when it re-opened on September 1, 1951, but instead enrolled at the Crowfoot Residential School on October 10, 1951. The information that we received is as follows:

"The father is deceased and the mother is responsible for her children. Mrs. Alfreda Royal has taken out a statutory declaration stating that she has been baptized a Catholic and is a member of the Roman Catholic faith. The mother requests the transfer of Floyd and Romana from the Old Sun's School to the Crowfoot School and the admission of Francis (who has not previously attended school) to the Crowfoot School".

The decision in this case was as follows:

"The mother being the responsible parent, is Roman Catholic and children should attend R.C. School".

As these children had not returned to the Old Sun's School on September 1, 1951, but enrolled in the Crowfoot School and were still in that school at the time the above-mentioned decision was given, there was no necessity to return them to the Old Sun's School.

Wolfchild -

Edward.

This boy was in the Old Sun's School to June 30, 1951, having been placed in that school on October 1, 1947.

At the time of his son's admission to the Old Sun's School he indicated that his religious denomination was Church of England. In a declaration dated July 31, 1951, the father stated that he had never been an adherent of, nor had anything to do with the Anglican Church and consequently requested the transfer of his son, Eddie, from the Old Sun's C.E. Residential School to the Crowfoot Residential School.

The decision in this case was as follows:

"In view of father's declaration, boy should attend the R. C. School."

As Edward Wolfchild did not return to the Old Sun's School at the start of the 1951-52 academic year, he was not returned to that school but has remained in the Crowfoot Residential School.
Turning Robe

George

The information received about this case was as follows:

"Father has taken out a statutory declaration stating that he has no connection with the Anglican Church and has completely severed connections with it and has become an adherent of the Roman Catholic Church. He has had his children baptized in the Roman Catholic faith. There is one son, George, 10, attending the Old Sun's School and the father requests the transfer of the boy to the Crowfoot School."

The decision in this case was as follows:

"In view of father's declaration, boy should attend the Crowfoot School".

However, as he had returned to the Old Sun's School at the start of the 1951-52 academic year, he is being allowed to remain in that school to the end of June, 1952, in order that his academic work may suffer no interference. The Old Sun's School is drawing the usual per capita grant for him.

In the last paragraph on page 13 and the top paragraph on page 14, reference is made to official letter of February 29, 1952. The date on the letter, namely February 29, was the date the letter was prepared in the Education Division. Ordinarily, such letter would not reach the Director's office until the following morning at the latest and no statement of policy could be made until the Director had signed the letter.

With reference to the section on page 14 referring to special grants, it is felt that it would give a more complete picture if consideration were given to the entire amount of government funds that were expended at church-owned residential schools, during the fiscal years mentioned on page 14. With reference to the third last paragraph on page 14, which mentions a letter of August, 1950, the following is a copy of the reply sent to Canon Cook at that time:

"August 29th, 1950.

"Rev. Canon H. G. Cook, D.D.,
Superintendent,
The Indian School Administration, M.S.C.C.,
102 Bank Street, Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Canon Cook:

Re: Your File Est-51-52

I desire to refer to your letters of July 12th and August 15th with reference to special grants for equipment and repairs to the Church-owned Schools as recorded on page M-48 of the "Public Accounts of Canada 1949".

In your letter you compare the average expenditure by the number of schools concerned. It is felt that a fairer comparison is on the per capita basis. The authorized pupilage at the 19 Church-owned Roman Catholic Schools is 2135. The expenditure for the fiscal year 1948-49 was $42,659.01. This makes an average expenditure per pupil of $19.98.

The authorized pupilage at the 6 Church-owned Church of England Schools is 325. The expenditure was $5,142.70. This makes an average expenditure per pupil of $15.82.

I might also point out that during the fiscal year 1948-49 (see page M-46) there was the following expenditure at the Church of England Schools:

| School     | Expenditure |
|------------|-------------|
| Wabasca    | $111,638.36 |
| Carcross   | $12,057.65  |

$123,696.01

There was no corresponding expenditure at any of the Roman Catholic Church-owned schools.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education."
Top of page 7  Re: Carcross Residential School

Re: Jerry Johnson -

This boy was admitted to the Carcross Residential School on September 1, 1950. The application form stated that his religion was Roman Catholic and attached to it was a statement from the father expressing a desire to have his son, Jerry, attend the Carcross School.

The application form should have been questioned at that time but reference to our file indicates that such action was not taken, but that his admission was approved in a letter dated December 27, 1950, signed by the previous Superintendent of Education.

Page 10 - Dillon Children

Application forms were received for the admission of three children,

Mary, age 7,
James Roy, age 9, and
Rose, age 11,

to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. The application forms stated their religious denomination to be Anglican. The following ruling was made:

"Except if the mother is of the Roman Catholic faith, the children, who are presumably of the same religion as their father, should attend Protestant School".

As the correspondence stated that the mother was Anglican, Superintendent Davis was advised that the children could remain in the Onion Lake R.C. School to June 30, 1952, in order that there might be no interference with their education, but that they must be discharged from the Onion Lake R.C. School on June 30, 1952.
MEMORANDUM FOR:

MAJOR MACKAY

The Minister met Most Reverend Dr. Barfoot on Monday June 23rd and at a discussion of the brief attached to Right Reverend Robert Jefferson's letter dated June 13th. Following the interview the Minister promised:

A. A full answer as to the cases.

B. A summary of capital and maintenance expenditures since the war.

Would you please have a draft letter prepared for the Minister's signature and submit the text to me.

The Minister also made the statement that he would try to provide more space at Fort George next year.

Laval Fortier.
July 2, 1952.

Re: Problem of Admittance to Residential Schools of Indian Children of uncertain religious affiliation.

1. Jimmie James,
   Paddy James,
   Albert Paul James.

This family is from the Stikine Agency, in the Province of British Columbia, and the application forms requested that the three children be admitted to the Carcross (C.E.) Residential School.

The religion of the children was not mentioned on the form but a statement attached to the form and signed by the father read as follows: "I do fully understand that this is a Protestant school and not a Roman Catholic".

Superintendent Clark was written regarding the religion of the children and he replied that the family is of the Roman Catholic faith.

Consequently, it was decided that these children should attend a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices.

2. Kenneth Johnson

This boy comes from the Stikine Agency, British Columbia, and application was made for his admission to the Carcross (C.E.) Residential School.

The application form was signed by the father and stated that the religion of the boy was Roman Catholic. Attached to the application form was a statement from the father.
reading as follows:

"I hereby state that I wish the under-named child to enter Carcross Residential School for term commencing September 4th, 1951. I do fully understand that this is a Protestant school and not Roman Catholic".

As the application form stated that the boy's religion was Roman Catholic, his admission to the Carcross (C.E.) School was refused.

3. George Dreafer,
   John James Dreafer

This family comes from the Meadow Lake Agency in the Province of Saskatchewan, and both parents are stated to be living.

The application forms stated that the religion was Roman Catholic and the forms were signed by the father.

Attached to the forms was a letter signed by the mother, expressing her desire to have the boys admitted to the Las la Range (C.E.) Residential School.

It was ruled that the applicant being Roman Catholic, the children should attend a Roman Catholic school.

In view of recent representations in regard to the above children, the Indian Superintendent has been written for additional information.
4. Annie Heathen (or Heather)
Dora

This family is from the Meadow Lake Agency in the Province of Saskatchewan and both parents are stated to be living.

The application forms stated that their religion is Anglican but the father signed the application forms, requesting their admission to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

The Department refused to approve their admission to the Onion Lake R.C. School as their religion is stated to be Anglican.

5. George Wesley
Bertie Andrew Wesley

This family is from the James Bay Agency.

When the application forms were received, the religion of the children was stated to be Roman Catholic and the forms were signed by the father. The application forms were approved by the local Indian Superintendent and as the forms appeared to be in order the Department approved their admission to the Albany R.C. Residential School.

Subsequently we received a protest against their admission to the school mentioned, from the Right Reverend Neville Clarke, Suffragan Bishop of Moose Cree.

On receipt of this protest, Indian Superintendent Allan was again written and we have been informed that Wesley and his present wife were married in the Anglican Church at Moose Factory on November 22, 1943.

In view of this additional information it was ruled that these children should be considered as Anglicans and consequently should discontinue attending the Albany (R.C.) Residential School.
6. Phyllis Mayfield,
   Bert Nelson Mayfield,
   Walter Mayfield

This family is from the Blackfoot Agency,
Province of Alberta.

The first two mentioned children attended the
Old Sun (C.E.) Residential School until June 30, 1951. As
far as the Department is aware, Walter had not attended
any school.

The application forms for their admission to
the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School were signed by their
mother and the Indian Superintendent advised the Department
that the father was deceased and the mother is responsible
for the children.

Attached to the application forms was a
statutory declaration signed by the mother, stating that she
has been baptized a Catholic, is a member of the Roman Catholic
Church and wants her children placed in the Crowfoot Residen-
tial School.

From the information just mentioned, it was
considered that the mother is the responsible parent and
that as she states she is Roman Catholic the children should
attend the Roman Catholic School.

7. David Yellowhouse
   Percy "
   Marie "
   Sylvia "

This family is from the Blackfoot Agency,
Province of Alberta. All of the children mentioned above
had attended the Old Sun (C.E.) Residential School to
June 30, 1951.

Applications were received for the transfer
of these children from the Old Sun (C.E.) Residential School
to the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School.
The father signed the application forms and also sent to the Department a statutory declaration stating that he had severed any connection with the Anglican Church. He further stated that he had been baptized a Catholic and is a member of the Roman Catholic Church.

It was ruled that in view of the father's declaration the children should attend the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School.

8. Floyd Royal,
Romana Royal,
Francis Royal

This family is from the Blackfoot Agency, Province of Alberta. The two first mentioned children were enrolled at the old Sun (C.E.) Residential school to June 30, 1951. They did not return to this school when it re-opened on September 1, 1951.

Subsequently, the Department received applications for their admission to the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School. The application forms were signed by the mother as the father is deceased.

The mother also forwarded a statutory declaration stating that she had been baptized a Catholic and is a member of the Roman Catholic faith. She requested the transfer of Floyd and Romana from the Old Sun School to the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School and the admission of Francis (who had not previously attended school) to the Crowfoot Residential School.

It was ruled that as the mother is the responsible parent and states that she is a Roman Catholic, the children should attend the Crowfoot (R.C.) School.
9. Edward Wolfchild

This family is from the Blackfoot Agency in the Province of Alberta.

This boy was in the Old Sun (C.E.) School to June 30, 1951. Both parents are stated to be living.

The application for his admission to the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School was signed by his father. A declaration was attached from the father stating that he had never been an adherent of, nor had anything to do with the Anglican Church and consequently requested the transfer of his son from the Old Sun (C.E.) Residential School to the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School.

In view of the father's declaration it was ruled that the boy should attend the Crowfoot School.

10. George Turning Robe

This family is from the Blackfoot Agency, Province of Alberta.

This boy had attended the Old Sun (C.E.) Residential School to June 30, 1951.

An application form, signed by the father, was received and this form stated the religion to be Roman Catholic. Attached to the application form was a statutory declaration from the father saying that he had completely severed connections with the Anglican Church and had become an adherent of the Roman Catholic Church. He further stated that he had his children baptized in the Roman Catholic faith and requested the transfer of his son George to the Crowfoot (R.C.) School.

In view of the father's declaration it was ruled that the boy should attend the Crowfoot School.
11. Mary Dillon
James Roy Dillon
Rose Dillon

This family is from the Meadow Lake Agency, in the Province of Saskatchewan.

Applications were received for the admission of these three children to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

The application forms were signed by the father and stated the religion to be Anglican.

When these applications were received, further inquiries were made and the Department was informed by the Indian Superintendent that the family is either Anglican or Pagan.

In view of the information just mentioned, it was ruled that the Department could not approve the admission of these children to the Onion Lake R.C. School.

12. Clyde Blackjack

This boy is an orphan, both parents being dead. The first information that we received regarding him was contained in a letter from Bishop Coudert (R.C. Bishop of Yukon). He stated that the Blackjack family had joined the Catholic Church nearly 10 years previously and that two of the other children in the family had attended the Grouard (R.C.) Residential School. Bishop Coudert requested that Clyde be placed in the Lower Post (R.C.) Residential School.

The information contained in Bishop Coudert's letter was forwarded to the Indian Superintendent, Mr. Meek, and he subsequently wrote to the effect that one of the boy's brothers thought Clyde should be placed in the Carcross (C.R.) Residential School. Later, Mr. Meek forwarded to us an application form signed by his brother Roddy Blackjack. This stated that the boy's religion was Roman Catholic.

The Department approved the boy's admission to the Lower Post (R.C.) Residential School.

Re: Problem of Admittance to Residential Schools of Indian Children of uncertain religious affiliation.

1. Jimmie James,
   Paddy James,
   Albert Paul James.

This family is from the Stikine Agency, in the Province of British Columbia, and the application forms requested that the three children be admitted to the Carcross (C.E.) Residential School.

The religion was not mentioned on the form but a statement attached to the form and signed by the father read as follows: "I do fully understand that this is a Protestant school and not a Roman Catholic".

Superintendent Clark was written regarding the religion of this family and he replied that the family is of the Roman Catholic faith.

Consequently, it was decided that these children should attend a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices.

2. Kenneth Johnson

This boy comes from the Stikine Agency, British Columbia, and application was made for his admission to the Carcross (C.E.) Residential School.

The application form was signed by the father and stated that the religion was Roman Catholic. Attached to the application form was a statement from the father, reading as follows:

"I hereby state that I wish the under-named child to enter Carcross Residential School for term commencing September 4, 1951. I do fully understand that this is a Protestant school and not Roman Catholic".

As the application form stated the religion was Roman Catholic, his admission to the Carcross (C.E.) School was refused.
3. George Dreaver,
   John James Dreaver

This family comes from the Meadow Lake Agency in the Province of Saskatchewan, and both parents are stated to be living.

The application forms stated that the religion was Roman Catholic and the forms were signed by the father.

Attached to the forms was a letter signed by the mother, expressing her desire to have the boys admitted to the Lac la Ronge (C.E.) Residential School.

It was ruled that the applicant being Roman Catholic, the children should attend a Roman Catholic school.

In view of recent representations in regard to the above children, the Indian Superintendent has been written for additional information.

4. Annie Heathen (or Heather)
   Doru

This family is from the Meadow Lake Agency in the Province of Saskatchewan and both parents are stated to be living.

The application forms stated that their religion is Anglican but the father signed the application forms, requesting their admission to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

The Department refused to approve their admission to the Onion Lake R.C. School as their religion is stated to be Anglican.

5. George Wesley
   Bertie Andrew Wesley

This family is from the James Bay Agency.

When the application forms were received, the religion was stated to be Roman Catholic and the forms were signed by the father. The application forms were approved by the local Indian Superintendent and as the forms appeared to be in order the Department approved their admission to the Albany R.C. Residential School.

Subsequently we received a protest against their admission to the school mentioned, from the Right Reverend Neville Clarke, Suffragan Bishop of Moosonee.
On receipt of this protest, Indian Superintendent Allan was again written and we have been informed that Wesley and his present wife were married in the Anglican Church at Nesse Factory on November 22, 1943.

In view of this additional information it was ruled that these children should attend a school conducted under Protestant auspices.

   Bert Nelson Mayfield,
   Walter Mayfield

This family is from the Blackfoot Agency, Province of Alberta.

The first two mentioned children attended the Old Sun (C.E.) Residential School until June 30, 1951. As far as the Department is aware, Walter had not attended any school.

The application forms for their admission to the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School were signed by their mother and the Indian Superintendent advised the Department that the father was deceased and the mother is responsible for the children.

Attached to the application forms was a statutory declaration signed by the mother, stating that she has been baptized a Catholic, is a member of the Roman Catholic Church and wants her children placed in the Crowfoot Residential School.

From the information just mentioned, it was considered that the mother is the responsible parent and that as she states she is Roman Catholic the children should attend the Roman Catholic School.

A declaration was attached from the father stating that he had never been an adherent of, nor had anything to do with the Anglican Church and consequently requested the transfer of his son from the Old Sun (C.E.) Residential School to the Crowfoot (R.C.) Residential School.
In view of the father's declaration it was ruled that the boy should attend the Crowfoot School.

10. George Turning Robe

This family is from the Blackfoot Agency, Province of Alberta.

This boy had attended the Old Sun (C.E.) Residential School to June 30, 1951.

Attached to the application form was a statutory declaration from the father saying that he had completely severed connections with the Anglican Church and had become an adherent of the Roman Catholic Church. He further stated that he had his children baptized in the Roman Catholic faith and requested the transfer of his son George to the Crowfoot (R.C.) School.

In view of the father's declaration it was ruled that the boy should attend the Crowfoot School.

James Roy Dillen
Rose Dillen

Applications were received for the admission of these three children to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

The application forms were signed by the father and stated the religion to be Anglican.

When these applications were received, further inquiries were made and the Department was informed by the Indian Superintendent that the family is not of the Roman Catholic faith.

In view of the information just mentioned, it was ruled that the Department could not approve the admission of these children to the Onion Lake R.C. School.

12. Clyde Blackjack

This boy is an orphan, both parents being dead. The first
information that we received regarding him was contained in a letter from Bishop Coudert (R.C. Bishop of Yukon). He stated that the Blackjack family had joined the Catholic Church nearly 10 years previously and that two of the other children in the family had attended the Grouard (R.C.) Residential School. Bishop Coudert requested that Clyde be placed in the Lower Post (R.C.) Residential School.

The information contained in Bishop Coudert's letter was forwarded to the Indian Superintendent, Mr. Meek, and he subsequently wrote to the effect that one of the boy's brothers thought Clyde should be placed in the Carcross (C.E.) Residential School. Later, Mr. Meek forwarded to us an application form signed by his brother Roddy Blackjack. This stated that the boy's religion was Roman Catholic.

The Department approved the boy's admission to the Lower Post (R.C.) Residential School.

Dear Mr. Harris:

Re: Indian School Administration.

When the Primate, the Bishop of Ottawa and I had the privilege of an interview with you on June 23rd, I understood that you would be sending me a memorandum of our conversations. To date such a memorandum has not reached my office.

I would particularly appreciate having further information and figures on the information you quoted regarding the special grant to Church-owned Schools. I have gone over my figures time and time again with the information that I have and I still come to the conclusion that Indian Affairs Branch gave to the Roman Catholic Church-owned Schools a grant far greater in proportion than that received by Church of England Church-owned Schools. I have taken the pupilage of the respective Schools receiving such grants and divided it into the total amount of the grants given the respective denominational schools and my figures still do not reconcile with your statement that the proportion was just about even.

Dear Bishop Wright:

I received your letter of October 11, advising me that the following motion had been passed at a recent meeting of the House of Bishops of the Church of England in Canada:

"That this House of Bishops requests the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration that section 117 of the Indian Act be amended to its original form, in which the consent of both parents be required when enrolling children in Indian Schools."

Section 16 of the former Indian Act read as follows:

Subsection 1 - "Every Indian child between the full ages of seven and sixteen years who is physically able shall attend each day, industrial or boarding school as may be designated by the Superintendent General (Minister) for the full periods during which such school is open each year; provided that where it has been made to appear to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General (Minister) that it would be detrimental to any particular Indian child to have it discharged from school on obtaining the full age of sixteen years, the Superintendent General (Minister) may direct that such child be detained..."
at school, for such further period as may seem to be advisable, but not beyond the full age of eighteen years, and in such case the provisions of this section with respect to truancy shall apply to such child and its parents, guardians or persons with whom such child resides during such further period of school attendance."

Subsection 2 - "Such school shall be the nearest available school of the kind required, and no Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices."

Section 116 of Bill 297, which was subsequently withdrawn, read as follows:

"Every Indian child who is required to attend school shall attend such school as the Minister may designate, but no child who is in the care or legal custody of, or whose parent or guardian is a Protestant, shall be assigned to a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no child who is in the care or legal custody of, or whose parent or guardian is a Roman Catholic, shall be assigned to a school conducted under Protestant auspices."

Section 117 of the Indian Act, Chapter 39, Statutes of Canada, 1875, reads:

"Every Indian child who is required to attend school shall attend such school as the Minister may designate, but no child whose parent is a Protestant shall be assigned to a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices and no child whose parent is a Roman Catholic shall be assigned to a school conducted under Protestant auspices, except by written direction of the parent."
You will note that none of the clauses cited above mention that the consent of both parents is required when enrolling children in Indian schools. As a result, I am at a loss to understand exactly what you mean when you request "that section 117 of the Indian Act be amended to its original form, in which the consent of both parents be required when enrolling children in Indian schools".

Our files have been checked very carefully and the only previous representation that we have been able to locate from the Church of England in Canada was contained in a letter dated September 28, 1930, a copy of which I enclose.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Canon Cook:

With reference to our telephone conversation this morning, I am forwarding herewith copies of our salary schedule. You will note that teachers are placed in one of four classifications, Grade I, Grade II, Grade III and Grade IV. Teachers with no certification are rated as Grade I; teachers with Second Class Certificates are rated as Grade II; teachers with First Class Certificates are rated as Grade III; and specialists such as primary teachers, who are specially qualified and devote at least half of the teaching time to the work in which they have had special training, are classified as Grade IV.

In general, the classification of Welfare Teacher is restricted to those schools which are located in the far north and where service is expected for twelve months of the year. We have very few of this classification, and I feel that it would be well if those to whom you are sending this information were warned that the classification is given only under very special circumstances, and after a very careful review by the department of all circumstances.

A maximum of five years of credit may be given for previous experience in placing teachers on the salary scale, except where the teacher is simply being transferred from one Indian school to another. However, if there is any break in service and the teacher has more than five years' experience, the teacher stands as having five years of experience only, and is placed on the salary schedule at the sixth period.

As you are aware, teachers employed in day schools operating for the full academic year of ten months, may be classified for superannuation purposes as Civil Servants,
providing they meet the qualifications, one of which is two years of satisfactory service with this department. Such a classification carries with it all the benefits of the Federal Civil Service Superannuation scheme. Immediately on appointment, however, teachers contribute to the pension fund in accordance with the provisions of the Act which apply to Civil Servants. If they make application and are accepted as Civil Servants for the purposes of superannuation, their pension contributions are transferred to their credit under this scheme. If they leave the service before they are pensionable, all their contributions are returned to them.

I think it would be well if you would tell the Bishops that the department welcomes the nomination of qualified teachers from the Churches but the actual appointment is made by the department. However, the department usually accepts the nomination, providing the teacher is qualified and there are no other grounds for anticipating that the appointment would not be satisfactory. The department, of course, has full control of all teachers employed in our day schools and may dismiss a teacher without reference to the nominating authority.

The policy outlined in the preceding paragraph has been in general practice for a number of years, and I merely mention it so that there shall be no misunderstanding.

As you know, there is at present a very acute shortage of teachers throughout Canada. A recent editorial in the "Ottawa Citizen" gave the number as 10,000. This is somewhat in excess of what is usually quoted, but there is no doubt that the shortage runs in the thousands. Because of this, the department must be in a position to engage teachers without delay and is not obligated to wait for the nomination of the Bishop if a suitable applicant is available. I am asking the Regional Supervisors to inform the Bishops of vacancies as soon as possible, and it would be helpful if the Bishops could submit the names of applicants immediately they are known without waiting for vacancies to occur. The department begins advertising in April for teachers for the term commencing September.

I wish to thank you for your very kind offer to solicit the support of the Bishops of the Anglican Church in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

"R. F. Davey"

Dear Archbishop Barfoot,

I have received your letter of October 7th in which you bring to my attention a report regarding the replacement of the Guy (Sturgeon Landing) Indian Residential School which was recently destroyed by fire. In this regard I wish to say that no consideration can be given to the replacement of this school for the R.C. children at The Pas or elsewhere before a complete school survey is made of the situation.

There were in excess of 100 children attending the Guy School at the time of the fire, 65 of whom have been moved to temporary Roman Catholic Church-owned quarters at The Pas. The remaining children have been returned to their respective reserves in the hope that accommodation will be found for them in day schools or existing residential schools.

The department is providing temporary makeshift classroom accommodation at The Pas for the 65 children mentioned. This, together with the dormitory and other space made available by the Roman Catholic Mission, should meet the immediate needs of this group until such time as a complete survey of the whole area, formerly served by the Guy School, and surrounding territory can be made. The arrangements being made should not in any sense be regarded as replacement of the Guy School. The construction of a residential school would cost over half a million dollars and I wish to inform you that no provision has been made in the 1953-54 estimates nor in the 1954-55 estimates for the replacement of this school.
The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch have made no comment in response to the charge of favouritism made at the General Synod of the Church of England. It is not the policy of the Branch to do so as the records with respect to expenditures and the reasons for making such expenditures are available at any time, and the Branch officials know that the Minister will make any necessary policy announcements.

With regard to the matter of high schools mentioned in the article to which you have referred, I may say that it is not the policy of this Department to build high schools. In 1948 and 1949, representations were made to the Department by the Oblate Order to purchase their Lebret Scholasticate at Lebret, Saskatchewan, for use as a departmental technical high school. This the Department refused to do on the grounds that it was contrary to policy to establish high schools, our policy being to encourage and assist Indian children to attend Provincial high schools. As you know, the Department provides the fullest opportunity for Indian children to complete entrance to high school. In addition to this, however, assistance is extended to Indian children who show aptitude and have the recommendation of the teacher in charge of the school and the school inspector to attend high school and, in some cases, university, where the results indicate that this should be done. Indian parents in a position to do so, however, are expected to meet part of the costs involved.

At a few centres, children are housed at residential schools in order that they can attend the local high school. In a few of our residential schools, high school grades are taught where the local high school is not in a position, because of lack of accommodation, to accept Indian pupils or arrangements for their attendance at high school cannot be made because of other circumstances.

The Mackay Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire on March 19, 1933. The authorized enrolment at the time was 60. Following the fire, the Church of England requested from time to time that consideration be given to replacing the school. We have no record of the department having made any commitment in this regard. It is our intention however, in view of your representations, to carry out a complete school survey in order to determine the school needs of the area formerly served by the Mackay School.
I should like, at this time, to assure you that, difficult as the problem has been and continues to be, the Indian Affairs Branch endeavours to deal with the provision of residential school accommodation as fairly as possible considering the need and all the other circumstances involved in making decisions.

Yours sincerely,

My Dear Sir:

I am most grateful for your letter of December 5th, together with a copy of your letter to the Primate. Dear Mr. Harris:

Each year the Indian School Administration of our Missionary Society has found it increasingly difficult to staff, with satisfactory teachers, the classrooms in its residential schools. One of the main difficulties is that the Administration is unable to offer to teachers a salary even approximating that offered by Municipal School Boards, and by Indian Affairs Branch, Educational Division. The per capita grants, as they now exist, are not sufficiently large to allow any further increase in any residential school staff category.

It must be stated also that our greatest competitor for the services of teachers interested in Indian pupils is Indian Affairs Branch itself. With its system of classroom inspectors and its ability to pay high salaries for teachers, Indian Affairs has been able to entice away from our classrooms a goodly number of former residential school classroom personnel.

Another factor involved is in the field of superannuation benefits. The Church has been unable, on financial grounds, to establish a staff workers' pension plan. Memorandum:

In reply to your memorandum of yesterday's date I beg to say that there are two schools at Oka, conducted by the Methodist Church, one called the Oka Village and the other the Oka Country. The Department contributed last year $125.00 towards the salary of the teacher of the first school and $100.00 towards the second.

Provision is made in the current year's Estimates for an increase of $25.00 to the Oka Country School, making the Department's contribution to each school for this year $125.00. The enrolment at the Oka Village School for last year was 21 with an average attendance of 12; at the Oka Country School the enrolment was 21 with an average attendance of 8.

With regard to the school conducted by the Methodists at the Caughnawaga Reserve called the Caughnawaga Mission, I beg to say that the Department has hitherto contributed $125.00 towards the teacher's salary, but in this year's Estimates a sum of $250.00 is voted for this purpose. The enrolment at this school for last year was 42 with an average attendance of 15.

There are two other schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve under the auspices of the Roman Catholics, one for boys and the other for girls: the boys' school having an enrolment of 117 last year with an average attendance of 40. The Principal of the boys' school was paid $450.00 and his Assistant $300.00. The girls' school had an enrolment
enrolment of 79 for last year with an average of 44. $300.00 was paid to the Principal and $200.00 to her Assistant. The salaries of both these teachers have been increased this year by $50.00.

With regard to the two Oka Schools and the Mission School at Caughnawaga I may say that these schools are managed entirely by the Methodists. They appoint the teachers and pay the salaries. The Department's contributions being sent to the Missionary Society, and I understand that they supplement the amount granted by the Department in each case.

The salaries for the Catholic Schools at Caughnawaga are paid direct to the teachers by the Department.

Coqualeetza Home:

My own view is that the grant should be made, there will be sufficient funds in the British Columbia vote to make the expenditure without any special appropriation. So pupils at $130 is now the per capita grant for this school, an ample one I think, and it is doubtful whether it should be increased. This school stands at the head of the list for pupilage. Red Deer:

He applied through the Commissioner's office for residences for the teachers, and hospital accommodation. My Dear Mr Pedley,

I hope the Department has been able to do something in connection with the various matters about which we conversed when I was last in Ottawa in company with Mr N.W.Rowell. Permit me to recapitulate in a few sentences the points in which we are the most deeply concerned.

1. Coqualeetza Institute.- A grant of $1500 to cover material for a dwelling for the Principal. This matter is not only very necessary but very urgent.

2. Morley.- The enlargement of the Boarding school which has not nearly sufficient accommodation for the pupils on the Stony Reserve who desire admission. You will remember that in regard to Boarding schools we urged the importance and necessity of an increased per capita grant, bringing the amount up to at least $100 per annum. This would apply to both Morley and Norway House.

3.- An increased per capita grant for the Muncy Institute. It is only by dealing very heavily in live stock (a somewhat risky experiment) that the Principal has been able to make ends meet. It is not desirable that he should be under this necessity; and you will
I readily admit that at the present time $60 is entirely insufficient to maintain such an institution.

I also brought before you and the Superintendent General the question of expense in bringing in pupils to the Red Deer Institute. When this question was referred to the Department in connection with the Brandon Institute, it was decided that the expense of bringing in the pupils would be met by the Department, and their expense home again by the Institute. I was quite under the impression that the same rule applied to Red Deer, and it was only within that last year that I learned that such was not the case. This is a reasonable request, and I hope that it will be conceded.

I would be glad to learn at your earliest convenience what has been done in these various cases.

MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Sup't, General of I.A.

With reference to the application of the Rev. Dr. Griffith of Montreal referred to in your memo hereunder for aid to the extent of $50.00 per annum to advanced pupils to enable them to the higher grades, I beg to say, first: that there are no funds specially provided for this purpose; second: that similar applications have been refused and in this connection I may refer you to the case of John Angus, late of the Shingwauk Home and to the son of L.F. Jackson of Caughnawaga both of whom applied for a grant to continue their education. Jackson is sending his boy to a Catholic College and is paying his tuition himself. Third: Indian pupils have been assisted in obtaining a higher education than our schools afford by the tribe or band to which they belong as in the instance of Mr. Green, lately of this Department, who was allowed $50.00 a year while attending McGill by the Six Nations tribe and $50.00 which was contributed by the New England Company to complete his studies. Other Indian boys have been assisted by way of a loan but the Department has hitherto made no contribution outright for this purpose.

I am of opinion that it would be an incentive to Indian pupils if a limited number of scholarships were provided by the Department tenable, say, for three years. Even if this proposition were favorably considered the question of how these scholarships were to be awarded would have to be settled. The custom in vogue in white schools is to bestow them upon the most successful pupils after competitive examinations. We have four industrial schools in Ontario and if one scholarship to each school were allowed it would be encouragement to the school and the pupils.

Mr. Delisle, teacher of the Caughnawaga Boys' School, discussed this matter and he was of opinion that if his school was granted a scholarship it would be productive of good results.

While in Caughnawaga the other day the Rev. Mr. Oke
Mr. Oke broached this matter wishing to know if there was any prospect of obtaining a grant to assist his niece who is a graduate of the Mount Elgin Institute to take up typewriting and shorthand with a view to passing the Civil Service examination and securing employment in the Department. I told Mr. Oke that we had no funds for the purpose and that the Department made no such grants. He said he was coming to Ottawa with Dr. Griffiths and I have no doubt that it is this particular case which has induced Dr. Griffiths to make the application.

MEMORANDUM:—

Mr. Pedley.

Rev. Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Methodist Schools, in a letter dated November 26th, last, beneath, submits a statement showing the amounts voted by the General Board of Missions of his church to be paid to teachers of Indian day schools west of the Great Lakes and states that the Board is of opinion that the Department should pay the respective amounts in full.

I have examined the list and find that we are now paying the salary agreed upon by the church at the following schools:— Oxford House, Fisher River, Battle River (Samson's Day School), Wyah, Glo-oose, Nanaimo, Skidegate, Kishpiax, Hartley Bay and Kitamaat.

At China Hat we are allowing $200.00 for the wife of the teacher for field matron work, which makes the total allowance at this school more than that asked for. The above mentioned schools need not, therefore, be taken into consideration.

The Goodfish Lake, Whitefish Lake and God's Lake schools
schools are now closed and may also be dropped from the list.

The Bloodvein School is conducted only in the summer months and the Department has paid at the rate of $50.00 per month, which is all that the church asks for.

At the following schools the average attendance is not such as to warrant the Department in paying any larger salary than is now being allowed:- viz.- Kitsegukla and Kitselas. At the first mentioned place I may say that the trouble is owing to the fact that the Indians are divided, a number residing in the new village and a number in the old. The school is situated in the new village and until such time as the Indians are induced to move there is little prospect of bettering the attendance. At the present time there is a recommendation that a school should be established in the old village, but the Department has not as yet had an opportunity to give it consideration. At Kitselas the attendance is too small to warrant the increase asked.

At the Port Simpson School the church has agreed to pay two salaries of $720.00 and $200.00 per annum. Here the boarding school pupils attend the day school; for the tuition of the boarding school pupils the Department, of course
course, is not responsible. We are now paying $400.00 for the day school teacher and I think the average attendance of day school pupils would justify us in increasing it to at least $600.00 per annum.

The reports on the work of the teachers at Bella Bella, Bella Coola and Port Essington are such that I think the Department would be justified in granting the increase asked for, viz.- from $400.00 to $500.00 per annum. The same may be said of Cape Mudge and Koksilah, where the increase asked for is from $300.00 to $400.00.

The teacher at the Poplar River School for various reasons has not been a success and I do not think under present conditions that we should make any increase in the grant, but the Department has already offered $500.00 for a competent teacher.

I would recommend the increase to $600.00 at Berens River to a competent teacher and also the increase asked for at Cross Lake.

At Norway House the church has promised a salary of $500.00 and, although the average attendance for the past year has been rather small, only eight, I think we should make the amount there at least $400.00.

There is a good attendance at Nelson House and the
the increase from $300.00 to $400.00 might be allowed.

I attach herewith a statement showing the salaries now paid and amounts asked for and indicating action I recommend taking.

Dear Mr. Scott:

In disbursing the $60,000 that is at the disposal of the Methodist Church for plant, was it your thought that any of it should be used for any of our large building schemes? As you will remember our pre-war program comprehended a boarding school at Morley, for which $25,000 had been voted; a boy's school at Port Simpson for which I believe provision of $25,000 was also made; a large industrial school at Hazelton; and the pulling down of the north end of the Brandon Institute and rebuilding the full length of the front part of the building making it three-storey high. Is it your intention that we should consider any of these schemes, or spending any portion of it towards aiding the change from Red Deer to Edmonton?

Over and above these our present needs are as follows:

1 - Boys' play room and work shop, at Muncey.
2 - Barn, root house, stable, and work shop, at Norway House.
3 - Cottage for carpenter, ice house, refrigerator, work shop, coal shed, and silo, at Brandon.
4 - Cottage for children, work shop, school room, at Coqualeetza.
5 - Day schools on reserves, Oxford House, Cross Lake, Chemong, etc.

You will see that the needs of Muncey, Norway House, Brandon, and Coqualeetza, and day schools, would take up all of the $60,000 and leave the larger schemes untouched. If the total appropriation is available for the smaller amounts needed at our institutes, it will just about cover the cost of the same. If, however, one of the larger schemes has to be taken into consideration we must greatly curtail the program of present needs. You will notice that I have mentioned nothing in connection with Red Deer, for it is not our purpose to do more than keep that property in a state of repair for a year or more.

You had better send your reply to Brandon.

Yours sincerely,

The new buildings for the various purposes as above mentioned are urgently needed to meet the requirements and complete the equipment at these residential schools.

At the Mount Elgin Industrial School there are no facilities for the boys in the way of recreation or gymnasium and during winter weather a suitable place for this purpose is urgently needed.

A workshop is also needed where the boys can learn carpentering and blacksmithing, etc., and where repairs can be made to the farm equipment, etc. A number of general repairs are also needed to the existing buildings.

At the Norway House Boarding School there are no
facilities for the storing of their crops or for the stabling of stock and a new barn, root house and stable are required. A workshop is also needed where the boys can be taught carpentry, blacksmithing and wherein all needed repairs to the farm machinery and other repairs generally can be made. There are no outbuildings at present at this school.

At the Brandon Industrial School a residence for the carpenter instructor is required as there is no accommodation for one. An ice house for the storage of the season's supply of ice and a refrigerator for the proper care of meat and other perishable supplies is urgently needed. There is no accommodation for the storing of fuel and a new coal shed is required for this purpose. They have a large farm at this school and a large number of stock and a silo is required to store the ensilage for the winter's feed for the stock.

At the Coqualeetza Institute it is intended to erect a building for the teaching of domestic science and to include a class-room. The older girls will live in residence in this building under the care of a competent matron and teacher and will be taught all branches of domestic science and general housekeeping. A workshop is also required for the teaching of trades for the boys and to provide equipment for the making of needed repairs to farm machinery, etc.

New Day School buildings are required at Oxford House and Cross Lake. There is a large number of children at these points and the work at present is being carried on in log buildings which are inadequate for the purpose.

The present facilities at Chemong are quite inadequate. The present building will require to be remodelled and enlarged to provide the necessary accommodation for carrying on the educational work at that point.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

PORT SIMPSON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

Representations have already been made concerning the advisability of erecting a large Indian residential school at Port Simpson. There are many children in this part of British Columbia and our small schools at Port Simpson and Kitimat are wholly inadequate to meet the needs.

A dam to conserve and insure domestic water supply for the Port Simpson School is urgently required. I believe an appropriation of $1,000 will meet the expenses in this connection.
COQUALEETZA:

The Principal has given a very extended list of needs. I might indicate a dwelling house for the farm instructor, sufficient cement to extend the front concrete fence to the full length of the main building, a hog pen and hen house, playground equipment ($300), covered play-sheds on account of the rainy season, also greenhouse, gymnasium, general repairs to the Principal's residence and some smaller items. However, I think that if you make us a grant of $8,000 for the coming year, it will be all that we should expect in the next Budget for this Institution.

[Signature]

Copy on file
EDMONTON:

We need an Implement Shed, Chicken house also Cement and Lumber for general repairs. The woodwork on the buildings should all have a coat of paint outside. We would need wire and posts for about 150 rods of fencing. We need gravel for walks around the main building. This has to be brought in in carlots.

[Signature]

Copy on file
BRANDON:

Half a mile of fence is required right through the southern half section of the farm on the main highway. The north side has a good wire fence with a caragana hedge growing on each side of the page wire. The south side is practically without a fence at the present time and is very much in need of it. This and general repairs will require an outlay of about $4,000.

[Signature]
NORWAY HOUSE:

Painting material, sufficient to paint the main building inside and outside, is required, also Alabastine for all plastered inside work. Eave troughing is needed for barn, henhouse, cold storage and carpenter shop, also conductors from the eaves of the main building into the drain or cistern. These have never been provided.

A new Generator for the Electric Plant is required. The one now in use is worn out and was originally installed just for the main building. Now that all the outbuildings are connected, it would not do to attempt repairing it, as it is too small.

The Steam Plumbing is in need of general refitting inasmuch as the pipe is rusted out in many places.

Lumber is needed for the horse stalls and walls of cold storage plant.

The Principal has been clearing and breaking a lot of new land on the island, for which we have spent some hundreds of dollars and we would like a grant of $500 to assist in this work.

A considerable amount of cement is required to replace that which was broken around the building and in the basement for the laying of drain tile to drain the foundation of the building.

The total cost will be at least $5,000.

The present building is filled to its full capacity and we have a waiting list of some 25 or 30 pupils. It is very necessary that our accommodation be increased to at least 140 or 150 pupils. This can be done for an outlay of about $40,000.

You will remember, in an interview last June, I brought before you the scheme that was on foot to erect a monument to the memory of the Rev. James Evans, our first missionary at Norway House. You kindly assured me that $1000 would be granted by the Department towards a $10,000 proposition.
MT. ELGIN INSTITUTE:

The urgent need is a Refrigerator Plant, which should include an ice house and cold storage. The two combined will cost about $1,500. Plans and specifications can be submitted in due time.

Dear Sir,

As you have kindly intimated your willingness to meet Senator Macdonald and the undersigned to confer in regard to matters affecting Indian Schools, &c., I beg to submit for your information the following memorandum of points that we would like to have considered:

I. INDIAN SCHOOLS AND MISSION PREMISES IN ONTARIO.

On the 2nd April, 1883, I sent a communication in reply to two letters received from the Department in which I set forth our views in regard to the Industrial Institution at Muncey, and also in regard to our ordinary Indian Schools. If the Superintendent General will kindly refer to that communication he will be in possession of the points we wish to present, so far as schools in Ontario are concerned.

In regard to sites for Mission premises on the different Reserves, we have frequently a good deal of trouble with the Indians, growing out of the fact that we have no legal or formal claim to any particular quantity of land. Sooner or later some grievance is sure to crop up, and some Indian will complain that we are occupying more ground than we are entitled to. We desire very much that this unsatisfactory condition of affairs should be ended, and we ask, therefore, that on all Reserves on which we have established missions there should be a distinct understanding reached between the Missionary Society, the resident Indian Agent and the Indian Department, in which the amount of land to be occupied for mission purpose should be clearly defined. Secondly, that the Department should give us a title of occupation (so long as we continue our mission work), protecting us alike from complaints of individual Indians, and also from trespass either by individuals or by the Band. This last request is owing to the fact that in some cases,-Cape Croker, for example,-the Indians have erected some of their own buildings upon land that was set apart for the use of the mission. Thirdly, if for any reason we should deem it expedient to withdraw from any particular Reserve, we desire either that the Department will take our buildings at a price to be fixed by arbitration, or else that we shall have a right to sell the buildings to any other purchaser who may offer to buy them.

II. SCHOOLS, &c., IN THE NORTHWEST TERRITORIES.

In regard to ordinary Indian Schools in the Northwest I beg to refer the Superintendent General to a communication of mine dated July 30th, 1883, in which the various points are presented in detail.

For the efficient carrying out of educational work among the Indians, we think it most important that provision should be made for Boarding Schools, and also for Industrial Institutions, where the children can be kept for a series of years away from the influences which surround them on the Reserves, and we call especial attention to the needs of the Indians in the following locations:
lst, Lake Winnipeg. For more than forty years we have been carry-
ing on educational and missionary work among the Bands around this
lake, and to the north and east; but nothing has yet been done tow-
ard supplying either a boarding school or an industrial institution.
We think that the work we have done among the Indians of that re-
gion entitles us to the consideration of the government. 2ndly,
Battle River. At the last session of Parliament the sum of $10,000
was voted for an Industrial Institution at Battle River, but so far
as we are informed nothing further has been done. The amount voted
is entirely inadequate for an efficient institution, and is in sug-
gestive contrast with the amounts expended on the institutions
placed in charge of other religious bodies. 3rdly, the Worley Re-
serve. The Superintendent General is doubtless aware that an Or-
phanage and Training School have been established by the Missionary
Society. Repeated applications have been made to the Government
for buildings and a grant towards maintenance. Hitherto the first
part of the request has been refused, while in regard to the second
an annual grant of $700 has been made for the past two years, and
recently a communication from the Department stated that Parliament
would be asked during the present session to grant an amount equal
to $60 for each pupil in the Institution. There are very strong
reasons why this institution should be enlarged in its scope, and
made similar to those at Battleford, High River, Indian Head and
Qu'Appelle, and the reasons which have led the Government to give
such liberal support to these latter institutions apply with equal
if not greater force in the case of Worley.

In regard to sites for mission premises our request is that in
all cases they be excluded from the Reserves, so that we may obtain
an absolute title to the property.

III. SCHOOLS IN BRITISH COLUMBIA.

What has been said about schools in the Northwest territories
will apply, to some extent at least, to schools in British Colum-
bia; but in regard to Industrial or Boarding Schools I would say
that we regard an institution of the kind, located in the neighbor-
hood of Chilliwack in the valley of the Fraser, an urgent necessi-
ty. It has been rumored that the Government have in contemplation
the establishment of two institutions, one on Vancouver Island and
the other on the mainland, but that the latter is not to be located
in the valley of the Fraser. I sincerely hope that this will not
be the final decision of the Department, and that in the establish-
ment and management of these schools, the work which has been done
among the Indians by our Missionary Society will receive practical
recognition. In this connection we beg to call attention to the
needs of the Indians in the northern part of the province, where
nothing has been done by the Government in the way of education,
except in certain small grants made to particular mission schools.
It is of great importance that some more advanced work be done in
that region, especially on the line of industrial pursuits. In
this connection I beg to mention the case of the Indian Girls' Home
at Port Simpson, which has hitherto been supported exclusively by
the voluntary gifts of Christian people. I think this institution
is fairly entitled to consideration by the government, and I hope
that when the nature of the enterprise is understood, a grant will
be made towards its maintenance.

Any further information I can give touching any of the forego-
ing points will be cheerfully furnished in a personal interview.

Yours Faithfully,

[Signature]

A. Butterland

I beg to state that the suggestions submitted to the Department by Dr. Macdonald in his letter of the 2nd April 1883 in regard to Industrial Schools & Day Schools conducted under the auspices of the Methodist Society in Ontario are as follows:

Industrial Schools
1. Increase the number of pupils who may attend from 50 to say 100 & make such provision in the matter of school rooms &c as may admit of classification of pupils under two separate teachers. Give prizes for proficiency in the various branches.

2. Fix the time of residence at five years for girls & six years for boys & make attendance for this term compulsory.

3. When boys have completed the term & learned...
learned a trade, give them money certificates but help to start in business, such as a good set of tools & a small stock of material. If they have learned farming, give them land of their own on the reserve to which they belong & advance a good oxen some implements to be repaid out of annuities.

4. Increase the number of trades taught at the institutions & make provision for the sale of surplus manufactured stock.

5. Goods are often purchased from the Industrial Institutions by Indians who give orders on their annuities in part, but in paying annuities these orders are sometimes neglected by Agents and the money goes to independent traders who hold similar orders. Agents should
