Hon. Sir:

We, a deputation of the Special Committee of the British Columbia Conference of the Methodist Church, are much gratified that the opportunity is afforded us by your presence in our Province of the present meeting to offer a few facts bearing upon the relation of the Methodist Church to the work of Instruction which is being prosecuted by the Indian Department among the Indians of British Columbia.

We may remind you that the solicitude of the Methodist Church on behalf of the aborigines of our country has been evinced by its earnest efforts for their evangelization and instruction from the earliest period of its missionary operations to the present. We have now no less than thirteen (13) of the Ministers of the British Columbia Conference engaged in this work; assisted by thirty-eight (38) teachers, lay-agents and other helpers, who have many thousands of Indians under their care. The assistance which we have received from the Indian Department in our educational work among the Indians, has been very much less than has been afforded other denominations in proportion to the work which we and they respectively have been doing. We are happy to state that since the advent to power of the Government of which you are a member, some improvement has taken place in this respect. We shall ask your attention to the appended Statistical Tables which have been compiled for our present
purposes from the last published Blue Book of the Department, viz: for the year 1896. From these it will be seen that whilst the Roman Catholic Church has four Industrial Institutes with 215 pupils, one Boarding School with 75 pupils, and two Day Schools with 40 pupils—making an aggregate of 330 pupils for which they receive from the Indian Department $29,000.

Our Church has one Industrial Institute with 98 pupils, one Boarding School with 25 pupils, and nine Day Schools with 352 pupils—making an aggregate of 475 pupils, towards which work we receive only $5,800. A comparison of the assistance bestowed upon schools under the care of the Church of England constitutes a less glaring illustration of the discrimination against the Methodist Church of which we complain which has marked the action of the Indian Department in the past. It is, however, worthy of attention. Reference to the accompanying tables will show that for the two Industrial Schools of 57 pupils, three Boarding Schools with 60 pupils, and eight Day Schools with 292 pupils—total pupils 415, the Church of England receives $15,050. Besides the nine Day Schools with 352 pupils reported in the Blue Book for eight of which assistance is received, the Methodist Church is carrying on four schools with 125 pupils, upon which no need of recognition is bestowed by the Department.

Not only in the matter of maintenance has our Church been discriminated against, but in that of establishment and equipment as well. In the face of the liberality which has marked the treatment of other denominations in this matter, we cannot point to one Institute under our care in British Columbia which has been established wholly by
Government. Towards the establishment of our one Institute, which in grounds, buildings and equipment cost in the neighborhood of $30,000, the Department contributed $5,000.

You will understand that it is impossible for us to feel that good citizens as we are, and laboring earnestly as we do, for the uplifting into civilization and good citizenship of the wards of the Government, we have deserved only the scant assistance which has been bestowed upon us as compared with the large liberality bestowed upon the work of rival denominations.

In defense of this policy of unequal distribution of the Government funds, it cannot be urged that the territory and school population over which the Methodist Church carries on its operations are comparatively circumscribed and its constituency limited. The fact is that outside the provision which is now made for the instruction of Indian children by the Government and the Missionary Society together about one thousand (1,000) children within the area of our Church's operations are as yet utterly unprovided for educationally.

Neither can it be objected that the quality or degree of instruction afforded by the Methodist Church is inferior to that provided by other denominations. Were any disposed to question the correctness of our statement on this point, our reply is that we court and challenge investigation by a competent and impartial inspector.

What we desire therefore, is that we receive as a Church such assistance as shall enable us to
extend our work. Let aid be afforded us according to the work we do. Place us on terms of equality in the matter of Industrial Institutes with other denominations in proportion to the children we are seeking to educate. This would mean, as the foregoing facts will show, that we should have at least three additional Institutes. Let these be placed at points mutually agreed upon by the Department and the authorities of our Church, adjacent to those school populations which are as yet practically uncared for. It would mean also that aid should be given in support of those Day Schools which have hitherto been unassisted by the Department.

We do not wish to be tedious, but we think that attention ought to be called to the fact that in all the ten Agencies of the Department in this Province, not one is presided over by an Agent who belongs to the Methodist Church. We are made sometimes painfully to feel that a certain kind of influence is used against us by agents who are not in sympathy with our denominational teachings and methods, and this too within the legitimate sphere of our denominational operations. The influences may be said to be within the personal rights of the agent. As in the matter of support for our schools so also in this matter of agents of our own Church, all that we ask is that we be granted our full share of funds and representation; nothing more, nothing less.

In conclusion, allow us to say that we have the utmost confidence that in making these representations, which cannot be gainsayed but are confirmed by the Department's own records of the past, we shall have your sympathy as far as it can have a basis in righteousness, and not only your persona
sympathy but that also of every Minister associated with you in the government of our country, in whom we see a most gratifying disposition to treat impartially and upon their merits, all classes of our population, and all causes which come under the wide range of your administration.

We have the honor to remain, Sir,

on behalf of the Committee,

Your most respectful and obedient Servants.

MEMORANDUM

About a year ago a deputation from the General Board of Missions of the Methodist Church laid before the Premier and the Minister of the Interior of the late Government a memorandum respecting Indian Schools and Institutes under the control of the said Board, pointing out what seemed to be a marked discrimination against the Methodist Church in the matter of schools and the grants for their support. Since that time some of the grievances have been removed, at least in part, and we feel assured that a friendly conference touching unsettled points will lead to a complete understanding, and the removal of any grounds of complaint that may yet exist. We deem it necessary, however, to repeat some things that were said in the former Memorandum, so that the present Government may see that we have not complained without cause, and our present requests merit favorable consideration.

It is well known to the Government that the Methodist Church has always taken a deep interest in the welfare of the Indians of this Dominion, as shown by its large annual expenditure on mission work among them. It has been glad to co-operate with the Government in promoting the Education of Indian youth, and is in hearty sympathy with the policy of gathering Indians boys and girls into Boarding Schools and Industrial Institutes, being convinced that this course will yield
more satisfactory results than the old system of day schools on the Reserves.

In Ontario, so far as Institute work is concerned, matters are now in a fairly satisfactory shape. The new building at Muncey supplies a long-felt want, putting us in a position to do still more effective work than in the past; and as the Department has authorized the admission of one hundred pupils, there are now as many in attendance as the dormitories will properly accommodate. But even on this basis it is impossible to receive all the Indian youth who desire admission, and this circumstance suggests the desirability of additional provision in the form of local boarding schools, where the younger children might be taught and trained till they were of proper age to enter the Muncey Institute. This suggestion is emphasized by the unsatisfactory results of the present day-school system. It seems to be impossible to secure in the day-school on an Indian Reserve anything like a regular attendance, and in many schools the average attendance does not justify the annual expenditure. It is our conviction that a limited number of boarding schools placed at a distance from the Reserves, would provide in the best way for the educational needs of the Indian children, and that the present day-schools might be closed. An exception might be made in the case of bands where the number of children of school age is large, or where the Indians are willing to pay the teacher out of their own funds. Should the suggestion respecting boarding schools commend itself to the Department, we will be prepared to co-operate most heartily in regard to those Reserves where
we have established missions, and those schools over which we have control.

In Manitoba, the necessities of the case have been to some extent met by the erection of the new Institute building at Brandon. When occupied to its full capacity it will provide for some time for the industrial training of those Indians bands included in the missions of the Methodist Church around Lake Winnipeg, and to the North and East, and recent correspondence from some of the missions indicate that it can be filled in the near future, as some difficulties in the way of obtaining pupils have been mainly overcome. It is our earnest desire that no time be lost in securing additional pupils, and that as soon as seventy-five or upwards are in attendance, the control of the Institute be given, as promised, to the Methodist Church on the usual per capita basis. The present system, which makes the Principal virtually a subordinate, renders efficient administration difficult, if not impossible, and we deem it essential that when the control of the Institute is given to the Methodist Church, all appointments and dismissals should be in the power of the Principal, subject to the approval of the Board of Missions. In no other way can he maintain proper control of the employees.

In a letter from the General Secretary of Missions to the Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs, it was stated that the Missionary Society would be willing to assume the support of the Institution on a per capita basis of $110 for eighty pupils with the understanding
1. That we be allowed to increase the number of pupils as soon as possible to one hundred.

2. That the buildings already authorized by the Department be completed.

3. That some additional requisites in the way of live stock and implements be provided.

4. That the Department make provision, in the near future, for a dairying industry in connection with the Institute; that is, provide the necessary building, plant and cows.

Turning now to British Columbia and the North-West Territories, an examination of the Departmental Report for 1895 reveals not only serious inequalities as between the different denominations, but what appears to be a marked discrimination against the Methodist Church. A careful summary gave the following results for the year ending June 30th, 1895:

One undenominational Institute, with 31 pupils on the roll, average attendance 16, was voted $5,640, or a per capita of $131 for 43 pupils.

Four Roman Catholic Institutes, with 151 on the roll and 139 average attendance, were voted $18,200, or a per capita of $130 for 140 pupils; and one Roman Catholic Boarding School, with 63 on the roll and 55 average attendance, was voted $2,400, or $80 per capita for 40 pupils. Total for five Institutions, $20,600.

One Episcopalian Institute, with 19 on the roll and 12 average attendance, was voted $4,550, or $130 per capita for 35 pupils.
And one Episcopalian Boarding School with 25 on the roll and 20 average attendance, was voted $1,500, or $60 per capita for 25 pupils. Total for two Institutions $6,050.

One Methodist Institute, with 97 on the roll, 76 average attendance, was voted $2,210, or $130 per capita for 17 pupils; and one Methodist Boarding School with 32 on the roll and 17 average attendance, was voted $1,200, or $60 per capita for 20 pupils.

Putting these figures in another form we find that in the case of the Episcopalian schools provision was made for 50 per cent in excess of the average attendance; in the undenominational Institute for 169 per cent in excess; in the Roman Catholic Schools for 5 per cent less than the average attendance; and in the Methodist Schools for 150 per cent less. At the Chilliwack Institute the average attendance in 1895 was 76 and although earnest requests were made for a per capita grant for at least 50 pupils, the actual grant was for 17 only. Since the time referred to the inequality complained of has been remedied in part,—that is a grant is now made for 50 pupils; but in the application of the grant 50 children are selected by name; and when one of these dies or is removed from the school, the Department claims the right to deduct that proportion of the grant, although many other children are known to be in the Institute for whom no grant is made. In addition to all this we understand that the cost of buildings for the Institutes controlled by the Roman Catholic and Anglican churches was provided from public funds, but the Methodists were compelled to provide their own sites and buildings at a cost of over $25,000,
less $5000 received from the Indian Department in aid of the Institute building at Chilliwack.

In presenting these contrasts we wish it to be distinctly understood that we do not complain of the amounts paid to other denominations, provided they are doing the work and keeping the schools up to the standard of efficiency required by the Government. But if, as we are given to understand, it is the policy of the Government to accept the co-operation of the churches in the work of educating and civilizing the Indians, we submit that there should be a nearer approach to equality in the dealings of the Government with the churches, and that we should no longer be subject to the discrimination so apparent in the past.

In Manitoba and the North-West the figures are equally striking. A summary taken as before from the Blue Book, shows the following results for 1895:

For three Roman Catholic Institutes, with 451 pupils on the rolls, average attendance 381, there was an aggregate vote of $50,300, actual payments, as Auditor-General's Report, $62,451. For seven Boarding Schools controlled by the same Church, with 195 on the rolls, average attendance 165, the aggregate vote was $12,216; actual payments, $11,681. Total amount voted, $62,516; total paid, $74,132.

For three Church of England Institutes, with 300 on the rolls, average attendance 260, there would have been a vote, on the assumed per capita, of about $33,600; but the actual expenditure seems to have been over $57,000, all expenses, in some instances,
being met by the Government. For nine Boarding Schools under the control of the same Church, with 239 on the rolls, average attendance 181, the vote stood at $14,688, the actual expenditure at $13,648. Total assumed vote, $48,488; total expended, $70,748.

For one Presbyterian Institute, with 137 on the rolls, average attendance 110, there was a vote of $19,500; actually expended, $17,630. For five Boarding Schools, with 136 on the rolls, the vote was $7,200; actual expenditure $4,786. Total vote, $26,700; total expended, $22,416.

For two Methodist Institutes, with 110 on the rolls, average attendance 69, there was an assumed vote of say, $14,000; actual expenditure, $13,787. In the case of Brandon, all expenses have been met hitherto by the Government. For one Methodist Boarding School, with 37 on the roll, average attendance 22, there was a vote of $2,448; actual expenditure $1,680. Total vote, $16,448; total expenditure, $15,467.

Since the foregoing figures were prepared the situation has changed a good deal. The Department has authorized an increase of pupils at Brandon, erected a dwelling for the Principal, and some other buildings for industrial purposes. At Red Deer provision is to be made for 89 pupils, with necessary enlargement of existing building, or erection of others. Provision is also being made, as we are informed, for the enlargement of the building at Morley, and the erection of outbuildings. When these undertakings are fully carried out our needs in regard to industrial training in
Manitoba and the Territories will be met to a considerable extent, but the question of Boarding schools at certain points will still remain, and for this we ask the favorable consideration of the Government.

Taking the whole Dominion, according to the Blue Book of 1895, the Roman Catholic Church controlled 17 Industrial Institutes and Boarding Schools, with Government appropriations aggregating $87,800, and an expenditure of $104,531. The Episcopal Church had 15 Institutes and Boarding Schools, for which the provision amounted to $59,538, and the expenditure to some $77,800. The Presbyterian Church, with but little mission work among the Indians, had 6 Institutes and Boarding Schools, with an appropriation of $26,700, and expenditure of $22,416; while the Methodist Church, the largest Protestant body in the Dominion, had but 6 Institutes and Boarding Schools, with a grant of $24,958, and an expenditure of $23,630. If this marked difference were the result of lack of enterprise on our part, in the work of Indian education we would have no ground of complaint; but since we are expending annually, from our own funds, a large amount of money in this work, and have urged upon the Government many times, during the last ten or twelve years, the removal of the disabilities under which we labor, it must be apparent that the responsibility does not rest with us.

The Government cannot fail to be aware of the fact that Christian missions are a most potent factor in the civilization of the Indian tribes. It is due to this influence, more than any other
that tribal wars have ceased, and that those Indians who are under
the care of the missionaries are obedient to the laws and are firm
friends of the Government. We call attention to the fact that during
the troubles with the Indians in the North-West, not a single
Indian connected with our missions was implicated in the revolt.
It is also well known that the firm attitude of Chief Pakan and
his people at Whitefish Lake contributed more than anything else
to prevent a general uprising among the Crees.

In Indian mission work some of the churches have been much
more active than others, and this has given them a "sphere of influence" that places them in a better position than others to aid
the Government in its civilizing and educating work. In making appropriations to schools and institutes, we think the expenditure
of the churches should be taken into account on the principle of
"helping those who help themselves." Unfortunately some of the
churches do not publish an annual report of agents employed and
money spent on Indian missions, and we are therefore without accurate information on which to base a comparison. Suffice it to
say, however, that the Methodist Church is spending over $40,000
annually on its Indian missions, over and above the grants from the
Government in aid of schools; and that in our Indian schools in
Ontario and Quebec, we pay in every instance, one-half of the
teacher's salary,—something which is not done, so far as the Blue
Books show, by any other Church.

According to the last census 28,199 Indians are classed as
"Protestants." We have no statistics showing the relative numbers
claimed by other Protestant Churches, but we claim that probably not less than 16,000 are under the care of missionaries of the Methodist Church; and this fact is sufficient of itself to show how utterly inadequate is the provision, in the matter of Boarding Schools and Institutes, for the children of Methodist Indians who ought to have the advantages of such training.

Turning now to another aspect of the question, we find that the total number of pupils enrolled in Institutes and schools of all kinds (boarding and day) in 1894, was 7,052, and that the Government appropriations amounted to $223,834, or an average per capita of $31.74. Distributing the pupils among the various churches as per returns, we find that the actual per capita grant to the various denominations was as follows:— Roman Catholic, $34.43; Episcopalian $29.75; Methodist, $17.49; Presbyterian, $84.40.

Averages like the above are not relied upon as an accurate presentation of the case, as one Church at least does only Institute and Boarding School work, and the per capita grant in consequence appears abnormally large. But the figures are introduced for the purpose of showing that whatever basis of computation is adopted, the Methodist Church, in regard to grants, is placed at a disadvantage.
The points on which we desire the favorable consideration of the Government are the following:

ONTARIO

1. The opening of several Boarding Schools, apart from the Reserves, and the closing of ordinary day schools.

2. In the meantime let all churches be treated alike in regard to existing Day Schools. That is, require all churches to pay fifty per cent of the teachers' salaries, as is now done by the Methodist Church, or else relieve us of that burden.

3. The disposition to be made of the old building at Muncey. At present it is useless, but with a very moderate expenditure it could be made to answer a number of useful purposes. Full information and sketch plan will shortly be furnished.

4. A modification of the method of computing attendance at Muncey and other Institutes. That is, when an authorized pupil leaves the Institute, for any reason during the year, let the Principal have authority to put another in his place, whose attendance shall be credited in the returns.

MANITOBA

1. In regard to Brandon Institute, the more pressing needs have already been indicated, and need not be repeated.

2. Provision for two or three Boarding Schools should be made, which might take the place of certain day schools now conducted on our missions.
NORTH WEST TERRITORIES.

1. The completion of the promised enlargements at Red Deer as speedily as possible, and additional pupils secured.

2. Enlargement of McDougall Orphanage as provided for, and recoup Missionary Society for expenditure on school house and laundry. When Orphanage is enlarged the two day schools on Morley Reserve to be closed.

3. Provision for Boarding schools at certain points, and the closing of certain day schools.

NOTE - Should a policy of this kind be favored by the Government, we deem it important that all young children should be sent to the Boarding Schools, and that admission to the Institutes should be conditioned upon ability to pass such examinations as the Department might prescribe. We also deem it important that all Indian children should be subject to a medical examination, and that no child infected with any serious disease should be admitted to either Boarding school or Institute.

BRITISH COLUMBIA

At the Coqualeetza Institute a per capita grant is now made for 50 pupils. The actual attendance is over 90. It is possible that some of these are not legitimate claimants, having white fathers still living; but we submit that a grant should be made for each bona fide Indian child actually in residence in Institute.

2. The entire cost of the site and buildings at Coqualeetza
was met by the Missionary Society, with the exception of $5000.00 granted by Parliament. In the case of the Roman Catholic Churches, Institute buildings and equipment have been provided from public funds, and there seems to be no good reason why an invidious distinction should be made in the case of the Methodist Church. We submit, therefore, that the Missionary Society should be recouped for its expenditure on site and buildings at Coqualeetza, and the ownership of the property assumed by the Government. Additional land is greatly needed at this Institute, and we strongly urge the purchase of not less than 50 acres more within easy reach of the Institute.

3. Provision for an Industrial school on the Upper Skeena. This we regard as an urgent need for the Indians of that part of the interior. A quarter section of good land has already been secured, part of which has been cleared, and two small buildings erected thereon. Our proposal is that the Government acquire this site and make provision for the necessary buildings and equipment. The cost need not be large, as a building of the plainest description will suffice; and with abundance of fish in the River, and vegetables raised on the land, the cost of maintenance might be kept at a minimum.

4. We again request that provision be made by per capita grant, for 30 pupils in the Girls' Boarding School at Port Simpson instead of 20 as at present; and that a similar grant be made for boys in the Boys' Home at the same place.
5. Boarding Schools are very much needed by us at Bella Bella Kitamaat, and Queen Charlotte Islands. Work will shortly begin at one or two of these points, if we have any assurance from the Indian Department that aid will be given.

All of which is respectfully submitted,

First, at Battle River in Sampson's Band. Second, at Whitefish Lake, or between Whitefish Lake and Saddle Lake in connection with Pakan's Band, and third, at Norway House, as a centre from which quite a number of Bands could be reached. He stated that the expenditure need not be very large and that in each case probably $2000 would provide a building large enough to begin with.

The Minister approved of providing for the proposed school at Norway House and the Department
contributed $3000 towards the cost of the building and made a grant of $72 each for 50 pupils. This school is now in operation and has an enrollment of 36 pupils.

These would be the schools on Sampson's and Louis Bell's reserve, where the majority of the Indians are Methodists. The Roman Catholics have a boarding school in this Agency on Ermineskin's reserve with provision for 50 pupils. Agent Grant gives the total population of the reserve as 138, which would be pretty evenly divided between the Roman Catholics and Methodists. The attendance at the day school on Sampson's reserve is not very encouraging, owing to the distance many of the children have to travel, and their absence with their parents during the haying and fishing seasons.

The establishment of a boarding school at Saddle Lake would, it is claimed, do away with three day schools: at Saddle Lake, Whitefish Lake and Goodfish Lake. These schools have a very fair attendance aggregating about 70 at the three schools and they are said to be doing good work, especially the one at Goodfish Lake. The Saddle Lake school was lately closed, owing to the teacher, who was also the missionary, being removed. No doubt if they had a boarding school, they would be able to retain a permanent missionary.

The Methodists have an industrial school in
in the neighborhood,—at Red Deer, which is attended by children from all the reserves above referred to, and unless it is the wish of the Department to increase the number of boarding schools, I think that accommodation could be found for even more children at this school.

The fact of the Roman Catholics having boarding schools in each of these Agencies is enough to make the Methodists ask for the same consideration, especially as the impression seems to have gone abroad that the Department is favorable to the establishment of more boarding schools. On the 30th June last there were 22 boarding schools in operation in the North-West Territories, and if all the applications for new schools of this class were entertained there would be no necessity for any day schools, as the boarding and industrial schools would more than accommodate the total school population.

Sir,

Pursuant to a conversation at an interview which you were good enough to grant me in October last, I have put in writing the result of my observation of, and enquiries into, the system of education at present in operation among the Indians of British Columbia, and now respectfully submit the same for your serious consideration.

Toward the end of October, 1900, whilst travelling along the North West Coast, I found the Indians with their families returning home after the small fishing and berry gathering. The children as a consequence could no more than get to school by the first of November. On another trip over the same ground about the end of January, 1901, I found these same Indians and their families had gone to their sealing grounds and elsewhere. On the fourth of February there were very few people at Bella Bella. On the fifth I found but three old women and one little girl at China Hat, and the same night at Hartley Bay. I learned there was not a single Indian in the village. Hence ab non discet omnia. Children must accompany their parents in these wanderings as there are no Boarding Schools to accommodate them. Schools are left with but few and occasionally no pupils. Children at school for about three months in the year and hard at work forgetting during the other nine—a
psychological absurdity. An educational plant on the ground and paid for twelve months in the year, but effective for about three months only — an economic fallacy. We see these conditions at all limited in area. They are really as widespread as the B.C. littoral. But that they should not be allowed to perpetuate themselves, goes without saying. And this the more that the remedy is not far to seek nor difficult of application.

What is the remedy? The remedy is the substitution of BOARDING FOR DAY SCHOOLS; but these to be of the simplest and most inexpensive character consistent with efficiency. Such a boarding school, with an attendance of 30, could very well be conducted by a Teacher, a Matron, and an assistant, and if unusually large a Deaconess or equivalent might be added. The children should live mainly on Indian food and in the Indian way, all being taught to keep themselves and their rooms clean and orderly, the larger ones also taking their turns in the workings of the institution; the girls helping in the housework, the boys in gardening, and outside work generally, and the use of ordinary tools. The Deaconess, where one is necessary, could take charge of the dormitory at night and during the day could visit the homes of the village and teach the mothers how to keep their houses.

This is no impractical theory. The demonstration of it can be seen at any time at Port Simpson, where for years our Boys Home has been run most successfully on just such lines. With such Boarding Schools, training boys and girls alike,
not simply scholastically, but practically to orderly lives and correct habits; training them not for three or four months at the most, but for nine months at the least in every year, with schools and children exerting their thus vastly increased influence directly upon the homes of the villages, the influence is bound to be incalculable.

These Boarding Schools should be built in or near the villages, and so subserve all the purposes of the Day Schools which should merge into them Day School purposes.

The Boarding School age might be from six or eight years to thirteen inclusive; after which the more promising pupils might be sent to one of the Institutes.

Attendance might be for nine months in the year, with short Christmas and long summer holidays. During the summer holidays the children could accompany their parents to the salmon fishing and earn money for them as they usually do. Attendance, if at all possible, should be compulsory as it is with us, for a given number, if not for the full nine months in each year. As to the offensiveness of the compulsory aspect of the question, I think that to the Indians hitherto, it has lain in the indenture system, by which he signed away all control over his child being generally placed in a school so far distant that it amounted to a heart-breaking separation to the Indian who loves his children dearly; dearly enough, I am sure, to send them to the village Boarding School, but too dearly to send them far away and be happy. To be able to see their children in Sunday School and Church every week, and in case of sickness...
at any time to have them with them during the holidays earning money would, I am sure, exactly suit the Indians.

At any rate they would feel that the present day schools could not fill the bill, and their constant appeal to me is to get them a boarding school in their own village.

The study of the first importance in these schools, for the Indian child, is the acquisition of the English Vernacular. This the coming Indian must have if he is in any degree to hold his own in the struggle with the rapidly invading whites. And where else could he acquire it, as he would in these schools where it would be the language of his daily life? In the school room, also, it is imperative that a reasonably adequate channel of communication be established between pupil and teacher, if education is to proceed with anything like reasonable facility and efficiency.

Were the first two years concentrated primarily on English Language Lessons, and but incidentally upon other subjects, the progress made in the following five years would be worth fifteen of the present regime.

Then should follow Reading, Writing, Arithmetic, and Hygiene sufficient for the needs of the child's Indian life; some Geography and History, so that he may know something of the world in which he lives and more especially of the Empire of which he forms a part.

Finally correct moral principles should be assiduously inculcated, and just as assiduously should correct habits be formed upon these, the whole having the fullest play and development in everyone doing his part in the building up of a clean systematic and efficient school, in which integrity, industry and order are paramount.
As to the Statistical aspect of the present Educational order, I refer you to the Report of the Indian Department for the year ending June 1900. The Statistics I have compiled therefrom I herewith append in manifest A.

I could not find in the report the exact number of children of school age, but took the number 3861 of children of the age from 7 to 15, inclusive, as approximately correct. As being somewhat too large it may discount, but should not at all destroy, the validity of the deductions therefrom.

The average number of pupils to the school under Ave. No. Atts 26 — accurately 25.7854, coupled similarly with the average number to the teacher II.040 gives food for reflection. The cost of a tradesman per annum $515.84 also contains sufficient truth for most serious consideration. Provision should be made by some kind of uniform Boarding School and some kind of compulsory attendance to raise these averages to an economically sound standard.

As to the Financial Statistics, they have been taken from the Reports of the Indian Department and Auditor General for the year ending June, 1900, and are herewith appended in the Manifest marked B.

At present the Average Vote for an average attendance amounts to $63.53 and the Average Grant to $57.84. On this basis $2553.52 added to the Actual grant of 1900 would have provided these 1082 Average Attendants, their full Boarding School per capita of $60.

Assuming the Indian School Population of B.C. to be 3000, an average attendance of 2000, a per capita of $60 on this average attendance, and Compulsory Attendance, then the
cost would be $120,000. Of this a proposition might be provided by the Indians. An Indian could very well give $20 worth of food stuffs and clothing for the support of his child. I am sure he would vote for such a law if he could have the Boarding School. The present system degrades the Indian by pauperising him.

In conclusion I may say that I have thrown out these thoughts by way of suggestion rather than finality. And from the standpoint of a churchman I would prefer four Boarding schools at $1500 each than one Industrial School at $6000. I may furthermore say that I speak from and for the coast line of B.C.

Respectfully submitted,

(signed) R. Whittington.

The Secretary:

With respect to the report of Rev. Mr Whittington, Superintendent of Indian Missions in British Columbia, on the condition of Indian Education in that Province, a copy of which was transmitted to the Department by Dr Sutherland, General Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society, I beg to say that Mr Whittington's suggestions as to future educational work among these Indians seem to be dictated more by the spiritual than the temporal necessities. Before acceding to the project outlined by Mr Whittington, it would be well to consider what the cost to the country and the corresponding benefits to the Indians would be.

Mr Whittington submits with his report two manifests marked "A" and "B" compiled by him from the Auditor General's and Departmental reports of last year, which excepting some inaccuracies will answer the purpose of arriving at the cost of the proposed change. He gives the total cost of schools in British Columbia for last year as $62386.00 for a total average of 1082 pupils out of an enrollment of 1568, or $57.64 per capita.

The schools population is stated as 3361 for 3000 of whom he wishes to provide boarding school accommodation, with an average attendance of 2000 at a per capita cost of $60, or $120,000 in all. This is a large amount but as there are at present seven Industrial schools in operation in the Province with an average attendance of 379 pupils.
at a per capita rate of $130 or a total cost of $48,270.00. This number of pupils would still have to be paid for at the Industrial school rate, which is $70.00 per capita higher than that of the boarding school; $26,530.00 would therefore have to be added to Mr Whittington's estimate, which would increase the sum required to $146,530.00 per annum and incidentals such as buildings, repairs, equipment, etc., would easily bring it up to $200,000—an annual increase of nearly $140,000 for one province.

The arguments used by Mr Whittington would have as much, or more force in all the other provinces, excepting some portions of Ontario and Quebec, as in British Columbia; and as there are fully 20,000 children of school age in the Dominion with numbers of equally zealous church workers to look after their interests, you can readily judge what outlay such chimerical projects would involve. I pointed out the other day the sturdy growth of the School Vote, which will nearly reach the half million mark next year. Festina Lente would be a good motto to adopt in regard to the Indian education policy.

If the general results obtained by the Industrial schools are at least problematical, there is no assurance that those of the boarding schools would be as good, even if at less cost.

I shall speak of the Indians of the North-West Coast of British Columbia, for whose special benefit Mr Whittington is derisive of substituting boarding for day schools.

Bella Bella is one of the points referred to by Mr Whittington and the census return for last year shows that there were 49 children of school
age on the reserve with an average attendance of 27 for the whole year,—not a bad showing considering that the children accompany their parents on their wanderings and that there is no boarding school to accommodate them. The quarterly returns of Miss Miller, who is in charge of this school, show a very high average for December and March quarters. This is a Methodist school and under the former teacher a still better average was obtained. If these children forget as readily as they learn the physiological absurdity is as much due to the methods pursued as to the absence of the children. The educational plant including the teacher, is under the control of the Methodist Missionary Society and could be utilized by them as to do away with the economic fallacy referred to.

The North West Indians are literally "Toilers of the Sea" which affords them almost their entire support. They make more from fishing than any other Indians in British Columbia, and in order to obtain the necessary skill and daring in these pursuits, they must begin to learn while they are young. No knowledge of books, refinements of life or manners will help them in perils of the deep and I do not think it would be wise to force them to change their present mode of providing for their sustenance until a better one can be offered them. They can find no other work! A man is not poor because he has nothing but because he does not work". Life even in a boarding school will unfit them for their work and increase their sensitiveness of wants without the means to supply those wants which will but add to the burden of life.

To show you that the North West Coast
Indians are not so badly provided with educational facilities; I shall quote from Mr Agent Todt's report of last year. Speaking of education he says:

"The education of the people of this Agency is carried on by five professional teachers, seven native teachers, eighteen missionary teachers and twenty-five missionary ladies—in all fifty-five religious and secular teachers having thirty-three churches and seventeen schoolhouses". There is a school population of 642 Indian children, 590 of whom live in the vicinity of schools. There are also a few Salvation Army officers who are helping to educate and improve the Indians.

I can easily understand that to keep this number of religious and secular teachers in the field is a heavy drain on the funds of the missionary societies and no doubt accounts somewhat for their anxiety to be relieved by the establishment of boarding schools which would provide for their maintenance by the Government.

The Department should not be asked to break up the Indian home such as it is and the Regulations for compulsory attendance were not passed for that purpose. Of course there are Indians as well as whites who would like to shirk the responsibility of providing for their children?

That the North West Coast Indian is capable of teaching a high state of civilization without coddling was proved over a quarter of a century ago by the work of the Rev. Wm. Duncan at Port Simpson and Metlakahtla. That none of his successors in the mission field have achieved similar success is not the fault of the Indians. Work was the chief incentive to civilization employed by Mr
Duncan,-work for the benefits to be had from it not merely supervision and direction.

That better results have not followed from the Industrial and Boarding schools is to my mind attributable to their failure to instil into the minds of the pupils the dignity of labor. They are taught to work, made to work and to work whether they like it or not, but they are not taught to see the necessity for work so far as they are personally concerned. "The laborer is worthy of his hire" and pupils should learn this maxim by practical experience. The Rev. Dr Ryerson in his report as to the best method of establishing and conducting industrial schools for the benefit of the aboriginal Indian tribes, prepared nearly fifty-four years ago, advocated this principle. Pupils should be paid for their work and pay for what they receive so that they may learn self-reliance and the orderly and intelligent conduct of affairs as well as a due sense of the value of money and other property and that the non-producer is a burden to himself and to the community and is to be dealt with accordingly.

The Indian should learn by experience that he can get nothing for nothing. In this connection I beg to refer to my report of the 23rd April last on the working of the George Junior Republic.

Martin Duncan

OTTAWA,

Dear Sir,

I hereby make application to the Department of Indian Affairs for the establishment of a Boarding School, with accommodation and equipment for 100 pupils, to be taken from the various Methodist Missions on the South end of Vancouver Island.

Between Cape Mudge on the East Coast, and Nitinat on the West Coast there are five Methodist Missions, at Cape Mudge, Nanaimo, Cowichan, Victoria, and Nitinat. The Nanaimo mission, including the Chemainus, Nellie, Uwhalas, and Penelakut tribes, has been steadily maintained for 40 years. The mission at Victoria for upwards of 30 years. The missions at Cape Mudge, and Nitinat for about 10 years each; and the Cowichan mission for 7 years.

Day-schools, with the usual Government grants are in operation at Cape Mudge, Nanaimo, and Nitinat, but these only partially meet the needs of the villages where they are established; and when the parents go to their hunting or fishing camps they must of necessity take their children with them, which necessity would be obviated by the establishment of a Boarding School. There are also numbers of our children at Snouche, Quilicum, Nanaimo River, Chemainus, Cowichan, and Victoria, who are far beyond the reach of our day-schools, and whose parents are looking to us for the education of their families. Besides these, there are numbers of pagan Indians who are asking to provide a school where they can send their children.

This matter has been laid before our Missionary Board, and while that Board has decided that such a school is necessary, yet it belongs to Dominion Government to take the initiative, hence this application.

Trusting that this will meet with the favorable consideration of the Department, and that steps will be taken as soon as possible for the establishment of this Institution, I have the honor to be, Dear Sir,

Very Respectfully Yours,

C. M. Tate,
Methodist Missionary.

OTTAWA, 13th February, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Rev. Dr Sutherland, General Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society, who called at the Department on Monday to discuss Indian school matters, laid particular stress on the insufficiency of the per capita grant allowed the boarding schools. He said that such schools in the West cost the Church $120.00 per pupil and that the grant should be raised to at least $100.00.

He called attention to the age limit fixed by the regulations for the discharge of pupils, claiming that eighteen was too soon to cast an Indian boy or girl upon their own resources, and that the most critical period of their life was between the ages of eighteen and twenty-one years, when they required more care and attention than at any other time.

He also referred to want of provision for the ultimate disposition of ex-pupils, alleging that their return to the reserve before their characters were formed was a misfortune, as in most instances any good received at the school was lost.

Dr Sutherland gave it as his opinion that the day school was of little or no use to Indian children in general, as the attendance was too irregular and uncertain. The boarding school secured the attendance but was in too close proximity to the reserve to have the desired effect of solving the Indian problem. The industrial school, if properly
properly conducted on a sound system, with longer residence and something for the pupils to look forward to besides a return to the reserve, is, he thinks, the only means of accomplishing any lasting results.

Regarding boarding schools,-if they are made more general, who is to bear the cost? The religious denominations carrying on these schools are not able to support those already in existence with the present grant and it will take as much to support a pupil in a boarding school as at an industrial school with much less to show for the money.

The cost of transporting pupils to industrial schools was also discussed. Dr Sutherland claiming that it should be paid for by the Department while the Department's contention is that it is only bound to pay for the filling up of the school to the authorized enrollment in the first instance,-and not for the filling of vacancies. The following extract from a letter addressed to Rev. John McDougall, Supt. of Methodist Missions in Man. and the N.W.T. on the 10th April, 1894, sets forth the Department's stand in this matter:-

"For the transport of children to the school to the number authorized by the Department in the first instance, in cases where it is found absolutely necessary to travel by rail, the Department will, on application, furnish requisitions to enable the children to travel at half rates and pay for the same, but the whole cost thereafter of transport to maintain the complement of attendance must be borne by the management".

This rule still prevails in regard to all industrial schools on the per capita system.

The Deputy Superintendent General—

With reference to the matter referred to in Rev. Dr. Sutherland's private letter of July 31, just addressed to you, I beg to say that the question of placing the Industrial and Boarding schools in the Northwest which are carried on by the Methodist Missionary Society under the management of Rev. Mr. Perrier, at present principal of the Brandon Industrial school, is one which should concern the Methodist Missionary Society only. This Society has four schools under its control in the West, namely, the Brandon Industrial School, the Red Deer Industrial School, the McDougall Orphanage at Morley and the Norway House Boarding school. These schools are all conducted on the per capita system and are in receipt of the following grants:

Brandon, $100 per capita for each of 119 pupils.

Red Deer, $100 " " " " " " 80 "

Morley, $75 " " " " " " 45 "

Norway House, $75 " " " " " " 50 "

The Brandon school is well and efficiently managed on the present per capita grant. Red Deer has a deficit owing to the mismanagement of former principals; the present one is being fairly successful. The Morley school is in a similar plight for the same reason, while the Norway House school is kept afloat by large additional grants from the Missionary Society's funds.
It is claimed by all the Churches carrying on boarding schools in the West that the present per capita grant is insufficient for their maintenance and the statement of receipts and expenditure received here bear out this contention. The question of increasing the per capita grant to schools of this class is now before the Department for consideration, and if the grant is increased to $200 there would be no grounds for complaint.

Mr. Perrier has shown himself to be a practical business man, and the financial affairs of the Brandon school prove this to be the case. If the Methodist Church wishes to make a financial success of their other schools, they should endeavour to place equally competent men in charge of them. There is no doubt about the present per capita grant for the Red Deer Industrial school being quite sufficient to meet the running expenses under efficient management, while if the boarding school grant of $75 is too low, it will be impossible for Mr. Perrier or any other man to make ends meet without large outside contributions. I think it would be a great mistake to remove Mr. Perrier from his present sphere of operations, where he is working so successfully, and I am certain that no amount of supervision could ever keep same principles within the limits of the per capita grant.

I claim that where a religious denomination takes control of a boarding or industrial school on the per capita grant basis, it should assume all responsibility for its financial management. If they can show that the grant is not sufficient, the Department can, if it wishes the school to be continued under their auspices, increase the grant. I think that it
is not too late yet to enter into an agreement with the religious denominations carrying on schools of this class, which should be binding on the denominations and the government, and if concessions in addition to the per capita grant are agreed to, they should be included in such agreement.

If Dr. Sutherland's suggestion were approved of, it would be simply adding a fifth wheel to the coach. They have four principals for their four schools, and it would be impossible for Mr. Poirier to be at more than one place at a time, and I doubt if they could get an good a man to replace him in the position he now holds. The Methodist Church must have good men available, and the best thing they can do is to place them in charge of these schools.

There is no reference made in Dr. Sutherland's letter as to the question of the increased expenses this proposed arrangement would entail, but I take it that he would expect the Department to pay Mr. Poirier's salary and travelling expenses, which would be no small item, as he would have to cover the whole of the West from Norway House to Red Deer to supervise work which properly belongs to the Church.

The Methodist Missionary Society controls all the grants to their schools, as the cheques are sent direct to Rev. Dr. Sutherland, who makes advances to the principals, and the Society should have full knowledge of the financial affairs of each central school under its control. Our Inspectors, also, are supposed to make a thorough audit of the books of all the schools they visit and report generally on their
management, and if these inspections were made more frequently than they are at present, it would be much better.

If Dr. Gutherion wishes to carry out this arrangement, it should be done at the expense of the Methodist Missionary Society, as there is no reason why the Department should be a party to it.

I herewith place before you some reasons why Norway House Boarding School should be placed in the Northern Division.

REPORT OF
THE ALBERTA PROVINCE INDIAN COMMISSION.

The Commission appointed by the General Board of Missions, October 1910, being an enlargement of the Commission appointed in the previous year to investigate and report upon the situation of the Indian work in the Province of Alberta, especially with respect to an educational policy, met in the Central Methodist Church, Calgary, on Friday, April 26th, 1911, at 9:30 a.m. There were present, Revs. T. Perrier; in the Chair: T. C. Buchanan; C. H. Huestis; T. E. Egerton Shore; the Hon. W. H. Gushing; and Rev. A. Barner, Secretary.

The Commission having carefully reviewed the whole situation, and two of its number having recently visited the Northern reserves, found themselves in unanimous agreement as to the policy which should be pursued by the Methodist Church with regard to this work, and respectfully submit the following recommendations:

1st. It is manifest to those who have personally studied the Indian problem that this work cannot be considered on the same basis as other forms of Missionary and educational work. The Indian people are a dependent race and must be regarded by the Church and Government from the standpoint of their need rather than from that of their productiveness. The Indian is the weak child in the family of our nation and for this reason presents the most earnest appeal for Christian sympathy and co-operation.

2nd. We are convinced that the only hope of successfully discharging this obligation to our Indian brethren is through the medium of the children, therefore, the educational work must be given the foremost place.

3rd. From past experience we have reached the conclusion that the day-school on the reserve cannot possibly accomplish the end in view. This is due to many reasons, the chief of which is that the Indian has not yet reached that state in his development which makes him sufficiently interested in the education of his children.
day. It would seem, therefore, that we are shut up to
the policy of the residential school.

4th. In the light of the foregoing facts we agree
on the policy of closing the Red Deer Industrial School,
providing that the Government establish, in lieu thereof,
three residential schools on reserves, feeling sure
that these will more effectually reach the constituency
of children and will at the same time exert a helpful
influence on the reserve life. We recommend that the
following be a committee on behalf of the Church to assist
the Indian Department in selecting sites on the reserves:-
Revs. T. Ferrier, G. H. Huestis, A. Barner and the
Hon. W. H. Cushing.

5th. These schools shall be located as follows:-

Morley in the Southern part of the Province.
Hobbema in the Central part of the Province.
Saddle Lake in the Northern part of the Province.

6th. The population of children of school age is
as follows:-

Morley Agency, Methodist, 125
Hobbema Agency, " 90
Saddle Lake Agency, " 60
White Whale Lake, 25.

7th. These schools should therefore be erected with
capacity as follows:-

Morley, 80 pupils
Hobbema 70 "
Saddle Lake, 60 "

In each case the buildings to be in harmony with
Class "A" of the Government agreement.

8th. If these schools were filled with pupils the

Morley, 80 @ $100 $8000.00
Hobbema, 70 @ $100 7000.00
Saddle Lake, 60 @ 100 6000.00

This, with the income from farm or ranch, together
with a grant of about $2000 per annum for each Institution
from the Missionary Society, would be sufficient for
maintenance.
9th. The Principal and his staff would be made responsible for the evangelistic work on all the reserves in the Province, with the exception of Good Fish and White Fish Reserves, which are forty miles North of Saddle Lake.

10th. In each case it will be necessary to secure a tract of land from the Indians on each of the Reserves where the schools are erected of not less than two sections, 1280 acres, suitable for the industrial purposes of the Institution and for such uses only.

11th. That there be secured for each of these Institutions, and under the direction of the Principal, a Nurse Deaconess, whose duty it shall be to visit the homes of the Indians in connection with medical and evangelistic work.

12th. That there be strongly presented to the Indian Department at Ottawa the need of bringing about, upon the adoption of this policy, the transferring of the Indians at White Whale Lake to the Morley or any other desired Reservation.

13th. That a treaty agreement shall be secured from all the Indians on the Reserves in question, subscribing to the following obligations:

a. Sympathetic attitude toward the Schools.
b. That all children shall be placed in these Reservation Schools as soon as they reach the age of seven, and shall be educated there until they attain the age of eighteen, according to the regulations of the Indian Department. We recommend that Rev. A. Barnor be appointed a Commissioner on behalf of the Methodist Church, and we would respectfully suggest that Mr. J. A. Markle, Inspector of Indian Agencies in Alberta, be appointed a Commissioner on behalf of the Government, together to negotiate this treaty.

We therefore recommended the establishment of three boarding schools: one on Saddle Lake Reserve, which would provide for Saddle Lake, White Fish and Good Fish Lake Indians; one on Hobema Reserve and one on the Morley Reserve.

I understand that the Morley Indians have been deprived of any educational opportunity for some years since the old McDougall Home was closed. It has been even impossible to maintain a day school as the Indians are so widely scattered on that large Reserve.

It seems to us a deplorable thing that during the past five years a large part of the generation of Indian children have grown up without any education whatever. We therefore believe that it is most urgent to have a Boarding School located on the Morley Reserve at the earliest possible date. We believe that it is almost equally urgent that one of the other two schools in the northern Reserves be established without delay. Expenses of repairs to the present Red Deer School would be wasted and the present state of the building is most unsatisfactory and discreditable.

Mr. Perrier has urged for some time the necessity of a new school building at Norway House and at Port Simpson. I have not personally visited these Reserves yet, but all the correspondence that has come to me as well as Mr. Perrier's personal reports, show that the conditions urgently demand consideration.

Of course we assume that the plans for the enlargement of the Mt. Elgin Institute, Muncey, Ont., are being carried out by the Government and that provision will be made in the Estimates this year for the completion of that work.

Dear Sir:

I have learned from Rev. Thompson Perrier, Superintendent of Indian Education of the Methodist Church, of his very satisfactory interview with you recently at Ottawa.

We deeply appreciate the personal interest which you are taking in the education of the Indian and earnestly hope that you will have the heartiest co-operation of the Parliament in carrying out your plans for the development of that work.

For three or four years past we have been in correspondence and conference with the Department of Indian Affairs in connection with several matters which we have felt required the generous co-operation of the Government to put upon a satisfactory basis. One of the most urgent matters has been the re-organisation of our Indian Educational plan in the Province of Alberta. There are five Methodist Reserves in that Province. The General Board of Missions appointed a Special Commission to investigate the situation in Alberta in the Fall of 1909. That Commission reported to our Board in the Fall of 1910, and the matter was re-committed for further investigation. I went personally over the ground on our Reserves in Alberta and met with the Commission in Calgary in April 1911, when we devoted the whole day to most careful study of the matter. We were unanimously of the opinion that the moral and social improvement of the Indians in that Province was to be accomplished most directly through the medium of the educational work. We came to a unanimous conclusion, which we have understood to be in harmony with the views of Mr. Scott, Superintendent of Indian Education, namely, that the Red Deer Industrial School should be closed, as the buildings are in a most dilapidated and unsanitary condition and as the School is so situated that it is impossible to get the Indian children from the Reserves to attend the school.

Dear Sir:-

On behalf of the General Secretary I beg to direct your attention to the following resolution, which was adopted by our General Board of Missions at its last annual meeting:

"That we memorialize the Dominion Government to call a conference of all the various government agents and missionaries in the Indian work with a view to the general betterment, religiously, educationally and otherwise, of all the Indian wards of the Government in Western Canada."

In my own opinion that resolution is based first of all upon a belief on the part of our Board that the Government keenly desires the welfare of its Indian wards and that its Department of Indian Affairs is giving earnest and intelligent attention to the whole Indian question. The churches likewise have no other object than to serve the highest interests of the Indians. During the past few years in particular a spirit of co-operation among religious bodies and between them and the Government has produced a new air of hopefulness in connection with this work. We believe that real progress has been already made.

But none of us believes that an ultimate solution of our common problem has yet been found nor that maximum efficiency has been attained in the work as a whole. Our Board hereby expresses its hope and belief that advantage could be gained by such a conference, as a result of which the information and experience of each body participating in this work could be placed at the disposal of all.

If such a plan, or some modification of it, were found practicable and viewed with favor by the Government we should be glad to facilitate its work in every way.

Faithfully yours,

Assistant Secretary.

Conclusion I:

Conclusion II:

That since financial deficits in the maintenance of Indian Residential Schools frequently arise in large part from the fact that although the Church is compelled to organize and maintain the schools on the basis of an attendance of the maximum number of pupils for which the schools have accommodation, a lesser number of pupils are actually in attendance, the Government put into force the Compulsory clause of the revised Indian Act, and secure an attendance of the maximum number of pupils at each and all Indian Residential Schools.

I have objected to this program of Boarding Schools, and given opposition to the scheme for these reasons:

1. On the ground of the enormous cost in building the plants, believing that neither the Church nor the State was justified into going into such an expense for such a system of schools.

2. If these schools were built we could be unable to provide for them with an efficient and capable staff of teachers.

3. That if the plants could be provided and efficient workers found to run them, the General Board should not be placed under the obligation to furnish the large amount of money that would be required from year to year to keep up the maintenance.

The five schools under our W.M.S. had an average attendance of 85 and an average cost of $135.00 per pupil for the ten years.

There are also included here two tables of figures from the Presbyterian schools. One shows that the average attendance for their seven schools for the past ten years was 96 pupils. Their schools being small boarding schools, and the average cost per pupil for the ten years was about $150.00.

I was not able to secure sufficient data from the Anglican Church to set forth the results in a tabulated form, but it was sufficient to show that their system was the small boarding school, and that they sent the Mission Board of their church as much, if not more, per pupil than is paid by the Presbyterian Church and our own W.M.S. for the schools under their care.

The object of setting forth these figures, data and information is to show conclusively that the small boarding school on the Reserve is not the type of school for our General Board to endorse for the education...
And however our hearts shall be led by the guidance of the Spirit, we have, on behalf of the Missionary Board, consented, through its own agency, to the budget recommendation thereof and do hereby request the Board's permission to make the same accord. We believe, as Missionaries, that missions and institutions connected therewith must be carried on under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, and that the products of our labor should not be used for any purpose other than the advancement of the Kingdom of God.

It might be added, if we were now within a system of schools of the old missionary school type, sufficient to educate the children, it would cost less money than this plan, but more to maintain them.

There are at the present time five Industrial Indian institutes under the administration of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Church. These are situated at -

Nunney, Ont.,
Norway House, Man.,
Brandon, Man.,
Edmonton, Alta., and
Coqualeetza, B.C.

NUNNEY: - The Government owns the buildings and 220 acres of land and rents an additional 600 acres. The 600 acres is mostly pasture land. The farm buildings are nearly all of modern construction and are for the most part adequate to requirements. The Boarding School is a good building, to which additions have been made since constructed in 1896. It accommodates 125 pupils, is always filled to capacity, and has a large waiting list of applicants for admission.

NORWAY HOUSE: - There is a farm here of 40 acres of land owned by the Government, of which 20 acres are under cultivation. We have also an Island where we cut hay and timber. The buildings, which are Government property, consist of a modern Boarding School, which accommodates 135 pupils, a cottage, class-room, barn, cold-storage building and some small out-buildings.

BRANDON: - The Government owns 900 acres, 500 of which are under cultivation. This farm is equipped with good up-to-date barns, stables, hen houses, out-buildings, and four good homes for employees. The school accommodates 175 pupils. The main building is old and not in keeping with the other buildings.

EDMONTON: - The farm, which is eight miles north of the city of Edmonton and consists of 955 acres, was purchased by the Government in 1919, in which year the Red Deer Institute was closed, with the understanding that all necessary buildings for an up-to-date Industrial Institute would be provided on the Edmonton farm by the Autumn of 1921. The War and change of Government prevented this from being done. We expect the buildings will be completed and the school opened in the Autumn of 1923. Five hundred acres of the farm are under cultivation; the balance is for the most part pasture and bush but first-class soil. All of the stock, implements, etc., at Red Deer, which were not sold before closing this Institution, were transferred to Edmonton.

COQUALEETZA: - The Methodist Church, many years ago, purchased 95 acres of land at Coqualeetza, B.C., and erected the necessary buildings for an Industrial School there. The school building having been damaged by an earthquake has become unsafe. In 1922 arrangements were made with the Government to transfer to it eight acres of this farm, on which the Principal's residence and other buildings stand, on condition that it would erect a
Modern Boarding School and farm buildings on this property. These will be completed by the Autumn of 1923. The Boarding School, when completed, will accommodate 175 pupils. About eighty-five acres of the Cocoualeetza farm are under cultivation.

The immediate management of these Industrial Institutes devolves upon principals appointed by the Board of Missions, subject to the approval of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa. Each principal selects his own staff, fixes their salaries, and assigns them their duties, his salary being fixed by the Board of Missions. Over them all is a Superintendent of Indian Education for the Methodist Church, whose services have contributed greatly to the efficiency of our Indian Schools.

It will be seen by the above figures (which for the most part were compiled from the statement prepared by Mr. Perrier and sent to members of the Board of Missions in February 1925) that the Mount Elgin Institute at Muncey is the only one of those Institutes which has not had a grant from the Missionary Society since the Conference year 1911-12, and the only one with a credit balance. This is the more significant since the per capita grant to this Institute was $45.00 per pupil less than was paid to Norway House and $50.00 per pupil less than to each of the other Industrial Institutes under our Church, except Edmonton, which not having pupils has not had a per capita grant since the Red Deer School was closed. This favourable showing is not accounted for by the quality of soil or acreage connected with Muncey School, nor by its geographical position in relation to markets, etc., since all these existed prior to the appointment of the present Principal.

The records show that for the six years before he took charge there were continuous deficits which cost the Missionary Society a total of over $16,000.

The impression made upon me when visiting this institution was that it is managed with rare efficiency both in regard to farming operations and in the education and training of the children.

BRANDON: From information I have gathered from personal inspection and other sources, I am of the opinion that Brandon is one of our best conducted Schools. The boys in attendance have an exceptional opportunity to learn how to farm according to the most approved methods, both as applies to cultivation of the soil and the care of stock, with which the farm is well supplied, including poultry, the care of which is an important feature in the instruction imparted. At Brandon, as well as in our other Indian Schools, Domestic Science is an important subject in the School course for girls.

The Missionary grant to this Institution in the last two years was $3,241.84. Had it not been for this, the deficit on June 30th last would have been $9,746.60.

EDMONTON: The Edmonton Institute is not yet ready to receive pupils. The Principal's residence, the farmer's residence, the utility building, the horse barn and the pump house are the only structures which have been provided. It is expected that a very fine school building to accommodate 150 pupils will be erected by the Government during the coming summer. Other buildings, such as cow barn, pig pen, hen house and implement shed, will, we hope, follow a year later. The absence of buildings which are necessary to extensive mixed farming, also an insufficient water supply, together with the extra expense consequent upon getting a new undertaking under way, account in some measure for the deficit of $5,246.66 in connection with this institution since January 1st, 1920, which, if we add to it the grant from the Missionary Society in 1921-22 of $4,200, would make a total deficit of $9,446.66.
It is disappointing that with no school expenses to meet there should be such a heavy deficit in connection with this farm but so many uncontrollable factors have contributed to this result that I am reluctant to attribute it to inefficiency of management. Conversations with previously successful farmers in Alberta, who in recent years have been unable to carry on without loss, suggest that the deficit at Edmonton is probably due to uncontrollable conditions. The Department of Indian Affairs has recently made a grant of $4,200 to reduce the liabilities of this institution.

COQUELITZIA: I have visited this School on two occasions, the latter being in March 1923. On each occasion I have been impressed with the inadequacy of the buildings. A new chapel with kitchen underneath was built last summer. A very fine school building is to be erected this year. The barn is now in course of erection.

Farming operations at Coqualeetza must necessarily be conducted differently from what they are on the prairie. Difference of climate and soil and limited acreage (95 acres) as well as the requirements of the pupils, are factors which must determine the policy of this institution. The usual field crops can only be grown in small quantities. Stock raising on a large scale does not seem practicable. The climate and soil favor extensive cultivation of fruits, especially small fruits and vegetables. These are the principal crops produced on this farm; scarcely enough field crops are grown to feed the cattle, hogs, and horses, kept on the farm. There is sufficient general farming done to give the boys a knowledge of this industry. A better example of how to care for farm stock should be in evidence.

I was not favorably impressed with the quality of the cattle and hogs on this farm, or of the care taken of them.

Most of the children who attend this institute come from the Pacific Coast, where very little farming is done. Boat building, fishing, carpentering and lumbering are the chief industries by which they will probably earn their living in later years. Manual training is consequently an important feature of the instruction given at Coqualeetza. Many of the boys show great skill in the use of tools.

The deficit for the year ending June 30th, 1923, was $2,457.15. It would have been $15,740.81 but for grants from the Missionary Society during the quadrennium, amount to $7,766.03, and grants from the Woman's Missionary Society, totalling $5,517.63.

NORWAY HOUSE: I have not visited our school at Norway House and cannot speak with personal knowledge of this institution. It makes heavier demands on the funds of our Missionary Society than any of our Indian Schools. This may, in some measure, be accounted for by a lower per capita grant from the Government, than the other Institutes in the west; by smaller attendance of pupils; by having no farm products for sale, and by the higher cost of pro-
The deficit at this school, on June 20th, 1923, was $2,716.53
and would have been $26,730.41 for the last quadrennium but for
missionary grants aggregating $26,074.18. The present principal
has been in charge only two years and so far as I can learn is
rendering splendid service.

The policy of appointing principals and holding them respon-
sible for the administration of these schools, is sound, but fuller
information as to assets and liabilities than has hitherto been
furnished should be at hand before grants of missionary money are
made to them. There should be a system of accounting which would
involve an annual stock-taking as well as an annual audit.

In this report I have referred to deficits in connection with
all but one of those Institutes. This may not, in some instances,
have been the proper term to use, since what is termed a deficit
may be a liability incurred in the purchase of stock which, when
sold, might bring a higher price than was paid for it and leave
a credit balance rather than a deficit. From any data available,
I am of the opinion that the term deficit when used in this re-
port, is the proper term, except in the case of Brandon, where
$2,500. is an investment in pure bred cattle, which are still un-
sold.

It should always be kept in mind that the purpose of these
institutes is to give Indian boys and girls such an education as
shall make them men and women of fine character, industrious
habits, and capable of earning their living in some useful occu-
pation. With this end in view, efficiency should not be sacri-
ficed to economy.

The officials of the Department of Indian Affairs contend in
every school where more than one hundred pupils are in attendance,
an assistant principal should be appointed.

The teachers in these schools impressed me as being worthy
of the positions they hold. Those who serve in the classrooms
have the usual academic standing and have been approved by the De-
partment of Indian Affairs.

The pupils in the schools I visited seemed to be happy and
contented. There was no evidence that they felt themselves to be
under arbitrary restraint or that unkindly discipline was admin-
istered by their teachers. An atmosphere of good fellowship and
mutual confidence seemed to prevail everywhere.
