This Conference was called by the Rev. S. L. McVitty, Principal of the School, and the Methodist Church was represented by Rev. G. J. Shaw, D.D., General Superintendent, Rev. G. B. Manning, D.D., General Secretary of the Home Department of our Mission Board, and Rev. T. Perrier, of Brandon, Man.

The Indian Department was represented by Rev. Russell T. Perrier, M.A., Superintendent of Indian Education for the Government.

Some 50 delegates and a large number of interested Indian visitors were present on behalf of the Indian Bands in Ontario and Quebec.

The meeting was opened by singing and Revs. Burgess and Robinson led in prayer.

On motion, the Rev. Dr. Shaw was appointed Chairman, and Rev. T. Perrier, Secretary.

Rev. S. L. McVitty explained the object he had in view in calling together representatives of the Methodist Church and the Indian Department to meet so many Chiefs, Councilors, delegates and visitors from the various Bands in Ontario and Quebec who send children to the Mount Elgin Institute for instruction in class work and industrial pursuits.

The Chairman appropriately addressed the meeting and declared it open for conference.

The first subject for discussion was the day school on the Reserve. This was opened by Mrs. Stebbins and Teacher Rockwood, who were followed by a large number of delegates. Some
difficulties, such as the following were set forth as reasons why no successful work was not accomplished in Reserve Schools—

Non-attendance, due to long distance from the schools; bad roads; bad weather; lack of suitable clothing by some who were poor.

Incompetent teachers.

Lack of suitable equipment, and the need of making the play grounds more attractive by providing such things as swings, footballs, basketballs and baseball outfits.

Opinion was in favor of more strict enforcement of the compulsory clauses in the Indian Act by the appointment of trained grant officers.

Mr. R. T. Perrier, on behalf of the Department, informed the Convention that the Department was remedying the needs wherever possible by sending to schools where they were sure they would be used—football, basketballs; and by erecting swings, but not sending baseball outfits, as the latter were easily lost and soon became private property. Already this year sums in the aggregate amounting up to $1,000 had been expended.

Mr. Perrier also stated that an addition of $17,000 was voted by Parliament this year for the purpose of securing more competent teachers in the day schools. The staff of teachers was not increased, but to teachers who were qualifying themselves and for new appointments, better salaries could be paid.

As to enforcing the compulsory attendance as provided in the Indian Act. The Department would take immediate action if requested by the Band Council and the Indian Agent. But in all other cases the Department preferred to note out mercy as well as
notice, in hope that in time the people would themselves take action
in respect to the suggestions for more thorough inspection of day
schools. It was stated that the inspection was made by the public
school inspectors of the Province.

A Committee consisting of the following Chiefs was
appointed to draft resolutions to cover the points debated:—
Chiefs Cornelius, Billy, Peter, Timothy
and James.

The need of an Orphanage to care for orphans was the
next subject for discussion. After a general discussion on the
need of such an institution, which has been under consideration by the
Church authorities and the Indian Department for some time, Rev. Dr.
Banning was called on to give information that he had gathered by
sending out a Questionnaire from his office in Toronto.

In reply he stated that all who had been requested to
answer his questionnaire had not done so, but from answers received
he was able to give the following figures as to the number of
children who should at present be in such an orphanage as was pro-
posed:—

Perry Island - 6 children
St. Clair - 10 "
Walpole Island - 35 "

together with others that make a total of 52 orphan children from the
reports to hand.

The Superintendent of Indian Education informed the
convention that not only was the Church taking action, but that the
Indian Department knew the need and was in hearty sympathy with the
movement; and that the Department was prepared to build two such
orphanages for the children of Ontario - one for the Protestant and
one for the Roman Catholic children. And such would be built as
soon as the Department could secure the money from Parliament.

The Convention was very much pleased and encouraged
by this information, and the following resolution - moved by Chief
Sagees and seconded by Rev. Father Sadie - was carried unanimously:

THAT this Convention desires to express its hearty
approval and appreciation of the forward move made
by the Indian Department in endeavoring to secure
the necessary funds to build two such orphanages to
care for the needy children.

The Convention adjourned for lunch (which was provided
by the Institute) to meet at 1:30.

The meeting opened at 1:30, with Rev. Dr. Shaw in the
chair.

Prayer was offered.

The Minutes of the morning session were read and approved.

The next question introduced for discussion was -
How can we improve the Mount Elgin Institute?

This question was discussed under different headings.

FIRST:
What age and class standing should be required for
entrance?

The age fixed by the regulations of the Indian Depart-
ment is 7 years for admission and 16 for discharge, thus pro-
viding a general policy for all residential schools in the Dominion.
However, there is sufficient leeway for adjustment, and Mount Elgin
is a case where there may be a change.

After a full discussion the following resolution was
moved by the Rev. S. R. Neville and seconded by Chief Legge—

THAT the age of pupils at admittance be about 16 years
and that their class standing be about the Second
Book.

CARRIED.

The general opinion was that this should not be too
strictly adhered to until we had an Orphanage to provide care for
children under 16 years.

SECONDED—The second question discussed was, Should girls or boys
of bad character be admitted as pupils?

The discussion led up to the conclusion that this
Institute was not a reformatory, and rather than run the chance of
contaminating the morals of the School, it would be better to care
for such boys and girls on the Reserves and only in very extreme
cases should they be sent to a Reformatory.

The discussion of this question ended when the Super-
intendent of Indian Education assured the Convention that a further
question should be placed on the application forms for admittance,
requiring the Band Council, Indian Agent, teacher or missionary to
vouch for the general character of the applicant before admission.

SECONDED—The next question was, How to get the children promptly
returned after holidays?

Many reasons were advanced why they did not return on
the date fixed when sent out from the School. Yet the general
opinion prevailed that a more active move should be made by the Band
Council and the Indian Agent in having delinquents more promptly
returned and that any noted transgression should be reported
immediately to the Department.
The next subject discussed was the half day system, which places the pupil in the class room half of the day and in some industrial department the other half. Some favored two days in the class room and one of work; others two weeks of class room and one week of work. Some of the points brought out in the discussion were:

A change of programs was more natural every day than every third day or every third week. Some thought the child could not make as good progress as if kept a whole day in the class room. It was shown that 20 hours of study per week were given under present system, including one hour of night work — more than the average in a Reserve School.

The pupils of these residential schools average a grade a year, which is about all that children do in the same grades in our city schools.

After a very full and lengthy discussion, the following resolution was moved by Mrs. Robidoux and seconded by —

RESOLVED THAT two days be given to class room work and one to industrial duties in the Round River Institute.

This motion was voted down by a large majority, so that it is understood that the present program of the half day system is to be continued.

The next question introduced was, Should we have a High School for all Indian pupils who have passed the Entrance examinations and wish to go on with a higher education?

A great deal was said for against such a school, the opinion prevailing that inasmuch as all High Schools, Colleges and Training Schools were open to any Indian boy or girl, it was a moot
better policy to take their places in such schools and colleges now provided.

The Superintendent of Indian Education stated that a vote of $25,000 was made this year to assist Indian pupils in their efforts for a higher education and that one hundred and ninety were the total number throughout Canada who were availing themselves of the opportunity. He also stated that four conditions had to be met before aid would be given by the Department. These were:

1. The educational standing and general moral character had to be vouched for and recommended by an Agent and minister, or the Principal of a Residential School.

2. The child must reside in a home approved of by the Department.

3. The child or its parent must help financially as far as reasonably possible.

4. The progress of the pupil must be sufficient to warrant continued help.

In answer to the question does the Government use funded Band money for this or for the upkeep of residential schools? The Superintendent replied: The Indian Department does not use money belonging to an Indian Band for building or maintaining Residential Schools or for helping worthy pupils in receiving a higher education. All such money is voted by Parliament from the consolidated revenue of the country.

In answer to a further question, viz.: What amount of money does the Government vote for Indian Education? The Superintendent replied by sketching a diagram on the blackboard, which showed that the vote of Parliament for Indian Education began in 1898. In 1916 it was half a million. It reached one million in 1926, and then dropped during the four years of the war to three-quarters of a million, rising again to the million mark in 1930.
Since then it has gone rapidly up until the last vote of the present Parliament reached $1,265,000 - $500,000 more than was voted by Parliament in any previous year. And it was hoped that a vote of $8,000,000 for the next ten years would give a plant and a standing for our Indian Educational work which would be satisfactory to the Indian Department, the Churches assisting for the progress of our Indian people.

The following resolution was carried:

THAT WHEREAS some of the pupils of the Institute after holidays do not return promptly to the Institute;

IT IS THEREFORE moved by P. W. Jacobs, and seconded by Jessie Logan that a resolution be passed at this meeting asking the Indian Department to instruct the various Indian agents to see that the children be returned promptly to the Institute; and that the Indian Councils assist the agents to do the work.

The Committee on Resolutions re Day Schools reported and the following resolutions were carried unanimously:

1st. That we highly approve and endorse the action of the Indian Department in securing qualified teachers where it is practical; and that Indian teachers be engaged to take Indian schools if they promise to qualify by taking a course at Normal School, when asked by the Department, as the Superintendent, Mr. Perrier, gave the committee to understand is being done.

2nd. That the Council should pass a recommendation of the teachers to be engaged by the Department.

3rd. That we approve of the Department helping destitute children with clothing in order that they may attend school.

4th. That we also approve of sport equipment being provided for schools.
That we recommend that the Council of each Reserve assist in the enforcement of the Compulsory School Act.

Having noted the statement of Mr. Fennell, Superintendent of Indian Education, that the government has appropriated $17,000 more in the estimates for better teachers among the Indians, we would ask the Convention to pass the approval of the action of the government and the Educational Department at Ottawa.

(Signed) HENRY P. FISHER,
WILLIAM HUNT,
JOSEPH JONES,
WILLIAM PHILLIPS.

Dr. Chown congratulated the Principal of the School on the success of the Convention and on the provision supplied for the comfort of the gathering. He also expressed thanks to Mr. Russell T. Fennell for his presence on behalf of the Indian Department and for the vast amount of valuable information which he so clearly and forcefully presented to the Conference.

The meeting adjourned by the singing of the National Anthem and prayer by the Rev. Father -

At the close of the Convention the representatives of Church and State and all the delegates and visitors were invited to take part in a picnic on the beautiful lawns of the school grounds.

The Ladies Aid of Canada and Nancy Mission each had a booth, from which the 1,000 or more people secured refreshments; and I am sure that the vast crowd of people who attended the gathering were greatly pleased with the closing day of the school term.

Nearly all of the 120 pupils left for a two months' holiday.

(Sgd.) R. FERRIER,
SECRETARY.

From the figures of the 10 years 1910-1919 inclusive, and the enclosed tables, the following statements can be made.

1. The Methodist Mission Board has educated an average of 528 pupils for five years in five schools at a total cost of $47708.00, or an annual average cost of $17. per pupil.

2. The U. M. S. of the Methodist Church has educated an average of 51 pupils for five years in two schools at a total cost of $68122.00 or an annual average cost of $267.00 per pupil.

If from this amount $20,000.00 is subtracted, being about the cost of a new building with furnishings, the average annual cost is $147 per pupil.

3. The Presbyterian Mission Boards have educated an average of 404 pupils in seven schools at an total cost of $181,141.00 or an annual average cost of $93.00 per pupil.

4. During the past year ending June 30, the Mission Boards have spent about $50,000.00 for the maintenance of the 14 schools that will come under the management of the United Church.

5. The expenditure of Missionary money by all the four churches engaged in assisting the government in the education of Indian children proves that the establishing of a system of boarding schools on or near a reserve has been very expensive as a policy.

6. If the Methodist Church had 20 small boarding schools to bring into the United Church, it would require from the Missionary treasury about $100,000.00 a year to maintain them.

7. A school that does not accommodate at least 100 pupils is a very expensive proposition to the Missionary Society managing the same.

8. A school that accommodates and has an average attendance of 125 or more pupils can be operated with little or no expense on the part of our Missionary Societies.

9. If the 1170 pupils now in attendance in the 14 Residential Schools were consolidated into nine schools giving an average of 130 pupils to a school it would save about $60,000.00 per year to the Missionary Societies of the United Church of Canada.

Dear Dr. Manning:

A further word in answer to some of your questions re our Indian schools, and their superintendency. We have three types of Indian schools for the education of Indian children.

1. The day school on the reserve, which is built and maintained by the government in harmony with the promise of education in the terms set forth by treaty.

2. Small boarding schools on or near an Indian reserve. These were originally built and maintained by the different churches engaged in missionary work among the Indians of Canada. In other words, the Church is responsible for the building and location of this type of school.

3. The large Industrial School, built by the government, usually convenient to a number of reserves, yet so situated as to have city or town privileges. The management of these schools has been given to the different churches doing missionary work among the Indians, the government support being the per capita grant and material for repairs to plant.

Twenty-three years ago, when I was appointed Superintendent of Indian Schools under the care of the Methodist Church, I gave careful study to each of these types of schools. The policy of the small boarding school on the reserve was very popular, and the churches were building accordingly.

The following places were pressing their claim upon the Methodist Church for favorable consideration and action. In B. C.: Clayquot, Muskitto Harbour, Namikow, Namikow, Cape Mudge, Bella Coola, Bella Bella, Kitimat, Skidegate, Port Simpson, and Hazelton. In Alberta: Morley, Robson, Red Deer Lake, and Good Fish Lake. In Manitoba: Fisher River, Behrens River, Norway House, Cross Lake, and Nelson House, a total of twenty-one in all.

My objection to the policy of building up this programme of small schools was fourfold:

1. I did not think the Church could be justified in spending such a large sum of money to educate wards of the Dominion Government.

2. If the plant was built, we could not secure efficient and competent people to manage so many small schools under the conditions and environment surrounding them.
3. The Mission Board would not be justified in the annual expenditure that would be necessary to maintain them from year to year over and above any government aid that we could expect.

4. The supply of pupils for the Industrial School would be cut off if, on the same territory we had a number of small boarding schools, consequently we had to make a choice between one large school, and a number of small residential schools.

Believing it was in the best interest of our Mission Board, and the education of the Indian boy and girl, your superintendent has, amid a great deal of opposition adhered to the policy of the large Residential School, with two exceptions, viz: lat Norway House, which is in part a missionary enterprise in the heart of our missionary work in the great Northland; and 2nd, Morley. The executive of our Missionary Board at its last meeting accepted of the responsibility of managing this school, which is now under construction, with a capacity for fifty pupils.

About four years ago, I compiled the grants made to Residential schools by the different mission Boards of all the churches through a period of ten years, from 1910 to 1919, and found that the average cost of educating a pupil in a school with less than 100 pupils was a little over $100.00 per pupil a year for the ten years. This $100.00 was missionary money over and above grants received from the government.

These figures further proved that a school with less than fifty pupils cost more per pupil than schools with fifty up to a hundred pupils.

Transmitted herewith are two tables of figures for the past five years of the fourteen Residential Schools that will come under the management of the United Church of Canada.

One table gives the annual expenditure of missionary money to maintain each school and the average cost per pupil for the 5-year period, and the total cost for the Mission Board concerned.

The other gives the average attendance of pupils in each school, also the average for the five years. These figures may throw light that might aid in framing a policy that should govern our Indian Educational work under the United Church.
Industrial School, Brandon,
July 1st, 1925.

Rev. Dr. G. M. Henning,
General Secretary of Home Missions,
Toronto, Ontario.

Dear Dr. Henning,

You have asked me some questions from time to time re the superintendency of Indian schools and hospitals, such as: Should the appointment be continued in the United Church? Is there sufficient work to occupy a man's full time? Could the work be done by one of the secretaries from the Toronto office? And some others re audit of accounts and the nature of the inspection by the superintendent. No doubt these questions have been prompted in search of light to aid you and others upon whom rests the great responsibility of framing the policy and organization of the United Church. They cannot be answered without my personal experience coming more or less into this communication, which may make a contribution to the policy that shall govern a small but very important part of our missionary enterprise.

I had only been about a year in the Indian work when the late Dr. Sutherland began requesting me to visit other institutions, inspect the same and report to him. These visits and reports led up to the appointment of a superintendent of Indian schools, and two years after, the Indian hospitals were added to the superintendency. The condition of our educational and medical work at that time certainly justified the appointment. I submit herewith some brief impressions made upon my mind of each of our institutions on the occasion of my first visit.

It is twenty-six years ago today that I took charge of the Brandon Institute. The farm was without a buggy, light wagon or cart, without a lawn, hedge, hen or a hog. The live stock consisted of four horses and as many cows and woods were thriving everywhere. One small workshop and barn made up the outbuildings. The main building had two hundred and fifty pieces of broken glass. There was a large debt, an empty fuel bin, empty wardrobe, empty cellar, empty pantry and empty kitchen and about one hundred empty mouths to feed. All the pets and clothing was on the ninety pupils who were destructive, untrained young men and women from thirteen to twenty-three years of age. They were having their own way, smashing everything they could not eat or wear and running rough-shod over a discouraged staff. It looked as though the institution had fallen into a pit and was waiting for someone to come and give it a decent burial.
Mount Elgin Institute at Nimpoy looks up in memory with its untidy yards and a lot of old sheds, outbuildings and dilapidated barns that had passed their day all unconscious of their need of repairs and paint. The main building had accommodation for about one hundred pupils who were receiving such harsh treatment as to call forth numerous complaints from the Indian people and the Indian Department. Several attempts were made on the part of the pupils to burn up the whole business all because it was under the management of a man who had the idea that physical strength was to take the place of what ought to be done by the heart and head in educating and training young life, who believed that it was safer to deal with the hide than the honor of the pupil and a man who took more interest in hydraulics than hygiene.

At Norway House we had a poor barn shaped building with broken doors, worn out floors, no modern conveniences of plumbing, heating or lighting, a cold shell of a place with partial accommodation for about thirty-five or forty pupils who were obliged to live without a balanced ration as there was no garden, poultry or stock. An incompetent staff were trying to penetrate the stronghold of heathenism with the belief that the problem could never be solved.

At Morley, the McDougall Orphanage was more of a boarding house to feed the entire population of the reserve, including their ponies, than an educational institution for the enlightenment and training of the young. We were operating a proposition that was prospering the people, at a great cost to the Missionary Society.

Red Deer had a miserable lot of buildings, the boys' home being very dark and unsanitary. There was a stable for horses but none for stock. The arrangement was unconscious of the great possibilities of the rich fertile land of the farm and the opportunity presented as a training school for farmers and stockmen. For many reasons the whole institution was very unsatisfactory with the Indian people of Alberta. The office appeared to be used more for a real estate business than to make a contribution towards civilising and educating the people.

At Coqualeetza I found the best equipped and managed institution under the care of the Methodist Church. Mr. Cairns a layman with a strong spiritual nature was carrying on, contending with the difficulties of shortage of funds and an insufficient plant.

At Fort Simpson we had twenty boys housed in a building and under a management that was a disgrace to the Methodist Church. The situation was such that I gave the man to understand that his services would not be required after the end of the year.
We had some thirty day schools west of the lines with about half of them receiving $300 each from the Indian Department towards salary, which was supplemented by $100 of missionary money. The other half of these schools were not recognized by the government and were carried on as a missionary enterprise, the Board meeting the entire cost. Very few of these thirty teachers had proper qualifications.

Two years later the General Board believed it had sufficient reasons for placing the hospital medical work under the same superintendency. I found the hospitals under the care of Dr. Large, Dr. Kergin and Dr. Wrinch, carrying on greatly handicapped by the need of more funds and proper plants. The names of these men and others who have followed them are household words all up and down the Pacific coast. Your superintendent has never assumed that he could instruct such doctors on how to manage a hospital, still I trust he has greatly helped them by his assistance in securing more modern and up-to-date plants with better heating, ventilating and sanitary conditions as well as more adequate support from the provincial government and the Indian Department. Stoves have been replaced by furnaces for warm air or steam heating. Electricity has turned out the lamps, water pressure has given modern conditions and a fine X Ray machine in each is helping to win patronage. The per capita grant from the Indian Department for Indian patients has been raised from 50¢ to $2.50 per day, all of which has practically made our hospitals independent.

One of the first and most important problems for your superintendent to decide was the type of school the church should adopt. A programme of some eighteen small boarding schools to be situated upon reserves, was pressed upon his attention for his support, sometimes by heated debate and intense opposition to what he believed was the safe policy. Had we this system of twenty small boarding schools to take into the United Church we would have had to meet a request of about $100,000 per year from our missionary treasury for their maintenance. In another communication I will send you some facts that will prove this statement.

At the time the appointment of superintendent was made, the Board was of the opinion that there was plenty of work to occupy the whole of a man's time. The conditions I have outlined are sufficient ground for this conviction. In harmony with this opinion, Dr. Sutherland arranged for me to accompany him to Ottawa for the purpose of placing my resignation as principal of the Brandon Institute before the Department of Indian Affairs. This resignation was not acceptable to the Department and the Deputy Minister offered
the home on the Brandon farm and the office in the institute towards the support of the Superintendent of Schools, providing he would remain as principal of the Brandon school, with a free hand to engage any person he wished for his assistant. On behalf of the Board, Dr. Sutherland accepted of this proposition and this arrangement remains to the present. The following year, the Board increased the work and responsibility of the superintendent by nominating him Chairman of the Lake Winnipeg District, which position he held for twenty years.

It may be said that the Brandon Institute paid the salary of the Superintendent of School and Hospitals for ten years.

What are some of the practical results of the policy of having a Superintendent of Schools and Hospitals?

1. The most of our day schools have teachers who are fully qualified for the teaching profession and instead of a salary of $300 being paid by the Department to only half of them and the schools run at quite a cost to the Mission Board, the salaries range from about $600 to $1,000, all paid by the Department and over and above this they are giving us $500 towards the salary of each of our missionary teachers. The greater number of these teachers are happy and contented in their work and nearly all our class-rooms are comfortable and sanitary.

2. We have three nurses and field matrons supported by the government with skilled medical service available for all Indians under our care.

3. One hospital has been replaced by a very fine new plant and the others are greatly improved. Special homes for nurses have been, or are being provided. The provincial support and that of the Indian Department are much increased both for plant and maintenance. The grant per day for Indians has been increased from 50¢ to $2.50 with substantial increases by the provincial government to patients other than Indians and the doctors are carrying on under very much improved conditions with all hospitals on a high standard as training schools for nurses.

4. The principals and staffs in all our residential schools are proud of their work. A fine Christian spirit pervades the atmosphere and the home life and training are all tending to the uplifting, educating, civilising and Christianising of the Indian people. Neither the church nor the state need be ashamed of the plant and the management of the same. The government have constructed some substantial and beautiful buildings and are prepared to erect more. They are giving us liberal up-keep for the support of each plant. The per capita grant has been increased from $80 to $110, to $140 and up to $170 and about all we need are full schools to make them self-supporting.
The government spent during the year 1924 for plant and maintenance of our medical and educational work about $500,000. The annual government grants for maintenance alone has been increased from about $40,000 to about $170,000 per year.

The relationship of the field officers of the Indian Department and the missionaries and teachers on the reserves is carried on with much less friction. The business of the church within the Indian Department has been conducted in perfect harmony. The government officials all through the years have shown their appreciation of the work of the church being connected with the Department by an individual. There has never been the slightest antagonism or friction from either side and the spirit existing between the officers of the Indian Department and the General Board is of a very high order.

All these improvements and many more have been brought about by a better class of workers and the loyalty and devotion of the great bulk of our entire staff. Your superintendent has simply tried to improve the machine, keep it well oiled, steer it in the right direction, secure the right type of people and advice, help, encourage and inspire them in their task. And above all to create a Christian atmosphere that light, love, joy and peace shall reign in all our institutions.

You will see that this historical and personal experience gives an indirect answer to most of your questions. I naturally feel like refraining from giving you a direct answer but the responsibility cannot be evaded.

1. Should the superintendency be dropped? Union will present new problems and a uniform policy must be provided. The building programme is not complete. There are need of a great many improvements. To drop this peculiar work at this particular time, in my judgment would be a mistake.

2. Should the United Church set aside a man to give his whole time to this work? If there is no other way of having it properly done, it could abundantly pay from a financial as well as from an efficient point of view. Your present superintendent has divided his time and effort between the principalship of the Branson school, the chairmanship of the most difficult district in Canadian Methodism and this superintendency and he has not given more than one half of his time to the latter. My experience would lead me to believe that to appoint a man to give his whole time would not be a necessity.

3. Can it be handled from the Toronto office by one of the secretaries? The experience of the past proves that this method ended in confusion and failure. When the manage-
ment was transferred from the Foreign to the Home Department of our General Board, the missionaries, principals, teachers and other workers gathered in convention in our different conferences, unanimously requested that no change be made in the superintendency of the work. This request was largely due to the attitude and treatment given our Indian work by annual conferences, stationing committees and even our General Board. These courts have placed the Indian work at the foot of the list and to the closing hours of the sessions and if it were not for the care, watchfulness and sympathy of men who spend all their time in it, it would be sadly neglected.

A proper inspection of one of our institutions cannot be done in less than a week by a man who is familiar with every detail of each department. This together with an annual visit to each of the day schools will be too great a task and claim upon the time of a man who is not familiar with the internal working of an institution and who has other interests which in his judgment, place the needs of the Indian work in a second or third position. Such an arrangement would simply result in a call which would be of no value to the principal, staff and pupils in the management and conduct of the institution. It would leave the Indian work without a special advocate as a living link, to connect the interests and details of our educational and medical work with the Church and the Indian Department.

I trust that this communication will aid you and all others who may be responsible for the policy and organization that shall govern this important part of our work, which has to be conducted not only satisfactorily to the Church but to the general public and the Government of our country.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,
Industrial School, Brandon, Man.,
September 2nd, 1925.

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier, M.A.,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of August 4th No. 160-3, re salaries of Day School Teachers:

I will write to all our teachers and when doing so will take the opportunity of encouraging cheerful service for the interest manifested by the Superintendent of Education.

Yours respectfully,

J. Ferrier

Dear Dr. Scott,-

I understand that a deputation of representatives from the different churches waited upon the Minister a short time ago in the interests of the schools they represented. The schools managed by the Methodist church were not represented in this deputation. The reason for this was that we were in a state of transition from the Methodist church to the United Church of Canada. Dr. Manning, our esteemed secretary, was of the opinion that we could not assume authority for the United Church, therefore the time was inopportune to approach the Minister on important business. In this opinion I fully concur. You will see that it was not for lack of interest or that we were perfectly satisfied with the present standard of the per capita grants.

My object in addressing you is to bring to your attention my personal opinion of what should be done for the Residential Schools that were under the care of the Methodist church, providing the Department should see fit to revise the per capita grants to that class of residential schools that were designated as boarding schools. I would suggest the following:-

Mount Elgin from $140 to $150
Norway House " $165 " $175
Morley to start at " $175
Port Simpson " $165 " $175
Kitamaat " $165 " $175

Brandon and Edmonton, also Coqualeetza to be left for future consideration. I do not know what the deputation asked for on behalf of the schools they represented, but would suggest the above scale providing it can be done in justice to the claims for other schools and should the Department revise the scale of per capita grants.

Trusting my request will meet with your usual courteous and just consideration, I remain

Yours respectfully,

T. Ferrier

OFFICE OF THE
Indian Commissioner,

NORTH-WEST TERRITORIES.

Regina, January 8th, 1889.

Rev. Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, and beg, in reply thereto, to state that the requests it contains seem to fall under two heads, viz., for assistance in building for school purposes, and for assistance in maintaining Indian pupils in schools.

In regard to assistance in building for school purposes, I would say that though you have not stated what sum is asked for, in order to purchase the Birtle public school, from what I remember of a conversation on this point, the whole monetary aid sought may be estimated at a low figure.

In regard to assistance in maintaining Indian pupils in schools, it appears that the grants at present provided for your Church, are about $8040 per annum; and that these, if increased as you suggest, by $100 per cap. per annum, and if a further

Rev. A. B. Baird, B.D.,
Winnipeg.
grant should be given to assist a school on
the Indian Head Reserve, would amount to
$16,870, or an additional subsidy of $8760;
in a word, over twice the amount now granted.

I am fully prepared to give every weight
to the consideration that you have so well
suggested, but there are others that have
recently led me to doubt whether the partial
ownership by the Department of schools
that in effect it does not control, is desirable;
and suggest to my mind the propriety of
of rendering more liberal assistance towards
the maintenance of children in school rather
than to increase its expenditure in the
direction of erecting buildings.

But before answering your letter fully, I
would like to draw your attention to this
point, and ask for an explanation of your
views in relation to it. It seems to me
that different schools will perform very
different work, and that whilst some will
be merely day-schools, at which the pupils
may have a little industrial occupation,
others they will be regularly trained in
certain trades; whilst at another or others
again, a higher education may be given,

Teachers
teachers be trained, and so forth. It therefore seems to me that as the expense incurred in carrying on different classes of institutions will be directly dependent on the work done in them respectively, it should be fully understood to what class any institution applying for a grant belongs to; and that the grant should be proportioned to the work to be done, and payment of it be dependent upon the accomplishment of that work.

I have to,

(Sgd.) Mayor Reed,
Commissioner
Presbyterian Church in Canada,

Dec. 31st, 1888.

To the Commissioners of Indian Affairs,

Sir,

The Committee which has charge of the missions of the Presbyterian Church among the Indians of the North West, begs to lay before you the following requests, and to invite your attention to some of the needs of educational work among the Indians, at the time when the estimates for the ensuing financial year are being prepared.

And first in the matter of buildings—The assistance for which we ask is in every case to erect or enlarge industrial schools, in which the pupils are to live while they are being educated. An addition is required to connect the present mission building with...
The Stony Plains reserve near Edmonton into a boarding school. Dear Sirs—

I am instructed by the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada to make application to the Department of Indian Affairs for the following grants:

1. DAY SCHOOL GRANT FOR DOUGLAS COVE.

In this Band located in Barclay Sound there are two hundred Indians. Our missionary has labored amongst them for six years, and a Day School was opened in March 1899. There are thirty-two children enrolled and an average attendance of thirteen. The application is for a Day School Grant.

2. BOARDING SCHOOL GRANT FOR THOUGHT.

There are nearly three hundred Indians in this Band, and there are one hundred and one children under sixteen years of age. A Day School was opened in December 1895. For five years previous no Mission work of any kind had been done in that village. During the last year sixty-eight children received instruction in the school, but fifty-six was the highest number on the role at one time.

The Day School Grant was given to this School in 1900. It was thought when the Iberni School was built in 1896 capable of accommodating from forty to fifty children, it would afford sufficient accommodation for the Tribes on the Coast. But it is already full, and very few of these are from the Coast tribes. It was found indeed that Iberni is beyond the sphere of the Coast Indians, and that they will not send their children so far.

It is accordingly deemed necessary in order to keep these children in regular attendance and give them the best possible advantages, that a Boarding School be erected at Thought. With that object in view application is now made for a Boarding School Grant for fifty children.

3. SHOAL LAKE BOARDING SCHOOL.

This is a new school, and the main building is about completed, and has cost us so far $3000.00. There will be added next summer an addition for kitchen &c., the whole being planned to accommodate forty children.

There are about four hundred and fifty Indians on the South and West of this Lake for which no provision is made.

This application has been presented to the Hon. Commissioner Laird, and he has notified us that he has placed in the estimates $2160.00 for this school, being the usual boarding school grant for thirty pupils at $72.00 per pupil and $54.00 for purchase of school debt.

4. CROFTON WATER SUPPLY.

This matter was already before the Department this year. Water has hitherto been drawn from the Assiniboine River from a point about one-half a mile away and up a steep grade. Not only is the labor great, but the quality is at certain seasons not good. There is besides no proper protection against fire.

According to request, Mr. Gilmour sent measurements to the Hon. Commissioner Laird. The lateral distance from the river he reports to be eight-hundred yards, and the elevation one hundred and thirty feet.

The Commissioner thinking that very strong power would be required to raise water such a height, and also that eighty hundred...
yards of piping would be expensive, deems it better to try and get water by borings. He accordingly informs us that he has placed in the estimates $750.00 for that purpose.

MEMORANDUM.

ON INDIAN MISSION SCHOOLS.

-----------------

The Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church having considered the Memorial re Indian Missions and schools, signed by the Honorable S.H.Blake, and submitted to the Department of Indian Affairs, beg to submit the following considerations:

1. The locality in which a school is situated necessarily affects the outlay for its maintenance. As the schools under the care of the Presbyterian Church are not in any case very far from a railway, the rates for transportation, and the cost of living are less than those that prevail in more remote localities. Yet, the cost of living has generally increased throughout the West.

2. The claims of Foreign Missions conducted by the Presbyterian Church in China, Japan, India, the South Sea and West Indies, are extremely urgent, which fact, along with the rapidly increasing claims of the multitudes of many nationalities pouring into the Western Provinces, impossible for the Presbyterian Church to increase her annual expenditure on the Indian section of her work. Material increase in cost of maintenance in that direction must be met by curtailment of the amount of work done.

The secularization of the Indian Schools, we regard as a national calamity. There is no expectation of any appreciable denominational advantage from Indians. So far as that is concerned, we would abandon all connection with them. But it is the Indians, more probably, than of any other community, that their chief weakness is on the moral side of nature. Intellectually, they can compare
experience has taught that the brightest, and most hopeful of them readily fall before the temptations which they meet when entering upon the struggle for self support. In order to fortify and equip them for such conflict, religious instruction is, we believe, an indispensable necessity.

The earnest desire of the Government to fulfill the pledges given to Indians by treaty, as to education and otherwise, the Presbyterian Church appreciates, and is still prepared as in the past, to co-operate, not only in providing the best available educational staff, but also in sharing in the expenses. How far ecclesiastical control and religious instruction could be practicable if all the expenses were borne by the Department, would have to be determined by the Department. Yet such control, especially as to the selection of teachers, is indispensable if the training is to be such as we think it ought to be. It is not possible too strongly to emphasize the thought that all agents that have to do with the Indians, whether in the school, or upon the farm, should be persons of clean lives and moral purpose, who feel that a sacred trust has been committed to them. We are persuaded that much loss has come to the Indians, to the country, through want of carefulness in that respect.

It seems to be universally agreed that the Indians be brought as quickly as possible to self support by the cultivation of the land. That being accepted, the administration of the Reserves and the Educational policy should be made to converge to that end.

The policy the Department has already adopted regarding the Reserves and keeping before each young Indian's objective, a homestead he can call his own, seems so important, and that for reasons so manifest as need no specification. The educational policy should therefore
so adjusted as most quickly and effectively to attain this object.

7. The educational system should, we think, centre around the Boarding School as best fitted to accomplish this end, and for the following reasons:

(I) They can be located sufficiently far away from the Reserves to avoid too frequent intercourse with the former life, and yet not so far as to make it impossible for the parents to see their children at intervals.

(2) Sufficient instruction can be given in farming and domestic duties to enable the young people to start on their own farms with such appliances as they are likely to command.

(3) This can be more economically done in the Boarding School, than with the more expensive equipment of the Industrial School, and, at that stage of the Indian's development, be more effective.

(4) The Boarding Schools reach a larger percentage of the children than the Industrial Schools have ever done or were intended to do. Instead of a select few, the policy should be that every child enjoy a training sufficient to self support, and this can be secured because of the location without hardship to either parents or children.

(5) The larger the school, the more institutional the less homelike it becomes, and the personal influence correspondingly decreased to the disadvantage of the child.

8. In order to enable the Boarding Schools to do this efficiently, it would be necessary to connect a sufficient amount of agricultural land with each school, to make industrial training possible, and also to adjust the per capita grants to the requirements of this curriculum of training. It is believed that this can be done more economically and to better purpose being done by the Industrial Schools.
4.

If this policy were adopted, the usefulness of the Industrial Schools would be practically gone. If not abolished, they could be greatly reduced in numbers. The few Indian youths of special gifts requiring a higher education than the Boarding School could give, could be provided for in existing institutions, or if Industrial Schools should still be deemed necessary, a very small number would suffice.

10.

There may be certain localities in which the Day School is not the only possible provision, and in such case should be continued, but in every case should be taught by teachers capable of appreciating the importance of moral and spiritual development.

Whilst Churches may, and sometimes do err in their appointments, yet on the whole, we believe the highest interests of the children would be better conserved if such appointments continue to be in the church's hands.

II.

If all the Reserves were surveyed into Homesteads, it would be possible to establish and encourage the closest connection between the school and the land, and excite in the mind of every child the ambition to have a home of his own.

Dear Sir,

Indirectly it has come to my knowledge that the joint committee representing the Anglican, Methodist, and Presbyterian churches have presented a new Indian educational system to the government which is being favorably received and that the intention is to act upon it in the near future.

As I am one of the workers in our schools and deeply interested in the advancement of the Indians, it may not be considered presumptuous on my part to ask for information regarding this new system and also if any steps will be taken without first giving the missionaries an opportunity to express themselves.

I understand it at present the intention is to close industrial and boarding schools and establish day schools on all the reserves.

If this is so—and I can speak from experience—I am firmly convinced that any such system, at the present stage of Indian civilization, will not be a success. No new system, it has been under trial for years and the experience of the past has shown the Indians in our western provinces to be...
wandering and scattered, admits of anything like regular attendance at school on the part of their children.

I taught for three years in a day school on the Mietanac Reserve, and probably under no favorable circumstances so will be found in most reserves. The school did its work and had its influence over the children and the parents but the uplifting effects were very much less comparatively speaking, to what it has been here in the boarding school.

In the first place the home life was unutilized and worse, although they were a Christian people and the children were daily in this environment, the attendance was irregular and not punctual and on bad days in order to secure anything like progress I had to walk up the road two miles in the forenoon (all the children happen to be living along the same road) go into a house and hear and set lessons. In the afternoon return, correct exercises of the morning, hear and set fresh lessons. The children could not come to school on bad days and had to go to them. Finally to secure anything like a satisfactory attendance, we took the children into our own home from Monday to Friday. This plan is still adopted there.

This is an instance I believe effective in a day school.

Advantages changes in our educational system could be made but before doing so it would be fair to give those who are on the field an opportunity to discuss such changes, as they are the ones who should know where the difficulties lie.

I would suggest a conference of the Indian teachers, agents and inspectors.
and have this question thoroughly discussed and gone into and any changes that are made, let them be on the basis of past experience.

May I ask if any change going to be made, and are those in the field going to have an opportunity to express themselves.

RESOLUTION of the INDIAN WORKERS ASSOCIATION
of
PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH for SASK. AND MAN., 343770

SCHOOLS.

The goal of our system of Indian education should be the compulsory education of all Indian children between six and fifteen years of age in public schools, situated upon the reserves, or in school districts adjacent to them. This aim should be kept before pupils and graduates, so that a spirit and a mode of life favorable to the early attainment of such a system, may be cultivated. At present, apart from compulsory attendance, even the most advanced and sedentary bands give but an indifferent support to the day schools, even when noon-day meals, shelter and food for the school days of each week, clothing, all features of the residential schools, have been provided. A semi-boarding school having these latter features, properly equipped and manned, would be the most servicable upon the larger reserves of the advanced type, more particularly if the Indians are sedentary, the children have far to walk, and no residential schools near. On small reserves with a small school population, if the children do not attend regularly a simple day school, the school should be closed and the children sent to nearest residential school until such times as compulsory attendance at a public school upon or adjacent to the reserve is feasible. At present, apart from compulsory attendance, no day school, no matter what its type, can reach all the Indians upon a reserve, or even the majority, unless the teacher be one of exceptional gifts for Indian work.

Where boarding schools are already well established, or where improved day schools are not feasible, or where there are a number of small reserves that can be grouped for school purposes, and yet have none of the reserves more than a few hours drive from the school, we would advise the erection of residential schools properly equipped and efficiently manned, where the industries adapted to the life of Indians might be taught to the boys, and household science, sewing,
and home nursing to the girls. Temperance, hygiene, sanitation, the care of the young and of the sick, should be on the curriculum of every school. Lantern slides should be used as much as possible since the sense of sight is highly developed in the Indian race. These residential schools should not be too large. Smaller schools with the home advantages do more efficient work especially in moral training. Boys and girls mingle freely and naturally under careful supervision. Such schools are more efficient than either the large residential school with its institutional government, its rigid separation of the sexes, its atmosphere of suspicion on the part of teachers, or the day school with half grown girls and boys, even upon nominally christian reserves are imbued with immoral ideals regarding sexual relations, that are a menace to their growing up to be pure minded men and women. Such boys and girls filled with Indian ideals are always the most difficult to control and instruct. Better have more residential schools with an attendance of twenty five then a few large institutions. Unless the moral training of the Indian children is efficient, they can never become good citizens of Canada. In this connection, it would be well to have rigid regulations made as to the amusements permitted at each school. Nothing that encourages the survival of previous Indian customs, the excessive desire of sports, or association with the evilly disposed sporting white population should be permitted.

Further, no Indian should be forced in any way to send his child to a school where his own religious faith is not taught, and in any reconstruction of policy, no reserves now served by schools of the same religious teaching should be so left by the closing of such schools, that they would be compelled to send their pupils to the nearer schools of an antagonistic faith, or to schools of their own faith far removed from such reserves. Such, for example, would be the position of Muscowpetung, Piapot, Pasqua and Hurrican Hill reserves should Regina Industrial School be closed. To go to Fil
Hills or Round Lake Boarding schools the Protestants would have to pass the Roman Catholic schools at Qu'Appelle and Crooked Lake. It is not just to place large bands of Indians so that the choice of a school is between their natural desire to have their children near home, on the one hand, and the wish to have them reared in their own faith, on the other. In the event of Regina Industrial being closed, (the Association believe all Industrial schools or none should be closed irrespective of creed,) we would recommend the following plan to meet the needs of the reserves connected with our Association. Improved day schools for Piapot and associated reserves also for Moose Mountain and Mistawasis reserves. Day schools with compulsory attendance at Swan Lake, Hurrican Hills, and Sioux Wapaston. Pipestone can be served either by the erection of an Anglican Boarding School at Oak River reserve, or by having the children attend the white public schools situated on one corner of the reserve or by attendance at Birtle Board school. The Portage Boarding School should be moved to the West of the town and given a farm so that it may minister more efficiently to the Indians on Long Plain, Indian Garden, Swan Lake reserves and to the Portage Sioux Band. Crowstand, Birtle, Round Lake, and Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding schools can minister to their present constituencies. The least needed school is at Okanase.

Attendance at all day schools should be compulsory, but if parents so request in writing, their children should be freed from religious but not from ethical instruction. Habitual truancy or irregular attendance should be punished by transmission of the delinquents to the nearest residential school favored by the parents. Instructions to agents in this regard should be strictly enforced. Where no day schools exist pressure should be brought upon Indians to send their children to the nearest residential school they favour. This might be done effectively by funding the annuity money of all healthy children of school age who are not sent to school and by giving the parents
the annuity money of all pupils sent to school. This is the reverse of the present policy, which has kept many a child out of school.

The age of admission in day schools should be seven as in the Provincial public schools. Children transmitted from day schools should be twelve years of age. Those from reserves where there is no school should be ten years of age. Children under that age should be admitted only when it is in their interest. Children who have never gone to school or who come from inefficient day schools, make very poor English scholars and are more difficult to train in every way, and more particularly morally, if they are over twelve years of age. Medical examination of new pupils and the medical supervision of all schools should be most rigid. Some provision should be made to meet the schools needs of diseased and delicate children rejected by medical inspectors.

The midsummer vacation should be extended and children allowed one month at home and two months free from the class room work, namely the months of July and August. Close confinement in hot weather is most injurious to pupils and teachers alike. The children can be better employed about the farm and garden during the month of August and be allowed the month of July at their homes. Holidays at Christmas should be discouraged so long as Indians reside in the present style of houses. No absent leave should be granted except for definite and essential causes. In this connection it is well to encourage the older boys to begin operations on their farms the two summers previous to graduation. This plan has been successfully tried at three of our schools. It is a gradual break between school and reserve or colony life. One or two weeks freedom from class room work in the spring time when an Indian's vitality is low would promote greatly the health of the pupil.

Permanency of efficient staffs should be aimed at if the confidence of the Indian is to be secured and good work done. The qualifications of the instructors in the various departments should be
clearly defined and graded. Salaries necessary to procure and retain such instructors should be paid. The inspection of each department of every school should be thorough, and each instructor should be given a written statement of the inspectors report as to the condition of his department. Inefficient workers who refuse to improve should be promptly discharged. It might be well to use entirely, the Provincial text books and have the Provincial public school inspector exercise oversight of the class room work in Indian Schools in whose district, they may be situated. This would keep the Indian School teachers in touch with the public school system into which they are to ultimately emerge.

The per capita grants for maintenance should provide for full expense of maintaining the schools, apart from salaries. The rapid rise in the cost of living and labor makes the present grants utterly inadequate to meet the demands made upon it. The salaries of class room teachers should be placed upon a par with those of Provincial public school teachers so that particularly in day schools the instruction in English studies may be efficient instead of meagre, as at present. We urge that Government Grants be sent direct from the Department at Ottawa to the different schools and that the Church Officials be notified of the amount sent to each school. Such a course would put us in possession of our Grant money some three weeks earlier.

All school buildings at present in use and to be used should be thoroughly overhauled so that good ventilation, light and heat may be provided. All new buildings should be built upon models provided by the Department. Further, the most sanitary methods of maintaining a school clean and healthful should be explained to and demanded from those in charge of every school. Residential quarters, either in the school building or adjacent, should be provided in every Boarding School for a Principal who is a married man. The best interests of
of our schools, have at times been sacrificed since there was no accommodation for a Principal unless he was a single man or a man without a family. Isolation dormitories, with lavatories and wash rooms adjacent, should be provided in every residential school, either in the building or on an associated agency or in a school hospital. Recreation rooms for boys and girls and a gymnasium should be provided in every residential school, and in every improved day school. Care in the selection of sites should be exercised so that good water and drainage are assured. Lavatories and bath rooms for pupils and staff, and proper fire protection also the best possible heating system should be installed in every school. All schools should be fully equipped and than be expected apart from any special recommendations of the inspector to maintain themselves out of the per capita grant.

RESERVES,

It is highly desirable that everything possible be done to safeguard and encourage the graduates of all our schools. The most effective method in view seems to be the Colony system. This system tends to put pupils on their own responsibility at the same time they they are under the guiding restraint of a Government Official and are protected from the parasitic habits of their worthless friends. These Colonies should be situated to meet the needs of all our school graduates and as such graduates show ability to manage their own affairs their privileges should be enlarged. Loans in the way of seed, implements, stock and buildings should be given to them, but strictly on the understanding that all such loans must be repaid at the date agreed upon. Provision should be made to compel such repayment or cancel their rights as settlers in the Colony.

The reserve Indians should be encouraged to develop their native industries such as tanning, moccasin making, and bead work since such articles, if well made, can always find a ready market.

A good farm instructor on each reserve is very advisable.
He can supervise the general farm work and give instruction in the use of tools so the Indians can make any necessary repairs around the farm. If such instructor has ability to lead and manage the Indians he will be of great service but if he lacks such ability his salary is wasted money.

Dances conducted in the old Indian fashion are found to be very demoralizing to the Indian race. They are filled with old pagan ideas and tend to unfit the Indian for the more modern duties of life. They crowd in great numbers, in very small houses poorly ventilated, and dance until morning. When overheated they go out into the cold and often the result is that Tuberculosis is hastened or developed.

The question of marriage and divorce is one of the greatest evils standing in the way of their moral betterment. At present on the majority of reserves the people live together and separate at will, cases being known of young women not over thirty years, having six different husbands. If they were compelled to register their agreement to live together as husband and wife before an agent and such an agreement to be as binding as in our own marriages we think that the difficulty would be greatly improved. Bigamy would then be with them a punishable crime and they would be subject to our criminal code. Some means, however, should be provided for honorable divorce in particular cases.

We believe that suitable hospitals on each reserve or where a number of small reserves are situated close together one hospital might serve them all. These need not be large or expensive buildings and as far as possible tents should be used for patients. A building would be required for the nurse and assistants, with living rooms, kitchen, small dispensary and store rooms. In some cases the hospital might be located near the school and the principal of the school be in charge, but accounts kept separately. In such cases the school girls might act as assistants to the nurse, and in this way receive valuable
instruction in the care of the sick. Where the institution is situated on the reserve, the nursing staff should be expected to instruct the Indian women in the care of their infants and in the selection and preparation of suitable foods for them. The appalling death rate in the Indian race is from among the infants.

We suggest that better ventilation of Indian homes should in every way possible be encouraged. These could be improved if there were some regulation as to the size and number of rooms in a house. If a few model cottages were built on some of the reserves it would encourage them along this line. The agents should be furnished with plans of such cottages that Indians buildings might have something to guide them in their work.

The practice of conjuring over the sick should be prohibited by law since many cases of death are caused by such practices.

We believe that the question of education and uplifting the Indians on the reserves is not so hopeless as is generally believed. Further, work accomplished among these people is permanent and greater effort should be made to help them. The women on the reserves need instruction in the selection and preparation of foods, care of their children, and the ventilation and sanitary care of their homes. The use of lantern slides, on the reserves, might be made a very useful mode of educating the older people along the lines of temperance, sanitation, and diseases if such views were accompanied by a talk in simple language. By means of such slides their minds are opened to the larger and newer things and they begin to think.

I have pleasure in reporting that the Western Committee have expressed their approval of the proposal to close Regina School and build a Boarding School on the Pasquah Reserve. Their resolution is as follows:

"The Committee agree that if a suitable Boarding School is provided at a convenient point on the Pasquah, Muscowpetung and Piasapot Reserves, it will cordially acquiesce in the proposal to close the Regina Industrial School, and that, if it be resolved to close the Regina School, only such further expenditures be made as may be deemed absolutely necessary to make the building habitable during the period that may elapse before it is closed."

Dr. Farquharson adds, "With a Boarding School at Pasquah, an improved Day School at Hurricane Hills, Moose Mountain and Mistawasis, our work will be well equipped."

May I suggest certain points that arise in this connection, and that will require consideration?

1. It will, I presume be necessary to spend one more winter at least in Regina, and if so, some expenditure will be necessary. Mr. Heron, who approves of the proposal to close Regina, says that three or four hundred Dollars, expended before the winter sets in, might suffice, but more, if continued through the coming summer.

2. Dr. Farquharson says that in transferring Regina pupils to other schools, the Department may have difficulty. In some instances in similar circumstances, the parents insisted on their children going back to the Reserves. That is a point still some distance in the future, and will be, no doubt, in mind when the time comes.

3. The Western Committee evidently considered, although they took no formal action, what might be the proper application of funds saved by the closing of Regina. Their judgment seems to be that the Department might spend the value of the Regina property in building schools, both improved Day Schools and Boarding Schools, and that they might distribute the stock and equipment at Regina among the Boarding Schools. If this were done, and then the $14,000 paid annually for the maintenance of Regina were applied to the maintenance of the other schools, it would put our work in good condition. Dear Sir:

I have received today from Dr. Farquharson the action of the Winnipeg Synodical Committee, which I beg to report:

1. They approve of the closing of Regina School as proposed. Of course the date of closing can be adjusted to suit the conditions, as already indicated by your Department.

4. They say that Mr. Bailey, who is at present missionary on the Lizard Point Reserve, is proving himself to be the kind of man needed to control a colony. He got the Indians to put up 800 tons of hay last season and to sell a good deal besides. He also got the Indians to go out harvesting and threshing so that over $2000.00 was brought back in wages, and that he so controls that the money is wisely expended. Mr. Bailey is himself a practical farmer and is besides a good stock man, having a knowledge of veterinary and medical science, obtained on an Irish farm and in Edinburgh Medical College. I should think that when such a man turns up, which is rare, he should be utilized.

The Committee think that there should be some co-operation between the school and the colony, so that pupils leaving the school could be placed on probation under strict discipline for a few years.

This seems to be a practical scheme, and if successfully applied would work a revolution not only on that Reserve, but throughout that whole agency. It will, I am sure, command the earnest consideration of the Department.

Dear Mr. Scott:

There is one point in connection with the new regulation upon which I am not clear. Is it the desire of the Department that temporary appointments, made in order to supply emergencies, must be approved by the Department? Inasmuch as the Indians are the wards of the Government, and the main concern of the Church is the moral and spiritual welfare of these people, it is the opinion of this Board that the Church should assume in future no responsibility for buildings or farms or equipment, but confine its support to the salaries of workers as hereinafter set forth.

In carrying out this principle,

(1) No money in future shall be spent on buildings or farms or equipment.

(2) That the upkeep of all such buildings, farms, and equipment, whether owned by the Government or by the Church, be assumed forthwith by the Government.

(3) That as soon as possible all the properties or assets owned by the Church be taken over by the Government on terms mutually satisfactory.

(4) That in order to safeguard the Government from extravagant management, a maximum expense for maintenance may be fixed beyond which the Church will assume responsibility.

Re appointments, salaries, etc.

(1) That all appointees by whomsoever appointed be satisfactory to the other party to the transaction.

(2) That all Principals, Matrons, teachers and farm instructors be appointed by the Church.

(3) That the salaries of Principals, Matrons and teachers in Boarding schools be provided by the Church.

(4) That the salaries of all teachers in day schools, all farm-instructors and of all employees not otherwise provided for, be assumed by the Government.
