Extract from Report of R. J. Ross.

I am pretty well convinced that the Indian child must first be taught industry before we can expect him to make a creditable showing in the class room. There is no place better than the kitchen, the laundry or the sewing room, or the farm for this purpose. I understand it is the custom in Indian schools to have the younger children in the class room for a full day and the older ones - both boys and girls - for the half of each day. During the other half-day they are being taught in the other departments of the school.

The Indian, himself, cannot endure sustained labor and thinks it a hardship that his child should be compelled to work. One Indian father told me recently that he was a H - of a man and a regular slave-driver, because when he came for his boy, he found him in the field with fifteen others weeding sunflowers. If you yield to the natural desire of an Indian parent, to let his child lead an indolent life, there is no hope for the child either in the class room or out of it.

Then we must remember that the white child is fitted at home to be a housekeeper or farmer. From his earliest years he has seen his father and mother toiling, and succeeding in their toil and making a home for themselves and their children. He himself is asked early in life to lend a hand, and is trained in the home just as the Indian child is trained in the Indian Boarding school. If the Indian girl is not trained to be a housekeeper in the boarding school, where will she get her training? She is decidedly at a disadvantage as far as her home is concerned. She sees nothing there that will be of any assistance to her in keeping house in later years. If she follows the custom of her mother, she will put an old quilt up to screen her from the heat of the sun and sleep there; and spend hour after hour in idleness with no thought of making a home for herself or anyone else. She will love her children but will know nothing about clothing them or feeding them or keeping them clean.

It seems true that the younger Indian have not the high sense of honor that their forefathers had. It may be that this could be accounted for by the fact that the Indian is in a transition stage. I cannot believe that all the religious and moral teaching of the schools will be ineffective.

As to the class room, our younger children are decidedly bright and receptive. We are putting forth every effort to emphasize the class-room work of the pupils. They attend regularly and discuss their school work while at play and they repeat their memory verses while at work. I am hopeful that with an experienced and capable staff of teachers, good results will be obtained.
Extracted from the Report of Mrs. Sara Marshall.

The half-day plan laid down by the Dept. of Indian Affairs, is of course not conducive to rapid strides in book knowledge.

However it is only the few in any nationality who climb to the heights in literature, medicine, or law and it is, and will be, the same with Indians - their population being 105,000 any marked success will be noticeable. When I entered Indian work 30 years ago the quarterly returns of school-room work were exactly as they are today. Your highest grade was and is Grade VI. The Presbyterian Church has risen to this and went far over in most schools.

In our schools populated by what we call white people, parents have no say in choice of teachers but leave it to a stated few to choose. Indian schools are on the same footing.

As to the present generation having lost a high sense of honor formerly a trait of a trait of the tribe, we have only to take our memories back to early days in time of regime of Cabots, Cartier and etc., noting how far exploiting the Indian went and wonder how they have not lost the trait in striving to follow up "Civilization."

We are also aware of intermarriages with types of white people and know that in all coming days children bear this burden. As to interpreting Cree - I am told by the Indians, there is very little pure Cree spoken. (I am only referring to Birtle agency, Cote reserve and adjacent reserves).

In cases where a large amount of land is cultivated, boys may be kept out of class room during the very busy seasons and we all know that around the ages of 14 years, when handling horse and being among the stock, appeals far more to a boy than sitting in a school room with a book written in, to him, a foreign language.

I think the standard of school room work in Catholic schools does not measure up to Protestant schools. I also think compulsory attendance in school room is not carried out in Catholic as in Protestant schools.

The Government travelling nurse stated to me that in all her travels no schools measure up in every way as Presbyterian Indian schools.
Compulsory School Attendance.

There is a point in this paragraph. Our conception of compulsory education is that children must attend a day school and not a residential school. The day school is our ideal in Indian education but we are far from it yet because of reserve conditions and the lack of responsibility among the Indian people. My opinion is that once children enter the residential schools they attend the class-room very regularly unless it is in the large Industrial Schools with nine or ten hundred acres of land.

Holidays, Selection of teachers, Course of Studies.

In any schools that I have known during my time in Indian work all children who have homes get away for holidays from one month to six weeks each year.

We have to follow the course of study outlined by the Province in which we work. Our classrooms are inspected by the Provincial Public School Inspectors. (Do you think it would be advisable to have some of the Indian parents on the Manitoba Advisory School Board?) The parents of today graduated twenty-five years ago when the standards are very low compared with the present time. The same holds true in regard to the Indian parents having a voice in the selection of teachers.

In all the residential schools that I know all the children attend class-room until they are 12 years old and go on the half-day plan from 12 to 18 years. The teachers are Prof. Second Class and have their standard in the class-room to keep up and would object to having children kept out. The Inspector will examine the roll and we must give a good reason for absent children, or it is reported to the Department.

In 1910, 1911 I was in the service of the Department and inspected 11 Day Schools each year and the work of the residential schools was 100% better. The improved day school was brought in to better these conditions.

Low Standard of Class-Room Work.

I have not found the parents anxious to send their children to school in fact I have found the majority of the parents absolutely indifferent. Regarding the children not being kept regularly in the class-room, I have never heard of this complaint except in connection with some of the very large Industrial Schools and I do not know if there is any truth in it. Indians will bring up anything on earth if they want to complain. The statement "Ex-Graduates have not enough education to enable them to transact ordinary business - scarcely enough to enable them to write a legible letter." To me, this is an extraordinary statement that I would not care to make until I had read all the reports of the Class-room Inspectors. Our Inspector, Mr. Maguire, said our Junior room was the best primary room in his Inspectorate. Half the children are in Grade 3, and very few of them are over 11 years of age.

The parents sent them because they could not manage them at home. They cannot learn English at that age. I sent two such boys home because it was not just to have them in the senior room and you could not put them in the Junior Room. Many such were pushed into the larger school in the early days because the smaller schools would not have them and if Mr. Heron does not refer to this class of pupils in his statement, I cannot think that he is correct.

The cure for such a state of affairs is compulsory education. If children are well they should begin their class room work at seven years of age and not at 14 or 16.

Industrial Education for the Indian.

After 25 years in Indian work, and seeing the problem on the reserve and in the schools, in B.C., Alberta, Sask., and Manitoba, it is my opinion, that there is no education that the Indian children need so much as the training they will get "on the farm, in the garden, laundry, bake-shop and kitchen." He may not work in some cases even when taught to work with his hands but he is more likely to do so since it gives one the confidence of accomplishment. A fair elementary education is necessary to transact ordinary business, to read the local newspaper, etc., I would say grade 6 to 8, but the higher education will not help much to solve the reserve problems, and the Indian must stand or fall on his ability to make a living on the reservation. I wish you could spend a month on a few reserves in Manitoba, go into every home, see the houses and equipment, stock, crop, tillage, roads and hear what you think about the necessity of industrial education. When the Indian enters fully into our economic atmosphere and can pay his own way, he can have any kind of an education that he wishes.

Class-Room Standards.

Paragraphs 6,7, 8, 9, deal with the same subject as was taken up in paragraph 4, and the Inspectors reports at Ottawa will settle this point. These men are Provincial Public School Inspectors, and the grading will be the same as in the English speaking schools. One has to keep in mind that the Indian children have no English when they enter school and also that the average age of entering school is about eleven years.

Lack of Self-Reliance.

I think there is truth in this at the present time. One must remember that all the foolish things that is apt to get into one's head is usually there around 20 years of age. If we could only do our youth over again as we think we would do it at 50 years it would be the pious age of youth. The lack of self reliance is in every community to a greater degree today but we are passing through a re-constructive period in history. The war may bring some good and grand things but we know already of some of the contemporary evil ones and the reservation is no more free from them than elsewhere.
The Department's Policy.

About 14 years ago the Department made a careful study of the Indian problem to re-adjust policy. They got reports from inspectors, agents, principals and we saw the fruits of that information in 1911, Improved Day schools on the reserves, better constructed and equipped residential schools, (100% improved) in many cases higher standards in class-room work and Industrial work, the latter very much improved, and the Provincial Public School Inspectors to take charge of the class-room work. This last change was introduced in 1922. As a Church engaged in this work we can do nothing better than to co-operate with the Department to the extent of our ability and I have found them the essence of consideration during all my years of work.

Sincerely yours,

Signed:- W. A. Hendry.
Report of F. Rhodes.

Replying to your communication of the 4th inst., enclosing a copy of a paper read by Mr. R. B. Heron to the Regina Presbytery meeting regarding Indian education; I beg to advise that Mr. Heron's statements are correct in only a few particulars.

Firstly it is noted that Mr. Heron does not offer any suggestions or solutions to the existing arrangements in Boarding schools, to say that an Indian child is brought to a Boarding school and does not attend classroom is not correct, so far as this school is concerned.

If we are to allow pupils to attend classroom for the full day, and if the pupils (Girls) are not to be taught Domestic Science then the staff of a School this size will have to be increased 100%.

In an institution such as this, who may I ask is going to prepare Meals for 70 people, bake bread, Laundry work and general cleaning of the school, further where are the Girls going to receive instruction in Domestic Science? Certainly not in their own homes!

We cannot make Pauline Johnstone, or Long Lance's out of all our pupils no more than we can make Ralph Connor's or Nellie McClung's out of our White boys and girls, but the pupils in our Church Schools are getting the best Training and Education that is possible.

I may say that no pupil in this school is kept out of Classroom for the purpose of earning Revenue of for the School, true there are odd occasions when it is found necessary to keep one or two boys out of the Classroom owing to pressure of outside work, this however does not in any way interfere with their education as the occasions are very infrequent.

Mr. Heron apparently loses sight of the fact that there are dull boys and girls amongst the Indians and it is not fair to these schools or their Staffs to cite these as examples of graduates.

It may be interesting to note that two of our Girls aged 16 years have just passed the Grade 8 Examinations and are now eligible for entrance to High School, these girls are the only pupils from this school who have sat for Examination.

Personally I fail to see how we can inaugurate a better system for Educating and training the Indian children than that which is now in vogue at this school, the work must be done either by Pupils or Hired help, if it has to be done by hired help then there will be a heavy drain on the finances of the Women's Missionary Society and as a consequence some part of the organization will suffer.

We have had nothing but praise from the Parents for the facilities and instruction given to the pupils of this school.

I hope to be in a position in the near future to give you the percentage of prizes won in classroom work in competition with the White Children at the Provincial Exhibition held in Regina recently. I know it is as high but have not been able to check over them yet.
Report of H. B. Currie, Alberni, B. C.

Yours of the 4th inst to hand re the paper read by Mr. Heron before the Regina Presbytery, and asking if in my opinion the situation is as Mr. Heron represents.

I know no Mr. Heron, in some respect the situation is as he says, but I would not care to stand in Mr. Heron's position. The worst prevaricator is the one that tells only half the truth. And that is just what Mr. Heron has done. In the second clause of Mr. Heron's paper he says Indians may be in school, living in it day and night; in fact, yet not be in regular attendance in the class room. This is a serious charge against the officers of the school and the Indian Agent, the Inspector of Indian education and the Indian Department. It is simply a charge that they are not doing their duty or that they would insist on regular attendance. So far as this school is concerned, the pupils are in regular attendance so far as the health conditions of the pupils will permit. Facts are the strongest evidence against such exaggerated statements as Mr. Heron has indulged in. So I will now turn up the class room Register of this school and give you the record for the past quarter (1st April to 20th June). In this quarter there was 64 class room days. On our Register is 86 names. 51 pupils were in the class room 64 days. 16 pupils were in the class room 63 days.

We had the Flu in March and the pupils that were in class room less than 57 days were in every case out recovering from said Flu. Those who lost time between 57 and 64 days were out for other minor ailments.

I have no doubt your other schools can show equally good Class Room attendance. Now I do not wish you to get a wrong impression from the above. When I say the above pupils were in the class room as above it simply means that the larger pupils were in the class room half of each day, as is required by the Indian Department. The other half day was spent just as Mr. Heron says - There are farms and gardens, laundries and bake-shops and kitchens in connection with Indian schools, and when the pupils are not in the class room they are receiving an important part of their training in the said farms, gardens, kitchens, laundries, bake-shops, sewing rooms and etc. This part of an Indian's training is of even greater importance to an Indian than the Class Room work. A large part of the Indians have not the strong constitution a white man has, simply because for generations they have not lived right. Food, sanitation, clothing and environment have all been wrong. With a result
that the Indian population was gradually decreasing until ten or fifteen years ago, when the training of our Indian school began to make its influence felt. Since then the Indian population has gradually increased. Even yet it is my opinion that were the Indian child closely confined in the classroom all day and hours of home work, and other things crowded into a white child's life - heaped upon the Indian child - well it would be only the strongest of them that would survive. It is the half day in the classroom and the other half devoted to the open life on the garden or farm - or the complete change to the kitchen, laundry, or sewing room that is their salvation, from a health viewpoint. On the other hand, for the time being at least, it is not important that the Indian should become a people of high educational endowment. What our Government is aiming at, at present, is to make good citizens out of them. When that has been attained, will be soon enough, to think of their higher education. Even now if a few bright pupils show aptitude, I am satisfied those in charge of the Indian Schools and the Government will be glad to lend whatever assistance. But as I was saying, the thing to do first for the Indian is to make him a good citizen. This cannot be done until the home life is right. The Home life cannot be right before the wife can cook a meal well, make, mend, and keep clean suitable clothing, and have a good general knowledge of good housekeeping and sanitation. While the father must have learned to work to provide a suitable living for those immediately depending upon him. All this our Indian Boarding schools are doing. So the farms, and gardens and laundries and bake-shops and kitchens are a real blessing to the Indians and not a detriment, as Mr. Heron would like you to believe. And under such conditions of school life I have been able during my thirteen years as Principal of this School to pass a number of my pupils at the Provincial Examinations for entrance to High Schools. And any number of the balance are bright, intelligent, young men and women today, quite capable of giving a good account of themselves in competition with the white population.

Mr. Heron is writing from Sask. I am not familiar with conditions there, I speak of the Indians of Vancouver Island as I find them, and will leave to my fellow workers in Sask. and Alberta to answer Mr. Heron's charges there. But I will say this Mr. Heron is apparently out to swipe everybody and everything in sight. I gather this from what he says about our schools of learning in Canada. "He says, Capt. Long Lance this man while a Canadian, Indian, had to go to the United States to procure the education that enabled him to write a good story. Well, I rather admire Mr. Heron's courage. He is a real hero or he would never have been able to stand before an intelligent body of men such as I would imagine constituted Regina Presbytery and say, Our splendid Universities and Colleges were unable to give Captain Long Lance the education to write so good a story. When he makes such charges against McGill, Queens or a dozen other Colleges or Universities one might mention, it simply shows that his unreliable statements are scarcely worth considering.
Extract from Report of G. A. Hackney.

I have been wondering what percentage of the pupils of the Boarding school are received at the age of 7 years and kept there in regular attendance till they are eighteen. Judging from the pupils that have been sent here from this reserve I should say that that percentage is very small indeed. Most of the boys and girls who have gone from us have been those who perhaps have not been sent to school at all until they were eight or nine and in some cases, ten. Thereafter they are so irregular in their attendance that when they reach the age of 13 or 14 they are still only in the second or third grade with rather poor standing at that.

Some of the quarterly reports that I have forwarded to the Gov't. have revealed a distressing situation. Children who should have been in school at least 4/5 of the time have only been present from 5 to 10 days and the aggregate of days absent has almost equalled the aggregate of attendance. I think I shall enclose one of these reports that you may see for yourself what we as teachers of the day school have to contend with.

This sort of thing goes on till those children, roaming about the reserve, commit some misdemeanor and are sent to the boarding school.

If it be true that the majority of the pupils in our boarding schools are of this type then it is small wonder that the results are such as Mr. Heron complains of.

Mr. Heron's statement that the Indians as a rule are anxious to have their children educated, is if this reserve is typical, pure fiction. From the Chief down they manifest little or no interest in these matters and an attendance officer is an urgent necessity.

Of course, the key man is the agent and, if he is not on the job, the teacher has not a chance.

The Indian children are intelligent and if given a proper chance will give a good account of themselves at school.
Report of J. L. Millar.

In reference to Mr. Heron's letter of Aug. 7th, I must say that the facts do not correspond with our local situation. We follow, as far as possible, the full day system for class room work. The Inspector always gives a very favorable report of the standing of our pupils.

It would apply to the graduates of the R. C. schools in the district.

We are careful also to educate along the industrial lines such as the kitchen, laundry, bake-shop, farm, carpenter shop etc., the children have not had the education along these lines as English speaking children generally receive. The Indian children have a "good capacity for education but generally lack in ambition and ideals to realize their possibilities. Our Indian School Inspector, Mr. Cairns, an old teacher of Indian children, is a firm believer in the half-day system, especially for the large schools. Our system suits the requirements of our school better.
Extract from Report of W. J. Cookson.

As to the matter of an Indian having a voice in the selection of a teacher or the course of study, it is unreasonable to expect that a parent without any education should be in a position to decide as to what is in the best interest of the child in either of these respects.

In the second place while the children are the wards of the Church and Department of Indian Affairs, in my experience I have always found that the parents are quite satisfied to leave such matters in their hands.

In the matter of work, a pupil at 15 years of age is put on the half-day system at least that is the rule in the Cecilia Jeffrey School. One half-day in the class-room and the other half in whatever work there may be to do around the building. I consider that their training in this respect is equally as important as their work in the class-room.

If in the years that a child is supposed to be in school, they are not able to get an education of a higher standard than that which the writer refers to, it is not by any means the fault of the system. A child that may not be sent to school as in the case of a girl that we admitted a few days ago, until they are thirteen years of age cannot be expected to make very much progress; on the other hand, if the discipline of the school is such as to allow the child to be absent from the class-room, it must necessarily be with the same result.

In conclusion let me say that I find that the children in this school far exceed anything that the writer has reference to and that the parents do not complain of the system.
Dear Mr. Edmison:

At your request I offer to reply to Mr. R. B. Heron's paper read before the Regina Presbytery. In doing so I do not presume to answer for all the schools under the different Churches - But so far as the criticism goes it applies to all Indian Boarding Schools for they are all conducted on much the same method being all under the direction and inspection of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

However, as Birtle is one of our oldest schools and the Reserves from which we draw our pupils are all under Presbyterian missionaries it is but fair that I should defend our methods and make clear to your Board and to the Church at large that the best course is being followed.

I wish to make clear at the outset that the Department of Indian Affairs has an educational Department to supervise and inspect the 100 Indian Schools under their care, in much the same way that the Provincial Educational Departments supervise and inspect the Public Schools. Consequently Mr. Heron's criticism of the methods of the Indian Boarding Schools is directed against the Department of Indian Affairs and not against any policy or method that the church defines for this work.

Mr. Heron evidently favors the establishment of the day school on the Reserves with the children living at home. This no doubt would be the ideal way of educating them if conditions warranted it. But the inspectors of Indian Schools and Inspectors of Indian Agencies and Indian Agents are all agreed that under present conditions on the Reserves, the day school is an absolute failure on most of the Reserves throughout Manitoba and Saskatchewan. Mr. Heron says that attendance under the compulsory School Attendance Act may mean merely living in a boarding school and not attendance in a class room; that the children put in too much time in bake-shops, laundries, housework and farm-work and too little in the class room. This is the Indian complaint. Nothing would please the Indian better than to sit down and have the White men feed, clothe and wait on him. If we did this work for the children in the school, we would be making them worse Indians and unfitting them still more for the conditions of civilized life.

In this complaint he assumes that the Indian Boarding School aims at doing for the Indian children just what the Public Schools does for the white child. Whereas the Boarding School not only teaches them to read, write, etc., but tries to teach them new conditions of living. Teaches them to eat different food, to sleep in beds, to dress, wash, bath, to bake their bread, cook their food, keep their houses and make a living on farms, etc. not like their parents have done but in a manner that shall enable them to live in civilized conditions in which they find themselves,- tries to instil into them energy, perseverance, self-control, morals, and religion, and make these so much a part of their life, that they shall practice them as long as they live.

Consequently, all their work around the school is a process of instruction to fit them for new conditions of living - the actual class room work is only a part of the training. There would be no use teaching them to do business unless they had been taught to have some business to do.
However they do get the actual class room attendance - In our Birtle School the number of School days exceed those of the Public School and the Hours are the same.

All the children under 14 years of age are in the class room for the full hours, unless sick. Those from 14 to 18 years work on the half-day system. The girls spend the alternate half-day in the kitchen, laundry, sewing room etc., and the boys spend the alternate half-day on the farm, stock, garden and general repair work. In a couple of generations much that we have to teach these children in the school, they will have learned in their homes and the day-school and class-room work and higher education can receive the attention that it does now with our white children.

Mr. Heron's complaint that the parents have no choice of the teachers and courses of study, of their children is far-fetched. Neither do parents of white children choose their teachers and up to High School there is no choice of subjects.

Mr. Heron says what it is doubtful if the majority of pupils of Indian schools leaving school at the age of 16 years could pass the examination equal to 4th or 5th Grade for White children - In Birtle school we follow the same course as the Public Schools of Manitoba and the 69 Indian children in attendance ranging in age from 7 to 18 are graded as follows: Standard I, 14; II, 17; III, 0; IV, 10; V, 19; VI, 8; VII, 1. In view of the fact that it is only about three years since the attendance was made compulsory for the Indians it was inevitable that with the first enforcing of this law, a number of boys and girls from 14 to 18 years of age came into the schools for the first time, most of them without English and are leaving as soon as they are eighteen. Consequently, they could not get on very far.

Then, many of the parents who have not been in school themselves keep their children out on all manner of pretexts, till they are 11 or 12 years old and they are thus at a disadvantage throughout their whole course. The complaint that Mr. Heron makes that few of the pupils are able to interpret English into Cree, or vice versa needs only a little consideration to see how unfounded it is. We do not expect pupils in Public School to translate from one language to another. Only when they get into High School, do they attempt this. With the range of thought and language so divergent as that of English and Cree it is not to be expected that a Public School pupil can easily interpret one into the other and it is especially hard to translate the abstract reading of an ordinary sermon into the simple concrete language of the Cree.

Further he says that one has only to attempt conversation with an ex-pupil to find out how limited his vocabulary is. Everyone knows that it is characteristic of the Indian not to talk more English than he has to. Even if he knows English well, he will often meet you with a blank stare when asked a question. And often it is very convenient for him not to talk and pretend that he does not know how. Many of them are not anxious to learn how or to use the white Man's language or copy his verse.
Mr. Heron points out that the younger Indians have not the same sense of honor and self-reliance that the older Indians had. He must admit that the sphere in which the older Indians moved was very different limited when compared to that of the ordinary Indian school graduate. And even if we admit the statement, may we not find an explanation in the changed conditions? Before the Indians came into contact with civil laws, the relationships within their own tribes were those of a family. They must respect the rights and possessions and women and children within the tribe. And if they infringed on any of these rights of another tribe their whole tribe had to answer for it. Civil law treats them as individuals and groups of families and thus leaves them to exhibit each other and to outdo the white man if they can.

I conclude by this by repeating Mr. Heron's own statement that "The Presbyterian Church is conducting a number of Indian schools in Saskatchewan and Manitoba, it is most important that as a Church, every possible effort be made to fulfill our obligations to these parents whose children we have taken and that we give these children that will best equip them for a place in the citizenship of the country." May I add to this that an expert staff at Ottawa assisted by a Commissioner at Regina with School Inspectors, Inspectors of Agencies and with Indian agents and Farm Instructors on the Reserves are in a position to know all the conditions of the Reserves and Indian Schools, have worked out through years of experiments the present Indian Boarding School. I have no doubt that they consider that under present conditions - and in this the staffs of our school will all agree - that the Boarding School, teaching the Indian children all these departments of work and keeping them away from the temptations and conditions on the Reserves is the best method possible to equip the growing generation of Indians for a place in the Christian citizenship of the country.

Signed: F.E. Pitts.
Principal of Indian Boarding School, Birtle, Man.
In the Regina "Leader" a news item from Ottawa states that the Social Service Council of Canada passed certain resolutions; one of which was to ask for better enforcement of the School Attendance Act as it applies to the Indian Schools.

Compulsory school attendance is quite familiar to us, but as applied to the Indian children it means something quite different from the law which governs the attendance of white children at the ordinary public school. In one case it means the attendance in the classroom - in the other merely the taking up of residence in a Boarding School or Industrial School - and this is the point the Social Service Council may have overlooked: viz., Indians may be in a School, living in it day and night, in fact, yet not be in regular attendance in the classroom.

Indian children are compelled to leave their homes at the age of seven - to remain in school, with only an occasional holiday, until they are eighteen. The parents have no voice in the selection of the teachers, nor in the selection in the course of study the children are to pursue, nor in the number of hours they attend the class-room.

The Indians, as a rule, are anxious to have their children educated, but they complain that they are not kept regularly in the class-room; that they are kept out at work that produces revenue for the School; that when they return to the Reserves, they have not enough education to enable them to transact ordinary business, - scarcely enough to enable them to write a legible letter.

There are farms and gardens and laundries and bake-shops and kitchens in connection with Indian Schools; the parents claim their children spend time at work there that should be devoted to the class-room.

The class-room standing of many of the graduates of these schools would indicate that the parents have considerable ground for complaint.

It is doubtful if the majority of these pupils, leaving school at eighteen years of age, could pass a higher examination than that set for a fourth or fifth grade class in a school for white children. To say that white children are more intelligent and learn faster, does not dispose of the complaint, nor explain the difference in the standing of white and Indian children with the same number of years of school attendance to their credit. Indians have shown over and over again that they are capable of holding their own in class-room and College halls, and also in literary work of very great value. I have in mind a Cree Indian, gold medalist in the University of Manitoba, who later translated the Gospel of Luke from the Greek to the Cree language, a volume of poems whose verse and story are inspiring to all Indians hearts, was an Indian woman. Lately there appeared in the Regina Leader, and also Maclean's Magazine, stories of Cree Indians, written by a young Indian of literature.
Indian is capable of great things, if given the chance.

The ex-pupils of our Indian Schools have such faulty education that very few of them are capable of interpreting Cree into English, or vice versa. A story is told of a clergyman who attempts to preach to an Indian congregation through an interpreter. From the text (Matt. 14:27) "It is I, be not afraid," when this came to the interpretation ears of the congregation in their own language, it was: "Hit him in the eye, don't be afraid"!

One has to attempt a conversation with these ex-pupils to find how very meager is their English vocabulary, and how painfully limited is their knowledge. This is further emphasized by the fact that very few of them subscribe to any paper or magazine of any kind; Any system of education that leaves young men and women without a desire to read, is open to criticism.

I would point out too, in passing, that men with years' experience among the Indians agree that the younger men have not as high a sense of honor as, and are less self-reliant than the old Indians who have never been in school.

The Presbyterian Church is conducting a number of Indian Schools in Saskatchewan and Manitoba; it is most important that as a Church, every possible effort be made to fulfill our obligation to these parents whose children we have taken, - and that we give these children the training that will best equip them for a place in the citizenship of the country.

Avenhurst, Sask.,
May 1925

Dear Dr. Scott:

I am enclosing a copy of a paper read by Mr. Heron before the Presbytery of Regina last summer. By resolution of Presbytery, this was forwarded to me. I at once sent a copy of it to the Principals of our Indian Boarding Schools and I received replies, copies of which I am enclosing as I thought you might be interested to get the point of view of these men.

At the meeting of our Executive, after reading Mr. Heron's letter, and the replies from the various Principals, the following Minute was adopted:

"A communication from the Presbytery of Regina was received enclosing a copy of a paper on Indian Education given at a meeting of that Presbytery by Rev. R.B. Heron. In view of the fact that through the publication of this paper certain criticisms of the Indian Residential Schools had received a measure of publicity, this phase of the work was given even closer than customary attention by the Executive. Full and carefully written letters were read by the General Secretary from the Principals of the Schools, dealing with methods employed, courses and hours of study, etc.

"As the outcome of this inquiry, the Executive expressed:
(1) satisfaction with the results being secured, taking into account all the difficulties incidental to the work; (2) approval of the practice now being followed by the Indian Department of dividing the children's time between study and practical training, as that which long experience has
found to be most effective; (3) confidence in the wisdom and devotion of the Principals of our Indian Boarding Schools and their associates engaged in this exacting, sometimes discouraging, work.

"It was agreed that a copy of this resolution be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs and that the Special Committee on Indian Work be instructed to prepare an article for the Presbyterian Witness, setting forth the work being carried on in our Indian Boarding Schools."

Mr. Heron's article was without our knowledge, published in the Presbyterian Witness. We regret this but you will see that the Executive has instructed the Special Committee on Indian Work to prepare an article for the Witness, setting forth the work carried on in our Residential Schools.

Memorandum:-

Deputy Supt. General.

I have given some consideration to the statement which you handed me the other day which might be thought to show that this Department was discriminating against the Roman Catholic Church in the distribution of educational grants.

The educational policy of this Department is for administration without prejudice as regards the various religious denominations engaged in the work. It may be said that schools have been established in various localities throughout the Dominion as the needs of these localities are represented to the Department. We have not been able, owing to the very large cost of this service, to give what might be considered a complete educational system, one which would reach all classes of Indians, and without a very large increased appropriation it would be impossible to do so. At present we vote $400,000.00 approximately, and the amount would certainly have to be doubled in order to establish what might be called a complete system of education to Indians. I cannot refrain from expressing the view that it is unfair to make the comparison instituted by this statement. I think, however, that the statement has been compiled from information which was obtained from our Annual Report for 1904 and if the writer had had the advantage of the full records of the Department a different statement would have been the result and the present one would not have come to hand.

The grants of the Department are not made on the principle upon which the statement has been compiled, and while consenting to examine the figures on this basis it must not be understood that this can be considered fair and just.
It is manifest that no fair comparison could be made between Roman Catholic grants and grants to any single Protestant sect. If such comparison is to be made at all it should be made between the Protestant and Roman Catholic bodies.

Making such a comparison we get the following result as the per capita expenditure. It would appear that the Protestants get $5.89 per capita of their whole number and the Roman Catholics $5.25. A glance at the per capita grant for the different Provinces will show how they vary and comment is superfluous on this point:

Of the 34,915 Indians shown as belonging to the Roman Catholic faith II,438 belong to the Province of Quebec and the Maritime Provinces for which only day school accommodation is provided, there being 34 day schools in these Provinces of which are under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. A day school system meets the requirements of these Provinces perfectly as the Indians have been a long time in contact...
with civilisation. They reside on reserves where they are directly in contact with the influence of their priests and there is no need of institutions to take them away from the evil influences of reserve life.

In British Columbia where there are shown to be 11,555 Roman Catholic Indians, nearly 50% of the total population, it is not the aim of the Department, as was before stated, to provide a complete educational system. The reserves are very many and of small area and the only way to meet the needs of these would be to establish a very large number of boarding schools which expense the Government could not possibly meet without doubling present appropriations.

For the Province of British Columbia, where the Roman Catholics have, as said before, nearly 50% of the population, our main estimates provide $64,500 for Industrial and Boarding Schools and $11,400 for Day Schools, in all $95,900. Of this amount $46,850 is devoted to Roman Catholic Schools, bearing the same proportion to the total vote as the Roman Catholic population does to the total population. The only new school provided for last year was the Schilt Boarding School, a Roman Catholic Institution.

In the Province of Ontario there are 6544 Roman Catholics being about 35% of the total population. The total vote for the Province of Ontario is $56,460.00 and the schools under Roman Catholic guidance receive of this amount $14,185. or more than 35%.

In Manitoba and the North West Territories the Roman Catholic population is 5284; the total population is 24,336 and the Roman Catholic Indians are about 21% of the whole. Now the grant for the North West Territories last year in the main estimates was $395,062., exclusive of Treaty 8. The amount set apart for Roman Catholic Schools is $118,197., being 30% of the whole expenditure. As the Roman Catholic population as I have shown is only 21% it will
will be seen that the Church is receiving more than her proportionate share.

Of late years there has been a disproportionate increase in Roman Catholic pupilage in all the schools in Manitoba and the North West Territories. Some little time ago I prepared a statement making a comparison between our expenditure in 1897-8 and 1901-02. I found that there had been an increased number of pupils - 253 - provided for the Boarding Schools. Of these 253 were for Roman Catholic Institutions or nearly the whole number granted.

I think I need not go further to show that instead of the Roman Catholic Church being discriminated against in the matter of educational there is no cause for complaint.

D. G. Scott,
Accountant.

With reference to your Grace's letter of the 10th May last, addressed to the Hon. the Superintendent General, on the subject of Indian education, and the respective grants made to the Roman Catholic and other religious denominations, I am directed to say that the comparative statement which accompanied your communication does not completely set forth the Department's policy with regard to Indian education. The statement submitted would go to show that the Department has discriminated against the Roman Catholic Church in the matter of educational grants. It is thought that your Grace will agree, after perusal of this letter, that this has not been the case.

The educational policy of the Department is for administration without prejudice as regards the various religious denominations engaged in the work. Schools have been established in various localities throughout the Dominion, as the needs of these localities have been presented to the Department. It has been found impossible (owing to the very large expenditure which would be involved) to organize a complete educational system for all Indians but as far as possible the Department has met, and continues to meet the needs of the Indians, not however, upon the basis of population. It is therefore clear that no basis for comparison by population or by religious denomination exists. Yet

The Most Revd Archbishop Duhamel, D.D.,
Archbishop of Ottawa,
Ottawa.
assuming the position taken in the statement forwarded by your Grace to be tenable the expenditure carefully analyzed does not show that the Department has failed in making grants for the education of Roman Catholic Indians which compare favorably with other grants. It is manifest also that no comparison could be instituted between Roman Catholic grants and grants to any single Protestant sect. If such comparison is to be made at all it should be made between the Protestant and Roman Catholic divisions of the population. Making such comparison we get the following results as to the per capita expenditure.

It would appear that the Protestants get $6.69 per capita of the whole number and the Roman Catholics $5.28. A glance at the per capita grant for the different Provinces will show how they vary and comment is superfluous on this point.

Of the 34,915 Indians shown as belonging to the Roman Catholic faith 11,453 belong to the Province of Quebec and
the Maritime Provinces for which only day school accommodation is provided, there being 34 day schools in these Provinces 28 of which are under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. A day school system meets the requirements of these Provinces, as the Indians have been a long time in contact with civilization. They reside on reserves where they are directly in contact with the influence of their priests and there is no need of institutions to take them away from the evil influence of reserve life.

In British Columbia where there are shown to be 11,555 Roman Catholic Indians, nearly 50% of the total population, it is not the aim of the Department, as before stated, to provide a complete educational system. The reserves are very many and of small area, and the only way to meet their needs fully would be to establish a very large number of boarding schools, which expense the Government could not possibly meet without doubling present appropriations. For the Province of British Columbia, where the Roman Catholics have, as said before, nearly 50% of the population, our estimates provided $64,500 for Industrial and Boarding Schools and $11,400 for Day Schools, in all $95,900.00. Of this amount $46,850.00 is devoted to Roman Catholic Schools, bearing about the same proportion to the total vote as the Roman Catholic population does to the total population. The only new school provided for lately was the Schelt Boarding School, a Roman Catholic Institution.

In the Province of Ontario there are 6544 Roman Catholics, being about 33% of the total population. The total vote for the Province of Ontario is $35,400.00, and the schools under Roman Catholic guidance received of this amount $14,125 or more than 33%.

In Manitoba and the North West Territories the Roman
Roman Catholic population is 5864; the total population is 24,336, and the Roman Catholic Indians are about 21% of the whole. The grant for the North West Territories in the main Estimates of 1905-6 was $295,063, exclusive of Treaty 8. The amount set apart for Roman Catholic Schools was $112,197, being 38% of the whole expenditure. The Roman Catholic population is, as shown only 21%; your Grace will therefore readily see that the church is receiving more than a proportionate share by population.

Of late years there has been a disproportionate increase in Roman Catholic pupilage in all the schools in Manitoba and the North West Territories. From a comparison between the number of pupils for whom provisions was made in the estimates for 1896-7 with the number provided for in 1907-8 it has been found that there has been an increased number of pupils - 880 - provided for the Boarding schools. Of these 676 were for Roman Catholic Institutions or nearly the whole number granted.

In British Columbia for the same years the increase has been 540, of which increase 150 pupils were assigned for Roman Catholic Institutions.

It is confidently thought that your Grace will agree that the Roman Catholic Church has not been discriminated against in the matter of educational grants.

Honorable and Dear Sir:

Allow me to recommend to your kindness Rev. Fr. Poitras, O.M.I., of Saint Mary's, Winnipeg, procurator of the Rev. Oblate Fathers for their missions; the Rev. Father accompanies Rev. Fr. Hugonard, the well-known Principal of Qu'Appelle Industrial School, and both are sent to state and explain to you our requests in favor of the education of Indian children.

BOARDING-SCOOl at CROSS LAKE, Keewatin.

The first request is in favor of a Boarding School at Cross Lake where there are (50) fifty children of school age and where the day-school is almost useless. Three hundred Catholic Indians and hundreds of pagan Indians are asking for this Boarding School.

The cost of the building to accommodate thirty children would be over $7000 dollars. We ask then, the capitulation for thirty children, and a grant of $3000 towards the new building.

THE ENLARGEMENT OF THREE SCHOOLS:
KENORA--TOUCHWOOD HILL--FORT PELLEY.

In these three schools which are doing very well, they are obliged to refuse children, and the boys have hardly any accommodation as I have seen it myself.

A grant of $3000 dollars to each of these three schools towards the building of a new edifice for boys according to plans that could not be put to execution without three times this amount, and an allowance of $1000 dollars for a heating apparatus in each school at Fort Pelley and at Touchwood Hill, and for a water-system or aqueduct for the
school at Kenora, would make it possible to put the work on a better footing and to increase the amount of good done to these Indian children.

I understand that the inspector in the western part, Mr. Graham, and Mr. Lemieux in the east, are favorable to these improvements.

INCREASE OF THE PER CAPITA GRANT.

Now, Honorable and Dear Sir, we never pressed you concerning the capitation or annual grant for each child in the "Boarding Schools"; but, we are aware of the movement on foot to have it increased, and we are in full harmony with the gentlemen who have been waiting on you in Ottawa, last year, for this special purpose.

It is evident for all those who follow things closely that we lose money and that we get in debt every year, to keep the "Boarding schools" going on, at Kenora, at Touchwood Hill, and at Fort Pelley. Would it not be possible then, to increase the capitation?

Often times, I have heard the superintendent of our missions, in the diocese, Very Rev. Father Vagnan, repeat to me: "These Boarding Schools are a cause of ruin for us"!

Let me hope then, Honorable and Dear Sir, that you will give the matter a new consideration, and that you will come to the conclusion that an increase of the per capita grant should be allowed.

No matter what certain people have said, the children, as a general rule, have taken great advantage of the education given in the "Boarding Schools", the intellectual and moral standard have been raised, and the new generations will show yet a better result.

With the hope that our requests will be granted to us,

I remain, Honorable and Dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

Arch.of St-Boniface.

This representative should be personally acquainted with the conditions of all the missions. That would mean long, expensive and difficult journeys, that would take all his time. BISHOP LEGAL ON INDIAN EDUCATION.

To the Editor of the Free Press.

Sir—I beg, with your kind permission, to reply to certain statements made in his official report by Mr. James McKenna, and dealing with the results of the education of Indians in industrial schools and boarding schools.

I quote his words: "There are people who think that the best way to correct thought to belittle the work of the missionaries is to send Indians to the Indian question seriously, and at first hand. They do not realize how much the civilization influences of their own country have been felt by them; they influence far in advance of the opportunity given them, and we bear witness to their great benefit to the nation."

These are words of common sense spoken by one who is in a position to know. It shows that he has not only seen, but, except for all, this silly nonsense about the failure of the mission schools. After a personal experience of 25 years in the field of Indian education, I find the results of the Indian education in our industrial and residential schools have been far in advance of what was anticipated or expected.

Unfortunately, not the half of those splendid results could have been anticipated.

It is perfect nonsense to expect that some of these children could be moulded in the short space of, perhaps, six years, or even ten, into a race of Indians, or child a creature absolutely immune against the influences of the world of an Indian child, that would do away with all the bad traits of the race.

If, after leaving school, some of these children fall back into the habits and misdeeds to which they find themselves exposed, it is not the fault of the youth of good and respectable families attracted by the promises of the school, but act in a bad or even worse manner, we must blame the lack of supervision, in the same surroundings.

What might have been avoided had the government adopted the policy of sending the parents, or guardians, of the children attending industrial or residential schools, under the direction of the school, to have readily submitted, and of giving them some supervision and guidance. Unfortunately in many instances, just the reverse happens, and instead of trying again the system of day schools, or dormitories, or residential schools, as it is purposed—thereby doing away with the very thing they want to get rid of (or them), it is for anyone who is even slightly familiar with the condition of our Indian reserves, at least in the West, to see that this is the case.

This system has been tried and found wanting. The reason, I believe, is the scattered condition of the Indians, and the fact that there are hundreds of more than half a dozen children living on the reserve, and therefore, on account of the distance; but even worse, the parents or guardians are in the immediate vicinity of the school, and there is no necessity for the officers to bring the attendance to any degree of regularity.

No, there is only one system which is applicable to the case, and that is the system on the Indian child. It is the system of the residential or dormitory schools, if you like to call them so. And even then, the child, after leaving the institution, has not always received the proper training and guidance, and the work done on his or her behalf is not always completed. It is a education, but not a complete education of it, and, after a short while, the effect of the school is lost.

Let the government spend a little more money for the industrial or residential schools, and the result will be still greater. The money is not extravagant, but we should generously look at the few thousand dollars spent, when the thousands are in possession of this immense existing Indian, in which we find practically every vice and crime, and an inextinguishable thirst for all kinds and all descriptions.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Dr. Roche -

In connection with the letter and statement presented by the Rev. J. Welch, O.M.I., to the Honourable the Minister of Justice in regard to Indian Education in the Province of British Columbia, I beg to report as follows:

The figures quoted by Rev. Father Welch relative to the population, number of schools, etc., are substantially correct.

I wish now to submit for your information a statement showing the expenditure on Roman Catholic and Protestant Indian Schools in the Province of British Columbia.

For the year ending March 31st, 1915, the year to which Father Welch makes reference, the Catholic population of British Columbia was 12,337, being 49.5% of the total population. During that year the total expenditure for salaries and grants to day schools and boarding schools was $115,719.00, of which amount $61,499.00 (or 53.2%) was paid to the Roman Catholic teachers and schools.

For the same year the Protestant population was 12,422, or 50.2% of the total population. The expenditure on salaries and grants in connection with the Protestant schools was $61,499.00, being 53.2% of the
total expenditure.

You will see from the above that so far as the expenditure for salaries and grants is concerned the amounts paid to Protestants and Roman Catholics were very nearly in ratio to the population.

I have also made an examination of the amounts expended on buildings and repairs in this province for the five years ending March 31st, 1915. This statement shows approximately an expenditure on Roman Catholic schools of $217,985.00, and on Protestant schools of $50,754.00. The expenditure on Roman Catholic schools was largely incurred in the erection of the new buildings at Kootenay and Kuper Island. These are the two finest Indian schools in the province and at no point are there any Protestant schools that can compare with them. You will see from this statement that in the way of capital expenditure the Roman Catholics have had during the past five years a decided advantage.

There are only eleven Roman Catholic day schools in operation out of a total of forty-six. I understand the policy of the Roman Catholic Church is not favourable to the erection of day schools and that their authorities are of opinion that our best educational work is performed in residential schools. In Indian Agencies where the vocations of the Indians are hunting and fishing it is held to be almost impossible to establish day schools and the Roman Catholic authorities urge upon us the establishment of boarding schools in these outlying districts. As a case in point you will remember the Roman Catholic Boarding School at Fort St. James, where we have just this autumn authorized a grant to 50 pupils at $125.00 per capita.
I think it will be conceded that these statements show that the Indian educational work of the Roman Catholic Church in British Columbia is being generously acknowledged and is receiving equitable support.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Mon bien cher père Guy,

En conséquence de la fameuse réunion du 7 janvier je vous adresse les rapports ci-joints indiquant les recettes et dépenses ainsi que les déficits de nos écoles, depuis 1922. Vous êtes assez au courant de nos affaires d'écoles indiennes pour vous rendre compte que les déficits proviennent de la différence entre l'octroi gouvernemental et les dépenses totales. Ce déficit serait encore plus grand si nous tenions compte du salaire que devrait recevoir les principaux, leurs assistants, les sœurs et les maîtres; ce salaire est en certains cas vraiment dérisoire. Comment est comblé le déficit? par les économies provenant des produits des fermes des directeurs, -oblats,- par le travail des sœurs, des frères et des pères, et, en certaines circonstances, comme par exemple à Lebret, en engloutissant dans le caisse de l'école les fonds des oblats.

Il me manque le rapport de l'école de Marieval, Sask., dépendante de St-Boniface. Le R.P. Naessens m'a fait parvenir le rapport de toutes ses écoles, Le R.P. Bellemare ne m'a pas encore répondu; chez lui les communications sont plus difficiles.

Vous aurez dans ces divers rapports la matière d'un bon dossier. Quelques sont bien clairs et très bien rédigés.

Mon bien cher Père, vous allez être mis à contribution. Je compte bien qu'on n'oubliera pas la rétribution, - sans attendre celle que vous prépare St-Pierre là-haut. Vous nous rendrez à tous un immense service, surtout à nous au Manitoba; je vous remercie d'avance au nom de nous tous, vous promettant les prières de vos obligés.

Votre frère tout dévoué en N.S. et N.I.,

Dear Sir:

Following your request in our conversation of the 7th instant re means to enforce compulsory education of Indians, according to The Indian Act of 1920, I beg to send a translation of Rev. Fr Baillargeon's remarks in the matter. Rev. Fr Baillargeon is Principal of Muscowequan Indian Boarding School. His letter is dated March 1st and is translated as follows:

"I would be highly interested to know if the Department has the intention to enforce the law of compulsory education for the Indians. What a relief it would be for me to learn one day of the appointment of a special officer with full authority. It is really provoking to see people of so inferior a condition as the Indians, who, for the most part are ignorant of the first word about education, dictate laws to us and raise all possible difficulties when they have to place their children at school. I am positive that if the gentlemen in charge of the Indian Department were completely aware of the circumstances and were themselves in our position that they would immediately put the law into force. For my part, I am convinced that most of the agents are bound by so many things that they are not free to see to the proper enforcement of the law. I am of the opinion that a Police Officer or Constable would be the only proper man to uphold the authority of the law and have it respected. He would be the only one having the necessary liberty and authority to enforce the different laws regarding the Indians and specially that of school attendance, which is not an easy problem. The Department is to be congratulated for having enacted such a Law."
I hope that the gentlemen in charge will consider the appointment of a proper official who would have full authority to settle any question without committing himself or compromising important matters. By such a nomination the success of educational and religious efforts would be secured and it would be for us a real pleasure to send the Indians with their foolish and unreasonable complaints to an independent tribunal.

I may add that Rev. Fr Baillargeon voices the sentiments of all the Principals which whom I have treated educational problems, and I am sincerely hoping that the Department will find the proper means to enforce the Law of compulsory education.

Will you kindly note also that this request was presented by the Deputation that waited upon Sir James Lougheed, on January 7th.

Thanking you for your kind attention, I remain

Yours very truly,

Joseph Guy

BUCK LAKE, SASK., Sept. 23rd, 1921.

W. H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
REGINA, Sask.

Dear Sir:

I went to Regina last week to consult you concerning the Buck Lake Boarding School. Unfortunately you were away and today I beg leave to state in writing the purpose of my visit.

The need of larger and more up-to-date buildings is well known to you personally and to every Officer of the Indian Department who has visited the School. During your first visit to the School three years ago you were struck by the dilapidated condition of the School.

We thought the time inopportune to ask the Department for new buildings because labor was scarce, the cost of building exorbitant and the attention and efforts of the Government were absorbed by the all important problems of the war.

Now that conditions are normal again, labor plentiful and price of building has considerably decreased, the Very Rev. Fr. Grandin, President of the Order of the Oblate Fathers, the Directors of the School, has petitioned the Department for new buildings.

To justify our request we submit to your consideration the following facts:

(1) The reports of the Inspectors show that since its erection in 1894, the School has a splendid record and has done excellent and efficient work.

(2) Since 1909 the School has been self-supporting and this is the first time we are asking for any financial assistance.

(3) The character of the training given by the School is shown by the number of former pupils who enlisted during the war, as well as by the marked and increasing thrift and industry displayed by the pupils on the Reserves.
W. H. Graham, Esq.

(4) The fact that the School is always full to its capacity shows that it enjoys the full confidence of the Indians.

However, the Oblate Fathers see opportunities for more efficient work and greater assistance to the Department in training and educating Indian children, if they had an up-to-date building that would accommodate 150 pupils.

Most of the boys leave the Delmas and Onion Lake Schools at the age of fifteen or sixteen, that is, before they have acquired fixed habits of work, thrift and industry. Could we receive them here we are in a position to give them a thorough training in mixed farming and domestic science.

We have 1500 acres of land for farming and stock raising. This land was bought by the Oblate Fathers for the exclusive use of the School. We have a good water supply and the farm is equipped with ample machinery and barns. All we need now, to have a first class and up-to-date Indian School, is a larger and more modern building.

The Oblate Fathers are not now in a financial position to erect such buildings, this is why they are petitioning the Department for assistance.

Knowing dear Sir, the special interest you take in the welfare of our Indian children, your long experience among them and the great influence you enjoy with the Department in your capacity of Indian Commissioner, I confidently ask you to approve and recommend our request.

Yours truly,

(Sgd)

Principal.

1o-RECONSTRUCTION OF DUCK LAKE INDIAN SCHOOL:

The question of the reconstruction of this important and very successful School has been seriously discussed this year and the principal arguments are embodied in a copy of a letter addressed to Mr Commissioner Graham hereto annexed. I understand that Mr Graham is giving his entire approval to this request and has consequently sent in his recommendation of same to the Department. Mr Ferrier after his appointment as Superintendent of Indian Education has visited Duck Lake School and struck by the splendid work achieved in it as also by the poor condition of its structure is fully endorsing this demand. Personally I consider the request for the reconstruction of Duck Lake School as the most important on my list and I therefore give my fullest recommendation to it. Dear Sir,

The members of my Provincial Council here, of late, give much thought and consideration to the question of the Indian Schools under their jurisdiction, and as a result have come to the conclusion that a change in the ownership of the school buildings and their dependencies which are now the property of the Oblate Fathers, is necessary and urgent.

They beg to submit the following reasons for the change of ownership:

A. A careful inspection of these School Buildings whether situated in Ontario, Manitoba or Saskatchewan shows a want of unity in their management due mostly to the fact that the Government of Canada which pays in part for the upkeep of those schools is not the owner of the buildings proper. Whilst there are eight schools under our supervision, only four belong to the Government. Those of Pine Creek, Cowesses, Muskowekwan and Kenora were built and now are owned by the Corporation of the Oblate Fathers in Manitoba.

B. A further consequence of this diversity of ownership is that Government Inspectors find themselves handicapped in their endeavors to secure uniform management of the schools in their inspection and are unable to give satisfaction to the staff, to the pupils and their parents.

C. The Indians have come to look upon the schools belonging to our Corporation with disfavor and much prefer those schools which are the property of the Government. Being wards of the Government they feel perfectly at home in buildings belonging to it, but consider themselves as strangers in buildings belonging to private Corporations.

D. Occasionally improvements of an absolutely urgent nature and which cannot be undertaken by the Oblate Fathers are made at the expense of the Government, and the Government is criticised for it on the ground that, as these buildings are not its property, it should not spend any money on them.
Still, if the Government did not carry out these improvements, the Corporation of the Oblate Fathers would not be financially able to do so, and the consequence would be that these schools would be left in a condition materially inferior to the Schools belonging to the Government, and the staff of these schools would be greatly handicapped in its work and would probably be unable to carry out the instructions of the Government Inspectors.

E. Under the present system the Department of Indian Affairs gives to the Corporation of the Oblate Fathers a per capita sum of $25.00 both for the upkeep of these schools and for interest on the investment. This sum is altogether inadequate for the purpose. As a result of our experience in the management of the schools belonging to our Corporation, we have come to the conclusion that our Corporation cannot any longer bear the burden of the maintenance of these schools for the per capita grant at present allowed, because this per capita is barely sufficient to keep the buildings in repairs and does not in any way provide for the improvements so widely recommended by the Department of Indian Affairs.

As an example of the unfair burden which the Oblate Fathers are asked to bear in the management of the schools which are their own property, we beg to instance the school of Pine Creek. This school represents an investment of $62,000.00. Allowing 6% interest per annum on the principal invested, 2% for depreciation, $400.00 for insurance and $200.00 for taxes, we have a total annual overhead outlay of $5,560.00. This latter amount does not at all provide for repairs. If 1% per annum were allowed for repairs, the total would be $6,180.00. The per capita grant for this school being $25.00 for eighty children, the sum which the Oblate Fathers receive from the Government is, therefore, $2,000.00. But they have to spend $6,180.00 to keep up the school. The weight of this burden is apparent to everybody and unless the Fathers receive help from the Government of some kind or another, they will eventually have to lay the burden down.

We might add that as the number of children authorized is almost never complete, in fact has never been so for a full period of one year, we have never received $2,000.00 in any given year, for the school of Pine Creek.
Mr. Duncan Scott #3.

Our Corporation was induced in the past into investing large sums of money for the building of these schools in the hope that the extra per capita grant of the Government, coupled with private donations, would enable them to carry on the work of the schools and pay the interest on the large sums of money invested therein. As figures prove, their hopes were never realized and, if the past is a gauge of the future, they will never be.

The Oblate Fathers, therefore, realizing the many inconveniences of the present dual-ownership of the Indian Schools under their management, are ready to transfer to the Government, the ownership of the schools which they own for a sum of money even less than the present value of the buildings and lands on which these buildings are situated. The purchase of these schools will necessitate a considerable outlay of money on the part of the Government. The latter in return will become the owner of very valuable buildings and lands, and which is more important than anything else, will be in a position to establish absolute uniformity in the management and upkeep of all these Indian Schools.

Hoping your Department will consider this change favorable, we remain,

Yours very truly,

CORPORATION OF LES REVEREND PERES OBLATS,

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

I have read the attached letter from the Rev. J.B. Beys, Provincial of the Oblate Order, requesting that the Department assume the ownership, upon payment, of the Indian Boarding schools at Cowesses, Pine Creek, Muscowequan and Kenora.

It would certainly be in the interest of our work if all these buildings were owned by the government, as well as other boarding school buildings owned by the Roman Catholic Church and the Protestant Churches who are interested in Indian education. The union of the Church and State in this matter of Indian education is well recognized, and in 1911, when we made a new arrangement with the schools, the then Superintendent General, the Hon. Frank Oliver, laid down as a principle that we should own our own school buildings, although he did not pledge the government to acquire the existing boarding school buildings owned by the Churches. One can readily realize that individual capital expenditure and the upkeep of these buildings are a serious drain on Church funds.

As a matter of general policy, I am in favour of the acquisition of all these buildings. As you are aware our Estimates do not contemplate any building operations for the approaching fiscal year, but it might be well, and I would propose with your concurrence to do so, to submit supplementary estimates for the value of these buildings, (which seems to me would be fair) and to include the necessary buildings for the other Churches which are now on requisition, in order that the denominations may be treated fairly and equitably, and that the whole matter may receive the careful consideration of the government.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that we have in the Archdiocese of Vancouver, B.C., six Indian Boarding Schools. Three of these viz., St. Eugene, Kamloops, and Sechelt, belong to the Government. The other three, viz., St. Mary's Mission, St. Joseph's, Cariboo, and St. Paul's, Squamish, are the property of Religious Communities. The schools at Mission and at Cariboo belong to the Oblates of Mary Immaculate. The one at Squamish is owned by the Sisters of the Holy Infant.

Now, as the Department is aware, we have carried on these schools for many, many years at considerable expense and self-sacrifice.

In the first place, we purchased the land and cleared it. Then we erected costly school buildings, and at Mission and Cariboo installed electric light and modern heating systems, and as time went on made many improvements, and all at our own expense. It has been a long and a hard struggle from the beginning. We have never taken any salaries, we could not afford to do so. The produce of the land and the entire Government Grant were needed for the running and upkeep of the schools.
But this condition of things we realize more and more is becoming insupportable. The Indian children after all are the wards of the Government, and so we have now come to the conclusion that it would be in the best interests of all concerned, to request the Government to purchase these schools from us.

We therefore respectfully venture to make this offer to you, feeling assured that you will give it your serious consideration.

I have the honour to remain,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Father Welsh:

I have yours of the 14th instant, referring to the St. Mary's and Squamish Boarding Schools and the Cariboo Industrial School - all three the property of Roman Catholic Orders.

In reply to your request that the Government purchase these institutions, I wish to state that I believe such action would be in the best interests of our Indian wards and would relieve the Church of the expense that it has long been bearing. The policy of this Department is to assume such responsibilities whenever we are successful in having funds voted for the purpose.

At present, the condition of the country's finances is such that all expenditures not absolutely necessary are being curtailed. For the coming fiscal year, the amount voted for Indian Education will be sufficient to meet the needs of only those institutions that are already owned by the Department. In the interim before moneys are released for a more extensive programme for Indian Education, all that this Department can do for church-owned institutions, in addition to the per capita grant, will, as in the past, be freely offered.
