While visiting our Indian Schools of the Blood and Peigan Reserves, I learned of the complaints lodged by different Inspectors concerning the insufficient knowledge of English and in particular of the faulty pronunciation of some of the Sisters connected with these institutions.

I frankly admit that in this matter all is not as perfect as would be desired; we will do our best to remedy this as much and as soon as is possible. Still it would not do to exaggerate the seriousness of this matter, nor should these complaints make us overlook certain other points of far greater importance than the defective pronunciation of English.

I would, therefore call the attention of the Department to the following observations, which those interested in the success of our Indian Schools ought to take into account.

I -
Most of the Indian Children upon their arrival at the school do not know a word of English, the only language authorized by the Department in the imparting of knowledge at these schools. Confide these children to the most eminent professor of the most celebrated University of the British Empire; of what use will be the purity of his language, the correctness of his accent be, if the pupils do not understand him?

In our schools there is a preliminary grade of instruction, absolutely necessary, wherein the knowledge of English and the English accent are of but secondary importance. And this preliminary instruction requires of the teacher special qualities on account of the inferiority of the Indian Children who, unlike the White Children, do not speak English before coming to School.

II -
Let us suppose that the teachers have a perfect knowledge of English and that they have not the slightest trace of a foreign accent, and let us suppose that they succeed in imparting to their pupils such a knowledge of English that their accent does not betray their Indian origin. Would this be sufficient to justify anyone in saying: This instruction is excellent, this education perfect? Certainly not! And why? For the simple reason that language is only a means of communication, and education comes chiefly from what is communicated and from the manner in which it is communicated; because intellectual and moral training require a proficiency far other than that of accent and diction. This proficiency in accent and diction is no test or criterion of the intellectual, and much less of the moral, value of a person.

No one would dream of maintaining the intellectual and moral competency exclude competency in any language, but the former competency infinitely surpasses the latter, so that if there are to be deficiencies in the educator, it is preferable that they be in his accent rather than in his intellectual worth or in his moral character.

III -
Let us enter further into the matter and suppose that we have been fortunate enough to secure the services of teachers with all the diplomas granted by Elementary Schools and by High Schools, teachers having at their service experience accumulated during years of teaching White Children: is all this sufficient to make of such men competent teachers in our Indian Schools? It is not. And this point is one that should be insisted on, because it does not seem to be understood that teaching and education in these Indian Schools have something all their own, a special character or stamp, and require special qualities in the educator. The value of our Indian Schools is judged by a comparing of them with Schools attended by White Children. The same criterion is used in judging both. This all starts from a wrong point of view which, if justice is to be done, must be rectified.
In Canada, the Indians are treated in a way altogether different from that in which the other peoples forming the Dominion are treated. Their social condition is altogether special. The Government considers them as minors.

The Indian Policy of the Federal Government has undoubtedly in view the welfare of the Indians from a social as well as from an economic point of view. In its conduct towards them, in keeping them under its guardianship, the Government does not deny their real intellectual qualities, more or less hidden deep down in their nature; it seeks to show not their inferiority, but rather the special nature of their character, of their way of life, of their surroundings. In this policy there is no injury done, no contempt shown: it is a policy dictated and imposed by facts.

In reality it is only by the process of a long and laborious evolution that the Indians will (if they ever do) become able to adapt themselves to our civilization. But this adaptation for the present at least, is not to be desired either in so far as the White People or the Indians are concerned.

They are unable to appreciate the nobler, the more elevated, the educative side of our civilization. From their coming into contact with the White population, the Indians get nothing but the White man's defects and vices. Whenever the pleasures afforded by civilization come within their reach, they give themselves up to these pleasures without restraint and to brutal excess. Left to themselves, they abuse of their liberty to work out their own destruction.

Intellect, will, aptitudes, temperament both individual and social, the conditions of surroundings, etc., all those elements in which the life of man is canalized, have a distinct mark and character of their own in our Indians.

Now, unless education is to come to grief and to become an obstacle rather than a stepping-stone on the way to progress, it must take these various elements into consideration. No being can be developed unless this development be according to that being's aptitudes and the fundamental conditions of its nature.

It is self-evident then that teaching and education in our Indian Schools require a peculiar pedagogy based on the nature, the character of our Indians and the peculiar conditions in which they are destined to live.

The one who undertakes to educate these Indians needs certain qualities which are acquired and developed only by constant association with the Indians and by persistent, detailed observation of their ways and customs. It is not by short visits made at great intervals, with methods and ideas formed in civilized surroundings, that a just, exact knowledge of the conditions required by those who educate our Indians is to be acquired.

Considering the question from this point of view, it is clear that the fittest judge is the missionary who lives constantly with the Indians and who has no other end in view than the good of those confided to his care.

And as for education in this special line, nothing can hope to compete with a religious Community which has made of this very branch a specialty and has made of it, so to say, its life-work. In such a Community there is a tradition: members of the Community may change or may disappear, but the tradition, the pedagogy, the method remains, and we must not forget that this method is the result of the experience of several generations of educators formed and trained on the spot always having the same difficulties to face and having the same end to attain.

While doing our best to make up for the deficiencies that exist in the teachers of our Indian Schools, we must not lose sight of their qualities, nor forget the good they are doing and the results they have obtained. We must encourage them in their devoted
enable them to make up for what is wanting.

To return to the Rev. Sisters engaged in teaching at the Indian Schools on the above mentioned Reserves, I would like to point out that as they receive scarcely half the salary of schoolmistresses teaching White Children, it would be hardly reasonable to exact of them the same diplomas as are required of other teachers, especially when we consider that in order to do their work in the Indian Schools competently these Sisters need other qualities as already explained.

On the other hand it would not be prudent to exact that those Sisters who have spent years in these Schools be charged under the pretext that their pronunciation of English is faulty. This would be to deprive these Schools of the experience these Sisters have acquired during the years they have spent in these very Schools.

The best means of settling the whole matter would be to afford these Sisters the opportunity of perfecting themselves in the knowledge, especially in the pronunciation of English. This can be done without much inconvenience. They could spend two months every year at Calgary or at Edmonton and there follow the summer-schools.

And I would suggest that the Department for Indian Affairs undertake to defray the expenses this might entail. And thus everybody will be satisfied.

F. Blanchin O.M.I. D.D.

MEMORANDUM.

On the 28th and 29th of August, 1924, a Convention of the Principals of the Indian Catholic schools of Western Canada was held at Lebret, Sask. The object of this meeting was to unify the methods of administration of these schools; to improve, as far as possible, primary and industrial education of the children entrusted to them; to get better acquainted with the intentions of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, and to co-operate more efficiently therewith.

The first step of the assembled Principals was to wire greetings to the Officers of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, wishing thereby to recognize not only their devotedness and unquestionable impartiality, but also the sympathy and encouragement received from them on many occasions.

The members of the Convention have successively attended to:

1.- The administration of schools.
2.- The education of children.
3.- The sanitary conditions.

In...........
In connection with these different points, it has been decided to bring to the knowledge of the Department certain resolutions unanimously adopted by the members.

ADMINISTRATION OF SCHOOLS.

1.- We are anxious to have the Department of Indian Affairs understand that our Principals are not mere employees, but a group of educators subject to a hierarchy, having their principles, their methods, etc.; and we request that this hierarchy be consulted in connection with serious measures to be taken regarding the education of Indians.

2.- We urgently ask: 1.- That the government and administration of these schools be directly and exclusively in the hands of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa. 2.- That the Department, in communicating with the Principals of these schools, shall have no other intermediary than the local Agents at points where these schools are situated.

3.- These Agents are the natural and ordinary supervisors of these schools; but for extraordinary inspections, such as auditing of books, enquiries, etc., we think it desirable to entrust them to the officers directly responsible to the Government at Ottawa.

4.
4.- In order to obtain more unity in the cooperation of both civil and religious authorities, we think it necessary that the requests of our Principals for repairs, enlargements, improvements, etc., to our schools, be addressed to us; and that we deal directly with the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

EDUCATION.

1.- We have given orders to three members of the Convention to compile a complete list of the books to be used in all our schools and to prepare a general program of study, the whole to be submitted to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

2.- There are, in our schools, quite a large number of children specially gifted to go through secondary studies fitting them to become machinists, engineers, book-keepers, teachers, etc. And we think it would be proper, for this purpose, to establish a high school for all children to enter on leaving our Catholic schools in the West. In order to save on staff and maintenance, this school could be attached to an ordinary school; for instance, to that of Lebret.

While..........
3.- While it is obvious that our Religious have, on the whole, given complete satisfaction as teachers, we are however of the opinion that we should conform to the wishes of the Department, and require them to have a Certificate from some Province of the Dominion, to serve as a certain guarantee to the public. In view of encouraging this movement, which can be accomplished but gradually, we believe that the Department should increase the per capita grant to the schools on reaching such improvement in their teaching staff.

4.- Industrial education of our children, of both sexes, must not for any consideration be neglected. If, from seven to fourteen years of age, class room work must be practically the only occupation of the child, we believe that, from fourteen to sixteen years, half of the time should be devoted to a training adequate to his future calling. From sixteen to eighteen years, industrial work should become the almost exclusive aim.

With the view of facilitating a proper agricultural training for boys, we would suggest that the schools be supplied by the Department with agricultural implements for the use of the children, and in some cases, where the school has little or no property, that additional land be secured for this valuable purpose.

Moreover, in order to extend the advantages of education, we wish that, on leaving the schools, with the.........
the recommendation of the Principal, and the assent of the Agent, the children receive from the Department, according to their merits and as an encouragement, a practical help in the way of articles to be used in their work.

5.- We realize the advantages that result from the inspection of our schools by Inspectors of public schools of different provinces; but we ask that these Inspectors respect our books and programs, and take into consideration the difficulties attendant on the education of Indian children; difficulties resulting from a defective start in bringing them up, from a very characteristic apathy, as well as from precarious health. We ask that these Inspectors receive instructions from the Department in this connection, and that the Principals of the schools be so advised.

6.- We would consider the above resolutions on Indian education incomplete, without thanking the Department for the sum of $1,000, placed at our disposal, for the erection of a monument to the late Rev. Fr. Hugonard, O.M.I., a pioneer in Indian educational work. We are pleased to state that steps are being taken to erect this monument at Lebret within the next year.
HYGIENE

1.- In the case of contagious diseases, such as tuberculosis, scrofula, etc., it is a well known fact that the Indian child, being far from his native locality, is liable to fret and pine and lose all chance of recovery. We, therefore, believe that, instead of grouping these cases in a hospital, or in a sanatorium, it would be better to have each school provided with rooms specially furnished for this purpose, and in charge of competent nurses.

2.- In the last few years, sanitary inspection by nurses has been inaugurated in our schools, a matter that has been everywhere the cause of regrettable incidents, and without compensating advantages. These nurses, who are no doubt capable, have ordered measures leading to the transformation of our schools into hospitals or sanatoriums; moreover, in their manners, their dress and their language, they have often forgotten certain requirements essential to the proper training and disciplining of Indian children. Even the physicians have, in the majority of cases, disapproved of the regulations prescribed by these visitors. We believe that the regularity of the sanitary service is sufficiently guaranteed by our nurses, who are competent, and subject to the control of the physician attending the school and to the local Agent.

In.........
In closing these meetings, the members of the Convention wish to recognize and highly praise the great work accomplished by our Canadian Government for the civilization of our Indians. We believe that no other nation has made greater sacrifices for its autochthon population; and that, nowhere else, means better adapted to the object pursued, have been employed. In making appeal to the different churches in its work of civilization, the Dominion of Canada has recognized that all true civilization must first be based on a moral law, which the Christian religion alone can give. Pagan superstitions could not,—whatsoever certain philanthropists might think,—suffice to make the Indians practice the virtues of our civilization and avoid its attendant vices.

Several people have desired us to countenance the dances of the Indians and to observe their festivals; but their habits, being the result of a free and easy mode of living, cannot conform to the intense struggle for life which our social conditions require. This has to be kept in mind for the training of new generations.

The results obtained in the work of civilization of the Indians are very remarkable, and we wish that the work accomplished might be better known.

The first step of the assembled Principals was to wire greetings to the Officers of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, wishing thereby to recognize not only their devotedness and unquestionable impartiality, but also the sympathy and encouragement received from them on many occasions.

Dear Father Guy,

During our discussion yesterday with reference to the Indian schools in charge of the Oblate Fathers for educational purposes, it occurred to me that you were somewhat disturbed about the administration end of this work.

Recognising the valuable service that your Order is performing in the interests of Indian youth, and having regard to the high esteem in which you are held by myself and the departmental officials here, more particularly on account of your zeal and perseverance in carrying on this work, I thought it well to write you a personal note expressing such appreciation.

From time to time, at conferences in my office, at which were present the Deputy Superintendent General and Commissioner Graham, you will recall that we settled matters of detail in a very definite way, and there should be no room for misunderstanding. You will appreciate that the Department must give consideration to reports from its officers in the field, Commissioners, Inspectors and others, who visit the schools in the course of ordinary duty, or who are instructed to make special inspections from time to time, but these officers have no administrative function with regard to the schools.

Dealing with the important subject of expenditure, it is understood that the estimates of actual requirements are made out by the Principals, forwarded to you, and by you discussed with the officers of the Department. It is necessary to decide upon the relative importance of the items presented as they affect the educational work of the Church, and to finally adjust the findings with the total amounts it is decided to ask Parliament to vote. This method has given good

Reverend Joseph Guy, O.M.I.,

Ottawa.
results and your judgment and your knowledge of the situation have always been of great use to us when consulting on financial questions. I know of no reason why this procedure should be altered, and I would like you and the Principals to know that I will be glad to receive your suggestions and recommendations in financial and general matters, and that it would be far from my desire to place any obstacle in the way of their transmission to me.

As you are about to visit the various schools, I think it would be well for you to discuss with the Principals details of administration, and if any matters require adjusting that will facilitate the carrying on of their work, we will be able to consider the matter on your return, for we have to depend very largely upon your advice and guidance with respect to this work.

May I convey, through you, to the various Principals and Sisters in charge my very great appreciation of the zeal, energy, and self-sacrifice displayed by them in carrying on this work in the interests of our Indian wards.

Dear Father Guy:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the agenda for the coming Convention of Principals of Indian Residential Schools under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. I am hopeful that these meetings will result in much good and I shall be pleased if you will convey to the Rev. Gentlemen as you gather the Compliments of this Department, which is so closely associated with you in an important work.

The programme of studies, which is returned herewith at your request, has been carefully examined by Mr. Perrier and its general worth and its suitability have been noted. When the Rev. Principals have given this question further discussion and have submitted a definite recommendation, you may be assured that the Department will give very sympathetic consideration.

It is our practice to assist promising graduates of Indian schools whenever funds can be found for the purpose. There are limited funds for tuition grants and the cases of successful graduates who appear worthy of assistance and who have been recommended by church and department representatives, will receive our favourable consideration from time to time. Further, when funds can be found, material assistance to establish homes will be granted, when there is a reasonable promise of permanent helpfulness.

The question of securing vital statistics on Indian reserves is somewhat difficult at times, and, if missionaries and principals will assist in this connection, the Department will be grateful for their cooperation.

The problem of tubercular children has engaged our serious attention for many years and I have tried to provide careful supervision, particularly in the case of pupils in residential schools. Considerable success has attended this effort to isolate and arrest the progress of this dread disease when still in the incipient stage. We are expending a large sum from Parliamentary Appropriation for this purpose and for the care of pupils and other Indians in the various sanitaria.

I will await with considerable interest a memorandum following the Convention of the Rev. Principals.

Yours very truly,

Dear Father Blanchin:

The question of vocational training for boys at Indian residential schools is more and more engaging the attention of the Department. I am prompted to urge upon you the advisability of the Oblate Fathers accepting the entire responsibility for the management and conduct of the Roman Catholic institutions for Indian children in your ecclesiastical province. An official communication in this connection concerning the Blood School was directed to your office some weeks ago.

Funds are being provided from time to time by Parliament for the replacement of old buildings by modern structures and equipment. The mechanical plant at these institutions is very costly and requires expert supervision. The Department would be very reluctant to ask the Church to take control of one of these schools unless it was clearly understood that a competent Rev. Settlement would be responsible for every phase of the activity. In addition to the Rev. Sisters, who give such excellent service, there should be on the staff lay brothers who are qualified not only to give boys vocational instruction but who are competent to take charge of a modern plant.

There is added satisfaction to the Department in having a Rev. Principal entirely responsible. He is subject to his Provincial and the Provincials are in close contact with the Rev. Father Guy, of this city. This principle of centralized control is one which I strongly reaffirm and it suggests that I might at this time again thank the Oblate Fathers for their great service to our Canadian Indians and to state that it is a source of much gratification to the Department to be associated with them in the conduct of Roman Catholic Indian residential schools.

D. Scott

OTTAWA, October 26th, 1925.

Mr Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr Scott:

The second Convention of the Principals of Catholic Indian Residential Schools has taken place at Duck Lake, Sask., August 26 and 27, 1925, under the joint direction of Very Reverend Fathers Beys and Blanchin, Provincials of the Oblate Missionaries for the Prairie Provinces. I feel highly pleased to place before the Department the result of our work as shown in the following resolutions and remarks.

The resolutions of our first Convention embodied in a Memorandum were submitted to the Superintendent General on October 1st, 1924. The principals assembled at the present Convention again approved of them, after having expressed their gratitude to the Department for action already taken in some matters and have requested the undersigned to bring them again to the attention of the Department for further consideration.

The resolutions of our second Convention read as follows:

RESOLUTION No 1:-WHEREAS:lo-All indian schools specially in the matter of education are under the immediate jurisdiction of the Federal Government;

2o-The principle of religious education in indian schools is recognised by the said Federal Government;

3o-We catholic principals, devoted to the education of indian children, belong to a religious denomination with distinct principles and for this reason requiring a program of studies in harmony with the tenets of our faith and that of the children confided to our care;

4o-The education of indian children begins at a later age than that of the white children;

5o-In their families indian children generally receive neither moral nor domestic education and consequently the schools must make up for those deficiencies by a special program extending over at least ten years;

IT IS UNANIMOUSLY RESOLVED THAT the Program of studies and list of books prepared by a special committee chosen at our last Convention and thoroughly examined by all principals and teachers be accepted and presented to the Department of Indian Affairs for final approbation.

RESOLUTION No 2:-WHEREAS: indian day schools established within the recruiting grounds of a residential school

1o-hamper the recruiting of the residential school;

2o-prevent the material prosperity and efficiency of said residential school;

3o-entail heavy expenses;

4o-give only the minimum of results;

5o-for the most part meet opposition from the agents:

IT IS RESOLVED BY AN UNANIMOUS VOTE TO respectfully request
the Department not to establish such day schools within the recruiting grounds of a residential school.

RESOLUTION No 3: WHEREAS: in some districts parents lo-show negligence or repugnance to send their children to school or 2o-encourage truancy:

IT IS RESOLVED to submit to the Department the desire of all principals that subsection 3, section 10, part 1, of the Indian Act be enforced in such cases.

RESOLUTION No 4: To give more precision to a resolution of our First Convention of Memo of 1924, page 3, Education: parag 2) another resolution has been passed as follows:

WHEREAS: lo-a certain number of our children better endowed than others are desirous to undertake higher studies or perfect themselves in mechanical arts;

2o-the number of said children does not justify in each school the appointment of a special teacher nor the opening of an extra class; the principals UNANIMOUSLY RESOLVE to request from the Department that said children be sent: lo-to Duck Lake School if they wish to receive higher education or

2o-to Qu'Appelle School if they desire to take up mechanical arts or carpentry; the Department to pay the salary of master engineers and carpenters together with the travelling expenses of the pupils.

RESOLUTION No 5: WHEREAS: in the case of young men leaving school it is considered advisable to follow a uniform system of help

IT IS RESOLVED to offer the following suggestions: lo-That every qualified young man recommended by both principal and agent be, upon his leaving school, supplied with a few implements and requested to work under the direction of the farming instructor;

2o-That at the time of his marriage if he has given satisfaction, said implements be turned over to said young man with a gratuity of about $200.00, to be spent under the supervision of the agent, for the building and furnishing of a home;

3o-That however special distinction be made in favor of pupils having remained a longer number of years at school;

4o-That boys be encouraged with the above prospects during their school days;

5o-That in places where farming of land is impossible the young men be supplied with the means of livelihood.

RESOLUTION No 6: WHEREAS: lo-On account of many serious reasons it is not thought advisable to send children to public sanatoriums;

2o-Evident facts certified to by our missionaries and principals show beyond doubt that most of the indian children sent to public sanatoriums have died, whilst the majority of those sent to their homes or kept in our schools under special supervision, have recovered their health;

IT IS RESOLVED BY AN UNANIMOUS VOTE to ask from the Department lo-That tubercular children be sent to their homes with special instructions to parents rather than sent to a public sanatorium;

2o-That for cases which could not be properly attended to at home special quarters be reserved in each school.

In connexion with this question all the principals as a body of missionaries heartily endorse the construction of the proposed annex to the North Battleford Hospital for indian patients and recommend same to the Department.
RESOLUTION No 7: WHEREAS; lo-The Provincial Governments are not in charge of Indian residential schools;

2o-Our duty is to centralize more and more our work towards the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa;

3o-Our requests to have more weight should be presented to the Department by a recognized official representative and our rights exposed, and if necessary, defended by such an intermediary; the members of the Convention by an unanimous vote

RESOLVE to ask from the Department of Indian Affairs that Rev. Fr Guy O.M.I., of Ottawa University, be hereafter acknowledged and considered by said Department as their official representative in all matters dealing with the education and betterment of Indians at large.

An official petition from our Right Reverend Bishops and Provincials will follow in due course to support the above resolution.

Together with the resolutions adopted at our Convention the following requests are also respectfully submitted to the Department:

REQUEST No 1:- It seems but fair that copy of the report of the school inspectors be sent to the principals, in order to enable them to judge the efficiency of the teachers and the progress of the pupils and if necessary improve the situation.

REQUEST No 2:- In the case of a school not having sufficient land for farming purposes, the Department is requested not to be unfavorable to recruiting, in order not to deprive some Indian children of the benefits of education.

REQUEST No 3:- In the interest of the Department and that of the schools, we request that in cases of repairs and alterations, invoices for material supplied and labour sheets be signed by the principals before payment.

REQUEST No 4:- For the same reasons as set forth in request no 3, and also in order not to estrange the inhabitants of a place where a school is situated, would it not be preferable to hire people of said place for certain works, when such people are well qualified? We deem that the advice of the principal should taken into consideration.

REQUEST No 5:- In order to help us to have an exact census of Indians, would it be possible to have a copy of the official lists kept by the agents given to the missionaries and school principals?

REQUEST No 6:- It is our desire that a competent doctor be placed in the proximity of the reserves and that one of his duties be to examine regularly our children in the different schools.

REQUEST No 7:- In consideration of Commissioner Graham's and many agents' efforts, we reiterate our request for the suppression of the Sun Dance. We would also welcome the prohibition of pool rooms and gambling places to Indians.

---

I hope that action along the lines indicated in the above resolutions and requests will be taken by the Department, and I wish to emphasize the desires of the Principals for closer and more effective cooperation with the Department.

Yours very truly,

Joseph Guy O.M.I.

Dear Father Guy:

In reply to your letter of the 11th ultimo, I wish to assure you that the recommendations of last year's Convention of Principals of Roman Catholic Indian Residential Schools have engaged the serious and studied attention of the Department. You may inform the Very Rev. Fathers Beys and Blanchin, Provincials of the Oblate Fathers for the Prairie Provinces, that I consider much good will come from these general meetings and that I welcome from time to time any suggestions for improvement in our educational work.

The Department is sympathetic to the request that a special programme of studies be adopted for the R.C. Indian Residential Schools. I should be grateful if you would discuss with Mr. Ferrier the content of the programme you have prepared. I do not want to depart from the grade system of grouping pupils and I wish to be sure that all texts authorized are suitable for Indian students of the West.

I have noted the second resolution of the Convention and I wish to assure you that day schools will be established only when they appear to have a definite, independent usefulness. With reference to compulsory education of the Indian children of Canada, I may say that, from time to time, as the Indian communities in different provinces are ready for such action, Section 10 of the Indian Act will be enforced.

I am very interested in Resolution No. 4, but I hesitate to name one Indian residential school as a centre for higher education and another for vocational training, until developments warrant such definite selection. For the time being, individual pupils, who show promise in any phase of their training, should be the subject of particular recommendations. I trust that, in the not distant future, there will be many children qualifying for more advanced education and training. At that time, the establishment of suitable institutions will be considered.

Resolution No. 5 has to do with the most important phase of Indian education. The Department has always recognized that the general success of our work depends to a large extent on the continued supervision of the ex-pupil on the reserve. Our staff of agents and farm instructors are in a position to do much towards making the Indian self-reliant and economically independent. I propose

Rev. Jos. Guy, O.M.I.,
University of Ottawa,
Ottawa, Ont.
to stimulate our officers' interest in graduates, by insisting upon proper emphasis on the discharge of a pupil and on regular reports concerning the progress of each. Material assistance will be granted whenever there is reasonable promise of permanent helpfulness.

Concerning Resolution No. 6, I agree that the treatment of tubercular children presents a most serious problem. I believe, however, that pupils in an advanced stage of the disease are best cared for in sanitariums.

I am very pleased to learn that the Convention of Principals has asked that you be their official representative in all matters concerning the education and other wellbeing of the wards of this Department. This resolution is evidence that the unofficial relationship and centralized control has been successful. An intimation from the members of the Church Hierarchy that are interested in Indian work and from the Provincials of the Oblate Order will make our satisfaction in this matter complete.

I have examined the requests of the Rev. Principals in convention, and I wish to state that, whenever a report of a public school inspector is such that any action is necessary, extracts will be directed to the principal of the school in question. In reply to request No. 2, I may say that the Department, when funds can be found, will always give favourable consideration to increasing the pupilage at a school, if the management is doing the best possible with the farm and the other physical equipment at its command. We expect, however, that all residential schools with facilities for teaching farming and other vocational work will give a systematic training that will fit pupils for the future.

Concerning request No. 3, I beg to state that, as far as is practicable and necessary, invoices for material supplied and time sheets for labour will be presented to the Rev. Principals for signature before payment. When building activity on the day labour plan is contemplated, the Department will secure the advice of the principal of the school before engaging labour, which will be local as far as possible.

Requests No. 5, 6 and 7 are being given consideration. May I thank the Rev. Gentlemen associated with you in Indian work for their expression of willingness to actively cooperate with this Department. Will you kindly assure them that my constant endeavour will be to develop the usefulness of schools established for the Indians.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Archbishop Sinnott,

It was my privilege last week to have a conversation with you on the administration of our residential schools in the West and I thought I should like to write you particularly on the subject of the qualifications of our teachers in these schools.

It is my policy to only recognize qualified teachers for all class-room work, that is teachers who are the holders of Provincial certificates. We are meeting with a fair measure of success I am glad to say, and I think the quality of our teachers generally has been much improved. As you are aware we have the benefit of inspection by the inspectors of the Provincial school system and this gives us independent criticism of our work and is being productive of good results.

I beg to thank Your Grace for your interest in educational matters.

Yours faithfully,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

I have just been informed by Mr. Russell T. Perrier, that from April the 1st 1927, a change has been made in the per capita grant for a number of the Residential Schools.

I fail to understand why there is such a difference in the grant for some of the schools under our administration. May I ask you to let me know on what basis the Department has established these rates? In the meantime allow me to submit some considerations. I fail to see why the Blood School should not get the same grant as the Duck Lake School, viz., £170.00.

At the Blood School, the new building is a duplicate of the one at Duck Lake, with all modern equipment and same general high expenses, having the same number of staff, cultivating a large farm and raising a good number of stock.

Again, why this difference between Ermineskin and Thunderchild, £170.00 each, while Crowfoot and Piagans only £155.00. For at Crowfoot and Piagans there is a modern, new and well equipped school, and they are doing Farm work more extensively than at Ermineskin and Thunderchild, and in my opinion should be entitled to the same grant, viz., £170.00.

And for the Piagans School, in particular, I might draw your attention that though the accommodation is only for 50 pupils, nevertheless this new school will now be under heavier running expenses; they have a Farm Instructor, an Engineer and a Carpenter. In their new location they will be able to do farming which work has already been well started. Moreover the School is farther situated from the Railway than in the case of the other two schools mentioned, viz., 5 miles from Brochet.

Therefore, dear Sir, I would ask you to reconsider this per capita grant, and would suggest a more uniform rate than mentioned in the letter of Mr. Perrier, No. 160-5, of May 4th 1927, and I would strongly recommend a uniform grant for any new and modern school built by the Department.

Respectfully yours,

Dear Father Beys:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to the per capita grant rates at Indian residential schools in your province. This year, the Department made an adjustment which, I believe, will result in a more fair scale. The old classification did not do justice to the small institutions and I am trying to increase their grant gradually so that it will equal that of the larger schools. Prior to this adjustment, the Duck Lake institution had been placed in the old "Industrial School" group. The Blood school received only $140 until lately but, commencing this year, the grant will be at the rate of $155. In the near future it may be possible to make it $170.

You ask why the Crowfoot, Onion Lake and Sacred Heart schools receive only $155, while Blue Quills, Ermineskin and Thunderchild draw $170. The last named institutions are church owned and I feel that where the capital expense has been met by the Church, the Department should allow the higher grant.

This question of per capita grant rates has engaged the attention of the Honourable Mr. Stewart and myself for some time and I wish to assure you that we shall not rest until the scale is made as fair as possible.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Father Guy,

I beg to draw your attention to the fact that the expense of education for the native population is upon the increase, and while the Department desires to provide a reasonably adequate system, it is essential that the outlay should be controlled. It is thought that the denominations should respect the zones of interest which have been established and not encroach upon them by the extension of missionary effort upon which a demand for separate educational institutions might be afterwards based. This view seems entirely reasonable, and in future the Department will not recognize requests for aid to educational institutions unless by pre-arrangement, and assistance must not be expected for institutions which encroach by the extension of missionary effort upon territory already provided for. Would you kindly advise the ecclesiastical authorities interested in Indian education of the contents of this letter?

Dear Sir:

The removal of Rev. Father Guy has left us without any representative in Your Department. I regret it as from time to time misunderstandings occur which are better settled in an exchange of views made orally rather than by correspondence.

We have at present several grievances of that kind and I therefor asked Rev. Father A. Thérien O.M.I., my first advisor, to go to Ottawa, in order to expose to You these rather intricate questions.

I must say that I received many appeals from our Principals, in regard to their relation with Your Department. I had some of these cases submitted to very reliable legal advisors.

You will see from these that there is some ground for their complaints.

As a consequence the officials on the reserves, inspectors and agents, are tempted more and more to disregard the rules of impartiality which must be foremost in a Government official. The appeal to the court in Blood Reserve is an instance of it but only one of many similar cases.

We feel sure that most of those things happen through some other official and without your being acquainted with the facts. The expense of sending one of our Fathers to Ottawa is heavy; but we felt that we had to let You know about all these facts, rather than take another procedure. You have always experienced your absolute fairness, impartiality and devotion to duty.
We therefore shall prove our confidence and gratitude towards you, in coming openly to You to settle our difficulties and we feel sure we shall receive your kind attention to same and a fair settlement.

In my name and in the name of the Oblates, permit me to express to You our deep esteem and appreciation and with these sentiments, I remain, Dear Mr Scott,

Yours very devotedly.

My dear Father Guy:

From your long association with this phase of our work, you will understand that I have to give attention to claims of this nature from all parts of the country, and it has been the policy to endeavour to so apportion the grants to be allowed by Parliament, that the most deserving cases should be dealt with first. My Dear Mr Scott:

Extreme pressure of work alone is responsible for what you must have considered a rather too long delay in communicating with you. I must admit that since my arrival here on May 3rd, I have been simply overwhelmed with work (have no secretary nor help of any kind) leaving no possibility for correspondence outside of strictly college business.

Dear Father Guy,

I was glad to hear from you, under date of June 24. I sent you a long telegram to Le Bret the other day, which I hope you received.

I trust the meeting this year was as successful as usual.

I have been very busy since you left. Mr. Stewart is in the West now and perhaps business is falling off a little bit.

Our plan for a residential school in Nova Scotia is developing slowly but surely. Mr. Stewart and I looked over a possible location at Shubenacadie, and I think the school will be located there; the ecclesiastical authorities appear to be favourable, and Mr. Ferrier and Mr. Orr are going down to view the site and to interview the Archbishop and probably the Sister Superior, whose Order is to be associated with the work. When we have this school established, one of the desires of my official life will have been accomplished. It will likely be located within full view of the railway and highway, so that the passing people will see in it an indication that our country is not unmindful of the interest of these Indian children.

I note that you are still working hard, it was always a bad habit of yours, and I presume if your superiors were to put you in a sinecure you would still be able to work hard.

Dear Mr. Scott,

On October the 27th, I have informed you of the sad accident that has taken place at Pine Creek, and to avoid, as far as possible, its recurrence, I have petitioned the Department for a special allowance to hire a night watchman in every Indian Res. School under our management. Since then, that boy McKay has confessed having set the church on fire and another boy has tried to do the same to the School. More than ever I believe it is a necessity to have a night watchman in every school.

As you have granted my request only in part, you will kindly allow me to make a new attempt. If you read over again my letter you will notice that my request was general, concerning all our schools, all being in the same predicament, namely: Lebret, Conesses, Pine Creek, St. Philip, Sandy Bay, Fort Alexander, Fort Frances, Kenora and McIntosh schools. The new Muscowequan School, being fireproof, has not the same need. For all these schools, I ask the same allowance that has been granted to Pine Creek School.

Moreover, to make sure that every night watchman will fulfil his duty it is essential to supply each of them with a watchman clock, costing about $30.00 more or less, according to the number of keys wanted.

Anticipating a favourable answer, I have advised our Principals to look, in the meantime, for a reliable man in order to be ready as soon as I have your answer.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Father Magnan,

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to night watchmen for the Indian residential schools in which you are interested. The situation at Pine Creek was so serious that the Department felt that a night watchman was advisable and offered to pay a grant towards the cost from Parliamentary Appropriation. It is not the intention, however, to pay for the services of a night watchman at all our institutions. Such an officer, where necessary, should be paid from the per capita grant or other school earnings. I know that, at Qu'Appelle, there is a night watchman who constantly patrols the buildings. At smaller schools, the Department issues instructions for a member of the staff to make a thorough inspection at ten o'clock at night and again at midnight and, further, that there should be an hour's patrol following the laying of fires in the early morning.

Dear Archbishop Duke:

I have Your Grace's letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the engagement of teachers of Indian day schools in British Columbia. In the past, Indian agents, generally with the assistance of the Inspector of Indian schools for the province and with the advice of the local Catholic missionaries, have recommended appointments and dismissals. As far as the Department is aware, this arrangement has been quite satisfactory, but there is no reason why Your Grace should not be consulted in most cases.

Perhaps the best method of dealing with appointments would be for the Department to insist on the cooperation of Indian agents with the priest in charge of the particular reserve. The priest could then communicate with Your Grace, particularly when in doubt regarding the suitability of an applicant. This is the usual practice in Canada as far as appointments to Indian day schools are concerned. If a special arrangement is desirable in British Columbia and you would like the Department also to notify Your Grace of appointments and dismissals, there is no reason why this cannot be done.

I am enclosing a list of the Catholic Day Schools in British Columbia, showing the post office address, the name of the teacher, the present salary and the date of appointment.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

The following is a list of the requirements (for 1933-34) for the Indian Schools under our jurisdiction.

Musconweguan School

1- Installation of electric wiring in barn and granaries. The Inspector of the Province of Saskatchewan reported the present wiring as defective. The authorities of the School will furnish labor if the Department provides the materials.

2- An air compressor for water pump Curtis, Model B, No. 3, 3½ x 3. We understand that Ashdown's of Winnipeg are the agents for this make of pump. We consider this improvement very necessary. On four different occasions last winter, we had to haul water for the needs of the School. As the nearest supply is one mile away, considerable inconvenience is experienced every time the water system of the School goes out of order.

3- Dormitories, recreation halls and dining room need to be painted and varnished. The School will provide labor if the Department will supply the paint and varnish.

4- We are told that linseed oil hardens cement floors. We would like the Department to supply one barrel of good quality oil so that the floors of the School may be treated.

5- There is no extractor for the laundry. As this is considered a very necessary piece of laundry machinery, we ask the Department to supply one.

The School is still without a laundry house, but in view of the present depression the School authorities will continue to use the present temporary building.
Sandy Bay School

1- This is a very old school and temporary repairs are continually needed. For the coming year, the Principal would like 1500 feet of flooring for general repairs to the chicken house and ice house.

2- The stable which is a very old building and which the Department had agreed a few years ago to replace with a new modern building is in need of repairs and the School authorities would appreciate a visit from the Inspector in that connection. The Inspector could recommend such repairs as in his estimation are necessary to prolong the usefulness of the building. In 1932, the Principal spent $59.68 in the purchase of materials for this work and would like the Department to assume the expense in this connection.

3- The water supply of the School is very defective and whilst it may not be practical to spend any large amount of money in view of the fact that a new site will most likely be selected for this school when it is rebuilt, something nevertheless should be done along the lines suggested by the engineer of the Department of the Interior, Mr. Gow.

Kenora School

1- The Principal has complained on several occasions of defective heating. The matter was previously taken up with the Department and action was promised but so far nothing has been done. It is possible that for a relatively small amount the heating could be improved to a point where there would be no further reason for complaint on the part of the staff.

2- There is very little land suitable for farming. The Department in the last few years has spent some money in clearing land for that purpose. An additional grant of $1200.00 would be of great assistance in this connection.

3- The present store house is too small and an addition of 16 x 16 would be greatly appreciated. The Principal estimates that this could be done for $600.00.

4- The painting of the outbuildings is not complete and an estimated amount of $150.00 is asked for this purpose. The interior of the
building was painted only in part last year and it is estimated that $300.00 more are required for this purpose.

5- The fence between the School property and the land adjoining it to the north was not properly laid out in the first place and a correction of the fence line is desired. It is estimated that this would cost $300.00.

6- The road from the village to the school is in very bad condition and during bad weather is almost impassable. Drainage and grading to the amount of $800.00 is asked in this connection.

McIntosh School

1- This School has no root cellar and although one has been promised for several years past nothing so far has been done. A sum of $600.00 would be sufficient for this purpose.

2- The School is situated about 2½ miles by water from the railroad station and materials and supplies have to be freighted on a barge. The present one is too old and dangerous to be used any more for this purpose. If the Department will supply the sum of $400.00 for the purchase of materials required the School will provide the necessary labor.

3- This School has a very small acreage for farm purposes and more is urgently required. The sum of $1200.00 would go a long way towards clearing more land.

4- This School has no implement shed. The sum of $300.00 would suffice for this purpose.

Lebret School

The rebuilding of this School is of course a necessity of the first order. The children, as the Department knows, are now housed in the Seminary of the Oblate Fathers and in the Town Hall. School accommodation is provided in the old parish Church of Lebret. It is hardly possible to describe the hardships experienced by the Principal and the staff in the conduct of a school as large as that of Lebret under such trying circumstances.

The Department last December agreed to build a temporary structure on the foundations
of the old administration building, but the Principal preferred to keep whatever money would have been spent in this connection for the new buildings.

It is hoped that the Department will be able to make a very early start in the reconstruction of the Lebret School this coming spring.

Pine Creek School

1- The house that was used by the hired help was destroyed by fire two years ago and has not been rebuilt. If the Department will supply the sum of $2000.00, the School authorities will provide the necessary labor.

2- General repairs, $500.00.

Dear Sir,

Following our conversation of yesterday, I beg leave to summarize as follows the views and suggestions I expressed concerning the Indian Schools in the Northwest.

In all the Provinces of Canada the Government is spending large sums of money for the maintenance of Indian schools. It has built or bought buildings that are in keeping with actual requirements. It not only pays "per capita" grants, but also supplies the occasional funds necessary for repairs, improvements, etc. These schools are under the management of the Churches.

Such are not, however, the conditions of the schools in the far North. There, the Churches have assumed the burden of building these schools. They maintain them at the cost of much exertion and must depend only on the "per capita" grant and a few occasional extra grants, not always easily obtained.

These grants are evidently inadequate. They are not sufficient to meet the exigencies of the standard of education required today. The actual conditions of the schools may have been satisfactory in the past, but the gradual opening of the country is bringing in changes that demand improvements from many points of view.

The paragraph on page two relative to "missionary activity" has highly interested me for I must confess that more than one of my requests in the past have been met with by the late Russell Ferrier by those words: "Missionary activity" which meant that, probably on account of remoteness and other reasons, the Department would not do anything in the way of capital expenditure and would therefore leave the construction of schools to churches, allowing at times a small grant. The case of our Wabasca school is typical. We were granted a sum of $15,000.00 on the condition that the school would cost double the amount. We reached triple the amount and over. We had borrowed the $15,000.00 from the Provincial Bank in Montreal at 7% and through a misunderstanding we had to wait for two years to get the grant, making an expense of $2,100.00 only in interest before receiving the money. Of course we had to borrow the balance of the money used for the total construction and sad to say is still owing. Details can be seen on File 131-3-5, after 1930. Of course, I do not wish in the least to criticize the attitude of Mr Ferrier who has always been so kind and obliging. I only wish to draw your attention to a difficulty from which we have suffered and are still suffering. Unless the Department comes to our rescue some day by way of a grant to cover such expenses I do not see the end of said debt. You will also realize how the 15% cut in annual grants has affected us who had and still have to pay interest on money borrowed for the above mentioned purposes and, if I were allowed to dig up the dead, also for the building of the following schools: St Bernard's at GROUARD (girls', first boys'

Dear Sir;

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th of last month, in answer to mine concerning a request for an increase in per capita grants to the Indian residential schools of my diocese.

I was sorry to learn that this request came too late to be included in the estimates or supplementaries presented to the Parliament before Easter. But surely there will be some other supplementaries presented at the reopening of the session this month, and could not then the question of an extra grant to our schools go in with them? I know that you will do your best for us, and I trust that you will be successful.

I do not think, that we are unreasonable in our demands. You state, in your letter, that the rate allowed to residential schools in the Yukon was set at a time when transportation facilities were inadequate in that district; yet, the school at Carcross, if I am not mistaken, was not built before 1900, and the railway from Skagway to White Horse was then already in operation. We have not the same facilities in the MacKenzie, even today. If the $250.00 grant for the Yukon schools may be considered too high at the present moment, I think that $175.00 for the MacKenzie on the other hand is too low. Besides, we have run some of our schools, like the one in Providence for 40 years, before we received any grant at all. Therefore, I do not believe, anyone could say, that we have been favored at the prejudice of other schools, and perhaps this fact may carry some weight in the consideration of our present needs.

However, I am very glad to note your willingness to discuss the possibility of the Department buying or renting the Indian residential schools under our auspices. Dear Sir;

After mailing you my letter of the 1st instant, I went once more over yours of the 4th of April, and again noted its contents carefully.

On the one hand, of being able to obtain this year, for our schools, a per capita grant equal to that allowed in the Yukon district, you are far from giving me great hope; the less so, that you say the Department is beginning to find the same rather high. Even the fact, that our transportation facilities are in worse conditions today than those of the Yukon 30 years ago, may not be fully appreciated, at a time when economy seems to be the order of the day.

On the other hand, although, you declare yourself willing to discuss the possibility of buying our schools from us, you do not fail to point out, that should we even come to satisfactory terms at once, yet a considerable time must elapse before the actual purchase is completed, as the necessary funds must first be obtained from Parliament.

Thus we are caught in a dilemma, from which there seems to be no issue. If a raise in the grant is to be considered as an impossibility, and the purchase of the schools, although a possibility, is only a remote one, what are we to do? To carry on the work, on the meagre allowance we are receiving is too heavy a burden, almost an unbearable one, as we found out last year, when we had to try and do without any supplementary grant. The Department must be aware of this, it has only to consider the grants allowed to other schools through the Dominion, and it will see, at once, that although we are working under the most adverse conditions, yet we are far from being the most favored.

May I therefore, make another suggestion, the following:

that, pending the discussion of the terms of the purchase of our schools, and while waiting for the transaction to be completed, a temporary arrangement be made, according to which the Department would rent our four schools of Aklavik, Providence, Fort Resolution and Chipewyan, and pay us yearly, let us say, a round sum of $6000.00. This would amount to a small rental of $1500.00 for each school, as an average. I feel that I am not here asking for much. Six thousand dollars hardly represent a 2% interest on the capital invested. I am, of course, making only a rough estimate offhand, not having all the particulars before me, but which, I am confident, will not appear exaggerated, if we take into account every dollar and cent, that has been spent from the beginning. It would only be a small, very small revenue from our investment, and yet one which would tend to make things more bearable.

This shows, once more, that while keeping in view what, I would call not so much our own interests as our pressing needs, we are also aware of the difficulties of the Department, in trying to meet all the requests made from different parts. That you cannot, no matter how much you would like it, give full satisfaction at once even to the most reasonable demands, we understand. Meantime, we are ready to accept and appreciate any help, however small, you feel in your power to give at the present moment.

Trusting that this new proposition may be found worthy of your kind consideration and acceptable to the Department of Indian Affairs, I am,

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

At the request of His Excellency Bishop G. Breynat, O.M.I., I beg leave to write concerning a matter which has already been brought to the attention of your Department: the "per capita" grant to the Indian Boarding Schools of His Excellency's district. The question has been the subject of correspondence and interviews during the past year and I rather hesitate to mention it again today. However, as your Department will soon study the estimates of the coming fiscal year, I hope it is not out of place to state anew the legitimate needs of H.E. Bishop Breynat.

First of all, it seems quite reasonable that the Bishop's schools be placed, from the "per capita" point of view, in conditions parallel to those of the Yukon. I am informed that the average cost of transportation, for instance, is higher in the Northern Mackenzie.

Moreover, the schools of His Excellency, except that of Providence, have been built without any help of the Government. Being the owners of these schools, the missions are deprived of the numerous substantial grants made to the schools of the Government, in which all expenses, even minor, such as the supply of tools, etc., are paid by the Department. The missions must make these purchases themselves, and besides...
pay for all necessary repairs and improvements. As the general revenues are quite restricted, it follows that a part of the "per capita" grant must be diverted for expenses which normally should be paid through supplementary grants. The financial conditions of our schools are thus inferior to those of the schools owned by the Government.

The nature of the soil and the severity of the climate make the revenue of the farms considerably lower than elsewhere. At Fort Resolution, for instance, hay has to be transported 40 miles on the Slave River. In the prairies floods occur frequently and render the hay supply difficult; this year, at Chipewyan, all the cattle had to be killed. A carload of hay was ordered from Edmonton in order to save two cows. At Aklavik, a meagre supply of potatoes and vegetables comes from other missions 700 to 800 miles distant.

Besides, the members of the staffs—lay employees excepted—never receive any salary, while in other schools all are salaried. His Excellency does not ask for salaries, but I think that this point should be considered in the question of a higher "per capita" grant. It is indeed quite unfortunate that more favorable conditions were not established long ago. Mgr. Breynat could be justified in asking for some compensation in return for the sacrifices of the past.

I feel confident that the Department will not hesitate to give a favorable answer to His Excellency's desires as expressed here and in previous correspondence and interviews.

Yours very truly,

During the past few weeks I have visited the Indian Schools in British Columbia and I beg to put before you some observations as the result of my work.

MISSION CITY SCHOOL. As you are doubtless aware, the Oblate Fathers have during the past year spent a considerable sum of money improving the buildings, providing accommodation for increased pupilage. At the present moment there is accommodation for 220 children whilst the Indian Dept. only recognises pupilage for 152 children. One could understand this state of affairs were there no children in the various Indian Reserves around seeking admission to the school. The fact is that not only are there large numbers of children eligible for school but the condition of these children is such as to cause even the Indian Agent himself to remark on their deplorable condition. These children are oftentimes the victims of sad circumstances and it is not at all uncommon, (my authority is Rev. Fr. Patterson who works on the Indian Reserves), for these children to be seen drinking with adults. Anyone interested in the Indian question and seeing the deplorable effects upon the lives of these children, will readily see what inestimable benefits would accrue to them if the Indian Dept. would, by sanctioning their entry into the Residential School, afford them the protection and care they need so urgently.

Dear Dr. McGill,

You will not be surprised to learn that it is with astonishment and deep regret that I heard of the 10% deduction which the Department has decided to reestablish in the allowances per capita made to Indian schools.

Please allow me to add my protests to those already made against this measure. You are aware of the hardships and the extraordinary efforts our Principals have to put up in order to balance their budgets, even in the most favourable circumstances and when allowances are paid in full. This measure appears to all concerned as a crying injustice towards the teaching staff and the work of civilisation and christianisation among the Indians, which they accomplish with so much devotion.

On account of this deduction it is impossible for some schools to continue their work with success and I mean the school of Lac d'Oignen, in particular, of which the Rev. Father Pratt is the Principal. You are fully aware of the high transportation charges in that region; so I am taking the liberty of asking you not to apply the deduction to that school, supposing you must do it for the others, or at least to find some means of counterbalancing the loss it will have to bear. The recruiting cost is always heavy in the north of our Provinces, and this, added to excessive transportation costs, will render almost superhuman the task of feeding, clothing and treating the children in the manner required by the Department.

Dear Dr. McGill,

You will not be surprised to learn that it is with astonishment and deep regret that I heard of the 10% deduction which the Department has decided to reestablish in the allowances per capita made to Indian schools.

Please allow me to add my protests to those already made against this measure. You are aware of the hardships and the extraordinary efforts our Principals have to put up in order to balance their budgets, even in the most favourable circumstances and when allowances are paid in full. This measure appears to all concerned as a crying injustice towards the teaching staff and the work of civilization and christianization among the Indians, which they accomplish with so much devotedness.

On account of this deduction it is impossible for some schools to continue their work with success and I mean the school of Lac d'Oignon, in particular, of which the Rev. Father Pratt is the Principal. You are fully aware of the high transportation charges in that region; so I am taking the liberty of asking you not to apply the deduction to that school, supposing you must do it for the others, or at least to find some means of counterbalancing the loss it will have to bear. The recruiting cost is always heavy in the north of our Provinces, and this, added to excessive transportation costs, will render almost superhuman the task of feeding, clothing and treating the children in the manner required by the Department.

Dear Mr. McGill I insist once more and I beg of you to grant the request I am making in favour of Lac d'Oignon school.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) U. Langlois, O.M.I.

MEMO

On the physical and economic conditions of the North West Territory Indians.

Having lived among the Natives of the North as a Missionary for well over 40 years, I feel that I am reasonably well qualified to give an opinion as to their physical state and their means of support of life.

Convinced as I am that their conditions are so serious, I would be remiss in my duty towards them and the Government of Canada if I did not make an effort to bring it to your attention.

EDUCATION

1. The schools in the North West Territories, notwithstanding special and great difficulties, have achieved quite satisfactory results. The children who have spent some time in schools are stronger, they, especially the girls, have brought home principles and habits of cleanliness, hygiene and housekeeping to such an extent as to cause a real surprise to the whites and to be a credit to the Government and to the Churches.

Boys, when they have not been kept too long in school, generally are better trappers and better hunters and are pretty hard to cheat in business and quite a few of them occasionally prove to be intelligent interpreters.

2. Yet, owing to the nomadic character of the life our Indians have to live and the difficulties of communication, it is not an easy job to induce the parents to send their children to school, although they gradually realize the advantages of a good school training.

Better results would be obtained if all the Agents would give a little more of their time and of their heart to recruiting, or at least to help the recruiters.

3. Until lately, the Department of Indian Affairs has been rather slow in helping for better equipment of the schools. It is to be hoped that in the future the Northern schools will receive a more fair share in the funds of the Department disposed for that end.

It should not be any more objected that the schools are owned by the Churches and that the Department cannot spend money on improvement of schools which are not its property. On the very contrary, the Department should be the more generous, as the Churches have done, for many years, at their own cost, what should have been done by the Government, as promised at Treaty time.

4. Day schools would be of no satisfactory avail in the North West Territories. Indians do not stay long enough at the trading posts. When they do ask for such a school it is generally on the suggestion of some white men who have some children of school age. (Another Department should attend to the needs of the increasing white population.)

Whenever some Indian family is resident at the Fort, the children could attend the school, the Indian Department paying for the attendance, as it is done in other places under the same conditions.
There are enough residential boarding schools in the districts, which this Memo is covering, to reasonably meet all the actual needs. The upkeep of small boarding schools is too great on account of the general expenses, and experience shows that should the Indians have a boarding school near to every trading post, they would still feel slow in sending in their children, especially when they have plenty of Cariboo around their camps. There always will be the difficulty of transporting the children on account of the great distances where the parents live and the difficulty for the latter to visit them as often as they could wish - one or two hundred miles, more or less, would not make a great difference. No school is actually filled to capacity.

Unless the Government is ready to enforce compulsory education, a system which I would not recommend, before opening new schools it would seem wise to wait until such time when our Indians show a better appreciation of education.

A good system of encouraging parents to send their children to schools would be to give some post scholar assistance to those who have been giving satisfaction and have stayed five years in the school. The boys would be given a rifle or a gun, with some traps, the girls, a hand sewing machine etc. As a rule the children should not be kept in school, the boys when they are over 13 or 14 years of age, the girls when they are over 16, unless when they are orphans and they ask to be kept until they are married.

When the children are sent home for holidays, the Agents should adopt the practice, which is generally followed in the southern districts, to see that the children are sent back in time to their school, unless their parents are in a real need of their assistance.

Too often poor orphans are kept in the camps as servants to greedy Indians, they are half clothed, even in winter time. They are also the last to be fed and they never are given any chance to enjoy any sympathy around them. They do not even draw one cent out of the Treaty annuity they are entitled to and which is fully claimed by their guardian.

In order to remedy such a pitiful condition, education should be made compulsory for all the orphans of school age and the Treaty annuity should be directly given to them as pocket money for little fancies.

When they leave school, the Agent or the Church should see that they are placed with some reliable and good people who would train them to make their living by fishing, trapping and hunting.

A few years ago, on my recommendation, the Department of Indian Affairs sent a circular to that effect to his agents in the North. The circular has been a dead letter so far.

G. Breynat, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Adramyte,
Vic. Apost. of Mackenzie.

Memorandum:

Mr. MacINNES,

A few weeks ago, I discussed with Bishop Breynat certain proposals submitted by him in a memorandum to the Department on December 8, 1936.

Bishop Breynat informed me at that time that he had given a great deal of thought to the preparation of a course of study designed to meet the peculiar needs of the school population of his district. I learned that the Bishop and Bishop Guy would submit a revised curriculum to me for consideration, in due course. I expressed the opinion that his proposals for additional vocational or semi-vocational instruction were very much in accord with my own views and that their adoption would be recommended by me, if I considered them at all practicable.

In paragraph 6 of his memorandum, Bishop Breynat suggests that promising pupils be given some post scholar assistance. I can see no objection whatever to this suggestion. Should we decide to do so, we shall be simply extending the help now given to Indian pupils entering high school to pupils in the North West Territories who are seeking to establish themselves on a self-supporting basis during the years immediately following their departure from school.

It is our intention to send out circular letters to our Agents in Bishop Breynat's district, asking them to take immediate steps toward the enforcement of Subsection 4 of Section 10 of the Indian Act. I heartily agree.
agree with the Bishop when he insists that an earnest effort should be made to save Indian orphans from exploitation. We have at the moment under consideration a "follow up system", which it is our intention to work out and adopt, in cooperation with the churches. If we are successful in the creation of an effective system of this kind, there is no reason whatever why it should not be extended to the North West Territories. I am personally convinced that the extension of this policy will correct a great many of the abuses to which Bishop Breynat refers.

My dear Mr Hoey:

Very reverend Father Edouard Lamontagne, O.M.I., Provincial of the Manitoba Oblate Religious Province, has requested me to write you regarding the pupilage in the ten Indian residential schools under his jurisdiction. Your Department maintains with the cooperation of Oblate Fathers under Father Lamontagne's jurisdiction the following schools:

| School          | Pupilage |
