| SANDY BAY       | 75       |
| LEBRET          | 225      |
| ST - PHILIPPE   | 70       |
| MARIEVAL        | 85       |
| LE STOCK        | 105      |

From the experience gathered in the operation of residential schools over a period of more than fifty years, we have come to the conclusion that residential schools with a pupilage less than 125 are economically unsound. It is probable that a pupilage of 150 would come closer to the ideal school.

The following schools: Fort Frances, Kenora, Fort Alexander, Fine Creek, Sandy Bay, Marieval, have been in operation under our management for more than 30 years. The experience that we have gathered in their operation should be fairly conclusive. During that period, we have had principals possessing fair ability. Some of them were considerably above the average and none, we believe, were so inferior in ability as to be unable to discharge their duties creditibly. Nevertheless, the operation of this group of schools shows a marked difference in increased cost as well as in lesser efficiency compared with schools having a larger pupilage.
This statement can be verified, we believe, by your inspectors and agents as well as by the officials of the Department in Ottawa.

Bearing this in mind, Father Lamontagne desires me to officially request the Department of Indian Affairs to increase the pupilage of the schools under his jurisdiction to the point where they will be placed on a sound administrative footing, so that those in charge of them may be able to render to the wards of the Government the services that these schools are expected to produce and that this will be done with the greatest efficiency possible and at a cost commensurate with such services.

My experience with residential schools leads me to believe that Father Lamontagne is quite justified in making this request and I hope that you will give it serious consideration.

Yours very truly,

Liard Post, B.C. As the Department fully knows this location is to say the least of the matter—a trouble spot. Even this year whilst Bishop Coudret was down that way, another bad break out of drunkenness took place. This attracts all the Indians who can come from other Posts, and this summer they all congregated here. Therefore His Lordship saw many Indians and many children, mostly of the McAmes district. Really there are very few Indian children located at this spot, who can be stated as Liard Indians.

At the time the McAmes School was started, Father Allard was in charge, that was about 8 years ago. After the building was three parts finished Father Allard turned his attention to Liard Post, at the end of each summer. Then the white men who were married to Indian women requested to have a school started and offered to build and help same along. Watson, LeGormier and Hazelburgh being the prime movers. Father Allard on this obtained a plot of ground outside the Reserve, and matters were started up. But no help was given and matters took on the coating that the Indian Department should do all this, and that it was their business to do so. After the R.C.M.I. Detachment had been moved away, much drunkenness came about, and it has been going on ever since. This in itself has induced many more Indian families to spend their summers at Liard Post.

However it was decided by the R.C. Missions to build a church at Liard Post on their own compound, and this they have accomplished. His Lordship stated that here would be a very fine place to establish a winters school. This Office would rather not say as to if this would be a success or not. It can be seen that there would be trouble ahead, for Liard Post is only 6 miles south of the Yukon Boundary Line and nearly all the real Liard Post Indians are really Yukon rappers. It can be seen that most of the Indian families would at once request Relief, they would not trap for a living but would trap for luxuries only. The cost would be great at this remote location and it would certainly draw Indian families from other points, in fact McAmes Creek Indians would no doubt go to Liard Post.

Another point to be considered is that of Law & Order, it is hopeless to try and do anything down there until some Detachment of Police is allowed.

Again, the Edmonton Air Pine Mail Service has just established a base on Watson's Lake, a very suitable point 30 miles within the Yukon, and it is now understood that Mr Watson is running a Store. If this is so, and it will be checked later on in the season, Liard Post as it is today, will go back to just a small trading spot, a meeting place of the Dease River and the Liard River proper.

The matter seems to be a real problem at the present time but will be looked into and reported upon when the summer's visit to here has been completed.

From the Office point of view all these schools must be taken in conjunction with the Indians Trapping Affairs—otherwise it results into a mere question of Rations and Relief. One thing is certain—if the Nomads give up or do not use their trapping grounds they will be entirely lost to the Indians in the near future.

All of which Sir, is a summary of the R.C. Mission work up to the present time, which it was thought correct to submit in view of the visit to these parts just completed by His Lordship Bishop Coudret.

Caribou Hide School PROPOSED. Much has been written regarding the needs of a school for this Band of Indians. The whole trouble in the way of this being accomplished, is the fact that these Indians live about 250 miles away from any place at all. The expense is very great in getting even flour out to these nomads.

Bishop Coudret has not visited this Band, but did just happen to meet one or two of their members—and of course they wish a School—at the Department's expense. This means a full load of a Plane, if not two runs. The "sachem" would expect to be taken in, with his supplies. The matter could be considered, but is quite out of the question to fix up in any proper way, this Summer. Books have been sent out, and no doubt some good work could be done if a Teacher would go out and start up. Mr Anglin now of Mo Dames has offered to go, and perhaps with some extra pay allowance, would undertake the work this winter. But a school house should be built here, and that takes time. However in this respect, during the last year an Air Mail Route is in operation up to Fort Ware (Old Whitewater) on the Finlay River, on the top end of which the Caribou Hide Band lives. It would mean ½ of an hours run—extra—or from Fort Ware to reach the Indians location. These Planes are run by Mr Chonicky (?) of Edmonton Alta. Prices could be obtained if the matter is considered.

Dease Lake Summer Day School. This school was rather a venture for a small set of Indians living at Dease Lake. It was thought proper to start a school especially as Inspector Emmell was requested to do so by these Indians, and they gave their promise to attend. Therefore Father Bosse went out there and started a school in an old cabin, much too crowded, but preferred to do that than use a special tent that was supplied. In the meantime the Church House was being erected, and last Fall completed. This Spring it is in use, being a very fine building. However it seems that some sort of difference in views has come about between the Indian Families, cause not known, but which can no doubt be settled. Here His Lordship seems to think another winter school could be established which would do much better than the present summer school. This Office is inclined to agree to this, taking into consideration the trapping affairs of these families, which are situated all around that Dease Lake District. This matter will be taken up with the Indians later this season when that area is inspected. However the school has done some good work up to now.

Mc Dames Summer Day School. This was the Agency's first venture and was started by the late Father Allard—it was a success from the start, and went along fine until we lost Father Allard by drowning. Father Bosse then took charge and the change was noticed. Father Bosse gave this attention and also Liard Post visitations at the same time and it was really too much. Lately we have had separate Teachers and the school has shown good results until this year. This season owing to several reasons the Indians have all side slip'd to Liard Post—there is more excitement at that point. Also owing to sickness in two families, and the fact also that they were questioned last summer in regard to the Mc Donald Murder Charge, undertaken by Cpl Blatta of the R.C.M.P., these two families with a lot of school youngsters, have not reported in to Mc James Creek this summer. It has all meant that the attendance is low. However it is most certainly expected that all the Mc Dames Indians will return again to that point—next summer. His Lordship thought that a winter school here also would be perhaps good. The Office point of view is that it is not quite possible. Should this take place these real nomads would just come in to the Post and sit down, and beg Rations—it would eventually be very expensive, and wind up in trouble with the Indians going away again to the "woods". Mc James is the centre of the cart-wheel arrangement of trapping grounds around that district, but is too large for Indians to be running in and out during the trapping season. This school should be retained as it is.
Sir,

I beg to submit a summary report hereunder on the general affairs of the R.C. Mission now operating in this southern end of the Stikine Agency. The reason for this being that His Lordship Bishop Bunoz, O.M.I., of Prince Rupert has recently given over this area for inspection to His Lordship Bishop Coudret, O.M.I., late of the Mackenzie River District, who might perhaps think matters in the Cassiar are indeed too rough.

Bishop Coudret arrived here on the 10th of June and along with Father Carpentier, newly arrived proceeded to inspect the Cassiar. He was met returning to Telegraph Creek on July 3rd, on the Dease Lake Trail, and then he stated that Mission Affairs were not as he thought they would be. The afternoon of July 6th, was spent within the Indian Office with His Lordship, and Father Carpentier, when all matters were talked over and gone into.

Therefore it is considered that a summary of this interview should be submitted, as so many points of interest are involved, which if not looked at with care might lead to useless expense and trouble.

To-day the following are engaged upon R.C. Mission work. Father Leo Bossé, O.M.I., who it is stated is "in charge" of general affairs. Father Pouletto with Father Drea are at Liard Post, whilst Father Carpentier is visiting around, and it is thought intends to settle at McPames Creek. In addition to the above Mr Moran is a Teacher, who was at the Klappan Winter School last winter but who now is teacher for the Dease Lake School (Summer). Mr Anglin is the Teacher for the McPames Summer School in operation now. It will be seen that there are now 6 persons engaged upon the R.C. Mission work, which considering the number of Indians within this area is really more than sufficient - it is thought.

The various points will now be taken in their trail order.

The Klappan Winter Day School. Klappan District south of Telegraph Creek. This was a new venture started some three summers ago, and as reported is no doubt a success. Bishop Coudret thinks highly of this idea, and goes so far as to say that all schools should be "winter Schools". However he intends to let Mr Moran return to this point for next winter, and all the Indians wish this, from the Office point of view it is a fine idea. Supplies have been submitted by Requisition, it is hoped that same can be allowed. They might seem to be much, but it must be remembered that the old Cabin was not too big, and now the school is working, it could be set on its feet once and for all. The School Masters job is not a nice one, and some comfort should be allowed him.
Sir:

I beg to submit hereunder a report covering the month of June 1938.

On the 10th instant there arrived His Lordship Bishop Goudret, O.M.I., with Father Carpentier, O.M.I., both going "inside" to look over their affairs regarding the R.C. Mission work. They were good enough to pay this office a visit, when the files were produced and all questions asked answered. His Lordship was told that matters within the Cassiar were much "rougher" than what he had been accustomed to in the Mackenzie River district, and that we were not nearly so civilized. This he did not quite believe then, but upon his return in July, fully assented to. A special report covering the various points visited by him, is being submitted; but he no doubt found matters rather upset all along the line. One bright event he was pleased with, and that was the successful operation of the Klappan Winter Day school. This has proved its worth. More fur was obtained by allowing the large families to come to rest at the school - all under supervision and correct order. The families this spring were found to be more orderly - cleaner, and above all - looking forward to next winter's schooling.

It was explained to His Lordship that the winter schooling and family arrangements were mixed up with the Indians trapping affairs, that one helped the other; and also that it was almost impossible to move families around the district if their trapgrounds were not in that same locality.

At Liard Post, which has always been a trouble spot; His Lordship found matters not at all to his liking. The run of events at this interior Post have greatly changed during the past three years, in fact even since the late Father Allard, O.M.I., decided to buy a plot of ground and establish a Church. About every four years the Indians of McDames Creek will trail back from their trapping grounds, and, for a change, go to Liard Post, in spite of the fact that the prices at Liard are much higher than they are at McDames Post. This summer this has happened once more. The reason for this is partly due to the fact that a plans calls at Liard from Edmonton. Also Mr. Strong of the Taku Trading Coy. has now made a very strong bid for his store at that point as against the H.B. Coy. and a small free-trader called Cormier. The Indians have a good time with such a state of affairs, as can be expected. But of course this will not last, and the McDames Indians with their families will return again next summer to McDames, leaving much "credit" at Liard Post.

Also on the top of all this excitement the Upper Liard is now being settled by white trappers, and plenty of provisions can now be obtained by "air" and so the halfbreed families who live up that way, do not now report at Liard Post. However, as stated a report of these affairs will be submitted under separate cover.

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I had occasion to meet His Excellency, Bishop Langlois of Grouard, last Saturday when he passed through Winnipeg on his way to Alberta. He told me that he was very sorry he could not see you when he passed through Ottawa prior to his leaving for the West as there were two problems that he wished particularly to place before you for your early consideration.

The first concerns the water supply in the five schools of his Vicariate. Your Department promised to thoroughly investigate this whole question and I understand that you have already sent one of your engineers to report on same. Unfortunately nothing seems to have been done since the engineer's visit. The season is fast advancing and if anything substantial is to be accomplished this year, immediate steps should be taken. His Excellency says that, since the money for these projects has been voted, the Department should proceed immediately with the work.

The other problem in which as you know His Excellency is taking particular interest is the establishment of a general Training School for Indian children when they leave the boarding schools. With the age regulation which has been enforced for several years past, the period between the time that the children leave the boarding schools and the time that they become established is, in most cases, very long and no particular kind of employment seems to be available for these boys and girls during that period.

His Excellency has in mind the establishment of a training or technical school which would receive and train the girls from the time they leave the boarding school until they could be safely sent back to their homes or duly
and honorably married. The boys are not exposed to quite the same dangers as the girls, but they also need to have training. It is impossible to do so in the ordinary Indian Residential Schools because the staff is either insufficient or not qualified for this purpose.

Eventually the school which His Excellency has in mind would provide training for boys in agriculture, carpentry and general mechanics but for the time being girls only would be accepted. Two nuns of the Order of Providence are now available for this school. Both are technical school graduates. If the Bishop cannot give them employment now they may be transferred to another part of the country and thus their services would be lost for Indian work.

For the purpose of establishing this school, His Excellency will place at the disposal of the Department, free of charge, for at least a few years to come, a substantial building situated at St. Augustine's, about ten miles from Peace River. This building is suitable and sufficiently large; it being used at the present time as a boarding school for white children of the district. If the sum of $3,000.00 could be set aside by your Department, the Bishop would undertake to assume all other expenses in connection with the opening, furnishing and operation of the school and agree to give training for one year at least to twenty Indian girls.

Another reason why the Bishop is very anxious to open this school for Indian girls immediately is that the Government of Alberta is pressing him to accept the wayward children of the district. Should the school once accept these children it would become almost impossible for the Bishop to dismiss them and his project as far as the Indians are concerned would be postponed almost indefinitely.

Your early consideration of the Bishop's request is, therefore, most earnestly desired.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Two Fort George Indians Attend Consecration Here

Two of the most interested spectators at the consecration of Mgr. Henri Belleau, O.M.I., apostolic vicar of James Bay, at Sacred Heart Church in Ottawa, were two Indians from Fort George on the shores of James Bay, who came to Ottawa to witness the colorful ceremony.

The two representatives of the Cree Indians were Peter Waaskahigan, 31 years of age, and Wally Rupert, 25. They were accompanied by Rev. Father D. Couture, O.M.I., Fort George missionary. Both are catechumens who are being instructed by Father Couture in the principles of the Catholic faith. When informed that Father Belleau was to be made a bishop, they expressed the wish to be present at the ceremony and paid part of their fare to Ottawa.

The missionary put up the balance.

It was their first visit to the civilized world. After counting by degrees the distance of 300 miles separating Fort George and the railway terminal of Moosonee, they saw a train for the first time. Neither of them speak English nor French and although very bashful over their new experience seemed to enjoy every bit of their maiden voyage to civilization.

Father Couture told The Citizen that they were highly impressed by the consecration ceremony which was presided over by His Eminence Cardinal Villeneuve. During their stay in Ottawa, the two Indians are the guests of the Oblate Fathers at St. Joseph's Scholasticate.

My dear Mr. Crerar:

The lot of Church owned Indian Residential Schools is becoming more and more difficult every day, and it occurred to those interested that some special regulations should be adopted by the Department of Indian Affairs for the administration of these same schools.

When the various Church organizations working in conjunction with the Department of Indian Affairs decided, years ago, to build Indian Residential Schools at their own expense, they conferred a favour on the Indian Department and Canada at large. It now seems that they are unwittingly penalized for this special contribution to the welfare of the Indians of Canada.

Whilst Government owned Indian Schools receive yearly a fair proportion of moneys for repairs, alterations and general upkeep without any undue obstacles being placed in the spending of such funds, Church owned Schools, the original cost of which was borne solely by the Churches concerned, find that on every occasion where funds are necessary for their upkeep, so many regulations have to be observed that the spending of the money voted becomes a more involved problem than the obtaining or the voting of it.

These Church owned buildings were originally erected solely for the accommodation of Indian children, and there has never been any departure from this principle, nor is it the intention of the Churches to use them in the future in a different manner than in the past.

Taking the above facts into consideration I feel that when requests are forwarded for repairs and improvements to these Church-owned schools the Department should not hesitate to assist simply because the buildings were originally erected from Church funds. When all is said and done these Church-owned schools are an integral part of the Indian educational system and as a consequence are entitled to receive the same fair consideration that the Department accords to the buildings which they themselves have erected.

Yours very truly,

Rev. J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Father Plourde,

I wish to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th ultimo, in which you refer generally to the monies provided by the Government for repairs to church-owned Indian Residential Schools. So far as I am aware, the Indian Affairs Branch adopts the same practice for all the Residential Schools whether they are church-owned or not. It is true, of course, that in the Government-owned schools the expenditures are made in accordance with the usual Government regulations covering the spending of money. As to church-owned schools, it is necessary to see that the money is spent for the purposes for which it was voted. In this respect there is no difference between either class of schools, except that in one case the church authorities spend the money under Government supervision.

You are aware of the difficulties we have had in the past in connection with repairs made to some of the church-owned schools where the expenditures have greatly exceeded the amount estimated. This, of course, should not be permitted and is probably the reason why the officials in the Branch may be more strict now than they have been in the past. As I said before, we do not make any distinction between the cost of repairs to either class of schools; in fact, I understand this year the amount set aside in the Estimates for repairs to church-owned schools is almost twice what it is to those owned by the Government.

Dear Sir:

Among the numerous letters which I have received from the Principals of the Catholic group of Indian Residential Schools, I find that all those that come from the small schools with an average attendance ranging around 75 and below, strike the same note of complaint; i.e., the cut in the per capita grant, or rather in the attendance, is particularly difficult to cope with in small schools.

The overhead is almost the same as in a school where the grant is allowed for 100 or more and the receipts are from 25% to 40% less. The only saving effected is in the matter of clothing and food. Clothing of course is always cash disbursements, but food is sometimes provided in part by the school farm so that as a matter of actual expense almost the only difference between the small school and the medium or larger one is the question of clothing.

Dear Friend of the Missions,

With the war draining so great a share of our country's resources for its work of destruction and death, will a few pennies remain in the pocketbooks of our friends, and will a bit of generosity be found in the depths of their hearts for the work of the Missions?

All Christians know it; this work must continue, and continue unceasingly. Our Saviour tells us so in Chapter X of St. John: "Other sheep I have: they MUST be brought to the fold."

These words are imperative and apply to each one of us who has received the gift of faith. Let me repeat them on behalf of the poor Apostolic Vicariate of Grouard, for nothing but this command would be potent enough as to make me extend today a begging hand.

DURING THIS LENTEN SEASON OF 1941, WILL YOU GIVE US A SMALL SHARE OF YOUR ALMS?

The fact is that our 18,000 Catholics, Indians and newly established settlers, are unable, in most cases, to provide for the upkeep of their Missionaries. This heavy task falls upon the Vicar Apostolic, who, besides providing for these Missionaries in sickness and in health, constructing numerous urgently-needed chapels etc., is often called upon to pay the travelling expenses of his priests from one Mission to the other, so that the ministry of souls be not neglected, and to obtain for them Mass stipends to maintain these priests at their posts of duty. Our Missionaries, I am happy to acknowledge, are not exacting; nevertheless, they must have the indispensables.

Were it not for the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, and the aid of friends living afar, the Vicar Apostolic would be practically without funds at his disposal. Judge for yourself: the collections taken up in 1940 in the Mission Church which serves as Cathedral (until more favourable circumstances permit us to build a church and a modest residence for the bishop in a more central and accessible location) have amounted to an average of seventy cents a Sunday. Our good people do their best, but they cannot give that which they have not.

Therefore, in the name of our Vicariate, in the name of my Missionaries who toil hard and of our institutions that should multiply, we confidently turn towards the friends of the Missions and ask them: "Will you give us a small part of your Lenten almsgiving?"

"To Saint Joseph, special Procurator of our Missions, to whom this month is consecrated, we confide this request. We beseech him to inspire you with all the generosity your means allow, and to grant you in return all the choice Blessings and favours you desire to obtain.

Please accept the anticipated expression of our deep gratitude and of our best sentiments in Christ.

Dear Bishop Jennings:

I regret that it is not our practice to supply copies of our audited statements of financial transactions at residential schools. As you may suppose, this is due to advancing prices on all lines of goods and the further fact that a year ago it was found necessary to reduce the pupilage for which grant is allowed. This latter action had to be taken by the Department due to war conditions. We realize that it has worked a hardship on our schools as it is not easy for the school management to reduce overhead expenses.

For the per capita allowance paid to each school the management is required to feed, clothe and educate the Indian children in their care as well as provide heat, light and other expenses incident to the operation of large buildings. Our reason for auditing the accounts is to assure ourselves that the per capita allowance paid to each residential school is expended only at that school for the welfare of the children who are in attendance. Reports that we have received indicate that the Indian residential schools in the Archdiocese of Vancouver are complying with the Department's wishes and no funds are being diverted to any other project.

Rev. Father O. Plourde, O.M.I.
General Superintendent,
Oblate Commission for Indian Affairs,
Ottawa University.

Dear Father Plourde:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your communication dated Oct. 27 and which I found yesterday upon my arrival here.

1.-Re Salary Cheques to be paid to our Missionaries teaching in our various seasonal schools, I think that the new arrangement will be more satisfactory, as it will allow me to follow more closely amounts paid to our individual missionaries. I will see that said cheques be forwarded to them without delay.

2.-Re rent of our buildings for school purposes, I will send the account in duplicate at the end of each year for each school. The amount mentioned is satisfactory to me, and all in all will cover the expenses of fuel and janitor, if paid by the Branch both for our summer as well as for our winter school.

3.-I take note of what you say regarding cheque to Father Poulet for the transportation of the children to Grouard School, and the promise to repay father A. Dream for the transportation of five children from Teslin Lake to Lower Post in connection with same.

4.-Regarding Evelyn Reid, born on June 15, 1929, and who should have been discharged from Lejac School last Summer, I understand the difficulties which Mr. Phelan may be up against at such time of the year. My advise for him is to let things go until next summer, but to remind both the Indian Agent Samson and the Principal Father Simpson not to keep the children of Norther B.C. and the Yukon over the time allowed by the School Regulations without referring the matter to the head of the Branch and to me; he may add that he knows positively that Evelyn Reid was anxious to go back north last summer and that her sister Mrs Henri Taku of Atlin Lake, B.C., was anxious to have her and to provide her with a good home, and, therefore, he does not understand why such a child was kept in Lejac School for another year. If the child was to be discharged now, the Branch would get in touch with Agent Samson and find out through him whether at such a time the Indians of Atlin Lake (especially Mrs. Henri Taku) are in town or on their trap line and can easily be reached.

5.-In my next Circular Letter to our teaching Missionaries I am going to insist on the necessity of sending in their school reports at the end of each month, if they want to be paid at once.

N.B.-Iskut Lake School is the same as Klappan (wrongly called so by the former Indian Agent Harper Reid). The school is located on Iskut Lake, but the Indian Band is called the Klappan Band.

6.-Re Indian Residential School at Teslin, I found your report to Mr. Hoey quite satisfactory, and hope it will soon bring a definite line of conduct on the part of the Officials of the Branch.

Thanking you for your kind services, I remain, dear Father Plourde,

Yours very sincerely in O.L. and M.I.

(signed) J.L. Coudert, O.M.I.
J.L. Coudert O.M.I. Vicar Apost.of Whitehorse.

It may be said that the crying need of Residential Schools is qualified personnel. This brings up many angles and points of view. I am merely pointing it out here, for, in my mind, it will break through sooner or later. The quicker it is tackled the better for all concerned. I do not wish to say that there are no qualified employees at the Residential Schools. On the contrary, many admirable men and women, of all denominations, fully qualified to take their place in any community, are working for the welfare of the Indian. But the schools must be able to attract more of these and in order to do so, must offer more attractive positions.

A second need for the Residential School is to eliminate as much drudgery, as is possible, leaving more time for valuable training.

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

I am sending forward herewith a letter dated October 24, 1947, with certain statements relating to a number of residential schools the property of the Church of England in Canada. This letter and these statements were left at my office by Doctor Alderwood a few days ago.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I am enclosing a letter from Reverend Father Meilleur, O.M.I., missionary in charge of the Manawan, Obedjiwan and Weymontaching Indian Reserves, which speaks for itself.

It is to be hoped that official action will be taken by your Department, so that the Indians will not be forced to miss their yearly religious exercises because the Departmental Doctor and Dentist will be on hand to pay their annual call.

It must be remembered that it is not Reverend Father Meilleur who has chosen the same time of year as the doctors, but it is the other way about. Your agent, knowing all Indians would be home for the religious retreat, has chosen this time to visit them in company of doctors and dentists.

We appreciate very much the medical cares given to our Indians, but the missionary does think that it is not necessary for the Medical Corps to choose the same time which he has chosen for the retreat.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
August 15/79

To the Sup't. manager of the Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

As a question of religion is concerned, I think that it is my duty to call your attention—and to ask you "justice."

I complain of your employment of Mr. Lariviere—

From the 14th to the 21st of August, here in Obligeeswan, it is the Great Week of Spiritual Recollection. I ask only one week a year.

Your employer, Mr. Lariviere, as he knows it, as he knows that the Indians being good Christians Catholics obey to their missionary in coming to that one week's Recollection comes to "break" my work, to disturb the Spirit of that recollection.

The Spirit of that recollection is whole against with an absolute character, he himself has the right to...
Besides himself, he has a dentist and a photographer...

Impossible to do my spiritual work.

Would it be necessary that I should bring this complaint to the Council of bishops, the archbishop and bishops of Canada?

I am quite certain that he will do again the same thing at Westmount, because he knew that then I will be there from the 4th to the 11th of September.

Please, give us justice & fair play.

Your all truly,

Ed. Muthens, O.M.I.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Maintenance of Church-owned Indian Residential School Buildings

As requested by you following the school construction conference, I submit the following comments with regard to several proposals for the allotment of funds for maintaining residential school buildings not owned by the departments:

1. The present system is to include in the estimates an amount for each Church-owned residential school in accordance with the request of the Church authorities concerned and the recommendation of the Superintendent of the Indian Agency in which the school is located. Normally, this amount does not exceed $5,000.00 in any one year. Difficulties arise with this arrangement because occasionally requests are delayed until it is too late for the work to be done or the equipment purchased before the end of the fiscal year. However, this method has the following advantages:

(a) It ensures that funds are expended for the purpose for which they were intended.

(b) Technical advice is made available to ensure that the work undertaken or the equipment purchased is suitable.

(c) Equipment and materials are secured through the Departmental Purchasing Agent.

2. The payment of a rental which would enable the Church authorities to maintain the building, would afford no assurance to the department that the money so provided would be used for maintenance. It is also unlikely that...
the Church authorities would receive the technical advice which is now made available to them through the department.

3. Purchase of Church-owned buildings by the department would result in the department taking over the maintenance of these schools. With the acquisition of the buildings, the department would have to insist that only Indian children are admitted. It is probable that there would be some objections from the Churches concerned to this arrangement. The list below gives the names of the schools in Bishop Trocellier's diocese and shows the authorized pupilage, the enrolment at the end of March, 1952, and the number of non-Indians in attendance at two of them. 2. "That proper steps be taken to prevent Agents, on certain Indian Reserves, from placing any restrictions on the teaching of religion in Indian Day Schools".

Religious instruction to the extent of one-half hour a day in all Indian day schools has been the policy of the Department for many years past. All field officials have been so informed on many occasions. At the present time the Department is preparing regulations for Indian day schools. These will be issued shortly and will contain the following instruction regarding the teaching of religion:

(a) A period of not more than one-half hour a day to be devoted to religious instruction may be included in the time table for classroom instruction.

(b) Religious instruction may be given by any person assigned for such purpose by the religious denomination in the faith of which pupils are to be instructed.
(e) A pupil shall not be required to receive instruction in the faith of any religious denomination contrary to the desire of such pupil's parent or legal guardian as expressed to the principal or teacher-in-charge of the school and recorded in the school register.

(d) When it is necessary to conduct religious instruction in the faiths of more than one religious denomination and the accommodation is inadequate for simultaneous instruction in the different faiths, the Superintendent, Indian Agency, shall apportion the use of the school premises and school time for the religious denominations concerned.

3. "That when teachers are to be appointed for Catholic Indian Schools, the name of the teacher in each case be first submitted for approval to the interested Bishop".

The supply of qualified teachers at the present time is limited. It has been our practice to advertise in both daily and weekly papers and when an applicant is interested in securing employment in an Indian school it is necessary to take immediate action, otherwise such applicant will obtain employment elsewhere.

To submit to the interested Bishops the name of the teacher being considered for a Catholic Indian day school would involve considerable time and this would result in our losing teachers as they would have obtained other employment in the meantime. Our Indian Superintendents and Regional Inspectors of Indian Schools are aware of the Indian day schools at which a Catholic teacher should be engaged and we have received no complaints to the effect that Catholic teachers have not been engaged at the schools where their services are required. However, if any of the members of the Canadian Catholic Hierarchy are aware of qualified Catholic teachers whose services are available, we would appreciate it if the names and addresses of such persons would be submitted either to the Indian Affairs Branch at Ottawa or the local Regional Inspector of Indian Schools. Such recommendations will receive very careful consideration.
4. "That the salaries of all qualified teachers in the Indian Residential Schools be paid by the Federal Government."

Ever since 1892, when the principle of payment of per capita grants to residential schools was adopted, it has been definitely understood, both by the Department and the Churches concerned in the operation of residential schools, that the per capita grant included payment of teachers' salaries. If the Department took over payment of teachers at residential schools, it would be necessary to make a deduction in the per capita rate. At a few of our residential schools we are experimenting with the system of paying the salaries of qualified teachers. It is hoped to obtain, during the next year, sufficient information to enable us to make a decision with reference to paying the salaries of qualified teachers at all Indian residential schools.

5. "The Catholic Archbishops and Bishops of Canada request the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration to take into account, in Article 117 of the Indian Act, the phrase 'Except by written direction of the parent' in such a way that this expressed wish of the parents may effectively serve as the method of procedure in determining the choice of the school by the Minister in disputed questions."

In cases of dispute regarding the religious auspices under which an Indian child should be educated, the Department makes every possible endeavour to ascertain the religious denomination of the parents and careful consideration is also given to the wishes of the parents.

Director.

Rev. Mr. Macdonald of Prince Albert and Dr. Duffield of Bella Bella met me at the boat landing and assisted in my transfer to the steamer which was to take me to Fort McPherson. And so I started on my long trip East.

The scenery along the Skeena River, as seen from our car window, was rarely beautiful. The water, crystal clear, runs among precipitous cliffs, while the pale foliage of whose trees makes a charming contrast to the dark green of the fir and pine and snow-capped mountains as a background.

We passed salmon canneries where, I believe, the Indians were only put up. Busy preparations for the fishing season, now close at hand, were in progress.

Early the following morning, being somewhat restless, I leaned up on my elbow to look out over the river. To my delight, I found we were passing through our great Rocky Mountains, and what a sight! The world, not seeing which, the Alps, can equal for grandeur. The rugged outline of their summits was silhouetted against the immense sky of ever-changing splendor, for the sun was just peeping above the horizon, casting shadows all around, making it all mysterious and beautiful. The mountain, with its fourteen thousand feet, towered above all, while not far away Mount Cheam, with its snow-capped height, reared its snow-capped crest.

Rev. Mr. Kinney, of British Columbia, some years ago named Mount Chown when scaling Mount Robson and named it after the Superintendent of the Methodist Church, the name being afterward ratified by the Dominion Government at Ottawa. He very kindly sent us a picture of its peak, done in sepia, which hangs in our home today and reminds us of our trip.

It were futile to attempt in an article such as this, even a slight description of the magnificence of the scene not seen in three days’ journey across our great North-west.

Suffice it to say that at an unearthly hour one morning I was set down at Brandon, Manitoba, the seat of Rev. Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Missions in Canada and Principal of the Indian Residential School of that city. The hour, however, was not too early for Mr. Ferrier, who, with his wife, Mrs. Ferrier, gave me a warm welcome when we reached their home. I was grateful indeed to a tired traveller.

My stay of a few hours was all too short to enable me to get anything like an accurate description of the work carried on by Mr. Ferrier and his wife. But I will try to give a brief indication. First, the site. The buildings stand on a commanding rise of ground, surrounded by fine trees, well trimmed hedges and cultivated fields. Beautiful beds of flowers on each side of the road draw aside the grounds. I know of nothing lovelier than the site of the Industrial School at Brandon. Next, there is the farm. While it trains the boys in the sciences of farming, it is also a school for life. Mr. Hamilton is the capable farm instructor. There are nine hundred acres under cultivation, and there is wheat, barley, hay, oats, barley and rye. Noting the rye and remembering that these are prohibited, I asked, “Why the rye, Mr. Ferrier?”

“Oh,” he replied with a smile, “just to feed the hogs.”

Seventy acres of corn is grown for silage purposes.

At the Hudson Winter Fair seventy-five fat cattle were sold this year; also many hogs of fabulous size and stock.

One hundred eighty-three chickens flourish in modern hen-houses and up-to-date “runs.”

Last year the sum of $8,000 was turned in as an asset to the Institution. The school itself has in residence eighty-five boys. Mr. Ferrier believes in co-education. He is an enthusiast in his work and is well fitted to carry on efficiently and executive ability. While he has a most capable staff, his is the directing mind in all operations pertaining to the school and farm.

I was struck with the opportunity offered first-hand, in vastly diverse fields, something of the Indian work as carried on by the Methodists in Canada. We should wish that more of our people would visit these homes of training for our Indian children, the future citizens of this country.

"He Refused to Quit"

ON THE campus of one of the large universities of France there is a monument has been set in honor of one of the students who died fighting for France during the first World War, but sealing inscription: "He played on the battlefield three years he refused to quit. During that day the hero—Hammond by name—went out and played with the 'scrub' to help the 'variety.' Hammond summoned the boys to a game on the fields of France, took him to the battlefields."

On the battlefield he exhibited the same fidelity as on the football field. One day his owner called Hammond for a hazardous bit. Hammond went out with the boys, never looked back. Hammond's little inscription on the monument calls to the burying ground of the dead: "He refused to quit."

A tribute can be given to Hammond for the qualities which he displayed, essential in a Christian, in the service of God, and he closed His life with the solemn words: "No man shall come to the plough without first being a learner for the King's Companions."
In Another World

SAT the other afternoon with a salesman from Chicago who had been homeward bound by the train. We discussed the European situation, Japan, and the mine situation in West Virginia. I asked him if he had ever read the Sermon on the Mount? "Not for many years! What is it about?"

I tried to tell him. It is hard to give any one an adequate idea of what that sermon covers. It is too big for words. "No, no," he replied finally; "that won't work in this world. It is not right to hold such high ideals. It is not a hopeless ideal. It will only work in another world."

We have expected it to work in this world. He gave it as the charter of a new world which would be built in the Kingdom of God. It is not in the clouds, nor in the future. His golden doctrine is that we must think and act to-day. The new world is the old world made new. It is with us now. We are living in it. We walk its streets. We are naturalized into its citizenship when we accept the lordship of Jesus Christ.—Hubert C. Herring.

Looking back upon some of our experiences in life, there is one form of sentiment which I recall vividly, because it was in the world of my childhood. It was the old-time sentiment which is expressed in the old-time song, like this: "Boys did do things in those days. I was very deeply impressed by the time, or inspired by the sight of a little boy who was a man in his indignation, or some visiting relative who seemed to have some significant side-glance in his eyes. I have no doubt those boys were merely reproducing what had been a commonplace observation before, and, now that we are growing old ourselves, we see something of the same thing all around us. Beyond that there is a good deal of truth in the old adage that there is a good deal of truth in what is said about the younger generation being changed wonderfully in a hundred years—yes, in fifty years. Things have changed, too, habits of life, and the way people think. It would be absurd to expect the boys and girls of today to do the same things which we did, or the same girls, or even the same boys, years ago, and to do them the same way. Their surroundings and circumstances are different, and that accounts for great deal which the eye of experience views askance.

So far as I can see not much is gained by attempting to prove that the world is growing better all the while, nor yet by attempting to show that it is slowly, but surely, getting worse. Personally, I doubt whether either contention is true. If we believe in God, we believe that He is the author of all—somehow, sometime—but no evolution goes straight forward to its goal. There are setbacks, and delays, and it happens again and again that we are left in doubt whether the tide is flowing in this direction or in that, or whether it is flowing at all.

The world is at its best when we are at our best ourselves. I have put this statement in parenthesis, for emphasis and special emphasis. The world where day dawned for me, where the morning sun shone upon my soul, where my spirit was still the great adventure, full of promise and mystery, will always be the best world that I shall ever know. That in mind, young reader, when you feel discontent and restlessness, when you long for the "good old days," and bear it in mind, too, when you stoutly contend that the world is going to pieces. There is a trifle of exaggeration in both judgments, for sentiment has its say.
Three Splendid Institutions

By Mrs. S. D. Chown

ON MY way home from a delightful stroll in the enchanting valley of the Fraser River, I turned aside, upon reaching our own country, to visit some of the institutions which are fostering and cultivating our Indian children.

As is everywhere known, these institutions are the means by which we are teaching the children of the aborigines of this country to be liberal education; fitting them to become citizens of their race.

And in the enchanting valley of the Fraser River, at the Canadian Institute, overlooking off from Vancouver one glorious day, I met a friend and took an auto-tour for New Westminster. If we made record time over the sixteen miles between the cities, this was because we were burdened with wide-spreading and well-cultivated fields, interspersed with way cottages, their tiny front gardens aglow with blossoming flowers, and happy little children frolicking happily. On we sped, now in the open, now passing under trees, and now crossing bridges, traversing three over whose grateful shade, until we reached New Westminster.

The air was exquisite, stiflingly warm, upon a hill, like a queen upon her throne, looking down into the blue-green waters of the river.

Here we alighted and immediately transferred to well-appointed train cars. Having passed the great bridge spanning the river, we were off for our further two hours ride into the country. There we arrived, and after a stroll around the base of great mountains we journeyed until we pulled up at a picturesque mission school, the name of which, in stentorian tones, had previously informed us was "Sardis."

At the outset when we reached the delightful home of Mr. and Mrs. Raley, whose hospitality was so generous. After supper we pulled our chairs up to the blazing grate fire, for the weather was still cool and crisp.

In the morning we found boys and girls, to the number of about one hundred, dressed in fine assorted dress, for worship. They were singing heartily when we entered, and the volume of sound which arose would have done credit to much larger assembly.

As Mr. Raley addressed the scholars I stood there and listened to their upturned faces and was deeply impressed with the high grade of intelligence depicted therein.

After a kind introduction by the Principal, there was a few words of prayer and then we sang together that soul-stirring hymn, "Faith of our Fathers."

After prayers the teachers and pupils followed, after which we were free for a walk around the grounds.

Our next stop was destined to record how gratified I was, in this day and age, which seem to attune so little importance to the training of the younger generation in etiquette, to observe the air of politeness and correctness in deportment which pervaded every movement. There is no doubt that this is due to the cultured atmosphere created by the Principal, who is ever ready to lavish his rare courtesy to every one. It is still a truism, as we used to write in our copy books in our youth, that "example is better than precepts."

It was quite a Sabbath Day's journey to reach the splendid building recently erected by the Dominion Government, but one full of interest. As much has appeared recently in newspapers and other things telling, I shall only say that it is imposing in appearance and complete in facilities afforded the work will receive fresh impetus.

In connection with the Institute there is a farm of ninety-two acres; a dear old orchard still bearing well and a variety of trees in the garden, where every known variety grow thriftily. The school has clever pupils, those of the Haida tribe being especially brilliant. This year one of the girls took ninety-six per cent. in French and ninety-five per cent. in Latin at the high-school examinations. Eight years ago she did not know the alphabet. She has also good high school examinations, taking ninety-one per cent., with an average superiority per cent.

The pessimistic cry that our Indians will not stand in the light of such educational records as these, seems to have lingered longer in this peaceful valley, but all delightful things must come to an end; so, bidding farewell to my kind hosts, we embarked aboard the train for my return journey. Two young ladies gave me, in parting, a most touching gift, which is fondly cherished in memory of my happy visit to the Coqualeetza Institute.

The Mission Girls' Home at Port Simpson was my next objective—a jump of six hundred miles north from Victoria.

Our route, inside the channel, is part of the famous route of the old steamer, Rupert, palatial in its appointments, was a most comfortable boat for two days and nights we were on board.

Upon arriving at Prince Rupert I learned to my disappointment, that no steamer touching at Port Simpson was due for two days. Hoisting however the sails of the Tug, which tug was in for supplies, I decided if possible to make the trip that way. Making my way to the dock, however, I was glad to see there were many small craft tied alongside, and I found the owner had got in touch with the owner, who kindly said I might go with them.

I had a most varied and enjoyable experience, that three hours' run, with the sea at our feet and snow-crowned mountains behind us. Once or twice a while a huge wave dashed its spray over us, as our powerful engine sent us through the water at a rate. On the earlier days, on the Ottawa River, I have seen just such a tug towing a boom of logs, but this little vessel, though small as an irate rat takes a naughty boy by the ear and drags him along wildly niftily, the tug-changer owning himself a path through the foamy brine until we arrived at the wharf.

At the landing dock a difficult arose. The tide was out and we were many feet below the top of the wharf. I looked below and saw a small ladder nailed flat against its side.

"Can you make it?" asked a bystander with a laugh.

"I'm not sure," I replied, "but I'll try;" and forthwith began my ascent laboriously until nearing the top when I heard a glimmering of sunlight and felt nearly so brave just then, and needed that some one come up behind me for encouragement, at a second attempt. More I was at the top, with my old friend, Miss Myles, giving me hearty congratulations.

Miss Deacon and Miss Myles are two devoted workers of the Western Mission, who have worked hard and long day and all the time for twenty little bright-eyed Indian maidens, ranging in age from three to fifteen years.

The mental, moral and physical health of these children is their constant concern. They are taught reading, writing, spelling, arithmetic, sewing; indeed everything that goes to the making of a house; it is interesting to see the little ones set out for school each morning. Two or three times they may be seen in front of the gate, accompanied by Miss Deacon or Miss Myles. The picturesque winding path leads to the Haida Indian school, very well trodden. I had the great pleasure of meeting Miss Roche, the capable teacher of the Indian school.

It is not, however, a study and work at the school. There is a lovely playground where they laugh and shout to their heart's content. In rain or shine, they are always fully constitutional of a mile or more.

At the devotional hour they repeat parts of the church service. Miss Billy noticed that, unlike some with greater opportunities, there was not the slightest indication of any lack of faith.

I attended a meeting of the Crosby Girls' Circle, offered entirely by native girls. The premises with grass and dignity, a sand pit and a pond for them, while seemed to give them pleasure, was a little disappointing for me a bouquet of wild flowers. Among them I noticed many butterflies, which Browning beautifully describes as the little things that live and die.

The new Home is well appointed and, though not so large as the old one, is very comfortable. The dining-room is lighted by electricity, furnished by a small plant on the premises, which Miss Pearson with great courage, manipulated herself.

One little hardship, or so it would appear to others, is that the nature of the land cows cannot conveniently be kept. If they wander away, the people there are obliged to pay to be helped out; so the missionaries have to purchase milk. They assure me they cannot milk it, so they buy it. An acquired taste, I could not truthfully endorse the sentiment, and laughingly suggested with a smile, "Well, I suppose you would certainly have a goat; that animal enjoying the reputation of being able to extract milk from anywhere."

Port Simpson itself is a pretty town, having been built more recently than Prince Rupert; though both have a wonderful outlook to sea. The ground being a slight slope, the streets are paved, and gravel paths are used for walks through the town. Beautiful moss and wild flowers grow in profusion, and there is the penalty of trying to gather them.

There is much rain, but no one seems to mind it. The Indians come out as if the sun were shining—a beautiful and picturesque frame of mind to acquire and one which is very agreeable to the casual visitor.

On account of the character of the soil, there are not many gardens, though I saw rhubarb, forget-me-nots and pansies, which were evidently to the best of nature's market gardener.

There are about five hundred and fifty natives at Port Simpson. In the fishing season they go to Prince Rupert, to Port Essington, Bella Bella and other fishing centers. I was told that a man who had visited my village could not be an able-bodied Indian left in the village.

I spent these two days at Port Simpson, 25th of May. From far and near, Indians with their families came to the little port, eager to participate in the day. Everybody came—from the smallest tot to the deeply-wrinkled grandmother. In the center of the village was the rallying ground; where an Indian band, in their Sunday dress, danced and sang, alternating from opera to the very latest jazz, to the evident delight of the assembled crowd, who gave loud approbations by the closest attention. Little groups dotted here and there, attired in bright colors, added a picturesque note to the scene.

Indians are artistic. They love music and dance. The girls do fine embroidery well and sew neatly.

I enjoyed every moment of my stay in this place. The Indians were much occupied, they took time for an occasional chat—and there was always Mrs. Sager, my life-long friend, for company.

We were kindly entertained by Rev. Dr. Mrs. Sager, proprietors of Mission House and Dr. and Mrs. Sager, of the Hospital. Miss Deacon and Miss Myles also made a "tea" for me, at which I enjoyed myself immensely.

One rarely beautiful morning, the sun sending its beams athwart the landscape, we started for Prince Rupert, on the Cariboo, which was to take me to Prince Rupert, from which point the Canadian Pacific steams east on its long trans-Canada trip.

A group of missionaries, who are in the doctoring line, I could not but think, as the boat receded, of the devotion of men and women of education and culture, who are engaged far away, who live in isolated places such as this. Free from thought of self, they cheer...

TORONTO, JANUARY 10, 1924

Making a Garden

Man plows and plants, and digs and weeds,
God sends the sun and rain and air,
And thus a garden's made.
He must be proud who tills the soil,
And turns the heavy sod.
How wonderful a thing to be
In partnership with God!

These lines are written by Ida M. Thomas. But they are very familiar with Jack Miner, for he has them printed on one corner of his stationery, on which he writes his letters. Jack likes to share up everything good with his friends.

Two things impress one as he reads this little poem. The first is, that God can't make a garden alone. He needs the help of man. "Man plows and plants, and digs and weeds," but God sends the rain, the sunshine and the genial air. If we would allow ourselves to think for a while, we would be impressed with the many things God can't or won't do, without our help.

The second thing which impresses us is, that when we are working with nature we are working in partnership with God. None should feel this more than the farmer who till the soil. The farmer's life is essentially a life of faith and obedience to law. Every man's life should make him a partner with God, but in no place is it more evident than in the life of the farmer or gardener.

The Better Way

A FEW weeks ago, outside a church in a large Canadian city, there was a sign with the pastor's text for the following Sunday: "Then God said me." Then followed the words: "Enormous eye. That eye looked awful, and passer-by seemed to shudder at its uncanniness."

The intention of those responsible for the sign evidently was to remind folks of the fact that the whole of life is seen by God, but one wonders whether the conception of God as a great "eye" is the right view to take. There is more than a suggestion here that God is kind of detective, eternally on the look-out for wrong-doers, and rather glad when He finds such.

It is true that God sees, and knows and understands, His glance is kind as well as searching, and surely the truth to be emphasized is that God's knowledge of human nature is that of a parent for a child. He sees the secret sorrows and the secret hangings. He knows how heavily burdens bear, and how frail human nature is. It is a great mistake to imagine that all God sees are the mistakes that people make, and the sins they commit; and furthermore, it is an error to assume that the perception of God as a mighty eye will win for Him the devotion and affection of His children.

Bishop Mclyntyre used to tell of an occasion when his father lay dying. One by one the members of the family were removed from him a few parting words. Then George Mclyntyre, who at that time was a lad of fifteen, went into the room while his heart was beating violently. It seemed to him at that moment that he had beyond reason and mischiefness and loomed up large. The dying man said to the boy: "George, you have been a good boy, a good son. The tenderness of your love was very precious for the lad. He could not speak, but he left the room determined to be worthy of that eulogy. It is the goodness of God that leads men to repentance. It is His love which makes them ashamed of sin.

I am I

HELLO, Jock," says a lady as she enters a room. Jock had been singing. He stops, steps a little forward, bends his head in an expectant attitude, his eyes beaming with gladness. Jock is a pet bird, with his name responds to his name. Dogs, horses, oxen, know their names. "I am I" is a fact recognized very early by the little child. To every living soul, young or old, there is a strong and vivid sense of individuality. Theosophy, with its doctrine and reincarnation, teaching that we have been some one or something else in another state of existence, contradicts a primal cognition of the human soul.

Every young person must work out his or her own destiny. The soul speaks to itself by name; recognizes its duties and responsibilities. The world about us singles us out, refuses to lose us in the crowd, opens up some special road for us, points to some personal objective. Friends, acquaintances, know our names, strangers wish to know them; God individualizes us. No truth in the Bible is more striking than this. "Jesus calleth His own sheep by name. He knoweth them, and stretcheth out His hands unto them. They follow Him because they know His voice."

Changing One's Mind

WE ADMIRE consistency; stability of character is of inestimable value. The constant, habitual, dependable, as it were, in matters of opinion, is one of the good things. What a chaos would result if we awake some morning to find everybody overnight had changed their opinions about everything—it would be a world of tumult! The sanity of the world is preserved by the constancy of human thought. Yet apart from certain exceptional individuals who hold his right to change his mind, it has been a marked characteristic of many of the world's most eminent thinkers that their opinions have undergone radical changes. We may take Gladstone with advocating measures which he had opposed twenty-five years before, when a young man at college, and the latter defended himself in terms of his former eloquent and effective speeches. On questions of political and social reform, Gladstone's views have been tremendous changes, and the facts have often been most conclusive in human progress. In reading biography it is most interesting to note how noted people, as for instance Charles Kingsley and Henry Drummond, have felt their way to clearer light and larger spaces.

There is more than humor in the prayer attributed to a Scotchman, "O Lord, start me right, for Thou knowest, Lord, Thou canst not change me. When the desire for consistency outweighs the sense of right and wrong, when men deliberately take their own way in reference to the indications of providence and the Spirit of God, the capacity to change one's mind is surely most desirable.

Famous Invalids

By R. WALTER WRIGHT

IX William Cowper

FROM the viewpoint of physical affliction there is nothing to compare among the famous men of the world than that of William Cowper, characterized as he was of English letter-writer, and poet, and diarist, and invalid of this day. Born nearly two hundred years ago, in 1731, his father was an English clergyman, a chaplain to George II. His mother, of whom he was passionately fond, died when he was nine years of age. His memory was affectionately cherished, and this fond expression manifested itself in many tender, beautiful lines addressed to her picture. Shortly after he was sent to a boarding-school, where he suffered severely from the blows and persecution of a bullying headmaster. It appears that he had cried so frequently that his schoolfellows became inflamed and he had to be removed from the school for treatment. At this early age he showed a weak and feeble constitution, and his life-long dependences.

At ten he went to Westminster School, where he remained for eight years. Here his surroundings were brighter, yet his unconquerable shyness isolated him home with the Rev. Mr. Truspin, who with his wife, treated him with affectionate care. Here he met with John Newton, the hymn-writer, at whose suggestion Cowper commenced to write his letters. This sudden illness already returned, reducing him to almost eminently immobility. Gradually he recovered, and took up seriously again his great vocation as a poet; he was then thirty-five years of age. His first volume was published. Again, for some months in 1787, he suffered from mental derangement, but recovered. He rallied, resumed his literary labors and accomplished a great deal of solid work for some years. His best poem, "The Task," was published in 1785 and gave him great reputation.

But his mental troubles came back seriously once more, and the darkness continued with light gleams of light for some time. His friend, Alexander Pope, visited him in his wretched existence.

Surely few have ever spent severer years of life under more discouraging circumstances than William Cowper, and yet he carried them as the inspiration that even the most difficult existence can accomplish something of real value. His writings are full of sincere views of religion which found credence in his day, and which tended to exaggerate the importance of religious duty much to do with influencing his mind in a wrong direction. Let us be thankful that God has given us His own joyous evangel, which recognizes our Heavenly Father's abounding mercy and has filled countless hearts broken upon the harrowed soil of Cowper as a glad revolution, and we should find his very complaints, after death, were an expression of holy surprise. Some of his best poems, such as "The Task," are sung in Christian congregations to the end of time. "O for a closer walk with Thee, dear Lord," "The task is done," "Blood, shed for man," "Sometimes a light surprise," are precious gems. To his credit stand also his poem, "The Divine Providence," written as he was relapsing into insanity in 1773—"God moved in mysterious ways."

While Cowper does not rank among the chiefest of English poets, his genius is acknowledged by all who study, acknowledged. Poetry had degenerated in England into glittering artificiality. Cowper's poetry was simple. Cowper brought back nature to poetry; and his influence has been extensive and enduring. He opened the way for Wordsworth and Tennyson. The mighty nerve that was needed to bring poetry once more in the air—Cowper gave it expression. He sang of men as the children of a Father's Favour, as the natural heirs of God's nation and having a work to do for man. His expanding spirit conceived that conditions of life and the rights of man were inalienable and extended to slave and savage as well as to the Englishman. The sentiment of international union rose before his mind, a mighty dream which was to become its fulfillment in the kingdom of Jesus Christ. Thus he anticipated the spirit of the internationalism of the present day. "The most exalted heritage of man is liberty, and as Stopford Smith says, 'Liberty is the root of human wrong, begins, that long, long cry against oppression and evil done by man to man, which is the petition of the priestly tyrant, which rings louder and louder through Burns, Wordsworth, Shelley, Scott, Byron, ever impassioned, ever longing, ever prophetic.' The spirit of liberty, the vision of the highest thought of God—yet how that spirit was manacled with terrible iron! And yet, when on his deathbed, his physician asked him how he felt, replied, 'I feel unutterable despair.'"
Duncan Scott, Esq., Litt.D., F.R.S.C., Deputy Superintendent General, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ontario.

CLASS-ROOM WORK:

Our class-room work in the residential schools is gradually increasing to a higher standard. We have a prospective class of twenty pupils for grade nine work, five for grade ten and one for grade eleven who will all be writing on the June examination. The most of our pupils make a grade a year. Our main hope lies in the education of the youthful generation. This education should be exceedingly practical. For a long time the Indian is going to live on the land and any system that does not take this into account is losing valuable time. The transition from fishing and hunting, the natural occupations of the Indian, to farming, gardening and stock-raising, is easy and natural.

INDUSTRIAL TRAINING:

The Indian's bit of land is to be his stock in trade, the one thing he has to begin life on. All our boys receive training in the care of horses, cattle, hogs, sheep and poultry and in all our farming and gardening operations they are taught to use the most up-to-date machinery. Many of the boys are instructed in manual training, carpenter and mechanical work and in the handling of gasoline engines. Our girls are being well trained in dress-making, cooking, laundry work, dairying and all kinds of house-work. We have made exhibits of drawing, writing, sewing, fancy work, canning, wood carving, manual training and products of the farm and garden in many of our public exhibitions. The British Columbia provincial diploma for the best residential school exhibit was awarded to the Coqualeetsa Institute.

GAMES & SOCIAL LIFE:

There has been a gradual growth in the desire of our pupils in changing from boisterous and unorganized games to well regulated and the strict rules that govern our modern games, such as football, soft and hard baseball, lacrosse, basketball and tennis. They enjoy keen contests for trophies and medals with other teams in the community. The scout and cadet work is greatly appreciated by our boys and tends toward erect carriage and prompt obedience to discipline. The girls are greatly interested in the C. C. I. T. work, supervised by class-room teachers. From the Brandon school we send a group of twelve each summer to the provincial camp which lasts ten days. We make a point of suitably celebrating public holidays. Through the winter, lectures, moving pictures, social evenings and indoor games are important parts of our institutional programmes.
RELIGIOUS INSTRUCTION:

Morning and evening devotions are held daily, organized Sunday School in all our institutions and Divine Worship is attended in the nearest church. Moral and religious instruction is given through Mission Bands, Circles, C. G. I. T., Tukis and Trail Rangers. Music is a very important part of our devotional services, assisted by the use of stringed instruments, organs and pianos. Our programme is planned for the training of our pupils vocationally, mentally, morally, physically and religiously.

MEDICAL WORK:

Our medical work is carried on by doctors, nurses, field matrons and hospitals. For all Indian Patients treated in our hospitals, the Indian Department pays $2.50 per day. For all patients other than Indians, the Provincial Government pays from 75¢ to $1.00 per day. These government grants together with the patients' fees, contracts with the Workmen's Compensation Board and voluntary contributions, practically make our hospitals self sustaining.

Our residential schools are managed by efficient, devoted and highly qualified workers. The hospitals are training schools for nurses and are noted for their excellent work in nursing back to life and health the sick and afflicted. The names of the doctors in charge are house-hold words in the constituencies served.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,-

I beg to draw your attention to the fact that the expense of education for the native population is upon the increase, and while the Department desires to provide a reasonably adequate system, it is essential that the outlay should be controlled. It is thought that the denominations should respect the zones of interest which have been established and not encroach upon them by the extension of missionary effort upon which a demand for separate educational institutions might be afterwards based. This view seems entirely reasonable, and in future the Department will not recognize requests for aid to educational institutions unless by pre-arrangement, and assistance must not be expected for institutions which encroach by the extension of missionary effort upon territory already provided for.

Yours very truly,

The following is a copy of a resolution passed by the Prince Rupert Presbytery on August 3rd, which was ordered to be sent to the Board of Home Missions, Toronto.

WHEREAS there are resident on the north British Columbia coast a sufficient number of Indian boys and girls under the United Church of Canada to warrant the building of a residential school, and,

Whereas the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church has for years carried on a faithful but inadequate work for the Indian girls of Port Simpson in the absence of a corresponding work for boys, who receive little schooling owing to the nomadic life of their parents, and,

Whereas moral and social conditions among these younger Indians of this region are retrograding to an alarming extent, and,

Whereas there was at one time voted by the Dominion Government $40,000 for the erection of an Indian school at Port Simpson and whereas the Mission Board and the Indian Department have long had under consideration the building of a school at Port Simpson, and

Whereas the Indians of Port Simpson strongly desire the early provision of such a school and whereas the Government has agreed to expend an additional $100,000 annually on the British Columbia Indians for educational purposes, and,

Whereas a Commission is called to discuss the Indian school situation in the province,

Therefore this Presbytery of Prince Rupert urgently requests the early construction of a Residential School at Port Simpson for Indian boys and girls under the care of the United Church of Canada and asks the Missionary Board of the United Church to arrange with the Department of Indian Affairs for the erection of such a school in the near future.

SIGNED

Alfred Wilson
Secretary, Prince Rupert Presbytery.

Indian Schools Are Improved by Department

Good Advances Made in Missionary Work of United Church Among Red Men

The Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, is making important improvements in residential schools where boys and girls of the various tribes attend. The mission teachers of the United Church of Canada. A new building is being erected at Brandon, Manitoba, which will be completed next summer. It will accommodate 150 pupils under Rev. John A. Doyle, D.D., principal, and his staff.

The residential school at Edmonton, Alberta, has been enlarged to house 85 Brandon pupils during the period of construction.

The hospital at Fort Macleod, B.C., has been extensively improved.

All the residential schools made progress during 1929, it was stated by Rev. Arthur Barnet, superintendent, during a recent visitation for the United church.

Three new United church hospitals for Indians in British Columbia and the two summer hospitals have been well patronized. The Hudson Bay Hospital established in 1900, is to be completed early next year under Rev. Horace C. Wrinch, M.D., M.P., who founded the hospital at Norway House, Manitoba, owned by the Indian Department and manned by the United church, serving the hunting tribes of the northern Indians, as well as the Indians of the territory in Hudson Bay Presbytery.

It is proved increasingly possible to interest the Indian congregation in the missionary work. The Deer Lake band of hunters in eastern Manitoba has never had resident missionaries, but continued to send annual contributions from headquarters at Winnipeg. Lake Winnipeg on Berens River. Missionaries visited the band and performed one week each year. The Haida Bella and Bella Coola bands in British Columbia receive larger missionary allocations ahead of most white communities.

Haida Indians, of Skidegate, B.C., who send their children 600 miles to the residential school at Sardis, have given more than half the posts on the board of control to Haida graduates. They are introducing advanced ideas and principles of government into their communal life. The graduates have formed an attempt to re-establish the villages of the Queen Charlotte Islands, where the missionaries first went nearly 50 years ago.
