RESOLUTION RE INDIAN WORK

Whereas there is unrest and dissatisfaction amongst our Indian people in the Province of Alberta, owing to the educational policy, resulting in the withdrawal of many of our Indian people from our Church to unite with the Roman Catholic Church, and whereas social and economic conditions are such as to result in the creation of a dependent, rather than a self-reliant people, therefore hampering the efforts of our Missionaries to such an extent as to make their task exceedingly difficult:

THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED that we as a Conference memorialize the General Council to investigate these conditions, with a view first of all of re-opening if deemed necessary the day-schools on Reserves, which, according to the terms of the Indian treaties were assured the people, so long as there were children available to attend such schools, we further believe that the reopening of such schools on the Reserve would result in a larger attendance at the Residential School in Edmonton. And secondly, to make a social survey of the Reserves, with a view of the Church and State cooperating for the betterment of social and economic and religious conditions.

WE FURTHER RECOMMEND that each Conference in which there is Indian work through its Presbyteries exercise a closer supervision over actual conditions, and policies, obtaining on reserves, and that a more democratic and careful selection of the men appointed to the Indian or educational work of the Church, be exercised.

WE FURTHER BELIEVE that the time is ripe to ask the Department of Indian affairs to consider the conditional enfranchisement of the Indians. We believe that the vote, while not depriving the Indian of any of his reservation or treaty rights, would make for self-reliance on the part of the Indian, and a more intelligent knowledge of, and interest in, our Indian population by the general public.

All of which is respectfully submitted.
Ottawa, September 16, 1930.

Dear Mr. Beaton:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with enclosure, and in reply I am forwarding a copy of the Indian Act. There were amendments at the last session of Parliament, but these do not affect the enfranchisement clauses. You will note that Indians may be enfranchised under Sections 110 and 114. Section 110 refers to Indians living on reserves and involves the alienation of reserve lands and the granting of title to such lands to the enfranchised Indian. There are very few enfranchisements under this section. Section 114 provides for the enfranchisement of Indians who hold no land on a reserve and who do not follow the Indian mode of life. Under this section, up to March 31, 1930, a total of 1531 Indian men, women and children were enfranchised.

Unofficially, I may add, for your confidential ear, that the Department has been somewhat disappointed by enfranchised Indians. Enfranchisement has not turned out as well as was hoped.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

RESOLUTION PASSED BY ASSOCIATION OF INDIAN WORKERS IN SASKATCHEWAN AT THEIR MEETING HELD IN MAY - 1930.

The association of Indian workers in the Province of Saskatchewan under the United Church of Canada has given careful consideration to the question of "Follow Up Work" among the graduates of the Residential Schools, and among the progressive pupils of the Day Schools. We beg to present through the Board of Home Missions to the Department of Indian Affairs the following resolutions:

1.- That we express our hearty appreciation of the interest the Department has taken in the matter throughout the years, and we desire to co-operate with them, as far as lies in our power, in furthering this policy.

2.- We are determined, as far as our work is concerned, to seek a closer and more sympathetic co-operation between the missions on the reserves and the Residential Schools, particularly in connection with those pupils who are nearing graduation.

3.- We are of the opinion that in the year previous to graduation some encouragement to independence and self-help might be given by the Department to promising students by allowing them to cultivate a piece of land for themselves or to engage in any other remunerative work under the guidance of the Principal.

4.- We would respectfully suggest that the principle of assistance to pupils of both sexes immediately after graduation be extended, particularly in securing horses and implements for work, and in cases where ex-pupils marry, in helping them to provide a house and furniture.

5.- We would suggest the following safeguard to this action, namely, that the officials of the Department give special supervision to these young people in the use of the equipment thus provided, and that in cases where the graduates thus treated fail to make good or prove unworthy, the horses and the implements be passed on to some more deserving person.

At the Executive of the Board of Home Missions of The United Church of Canada, held in October, 1930, - It was agreed to forward this Resolution, simpliciter, to the Department of Indian Affairs.
RESOLUTIONS PASSED BY THE COUNCIL OF INDIAN WORKERS
IN BRITISH COLUMBIA - May 1930 - AND ENDORSED BY THE B.C. CONFERENCE.

WHEREAS the following resolution, fully considered and unanimously adopted by the Council of Workers among the Indians in British Columbia, assembled on May 12th, 1930, in St. Andrew's Church, Vancouver, and presented to us with the request that it be forwarded through the Board of Home Missions to the Department of Indian Affairs:

The resolution reading:-

"WHEREAS the beneficial result of the present system of education fostered by the Department of Indian Affairs, especially in regard to technical training, are fully appreciated by all, and

WHEREAS we recognise the splendid opportunities thus offered to the Indian youth of Canada, the results thus fully justifying operations along these lines, and

WHEREAS we are convinced that neither the Church nor the Government of Canada is reaping maximum results from the expenditure of money and effort thus entailed, and

WHEREAS there is a missing link which should be forged into the present system along the line of "Follow up work."

IT IS RESOLVED:-
(1) That for the advancement of the best interests of graduates and ex-pupils generally, we respectfully request that the Department of Indian Affairs take the whole question of what is termed 'Follow Up' work under advisement as soon as possible, and appoint a 'Vocational Director' who would be responsible to the Department of Indian Affairs, who would act as intermediary between employers and graduates, and endeavour to find suitable employment for graduates at wages commensurate with their ability. He would be a man well qualified to supervise the graduates in their employment and to give vocational guidance, to protect their interests and direct as far as possible their future welfare.

(2) That to give maximum effect to this 'Follow Up' system, we further recommend that the Department of Indian Affairs establish an office and home in the City of Vancouver where students and graduates should reside when taking extra vocational training or when seeking employment; inasmuch as by this means the director would be able to look more effectively after the moral welfare of the Indian young people who visit the city or who are in residence while employed.

Moved by Rev. H. Allen and seconded by Rev. E. McGougan.

Signed

That this Conference endorse this resolution and forward it through the Board of Home Missions to the Department of Indian Affairs.

CARRIED.

The Executive of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, at its meeting in October, 1930, agreed to forward the above Resolution to the Department of Indian Affairs, simpliciter.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I have not previously made any direct reference to your letter giving a detailed statement of the various needs of our Indian Residential Schools, provision for which may be included in your estimates for 1931.

I have tried to investigate as carefully as possible the situation at the various places. There are only two or three matters to which I should like to refer.

Re Norway House.—I notice that you are not planning to ask even for a small grant for minor repairs in connection with the Residential School there. My impression of that old building, after going over it very carefully last year, is that there should be a small sum of a few hundred dollars available annually for repairs. It would, for instance, be vastly improved by a serious attempt to re-paint the walls and furniture in the dining-room and by a re-lacquering of most of the beds in the dormitories. When I was there I discussed with Mr. Gordon the possibility of improving the storm windows by stripping them, and we had Joe Keeper look over the building in order to get an estimated idea of how much it would cost. I do not know whether the stripping has actually been done or not. As I intimated to you in my conversation, I think the fire alarm arrangements, with only one gong in a building of that size, are entirely inadequate, and that steps should be taken immediately to install a system similar to the one provided in Mount Elgin.

Re Morley.—I have had some further correspondence with Mr. Staley and am enclosing a map, which I asked him to prepare, showing the amount of reserve land which is now actually flooded. This will give you some idea of the basis on which he estimates that he will have a deficit of $1,000 this year. I am rather disappointed that we have not received a copy of his annual report. It does seem as if the Calgary Power Company, in addition to giving us compensation for the United Church land which is flooded, should also do something for the school in regard to the part of the land on the reserve previously used as a school garden and which is now useless.
Re Ahousant.— We are very grateful for your attention to the needs of the school there and believe that the plans that you are making in that respect are perfectly satisfactory and quite as much as Mr. Jones can expect during the current year.

Re Portage la Prairie.— I hope that it may be possible to proceed this year with the building of a Principal's residence. If we are to retain Mr. and Mrs. Hendry in the service of the Church and of the Indian Department, it is going to be necessary to find a separate place of residence for them. Of course, I realize that this will add to the total expense of carrying on the School, as we shall immediately be faced with the necessity of engaging a Matron. However, I am personally quite impressed with the value of Mr. Hendry's services and I am very anxious to retain him if it is at all possible. They have, I think, borne their full share of the burden for us and the Department by their willingness to reside in the school with all the noise and confusion for so many years.

In conclusion, may I say that I am leaving to-night for a visit to the Maritime Provinces, but I am expecting to spend March 8th and 9th in Ottawa and hope it may be possible to have an unhurried interview with you on Monday, March 9th.

With very kind personal regards,

I am

Yours sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

RE: HANDICRAFTS.

WHEREAS there is a definite movement amongst nations responsible for the development of under-privileged peoples, especially aboriginal people, for the development of native handicrafts;

AND WHEREAS the Indians of Canada have wonderful material in every province for the promotion of native arts and crafts, and a revival of native carving, weaving, bead-work, leather work, and basketry, with artistic Indian designs, would be of considerable economic value;

AND WHEREAS we are convinced we could not only save these Indian arts from perishing, but direct the efforts of the Indians along natural lines of native industry, whereby their talent would find outlet for self-expression;

AND WHEREAS other countries have succeeded in developing a market for home-made products to the advantage and welfare of their native people;

IT IS MOVED, SECONDED and RESOLVED that this matter be referred to the Board of Home Missions of The United Church of Canada for endorsement; thence to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, for support and, if necessary, legislative action.

In this regard, we respectfully recommend that the development of a Canadian Indian Handicraft League would be a medium of economic value.
RESOLUTIONS ADOPTED BY CONFERENCE OF INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL PRINCIPALS OF THE UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA HELD AT TORONTO JAN. 29-FEB. 1, 1934.

RE: FOLLOW-UP WORK AND PLACEMENT OFFICER

It was moved, seconded, and RESOLVED THAT:

WHEREAS the beneficial results of the present system of education fostered by the Department of Indian Affairs, especially in regard to Residential Schools, are fully appreciated by all;

AND WHEREAS we recognize the splendid opportunities thus offered to the Indian youth of Canada, the results obtained fully justifying operations along this line;

AND WHEREAS we are convinced that neither the Church nor the Government of Canada is reaping maximum results from the expenditure of money and effort;

AND WHEREAS there is a missing link to complete the work, which should be forged into the present system along the line of "follow-up" work;

(1) For the advancement of the best interests of graduates and ex-pupils generally, WE RESPECTFULLY REQUEST the Department of Indian Affairs to take the whole question of what is termed "Follow-up" or "placement" work immediately under consideration and appoint a Placement or Welfare Officer, who would act as intermediary between employers and graduates and endeavor to find suitable employment for graduates at wages commensurate with their ability. He should be a man well qualified to supervise the graduates in their employment and capable of giving vocational guidance, to protect their interests and as far as possible direct their future welfare.

(2) That, to give maximum effect to this "follow-up" system, WE FURTHER RECOMMEND that the Department of Indian Affairs establish in central locations a hostel which would be an office, a home and a club-room, where students might reside when taking extra vocational training, or when seeking employment, or when passing through the city, inasmuch as by this means the Welfare Officer would be able to look more effectively after the moral well-being of the Indian young people who visit the city or who are in residence there while employed.
RESOLUTIONS ADOPTED BY CONFERENCE OF INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL PRINCIPALS OF THE UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA HELD AT TORONTO JAN. 29-FEB. 1, 1934.

* * *

RE: INSURANCE OF INDIAN MEANS OF LIVELIHOOD.

WHEREAS the Indians of the coastal waters of British Columbia are suffering today from the invasion of their ancient fishing grounds by white men and Japanese, who with their superior equipment and aggressiveness are making it very difficult for these Indians to make a living,

AND WHEREAS certain large areas throughout the Dominion are becoming depleted in fur bearing animals through the destructive methods of white people who have invaded the trapping grounds held by the Indians for centuries past and it is becoming increasingly difficult for the Indians to depend on trapping to provide for their needs,

THEREFORE be it resolved that this Conference ask our Mission Board to call the attention of the Department of Indian Affairs to these problems, urging them to work out a plan whereby certain coastal waters shall be reserved for the exclusive use of the Indians.

FURTHER we would ask the Department to assume supervision of trapping grounds with the object to setting aside certain large areas for the exclusive trapping rights of the Indians.
RESOLUTIONS ADOPTED BY CONFERENCE OF INDIAN RESIDENTIAL
SCHOOL PRINCIPALS OF THE UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA
HELD AT TORONTO JAN. 29-FEB. 1, 1934.

RE: RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL POLICY.

WHEREAS the Government of Canada, through the Department of Indian Affairs, entered into an agreement with the Churches in regard to Indian Education in 1910, in which the Residential School for Indian boys and girls under the management of the Church was to be the chief factor;

AND WHEREAS this agreement has not been revised in the past except by mutual consent;

AND WHEREAS the Residential Schools, as conducted by The United Church of Canada have demonstrated their ability to fulfill the undertakings entered into with the Government of Canada. The Church itself has put large sums of money into maintenance from year to year and given the services of some of her finest personalities.

AND WHEREAS there is a feeling of uneasiness in regard to the attitude of the Department of Indian Affairs towards the Residential School policy in the future;

WE, THEREFORE, REUEST THAT the Government make a declaration in the immediate future concerning their intention to continue Residential Schools for Indian boys and girls and to support them in such a way, by financial and other official assistance, that their efficiency will be unimpaired and we hope increased.

In support of our position we submit the following considerations to show that the Residential School is today the most vital factor in the preparation of the Canadian Indian for citizenship:

(1) The safe-guarding and developing of the health of the pupils.—The annual report of The Department of Indian Affairs', to mention only one aspect of this important problem, says in regard to trachoma that the Residential School is the key to the solution of the problem. This would apply also in some measure to tuberculosis.
(2) The preparation of Indians for full citizenship by -

(a) Providing them with vocational training.

(b) Giving them sufficient educational equipment, so that they can compete with other Canadians in various occupations.

(c) Developing moral fibre and Christian character, which are absolutely essential in order that the Indians may not only attain citizenship but have the necessary intellectual and spiritual background to take full advantage of its privileges and make their contribution to our national life.

(d) The preservation of native arts and crafts as a part of Canada's contribution to the culture of the world.

(3) While we are entirely opposed to the theory that Residential Schools should be merely orphanages we do recognise that they are still necessary for the adequate care, both physical and moral, of Indian children from isolated homes, from destitute homes, from homes and reserves where moral conditions are questionable, and of Indian children who have no parents.

We protest against any curtailment of the Residential School policy, as carried out in the areas which we serve today, in the interests of the improved Day School for the following reasons:

(1) The nomadic character and seasonal occupations of many of the Indians, which makes regular attendance at the day School impossible.

(2) The impossibility of giving the Indian the type of education, which is essential to his earning a living and competing in the labor market, in the improved school as compared with the Residential School with its specialized staff.

(3) An increasing proportion of pupils are children of graduates and are by long odds the most promising material for developing leadership among the native people, and they will be shut out of the Residential Schools by a rigid enforcement of compulsory Day School attendance.

Of 558 Indian pupils in Grade VIII. in Canada 204 are in Residential Schools. Among the 94 taking High School work 67 are in the Residential Schools and 47 of these are in the schools under our auspices.
RESOLUTIONS ADOPTED BY CONFERENCE OF INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL PRINCIPALS, OF THE UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA HELD AT TORONTO JAN. 29-FEB. 1, 1934.

RE: RELATIONSHIPS WITH OTHER RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS.

WHEREAS it is not the policy of The United Church of Canada to solicit pupils from homes which are affiliated with any other denomination;

WHEREAS there are always some parents, however, who appreciate the privileges afforded by our schools and desire to obtain them for their children;

AND WHEREAS in several recent cases we feel that the decisions of the Department of Indian Affairs, in regard to refusal of admission of children of parents who have at some time been affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church, have been unsatisfactory;

BE IT RESOLVED: THAT we request the Secretaries to keep this matter before the Department of Indian Affairs and also take such steps as may be necessary to secure the co-operation of the other Protestant Churches in presenting the case to the Government;

AND THAT in cases where the religious affiliation is not clear ample opportunity should be given to the Principals of both denominations to state their case before the application is recommended by the Agent or considered by the Department;

AND THAT the Principals be requested forthwith to supply the Secretary with all information concerning cases which are pending.

CHURCH DOESN'T WANT INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS

Ask Government Not to Take Present System Out of Missions' Hands

Hearing that the Canadian government intends to inaugurate a system of day schools on Indian reserves, rather than encourage the Indian residential school system conducted by church organizations, the United Church of Canada has sent through its department of Indian missions a request that the government do not "slacken up" on the residential schools.

In their appeal officials of the United Church of Canada point out that trachoma and tuberculosis, prevalent among Indians, may not receive as efficient treatment in the residential schools as in the day-schools.

They further seek to have the residential school system continued and encouraged because "it is a question for full citizenship, that it develops moral fibre and Christian character and encourages the teaching of native arts and industry."

These are the words of Rev. Kenneth Macdonald, head of the United Church home mission department, who told The Star today that the nomadic character and seasonal occupations of the Indian people would prevent successful working of a day-school system.

How seriously did the United Church of Canada take the situation? The Star learns, that for the first time in its history a conference of all the principals of the residential schools was held last weekend in Toronto to prepare the appeal.

My dear Mr. Ross:

Re: Belanger Case.

I am in receipt of your communications concerning this case and wish to express my personal opinion that it would be very unwise to receive these children into your School until such time as the Department has given a final ruling on the matter. While I am convinced that they are not justified in the attitude which they have taken up to date, nothing is to be gained by presuming that the ultimate outcome of the negotiations will be favorable to the desires of the parents.

I found it rather difficult when I was discussing this question with officials of the Department of Indian Affairs in Ottawa last week to answer the question as to why the United Church was so interested in securing the attendance of these three children when there are, according to their information, several Protestant children of school age on the Reserve who are not in residence and therefore not receiving any education.

I discussed the matter with two or three men in the Department, including the Deputy Superintendent General, and I am convinced that they are sincerely trying to be just and fair in the decisions made where controversy arises concerning whether children should be placed in Protestant or Roman Catholic Schools.

It is quite clear to me from my experience in this case that we have been handicapped in the past by the fact that Principals of our Schools have tried to make their representations directly to Ottawa without having the influence of the whole Church behind them, while the Roman Catholics are thoroughly organized and the man who approaches the Government on any question - even though it be the matter of the admission of a single child - speaks with the authority of the whole communion.

I am not writing in this vein to indicate that I have given up protesting against the rulings which have already been made in the Belanger case, but to assure you that even if the final decision is against us, we will have done our duty when we placed the indisputable facts before the
Government. The suggestion of the Agent that he should resort to courts of law or to the use of the Mounted Police, in order to force these children into a Roman Catholic School, is simply ridiculous and should be completely ignored.

MEMO FOR FILE:

Letter of May 8th, addressed to Rev. Mr. Beaton, was written in view of the following paragraph contained in Mr. Beaton's letter of April 24, 1934, on File 1-1-3:

"Rightly or wrongly, there is a growing feeling on the part of our missionaries and their representatives on the Board that the Government plans to take away from the Missionary Societies of the Churches the right to nominate teachers for Indian Day Schools. This feeling is very pronounced and exceedingly vocal over our whole British Columbia Conference. We had before us a very strong resolution which was passed by the British Columbia Conference last May. After due consideration, the Committee recommended a resolution which is copied here-with, and it was unanimously adopted by the Board:

"That we re-affirm our conviction that it is in the interests of both the educational and missionary work on Indian Missions that the Church should retain the right to nominate teachers for Indian Day Schools, and that the Secretaries be asked to call a Conference with other Churches engaged in Indian work, with a view to making representations to the Department of Indian Affairs asking for assurance that no infringement of this right is contemplated.

"We further recommend that the teachers nominated should possess the following qualifications:

(1) Must be missionary minded.
(2) Must have adequate professional qualifications.
(3) Must be old enough to appreciate the problems involved in living on an Indian Reserve.
(4) Must be able to work harmoniously with others.
(5) Must, preferably, be members of the United Church of Canada."

Mount Elgin Residential School, Muncey, Ont.-

Annex Building:
- Finish senior classroom.- This includes floors, walls, ceiling, painting, blackboard, &c.
- Ten-tent ceilings in junior and intermediate classrooms.
- Hardwood floors in junior and intermediate classrooms.
- Finish halls.
- Check heating plant

Main Building:
- Installation of jacket heater and hot water tank, adequate for pupils and staff.
- Electric refrigerator room.
- Toilet accommodation in dormitories.
- Larger capacity electric pump.- (present pump overloaded; hopelessly inadequate in case of fire.)
- Overhaul heating plant.
- Remove partitions between present senior classroom and boys' reading-room, converting enlarged room into auditorium, with chair seats.
- Remodel pupils' diningroom and kitchen.
- Paint all woodwork and windows outside.

Barns:
- Repair and paint all roofs, at present rusting badly.

We are aware that the Architect of the Department has it in mind to remodel the whole interior of this main building at Muncey. We do not see the necessity of this but believe that, with the changes and improvements suggested and a normal sum spent on repairs annually, the present building can be made quite adequate, - unless it is the desire of the Government to greatly increase the number of pupils.

Norway House Indian Residential School, Man.-
- Remodel and refurnish kitchen, with the exception of the stoves.
Re-cover diningroom tables and provide new benches.

Install a steam-pressure plant for hot water and laundry purposes.

New roof for school verandah; present roof leaking badly in all directions.

Fill all cracks on outside with oakum or putty, and paint the whole exterior, including roof.

Refurnish staff bedrooms with proper beds; at present using same type of cots provided for children.

Purchase 50 new mattresses for children's beds.

These are imperative needs. The Department should also look forward to enlarging and improving the present outside classroom at Norway House, so as to provide teaching accommodation for both teachers and leave the present classroom in the main building as an auditorium.

In this connection, I would also suggest that serious consideration be given to uniting the teaching of the children from the Reserve with those in residence, bringing the whole programme of education on the Reserve under the direction of the Principal of the school.

Brandon Residential School.-

There is another spring, 600 yards farther up the hill, which even in this especially dry summer, has maintained a steady flow of good water. It would be an inexpensive matter to extend the lines to tap this source.

God's Lake.- New Day School.-

Morley Indian Residential School, Alta.- Furnishings for the new wing at present in course of erection.

Change Is Made In Indian Work

Dr. Barner Resigns and Home Mission Committees Take Over Task of Supervision

An important change in the administration of the work of the United Church in Canada, among the Indians in this province and elsewhere, becomes effective at the present time.

Up to the present the supervision of the work of the United church among the Indians has been under the direction of Rev. Dr. Arthur Barner, who for earlier years was in charge of the mission for the Methodist church of Canada, which always took a keen interest in the welfare of the native people.

Dr. Barner has now reached the age for retirement and has given up active work. A change has therefore been made in the manner of supervision and in future the care of the Indian missions in the province will be the direct duty of the home mission committees.

The work of the United church for the Indian people in the Manitoba conference is larger than in any other conference of Canada, Manitoba being closely followed by British Columbia with almost third. In the Manitoba conference approximately $50,000 is expended annually on the work, of which slightly more than one-half comes from the federal government.

The list of Indian missions which are 16 in number in this conference includes: Falcon Lake, God's Lake, Island Lake, Nelson House, Norway House, Oxford House, Little Grand Rapids, Berens River, Fisher River, Pikan-geehi, Portage la Prairie, Long Plains, Indian Springs, and the Portage and Brandon residential schools. At Norway House the church has a residential school.

Dr. J. A. Cormie, superintendent of missions in the conference, will visit each these places as possible during the present year.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of January 24th, addressed to Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

I note your request for certain information with respect to the administration of Indian schools.

1. My answer to your first question is based on the assumption that the question itself relates to the administration of Indian day schools and not to Indian residential schools. I may state that it has never been found possible to evolve a policy of uniform application throughout the Dominion, with respect to housing accommodation for teachers at Indian day schools. Where such schools are established close to white settlements, cities, towns or villages, teachers in charge, particularly female teachers, prefer to secure board and lodging in the white settlements, and, in these cases, no accommodation is provided for teachers at the schools. In the outlying districts of the Dominion, accommodation for the teacher is usually provided and in most cases forms part of the school, itself. The furniture, fuel and general supplies are provided by the Department. In a number of schools, the teachers in charge live in homes provided by the denominations or the religious orders to which they belong. If the teacher is the sole occupant of such a house, fuel is provided by the Department.

2. In reply to the second question, I may state that Section 10 of the Indian Act reads as follows:

"Every Indian child between the full ages of seven and sixteen years who is physically able shall attend such day, industrial or boarding school as may be designated by the Superintendent General (Minister) for the full periods during which such school is open each year; provided that where it has been made to appear to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General (Minister) that it would be detrimental to any particular Indian child to have it discharged from school on attaining the full age of sixteen years, the Superintendent General

(Minister ...

Hazelton, B. C.
(Minister) may direct that such child be detained at school for such further period as may seem to be advisable, but not beyond the full age of eighteen years, and in such case the provisions of this section with respect to truancy shall apply to such child and its parents, guardians or persons with whom such child resides during such further period of school attendance."

Indian pupils who have obtained creditable standing on their Entrance Examinations and who are physically fit are eligible, from year to year, for departmental tuition grants. These tuition grants enable a number of Indian pupils to proceed with the regular high school studies or, if they so prefer, with courses of vocational instruction. In a limited number of cases, grants are also given to encourage Indian pupils who have graduated from high school to proceed with professional courses, Law, Medicine, Nursing, etc.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

You will remember writing me on August 30th that the officer in charge of the Treaty payment trip had reported that the Indians of certain districts of Northern Manitoba had very little knowledge of English. I wrote to Dr. Cormie, our Superintendent, asking him to draw the attention of the school teachers to the situation, and at the same time I expressed the opinion that the children probably knew a little more English than they would be willing to admit to a stranger. I am, however, in receipt of the following from Dr. Cormie:

"The report which goes forward by today's mail may throw a little light on this whole problem. It is perfectly true as you say that some children know a little more English than they would be willing to admit to a stranger, but the conditions under which education is carried on on the reserves make it impossible to do very much in the way of teaching English or anything else. A small enrollment, the irregularity of attendance, the equipment in the schools, to say nothing of the attitude of the people generally toward the education of their children, all contribute to make satisfactory educational work difficult, if not impossible. In addition to all this, there is no reason why they should learn English as far as their social contacts go, since English is never used on the reserve.

"I will, of course, write to our teachers, though I know that they are doing the best they can."

In addition, Dr. Cormie asks us to draw your attention to the urgent need of doing something to meet the educational requirements of the Indians of the Island Lake reserve. There are about 150 children of school age for whose education there has been provided a dingy log building, with seats for 18 children. Dr. Cormie was good enough to send us a couple of photographs of the type of equipment in use in these schools, which I am sending to you. They are taken outside for the purpose of photography. I think that better seating facilities would indicate to the Indians that the Government was really
interested in their education.

I know you have many problems and I hesitate to add to them, but there are some things that I think should be drawn to your attention. Someone, I think, described the ideal university as "a log, with a student on one end and Mark Hopkins on the other." Well, here is a picture with four students alongside of it, but no Mark Hopkins. Dr. Comrie says this log was actually in use in one of the schools in Northern Manitoba that he visited.

Sir:

Referring to Departmental letter of 27th ultimo,
I have the honor to state that the entire Indian population at River's Inlet is 109; of these about 15 are of school age.

There is no schoolbuilding or missionary at this place. The summer village of these Indians, where they stay most of the time and have their best houses, is close to salt water, but about a quarter of a mile below the Reserve, on land belonging to a salmon canning company. Here the Methodist Mission have secured the lease of a plot of ground. It seems that the school ought to be built at or near this place.

Experience teaches that it would hardly be wise to leave an Indian graduate of an Industrial School, especially if he is a member of the same band, in complete charge of a school. Personally I have no knowledge of the applicant, David Bernard; he may be exceptionally fitted for the work.

If the Department is ready to build a school and pay a teacher, the Methodist Mission might be willing to supervise the school and keep a missionary here. The Indians here are in a primitive state, and have a poor reputation morally.

When I hear from the Department again in this matter I might write to the Chairman of the Port Simpson District of the Methodist Church to find out what the mission would do.
All the land on the River's Inlet Reserve is held in common; no subdivisions have been made. Very little is under cultivation and the climate is humid. If David Bernard is a member of the band, I should not think the other members would object if a piece was set aside for him.

Sir:

I beg to report that at the head of Rivers Inlet lives the Gwekano Indians, 37 in number, on the Katit reserve. Year ago the Methodist Church had a Missionary at this place. The Mission house and Church burned down, and the work was discontinued.

Now I have a letter from Rev. D.S. Osterhout, Superintendent of Indian Missions of the United Church, saying that the Church intend to place a missionary-teacher here, asking the Department to grant salary to the teacher, etc. The number of children below 16 years of age is 26, some of these being at the residential school at Alert Bay. It would be well if a good white man could be placed here, as the Indians are somewhat demoralized.

There is no village on this reserve. The old one consisting of smoke-houses burned down a year ago, and the Indians now generally live in houses below the reserve belonging to the B.C. Packers Ltd., The Pacific Mills Ltd., have bought the timber, and proceeds of this sale coming to the Indians should be ample to build a new modern village, if they were so minded. This is Katit reserve No. 1.

Until the site of a new village is located, and assurance obtained of one being built, it is not thought advisable to build a school house. It may be possible to rent a suitable building from the British Columbia Packers Ltd. The Church is anxious to get the work started with the least possible delay; and the main consideration for the Department would be the ability to grant teacher's salary.

Yours obediently,

Dear Sir,

There has been consideration correspondence between our Board in Toronto and your Department at Ottawa and the Indian Agent at Alert Bay, Mr. Todd, concerning the little Reserve at Takush, B.C., where there are less than 50 Indian men, women and children and where there are insufficient children to make possible anything like a respectable school.

Two other small tribes have been mentioned with which the Takush tribe might be persuaded to amalgamate, namely, Blunden Harbour and River's Inlet - the latter familiarly known as the O-wee-kee-no tribe. Their old village of smoke houses was burned down a few years ago completely, and I have heard that there is a possibility that a fine stand of spruce timber on the Katit Reserve which belongs to the O-wee-kee-no people may be sold to the Pacific Mills Co., for the considerable sum and that the proceeds might be used for the construction of a new village, more modern and better placed than the old village on the river bank.

In my opinion, if the Takush people could be persuaded by Mr. Todd to move to that location, it would be much more desirable than to Blunden Harbour, and it might be possible that when arrangements are made for the building of the new village, perhaps by the Pacific Mills Co., that a small school might be erected with accommodation for 20 or 25 children and for a missionary-teacher at the same time. The Methodist Church, now merged in the United Church of Canada, had to my knowledge a mission among these people at the head of River's Inlet over forty years ago and we should be very happy to co-operate in any possible way if conditions are so improved as to make possible some missionary and educational work among them again.

I enclose you herewith three pictures - one illustrating the destruction of the old town by fire and the other one of the buildings, also burned down, in which some of the tribesmen lived a few years ago. The third picture shows a number of the O-wee-kee-no people at the head of the inlet with old Capt. Oliver and one of his helpers sitting in the centre of the group. Unless something is done for these people at an early date the destruction of disease
and intemperance will have finished its work.

I shall be glad to have these snaps returned as I wish to use them when I proceed to Toronto the latter part of this month.

With very kind regards,

I remain,

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir,

Very Reverend F.M. Bunoz, O.M.I., is perfect Apostolic of the Yukon. His residence is Prince Rupert. His jurisdiction extends from the 54th Parallel northward west of the mountains on the mainland, but includes Queen Charlotte Islands and Fort George. This is his diocese. He is not a bishop, but may be addressed as such.

Regarding Indian schools in his diocese.

There is a building at Stewart Lake almost ready to open. He is inclined to open it if the amount contained in this year's estimates for Atlin School and the Babine could be applied to the support of the Stewart Lake. I have told him that we could switch the grant to the Atlin School and the grant for salaries and support of the Babine Schools, but could not switch the amount for the Babine School building. That next year we might give him a larger grant but I am not favourable to establishing a school at Stewart Lake permanently. He himself is favourable to the permanent establishment of a school in his diocese at Fraser Lake on the line of the Grand Trunk Pacific. He will write his decision to build the Babine school or switch the grant to Stewart Lake when he returns to Prince Rupert. Hold the matter in the meantime.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your communication of July 24th ult., I must say that I regret very much that long delay with regard to the erection of the Fraser Lake Indian school but I suppose the Department can't help it under prevailing circumstances; Remember, however, that the railway is getting close to Fraser Lake now and it will reach that place next summer.

During the meantime and providing it would not cause unnecessary delay in the erection of the boarding school due the Indians by specific contract, I would be very glad to see day schools established at Babine, Stewart's Lake and Hagwelget. These are three important places especially Babine and Stewart's Lake where you could find houses to rent, which could do for temporary dayschools. The salary of the teachers however must be up to the standard of the district. Here at Prince Rupert the Lady Teachers are getting $100.00 a month. I don't think that any competent person would accept to work in earnest for Indian children for less than the above amount. I hope, therefore, the Department will understand the importance of paying decent salaries in order to secure immediate and good work in the schools to be established. I may add in concluding, that all the Indians of that region are clamoring for schools, they want to read and write and the new white settlers show amazement at the fact, the Indians have no schools up to the present date.

Very respectfully,

E.M. BUNOZ, O.M.I. P.a.

Rev. Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant in further reference to the opening of temporary day schools at Babine, Stuart's Lake and Hagwelget.

In reply I beg to say that if there are temporary buildings available at Babine and Stuart's Lake the Department is prepared to make a grant for the teachers' salaries and also to supply the necessary school material. However, the salary mentioned by you $100. a month, is more than the Department pays at any point in British Columbia. As to the salaries, much would depend upon the qualifications. Presumably it would be almost impossible to get teachers with proper professional qualifications for these inland districts, but it may be possible for you to nominate teachers, who, if they have not the professional qualifications may nevertheless be competent to conduct the work at these day schools.

With regard to Hagwelget, a school was conducted at Roche Deboule, but was closed sometime ago owing to the fact that the Rev. Father Godfrey's time was so taken up with his Mission work that he found it impossible to give any attention to the day school. Father Godfrey informed the Inspector that he hoped to obtain an assistant and Mr. Green was then advised that in this event the Department would be pleased to have this school re-opened.

The Department will take up in the meantime, with the respective Indian Agents, the question of securing temporary buildings.

Rev. E.M. Bunoz, O.M.I.,

Sir:

To-day I received a letter of H. Father Wolfe. In this letter he announces me that my salary will probably start with the 1st of August and that there will be a raise of salary. It seems to say these two tidings are very welcome, and I will do my best to make this school a success.

In re-arranging the correspondence between you and Mr. Van Dyk I see that the teacher's salary is paid quarterly, so that the 30th of September will be next pay-day. If it is the same to you, would you please be so kind and send my salary to me? As, on account of the nearly total failure of crops in my district (Chilcotin, Alberta) I could not collect the wages due me by different farmers, and so I had no money to take her with me. If you send the money to me, I will have to sign the check first and then send it to her; and where the mail goes only twice a month from here and the mail route to my post-office in the Chilcotin district is not very well arranged, it might take another month before she can come and it would be too cold then to travel those forty miles between Vanderhoof and Fat H. James. Moreover, if my wife were here, I could do several things I am planning.
in connection with the school and of which I will talk below.

My family will need only 50 dollar for railway expenses; about 33 dollar from Macleod to Vanderhoof for my wife and about 17 dollar for a half fare ticket for my oldest daughter; the other two go free. I send my wife my last ten-dollar bill for travelling expenses on the road, as food, one might say in Calgary etc. If it is not too much trouble to write the check for my salary on my wife's name, I will be very much obliged to you. Her address is:

Mr. A. K. J. Okon Ochoniy
Alderville (Macleod District)
Alberta

I am planning the following things for the school:
As soon as my wife is here and takes over the cooking, I will start a second school in the evening for the adults. Several adults want to come to school and I think it will be best to make two schools, one for the smaller boys and girls, those who come to school now, and the (probably evening) school for the grown-ups, big boys and girls and grown-up people. I have been inquiring and I think I can count on a floating number of between 20 and 30, sometimes over 30, as in the two months of December and January. There is some Indians who have big children at school now and who want to come themselves. Will keenly they are and better they will learn.

I intend moreover to start a separate class of music for all there (above 10 years old) who have good voices and like music, this class to be held probably on Saturday morning.
It will not be necessary to say that, if I intend to do these things, it is with the implied condition that you approve of these plans. I know that these plans are far-reaching, but nine years of teaching in the Old Country (4 at a public school and 5 at a boarding school) gave me a liking for teaching and I want to honor the position I accepted.

I enclose herewith a requisition for 3 dozen of lead-pencils for the grown-up school; I do not intend to let them work with ink, as I want to be practical before everything and most of the Indians do not carry fountain-pens, but most of them have or can get a pencil and so it will be better to let them get handy with pencils. There are lots of blank drawing-books left and I will make lines on these and let them use these as scrubbers.

Of course, I can not start any of these things before my wife is here. The reason I would like you to send my whole salary is because things are so much cheaper in Mackled than here and she can buy what she needs for her and the children and ship it up here.

I am still doing the cooking and intend to keep it up until my wife comes. It takes lots of time, of course. For instance, to cook the beans well, I have to start cooking them at about 7 o'clock in the morning, after they have been soaking in water overnight. The meal of the children consists of a plateful of soup (rice-soup one day, bean-soup the other), a cup of tea and two crackers. You see there is not much variety in the menu, but my wife will do both
better, of course. The cost per child per day until now has been about 5 cents, for these three weeks. Next mail I shall send the bills in duplicate, as requested.

Enclosed please find the attendance report for these three weeks. I do this because I have seen in your letter of the 21st of July to Mr. Van Dyl that "monthly reports have to accompany quarterly requisition for salary" and I would like to have my family here as soon as possible, on account of the cold weather next month (the long drive through the cold for my children) my planned evening school and the cooking (not forgetting I feel very lonesome without my wife and children) and I can not get them here before I touch my salary.

In the hope you will grant me the favor I asked,

I remain,

Sir,

Yours respectfully,

Mr. Oka Ochonig
Teacher

Report of the Indian School Garden at Small Lake B.C.

This garden was composed of three patches, each patch in a different soil:

a) Pure clay, worked three times, once with the plow, two times with the spade; last year, 1915.

b) About 4 inches of leaf-mould, mixed with about 4 inches of clay. This ground was broken in the spring of 1915, put in clover without manure, plowed again last spring and pulverized with the hoe.

c) About 8 inches of leaf-mould, with very little sand. This ground was worked two times with the spade in 1915.

In a) were sown: peas, onions, parsley and beans. Everything came up fine, but owing to the dry weather the onions died off. The beans did very well, but were killed by night-frost. The parsley was good. The peas did very well and gave an abundant crop.

In b) were sown: peas, parsnip, kale, cabbage, onions, sage, cress, carrots, squash and radishes. The squash was killed by the night-frost, but the other vegetables did very well, excepted the cabbage, and gave excellent results.

In c) were sown: carrots, beets, turnips, onions and lettuce. This piece proved to be an excellent one. I shall the pleasure of showing to the Indian Agent, Mr. McLean, carrots weighing 2 lbs.
and turnips weighing 18 lbs; also there were seed onions which grew to a bigger size than some grown from onion sets.

In short I believe to be justified in calling the garden a success. I tried as much as I could to show the Indians how a well-worked piece of land produces more than a badly worked one. I made the following experiment: I broke a piece of ground with the spade in the spring and put in some onions and turnips of the same kind I put in ground I worked last fall and showed them the difference in growth and production. I did this to show them the advantages of fall-working of the land in our semi-arid climate. When they wondered how I had better garden-huck than they had in the same soil, I told them because I worked the land in the fall and waited it well so as not to disturb the land in the spring and keep the moisture in. Last year's fall they found it funny to see me work the land; but I am very glad to state that (a thing which never happened before) this fall quite a number of them made their land ready now instead of wasting till spring, as was their custom, and I am sure next year's crop will show them I gave them good advice and example.

I must add that the conditions this year were very unfavorable, as we did not have any rain after July 3rd, and we had seven night frosts on August 15th, 16th and 17th.

[Signature]
M. M. Okon O'Konn
Teacher

February 2nd 1917

My dear Sir,

The acknowledgment of the aboriginal Indians' right to a school and the generous support of the said school a few years ago was the good work of the administration of which you, sir, are the head. As I was the founder and manager of the said school, I had several opportunities to deal with your important Department.

The fair treatment I have then received was not the least encouragement that lead me to assume the task of building and directing a boarding-school at Fort St. James B.C.

It is in behalf of this last institution that I am addressing you these lines.

Much to my surprise Mr. McMillan, Indian agent for this district, advises me that the Department wants the Stuart Lake Indian Day School to be closed immediately after the boarding-school has been started.

If such a plan were immediately followed I could not do justice to all pupils nor would I economize any of the Department's money.
To do justice to all pupils, both boys and girls, must have their own apartments for class and manual labor, for eating, sleeping, recreation etc. This would require a very spacious building, and during these war-time (the Government having declined to actually fulfill its pledge of erecting here such a spacious building, that might cost $50,000) the ecclesiastical authorities have done the next best thing. According to means and time we have erected a school which is not sufficiently large to fully accommodate both sexes.

Therefore I beg of you, Sir, to allow me to keep open the Heart Lake day school for girls, while boys will all attend the Boarding School, so Indian parents are more eager even to have their girls than their boys educated.

To attempt to accommodate both boys and girls in the actual building would I am afraid not only compromise the success of the work, but instead of lowering expenses it would increase them. For instance twenty girl boarders would cost a good deal more to the Department than the small teacher's salary of $800 a year and the small amount expended for fuel and lunch. The lunch to the day-school pupils will be even less expensive owing to the fact that no boys shall share in it. To tell the pupils and the Department's interests will, I am convinced, be better served in the time being by keeping open the Heart Lake Day School for some time, along with the new Boarding-School of the same place.

May I hope, Dear Sir, that after you have weighed
the justice of my demand you shall see your way through in granting it.

I remain, dear sir,

Yours truly,

J. Allan O.M.S.
Principal

REPORT ON OKANAGAN AGENCY FOR MONTH OF DECEMBER 1937.

SCHOOLS

As there were a number of children on Spallumcheen I.R.No.1 at Salmon River whose parents were extremely impoverished the clerk (Miss Milne) and I purchased sufficient toys, etc., to brighten things up for them and Miss Milne attended to the details on the reserve. A number of toys were received from the Coldstream Anglican Girls Club which were sent to Westbank Reserve where there were a number of children for whom Christmas meant very little. Thus, with the Missionary, Father Collins, attending to other points, practically every reserve in the agency was taken care of so far as the children were concerned.

James Coleman,
Indian Agent.

"ALL HALLOWS"

INDIAN MISSION SCHOOL, YALE, B. C.

REPORT FOR 1886.

As Secular Education is not the primary object of the Sisters' work in their school for Indians and Half-breed girls, only one examination has been attempted this year.

Before the midsummer vacation the Rev. R. Small, visiting the school in his capacity of Chaplain, kindly undertook to examine the children in the following subjects:

- Church Catechism, Holy Scripture, History, Arithmetic, Geography, Dictation and Reading. We quote from his report sent to the N. W. "Gazette," in August.

"The work produced betokened great pains and interest, and an effort on the part of all to do their best.

Scripture, as was right, pre-eminently took first place. The answers given by the elder class on this subject were clear and accurate. In the junior class it was at first a matter of difficulty to elicit audible answers, nor was this unnatural considering it was their first formal examination.

The progress made in History and Geography seemed fairly, even amongst the bigger girls, though there was more discrepancy in the reading.

Perhaps Grammar and Arithmetic are the subjects where there is most room for improvement.

The Writing and Dictation showed remarkable progress.

Three Indian girls were examined only in reading and religious knowledge, and very creditable specimens were shewn of their writing copied from print."

As domestic work in its various branches forms part of the girls' training, it is impossible for them to give more than four hours a day to lessons, but this is done with scrupulous regularity.

Needlework also receives special attention. The Indians take very readily to this part of their education. One of the pupils who is very skilful in making moccassins and gloves, has received orders for several pairs, and executed them most satisfactorily.

During the early part of the year the Sisters were much encouraged by the increase of the numbers in their school, but since the Autumn several pupils have of necessity been removed.

Two little girls who were inmates of the house during their mother's temporary absence have now returned to their home, but they continue to attend as day pupils. Another has gone out to service, and we hope that in her case the seed sown will, under the care of a kind mistress, bear some fruit.

Anxiety and disappointment have in some cases attended the Sisters' work, but calling forth as they should do an increase of love and patience, such troubles cannot be regarded altogether as misfortunes.

During the summer vacation, eleven children remained with the Sisters, spending part of the time at the little Mission House, Hope.

One drawback to the growth of the school is the continued want of funds. Half-breed girls have no friends to pay for them, and Indian parents are only able or willing to give very little towards the support of their children.

A subscription received by the Sisters last May in New Westminster, Vancouver, Moodyville, Victoria, have materially strengthened the maintenance fund for this year.

A special result of the Sisters' collecting tour shows itself in the improvement of the school room. The room was originally a kitchen, and it has required many persevering efforts to obliterate traces of Chinese labor from the floor and walls. A new window has been thrown out to admit light, an old store cupboard removed, and a few other alterations render the room more habitable, at least for present needs.
From S. Paul's Mission back to Lytton, to take train for Yale. Where I arrived on the morning of Wednesday the 13th.

The most deeply interesting part of my work soon after my arrival, was the examination of the girls' school carried on by the Sisters of All Hallows, in the old parsonage house, to which has been tacked on the hospital built when the C. P. R. was in course of construction.

No words of mine can express the intense interest attached to this work. I could speak of the careful and successful teaching; of the readiness and accuracy with which my questions were almost invariably answered; of the quickness of apprehension and the clear understanding of the subjects treated of in the examination; but what are all these compared with the conviction that could not but come home to my own heart, of the love, the trust, the patience of the Sisters; so devoted to their work, so fully answered by love and trust and quiet gentle obedience on the part of the children under their care.

The examination occupied the greater part of two days, the subjects of examination being the Catechism, a selected portion of the Old Testament (from the Call of Abraham to the last of the ten plagues), The Ministry of Our Lord, Grammar, History, Geography, Arithmetic, Reading, Dictation, Analysis, Parsing, Recitation, &c. I began my examination by a strict adherence to the text books given me by the Sister Superior, but I soon laid these aside and took up the examination just as I should do in any school which I might be called on to examine, and I was more surprised and gratified than I can say when I found the intelligent, ready, quick answers. The children themselves seemed to brighten up and look pleased when I laid aside the books and appealed to their intelligence rather than to their memories.

The afternoon of the second day, when several visitors were present, was given to singing, recitations, &c., and the specially pleasant task of giving prizes and rewards, which were so really merited.

In addition to their regular work in the education of Indian and half-breed girls, one of the Sisters has, at the urgent request of some of the residents in Yale, undertaken the charge of a few of their children, who come daily to school, and I know I do but express the feelings of the parents when I say that they are more than satisfied with the progress their children have made, not only in general knowledge, but also in the increased gentleness of demeanour and quietness of manner we all love to see so much in our daughters.

CHARLES T. WOODS,
Archdeacon of Columbia.

Sir,

Will you allow me the favour of bringing before your notice two several matters relating to Indian Affairs in this Province, and within the Town of New Westminster, wherein (I think) the assistance of the Department may be legitimately invoked in furtherance of the intellectual, industrial and physical improvement of three Indians who are being cared for by the Church of England?

(1) The School for Indian Girls, at Yale, under the management of the Sisters of All Nations.

As a result of the encouragement which the Department has already given us here, our accommodation is already now taxed to the utmost, and we are compelled to refuse all new applications. We have prepared plans for the extension of our premises with accommodation for twenty-five more boarders, and including a new schoolroom, and a play-room for wet weather, and bath rooms.

This extension is estimated to cost £5000 (£5000 or five thousand dollars). We have ourselves raised £2000 (£2000 or two thousand dollars) towards this, and, if the Department would contribute the balance, we would make a further effort to provide the sum necessary for fittings and furniture, probably another £300 (£300 or three hundred dollars).

The enlargement of our buildings, and the growth of our numbers makes it very desirable that there should be more land about the School. We have at present but three acres. An adjoining lot, consisting of about ten acres of grave land and orchard could be purchased. The same rate offered for it, but I think, on a definite offer, would take readily.

Will the Department consider the possibility of assisting us in this direction also?

I ought to remind you that the whole grant at present...
made by the Department is extended in Montana. The latter receive no salary whatever.

(2) Industrial School for Boys.

While schools are available for each work amongst girls as is progressing at Yale, we have not yet in the Church of England similar communities of men for agate work amongst boys. The former, consequently, is very much greater, and has hitherto been beyond our accomplishment. It is, however, equally important.

The government scheme of Industrial Schools has left untouched the whole district worked by the Church of England, viz., on the Fraser River from Yale to Lillooet, about 104 miles; on the Thompson River from Lytton to Ashcroft, about 50 miles; and on the Nicola River from Spence's Bridge to Battle's, about 40 miles. The school at Kamloops will be more than 50 miles from the nearest point in the Church of England District, and more than 100 miles from Lytton which is the centre of that District. We estimate the number of Indians in this District at between 2000 and 3000.

I venture, therefore, to press most earnestly upon the Department the need of such an Institution in this District.

Lytton, at the confluence of the Fraser and Thompson Rivers, armed by the natural situation of its soil only on account of its geographical position, but also because the Indians generally regard it as a kind of head-quarters to which they are in the habit of resorting. Two physicians reside there, and it is easy of access by our Medical Missionary who visits it almost invariably every week. I have the dead advantage of being very dry, but I have water rights there which would be available, although at present they are extremely bespattered upon by the C.P.R. and the townspeople.

(3) Medical Aid.

I have for some years been in correspondence with the Department on the subject of providing medical attendance for the Indians in our district throughout the whole of which no doctor has been needed excepting during the period of railway construction.
Last year I again brought the matter before the Superintendent in Victoria, and received from him a letter dated 19th May 1868 in which he undertook to bring my proposal before the Department "without delay," expressing his strong approval of it. Six months later, having heard nothing further from the Department, I engaged, on my own responsibility, a gentleman with double English qualifications who has now been nearly a year at work.

He resides at Yale for the advantage of the School, the health of which is my most anxious consideration at present, but he has inspected the whole district several times, and makes trips to Lytton & other populous villages at frequent intervals.

I am compelled to allow him the privilege of private practice amongst the whites because the stipend I am able to attempt provide him is altogether insufficient for his needs, but he might quite comfortably occupy himself wholly with Indians were we could afford it.

The contributions of the Indians themselves are not worth taking into account at present, but we are educating them to a sense of their responsibility in this respect.

Dr. Pearce's services are at the disposal of all Indians within his district, whether belonging to the Church of England or not. I have the honor to report that at the request of Bishop Selkirk I left Victoria on the 28th ultimo for the purpose of visiting with him the All Hallows School for Indians just at Yale.

I was much pleased upon my arrival to find the uniform proficiency in all departments evidenced by the careful organization of that establishment by the Rev. Superior, and those acting under her direction.

The school house recently built was a most necessary addition and was very much needed to accommodate, with healthful comfort, the number of children there provided for.

Underhill and myself had with you at Ottawa on Sept. 20th., in reference to an increase of the grant of $60.00 per head to our School for Indian Girls at Yale, B. C., you requested that I should forward a statement through the Superintendent at Victoria.

The School was started over twenty years ago, and is still under the Supervision of the Sisters of All Hallows Community. The Head Mistress is a Public School Teacher with Normal Training, and over twenty years experience in Prince Edward Island. There is a Matron, a Pupil Teacher, and two of the Sisters assist in Teaching and in the care of the Children, is evidenced from the remarkable fact that there have been no deaths in the school for seventeen years, and during that time only five deaths from illness developed in the School.

The two main reasons for asking for an increase are:

(1) The increased cost of living. In a statement prepared by the Letter Carriers some time ago, this increase in British Columbia was stated to be forty-seven per cent. The

$60.00 has had to be supplemented to a large extent for actual living expenses, and clothing is entirely supplied by Church organizations, mainly from the Women's Auxiliary.

The teaching of Special features makes additional expenses. The Policy of the School is undergoing a change. In the early days the Homes from which the Children were drawn, were such that it was wise to train them for Domestic Service, and many had no Homes at all. Now there is a great improvement in the Indian Homes in the District. It is a gratifying fact that seven Children at present in the School are Children of former pupils. Except in exceptional cases they should be trained to go back to their homes and be able if necessary to earn their own living, and be a help to their families.

General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, again urging compliance with the request previously made.

In connection with the application, it may be stated that while it is true that the cost of living has materially increased - perhaps to the extent of 50% within recent years - such increase affects chiefly those institutions and persons who have to purchase everything or almost everything worn and consumed. This can hardly be said to be the case with the institution in question, for the reason that much of the garden truck

truck, if not, indeed, all of it, so expensive to the city consumer, is grown on the school grounds. This food supply, with the poultry etc. raised from year to year goes far to supplement the school's funds. Then again, the Indian girls, who do most of the actual work of the institution, bring about a considerable saving in the matter of labor which, especially in these times of high wages, must help out materially the school's finances.

Another point on which stress is laid by the management is that were the grant to the institution increased so as to bring it within the scope of an industrial school much more effective work could be done and the usefulness of the institution enhanced. I rather fail to see how any more good could be had thereby than is now actually the case in the boarding schools throughout the superintendency where all the usual household duties, including the useful arts of knitting and sewing, are regularly taught to the pupils therein domiciled. In view of the circumstances mentioned I do not see any way clear to support the application.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent, B. C.

P.S. Were the request granted all boarding schools in the Superintendency would expect similar treatment.
