Easter Carol

Joy of joys! He lives, He lives,
Jesus, Who salvation gives!
Rising, in the earl gloom,
Lo! His glory fills the tomb;
All the earthly guards are fled
From the Mansion of the Dead;
Listen, for the Angels say,
See the place where Jesus lay.

Enter, if ye seek for Him!
There the light shall not be dim;
At His head, and at His feet,
Mark the clothes and winding sheet,
All in sacred order seen,
In the grave where Christ has been;
So He left it, all was done,
Ere the rising of the sun.

Earth was trembling—Jesus rose,
Calmly passing through His foes;
Death hath no dominion now,
Captain of Salvation Thou.

Jesus, Conqueror of the grave,
Jesus, Master, strong to save,
Teach our hearts the unearthly bliss
Of a purer world than this!

Bid the powers of darkness fly,
Shew to us the shining way,
Us the children of the day;
Onward, onward, in the road,
Radiant with the Light of God,
God the Father and the Son,
And the Spirit, ever One!
Garden Thoughts.

Every Spring the Holy Spirit teaches us by our gardens a great many things about the resurrection, and the joy of the Eternal Easter.

He shews us that even the tiniest seed, or root, or bulb in our gardens, if it has life in it, rises again, even if we planted it so long ago that we have quite forgotten about it.

We learn to understand in this way, that, if we were given Life in our Souls at Baptism, and the Life has been growing in us through the other means of grace, when our bodies die and are buried, they will rise again at the Resurrection Day.

We see, too, that the plants which come up in our gardens do not look at all like the little plain brown seeds, or bulbs, which we planted. They each have their own body, so that we know them all when we see them, but what a beautiful body it is!

So it is with people, who are God's flowers. We can only see, perhaps, what is just on the outside of their lives, and they may seem to us very dull, and plain, and uninteresting; but God can see into their hearts, and He sees the beautiful soul that is growing so quietly all hidden away, just a secret which He alone shares. Then in the Resurrection day He gives that soul a body "as it pleaseth Him," a "beautiful body to a beautiful soul, or an ugly body to an ugly soul."

The Bible tells us that some will be more beautiful than others, for some souls have been growing more beautiful on earth, giving themselves up more every day to be made holy by the Blessed Spirit, coming closer to our Lord in the Sacraments, and trying every day to please the loving Father a little more.

That Life, which is our Lord's Life, "can never die"; what dies and is buried is only the outside, ugly part, while the true Life is set free then, waiting for its Resurrection body.

So St. Paul ends his wonderful teaching on the Resurrection by telling us to be very steadfast in all the duties God gives us to do. He does not call them "our work," but "the work of the Lord"; for he says that we know now that none of our work is "no use," so long as we do not try to do it all by ourselves, but ask and use the grace of our Lord.

Or, if we think of it in another way, every little duty faithfully done, every kind deed, or loving word is like a little seed sown in God's garden, and hidden until the Eternal Spring comes, when it will blossom and make glad God's beautiful garden for ever.

There are some who seem to have more suffering than anything else to bear, but they too, know that not one moment of their pain or sorrow is of "no use," for if they have borne it patiently for love of our Lord, who suffered so much for them, they may perhaps have the gladdest surprise of all in the Resurrection, when they see how God is glorified by

"The mighty harvest
From small seeds of pain."

The Year Round.

CHRISTMAS, 1909.

We began our decorations in good time this year, even the Christmas Tree was standing in the Schoolroom by Christmas Eve, with its wide-spread expectant branches, so that everything looked very bright and festive indeed.

After the children had gone to bed early, the older ones to get up for the Midnight Celebration, and the little ones to sleep peacefully and dream of their "stockings," we elders settled down to finish our own Christmas preparations, when, very unexpectedly, a welcome visitor from far-away Japan arrived, just in time to join with us in the Great Christmas Feast. So those who had come from far, the East and West, met together where the fir trees beautified the place of God's Sanctuary at that snowy Christmas-tide!

Full of joy was all that Festival, but almost the gladdest part of all to the children (besides the services) was the beautiful Christmas Tree on St. John's Day.

Many kind friends had generously contributed all sorts of lovely things, dolls, toys, and useful gifts too for the children, besides
ALL HALLOWS' IN THE WEST.

In April we had to say goodbye to Miss Harris, after her years of loving service; but we wish her every joy in her new life, and hope we may have the pleasure of seeing her again from time to time.

In May we were all so grieved to hear of the Bishop's illness. He had always been so kind in visiting the School, and we were looking forward to seeing him amongst us again very shortly, for a Confirmation. But God ordered otherwise, and very soon we heard that our Bishop had entered into the rest of Paradise, of which he had so often spoken to us. Eager children bought little mountain searching for the first white trilliums, or brought little offerings of snowdrops from their gardens, to make a wreath for Sister Superior to take down for the Bishop's grave.

In June, Bishop Perrin of Columbia kindly came up to take the Confirmation in the little School Chapel, when four of our girls, Isabel, Flora, Rena, and May, were confirmed, and had their first Communion on June 12th.

The Bishop came into the schoolroom to say a few words to all the children after the Confirmation. He told them to try and remember these lines, as they would help them:

"I can't, can do nothing,
I'll try, can do many things,
I will, by the help of God, can do all things."

Everyone was very busy during the month of June, preparing for the school closing, for this year we were not simply going to have an ordinary programme of songs and recitations, but the children, under Miss Flower's direction, were learning a little Cantata called "Granny's Birthday."

Three "old girls," Emma, Bee, and Ada, came to stay for the great event, and another, Alice Macpherson, came just for a day or two before hand. It is one of our greatest pleasures to see the "old girls" back at the school again, to hear how well they have done, and to share their joy in all being together again. One of the ways in which they are always ready to be useful is in helping to pick cherries! They all feel quite at home up in the branches of the cherry trees!

The flowers were lovely this year, we had quantities of all sorts for the closing; roses, honeysuckles, daisies, and many other kinds, in spite of the gaps we feared we should have in the garden after

warm scarves, socks, caps, etc., for the older people.

How eagerly young eyes scanned the branches to try and see the names on dolls and toys, and what delight it was to find their own name on some specially beautiful thing!

Our Indian friends quite entered into the children's delight, and enjoyed their pretty toys almost as much as they did!

When it was all over poor old Chief Charlie from Squatetch, made a touching little speech to say how glad he was to come once again, for he felt so sad at home now, so many of his friends had died, and he was almost alone in his old age.

During the month of January, 1910, we were very busy as usual, but we had a rest from taking care of water-pipes for ours were frozen outside for six weeks. It was quite a change to feel that it did not matter how cold it might turn in the night if there would be no danger of boilers bursting, or taps having to be thawed out! True, we had to get all our water carried up from the brook, but that was something new, and children always like new things, so no one really minded that very much. We were so much better off than our neighbours, for no one else had such a convenient brook!

During February and March we had a great many snowstorms, and also an epidemic of influenza, so that we were very glad when April and May brought spring flowers and sunshine, and everyone was able to be out of doors again.

During Lent everyone tried very hard to fill our Missionary Box, several of the girls who had left school lately sent some money for it too, and though the last sums came rather late, yet we were able to give $30 altogether as our offering. We hope that this year more of the "old girls" will help us, so that we may be able to send more to help the Missions of the Church. Archdeacon Penrettah told us that Mission work ought to be especially an offering of love from women, for our Lord had done so much for woman, and her position in Christian lands to-day was the result of our Lord's teaching and example.

Easter was, as usual, a time of very great gladness, and though many voices were not very strong, after influenza, yet all tried their best to sing the joyful hymns and the other music of the Church Services.
the winter's frost.

Summer holidays are very busy times, indeed. First there is all the excitement of finding out who is going home, then packing suitcases, buying holiday clothes, and going to the station with a merry party to "see them off." Then those who are left behind settle down for their special holiday-making. They divide the lodgings between them and feel very important people!

The youngsters are generally spent in fruit picking, after the little daily duties are finished, but sometimes we all go down to the beach, for there is plenty of sand there, and large shady rocks, also wild flowers and berries.

There were some very nice pictures, as usual, and the "holiday children" enjoyed themselves very much. Five of them were "new girls," Lucy, Lizzy, Evelyn, Lulu, and Kitty. It kept us very busy taking care of them all, for they were very new to school ways.

In August the other girls came back from their homes, and every one had plenty to tell of all the things they had been doing. Grace had been away for her first real holiday this year, for Nellie's mother had kindly invited Grace and Emma to go home with her and spend their holidays in Chilmark. They enjoyed themselves very much indeed, everyone was so very good to them.

In September lessons began again, and everyone settled down for the new term.

In October another little girl came, Suzanne, Makura's little daughter. That made quite a party of very little ones, who had very happy times together, playing all sorts of games among themselves out of school hours.

Most of the children have been buying their gardens ready for the winter, and planting their bushes.

Everyone welcomed the All Saints Festival; the beautiful services making us realize more deeply our awareness of those who have gone before, and leading us on to fresh efforts, as we think of the "great cloud of witnesses," who are looking and praying that we too, may overcome as they did in the strength of God.

The snow was late in coming this year, but it was nice and mild, so that the garden did not suffer at all.

Then there were three blizzards, one after another, and after lessons had begun again, in February, the influenza began all over again too, but not so badly this time!

Monday, January 8th was perhaps the most eventful day of the whole month. It had been quite mild weather till then, but on Sunday the snow began falling fast, large soft flakes like feathers. In the night a gale rose, banging doors open, and driving the snow through the windows.
Several of the children's beds were covered with snow, and the little girl had a snowdrift over her, but it was all removed, and dry warm things put on before waking-up time came, or there would have been fine games of snowballing in the dormitory!

Later on in the day the thermometer fell about 40 degrees, and the gale changed into a blizzard, which lasted about five days, and was the worst we have had for eighteen years, it being 20 degrees below zero in town, they said.

On that Monday, Inspector Ditchburn, the new "Inspector of Indian Agencies," visited us for the second time, though he found it very cold work taking all his measurements, etc., in such weather. The results of his visit will be found mentioned elsewhere.

Naturally we were not free from water troubles in such conditions as these, but we fared so much better than our neighbours, that we could only feel thankful for all the water we had, even if it did come down in rather inconvenient "fluids" sometimes!

At the end of February, though the snow is still deep on the ground, and piled up many feet high round the houses, and though the river has been frozen over (all but one little green strip), for five weeks, yet there is a feeling of spring in the air. Seed lists are being consulted, and gardens planned, while tomatoes are being started on top of the plate-warmer in the kitchen!

We have Lent before us, but there is the joy of Easter to hope for at the end; just as there is the joy of the last great Easter set before us, when the Lent of this world is over for ever.

Sermon before the Consecration of the Bishop.

ST. JOHN'S CHURCH, YALE, B.C. (July 24th, 1910.)

"As My Father has sent Me, even so send I you."

To-morrow will be a day of great importance, for something will take place which has never happened before in the history of the Church in this Diocese.

To-morrow a Bishop will be consecrated for the Diocese of New Westminster, in St. Paul's Church, Vancouver.

Some time ago we met in the Synod and chose a Bishop. We chose him, but still we have no Bishop, for our choice did not make him a Bishop. The other Bishops of the Church approved of him, but even that did not make him a Bishop. He will not be a Bishop until to-morrow.

Then the Archbishop has to travel two thousand miles, and the other Bishops have to leave their Dioceses, the Service of Consecration takes place, and he is made a Bishop of the Church of God; not a Bishop of New Westminster only, though he belongs to this place, and will minister in this Diocese, but he will take his place as a lineal descendant of the Apostles in the Church of God. To him the words of the text will be said, the words our Lord said to his Apostles when he made them apostles of His Church, "As My Father hath sent Me, even so send I you."

After His Resurrection, and before His Ascension, our Lord said these words to His Apostles, when He breathed on them and gave them the Holy Ghost.

That was not the same gift of the Holy Ghost as that which they received at Pentecost, but a special gift to enable them to fulfil their work as Apostles in the Church of God.

In the forty days before the Ascension, our Lord taught them about the Kingdom of God; but He never filled up the place of Judas (He left that for the Church to do), there were only eleven Apostles at the time of the Ascension.

Then, immediately afterwards, we read how the Apostles met to choose another to make up their number. They chose two who were witnesses with them of our Lord's Life and Resurrection, and then they prayed to God to show them which of the two He had chosen, and the lot fell on Matthias, then we read that he was numbered with the Apostles.

We never hear again of their casting lots, but we do read, after the death of St. James, that the Holy Ghost said "Separate me Barnabas and Saul for the work whereunto I have called them," then they laid their hands on them and they were called Apostles too, so there were thirteen Apostles then.
ALL HALLOWS IN THE WEST.

St. Paul had been chosen by God before he was even a Christian, but that call alone did not make him an Apostle then; he was made one by the Apostles, who laid their hands on him at the command of the Holy Ghost.

Some people say the Church of England is too narrow, but while we do not wish to condemn anyone else, we must hold fast to that which has been committed to us.

We have in the English Church what many others have not, perhaps they do not care to have it, perhaps they do not believe in it. But we have that which has been handed down to us for 1900 years from our Lord Himself.

He gave the power and the government of His Church to His Apostles, and they in their turn, handed it on to others. They did not, as we saw limit their number only to twelve, for Bishops were set apart in many cities, both by St. Paul and others, but the same authority was handed down to them.

Either we must believe that the government ordained by our Lord in His Church came to an end, or else that same government is in the Church today.

This last is what we believe, we maintain that our Bishops are the literal descendants of those who were first set apart by our Lord Himself.

So to-morrow another will be consecrated to take his place in the government of the Church of God.

It is not learning, it is not personal holiness, it is not experience, it is not age that can make a man a Bishop, but the solemn consecration by the other Bishops when the gift of the Holy Ghost is given, and he is made a literal descendant of these who were made Apostles by Christ, when He said to them "As My Father hath sent Me, so send I you."

It is Christ Who gives us all spiritual blessings. Our Baptism, our Confirmation, our Communions, all come from Him. We believe that beyond the Bishop, beyond the Priest who ministers to us in the Sacraments of the Church, stands Christ Himself, the Fountain of all Grace.

CLOSING DAY, (June 30th, 1910).

An ideal summer day! Bees and butterflies flitting about among the Acacia tree blossoms and flowers. Birds singing merrily—when they were not too busy among the huckleberries in Sister's garden. Our brook rushing noisily down from the mountain behind the Schools, to join the Fraser below, where perchance one sees the Indians threading their way up the river in their curiously carved canoes, laden with fresh salmon or some of their beautifully woven baskets.

In the Schoolroom with Sister Superior were assembled a large gathering, the Rev. H. J. and Mrs. Underhill, Mrs. Pugh (wife of the Archdeacon of Yale), the Rev. C. C. Croucher, some ladies from Emory, several friends from the village, including Mr. Dodd, accompanied by Judge Howie of New Westminster, who kindly presented the prizes and made a very happy speech at the close.

The schoolroom and stage were prettily decorated with a profusion of ferns, daisies, syringa, deutzia, and an archway of roses.

The programme opened with a very pretty "Wind Pril," followed by a grand march by the whole school. Then the Cantata entitled "Grammie's Birthday," which was intensely interesting and exceedingly well done by the children, the result of long and careful training by Miss Plover.

Eva, surrounded by all the children in their pretty pink dresses made a charming old gramme of eighty-one with her snowy hair, soft white shawl and lace cap, kindly designed by Mrs. Pugh.

The songs of "Greeting" to Grammie, the crowning her with flowers, Grammie's song to her children, and the soft "lullaby" at the close, with little Alice asleep on her knee, were particularly well suited to the children's voices and were sung with a sweet pathos, not often heard.

A Patriotic Song, the prize-giving, some speeches by the visitors and "God save the King" brought a very happy occasion to an end.
Then all went to the Dining Hall, where the tables had been tastefully decorated with maiden hair fern and flowers, and were laden with cherries, jellies and cakes, and other good things, which presided over by the Sisters, and surrounded by the happy faces of the children made a pretty scene that will never fade from the memory of those who had the privilege of joining in the closing of 1910.

E. M. Dickson.

A Christmas at Yale.

As one who has spent a Christmas at Yale, I will begin by saying how greatly I enjoyed it; this most peaceful happy time will not readily be forgotten.

Well, for some days before, there seemed to be a thrill of expectation in the air; preparations were going on for that wonderful Christmas tree—which was to dazzle the eyes and gladden the hearts of the Indian Children.

On Christmas Eve, we had a midnight Celebration of the Holy Eucharist; the music was beautifully sung by the children, whose sweet voices rang out in the magnificent words of the Service; and there we met our Lord, Who once more deigned to come to us.

There were several grown-up Indians present—one very feeble old woman had to be helped up to the Altar.

After Service we had a very early breakfast, and adjourned to bed.

On Christmas Morning the children came round to all the bedrooms singing a carol very sweetly, under the direction of Sister Marian. They had had the exquisite pleasure of opening their stockings, which, together with the breakfast, was a lengthy process.

As it was Sunday, we went to Matins at the Village Church.

We were sorry to miss the Vicar, who had been obliged to go one of his outlying parishes.

On our return we all had dinner together in the Dining Hall, which was very prettily decorated by the children, and we specially made two turkeys look very foolish, and several puddings vanished altogether. The children had dessert, and pulled crackers, and seemed to thoroughly enjoy themselves. We were all sorry that one little girl was ill, and had to spend her Christmas in bed.

In the evening we had Service in our own Chapel, and several Carols were sung.

CONFIRMATION.

Before we are confirmed we have to be Baptised, and come to years when one can choose right, and know right from wrong, and try to do better.

When we come to be confirmed we have to be really sorry for our sins, and try to lead better lives by teaching others to be good, and by being good ourselves.

When we go to be confirmed we are going to receive the seven-fold gifts of the Holy Ghost, though we do not see the Holy Ghost coming down and resting on the ones that are to be confirmed.

The wind is one of the types of the Holy Ghost—the wind can do mighty things and blows where it likes to blow: and so the Holy Ghost goes where He wants to go, and makes mighty things happen.

When a person is confirmed, that person cannot be confirmed again, for when that person was confirmed his character was sealed.

When we are confirmed we don't expect to be better or perfect all at once, but we are to try more and more every day.

Jemus.

CHIEF JOE.

When I used to live in North Vancouver I used to go and see Chief Joe.

He was a nice old man. He was the Chief of all the Chiefs in British Columbia. He lived in Capilano. He had two daughters, and one son named Mithras who is Chief now.

One of his daughters can make nice baskets, another of his daughters was still going to school. Chief Joe and his son used to go fishing in the summer.

Chief Joe's wife is a very old woman. She is always picking berries and digging clams to sell. Sometimes I went with her when she went to sell her berries.

Chief Joe went to see the King (King Edward), and all the Indians were gathered together to see him go. They were all dressed the way they used to dress in the olden days. I watched them all until they got to the station in Vancouver.

When Chief Joe came back he told the people all what he saw.

He said when he got to London they did not think he could see the King. So one of the men went and asked the King if he would see him. He said of course he would see him. So Chief Joe went to the Palace.

He said the ceiling was all made out of looking-glass, and the other Chief got scared because he saw himself walking on his head.

They went before the King, who was on a platform. All the other people felt so grand that they never came down to shake hands with Chief Joe, but the King came down and shook hands with Chief Joe. The King's wife also came down to shake hands with him, and he gave her some baskets; and she said to him she would take them to carry their lunch in, when she went with her grandchildren.

And Chief Joe told the King the things the Indians wanted, and the King said they must be patient, and they would see what they could do for him.

When Chief Joe came back all the people were very glad to see him.

Nellie (aged 13).
ALL HALLOWS IN THE WEST.

Besides this disadvantage there is another almost more grave. The closing of the Chinese laundry where our washing used to be done, necessitated its all being done in the School. This is splendid training for the girls, and they quite enjoy it, but for lack of any laundry building, all the boiling, drying and ironing of the clothes has to be carried on in their Playroom, or general "living room" where meals are also served. The discomforts of these arrangements are obvious, yet it is all that can be done under the present circumstances.

Also there is no basement, or even any foundation to the building at the back, so that the water coming down from the mountain rots the sills and woodwork.

It had been therefore, planned to move the entire Indian School building out of its present rather cramped position over to their playground, so as to allow of the addition of a kitchen and laundry, and to leave the present site for the erection of the new Chapel which would thus be built between the two Schools.

But times are changing in B.C. as in other parts of the world and buildings that seemed quite satisfactory to the authorities twenty years ago are found to fall short of the new requirements.

For instance in the dormitory where formerly twenty-five children were allowed, only eighteen may sleep now so as to have the requisite amount of cubic feet of air for each child.

This means that even by filling up every bedroom, so that we can never have visitors or "old girls" to stay, we can only take in twenty-six children at the very most, although our grant now permits us to have thirty-five.

In January of this year we were visited by Inspector Macdonald, who passed the School as a "School in Class C," (subject to the above condition as to the dormitory), which means that we are to have a larger grant; a hundred dollars a year for each child instead of sixty dollars as formerly.

This is good news, for expenses have so much increased of late years that the cost of maintaining a child is now a hundred and twenty dollars a year (about twenty-five pounds), allowing nothing for clothing, house repairs, or expenses of that sort.

A History and an Appendix.

In 1884 three Sisters from the Community of All Hallows, Ditchingham, Norfolk, England, came out at the request of Bishop Sinne, the first Bishop of New Westminster, to undertake Mission work amongst the Indians in his diocese.

At first they lived in the vacant Parsonage at Yale, which was then a large town of about six thousand inhabitants, and they held classes in the Indian church.

After a year or so, the nucleus of the present Indian school began to be formed, using the old C.P.R. Hospital behind the Parsonage for a temporary shelter.

In 1888 the Sisters moved to the "Onderdonk" house, about half a mile west of the town.

The good news soon came that the Dominion Government had decided to help the Sisters with a grant of $60 a year, for each pupil up to the number of twenty-five.

In 1890 the present Indian school building was completed, the money being raised by the Sisters in begging expeditions, aided by a grant of $1500 from the Dominion Government.

The School numbers varied, at times being as high as thirty-six, when part of the old Laundry was used as a dormitory.

Additions and improvements have been made from time to time with the help of funds raised by the kindness of friends, and by a grant of $350 from the New England Company.

Thus a lean-to Washhouse was added to the Playroom, some small rooms built on to the Chapel end of the building, etc., so that the School is much more convenient in some ways than it was formerly.

But there is no kitchen, so that meals have to be carried over from the other house, where culinary operations are on such a large scale that it is impossible now to give the simple teaching in cookery that girls ought to have to fit them for their after life in this country.
The Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge has very kindly given us five Scholarships of ten pounds each a year for some years past, and other friends have helped us most generously, most notably St. Peter's Sunday School, Charlottetown P.E.I.M.T. As a rule, donations towards the maintenance of the Indian School average not more than one hundred dollars a year.

So that it will be seen that to "make ends meet" with sixty dollars a year to come from "somewhere" for each child, has hitherto been an almost impossible problem so far as the Indian School is concerned.

Quite impossible, it would have been, without the constant and most generous help of the W.A. and other friends in England and Scotland, who relieve us entirely from all anxiety as to clothing or bedding, and also provide articles for sale, which raises a small fund to meet current expenses in the garden, or for house furnishing etc.

Now we find, by the new arrangements as to Indian Boarding Schools, that if, instead of spending two or three thousand dollars on moving and adding to this present rather unsatisfactory building, we were to raise enough money (perhaps about five thousand dollars) and build a "Class A School," up to modern requirements as to sanitation, ventilation, heating, isolation of infectious diseases, etc., that the Dominion Government would give us the maximum grant of a hundred and twenty-five dollars a year for each pupil, provided that the plans were submitted to, and approved by them.

It does seem such a splendid opportunity to be taken advantage of! For this would just about make us self-supporting, provided that the W.A. and our other kind friends still helped us with clothing.

Even if the new building only allowed us to take in thirty children, that, with the increased grant would mean a clear gain of seven hundred and fifty dollars a year towards the work of the Church!

We have the great encouragement of hearing that a sum of six hundred and fifty dollars has already been given in England towards this building fund, and other efforts are being made on our behalf,

May we plead very earnestly for these children, the descendants of the original owners of this beautiful land among the mountains of the Far West?

We ask for means to build a suitable house for them, where they may be gathered in to learn all that shall fit them so to fulfil their duty to God and their neighbour in this world, that they may be prepared for their everlasting home in the "Land which is very far off."

OUR NEW PICTURES.

We have two large pictures of the King and Queen, which were sent to us for our schoolroom.

I have seen the King and Queen a long while ago, but I could not remember all what we did when they came. I just remember we sang to them out in the front.

Their train stopped right in front of the school. We were all put in rows, and all had maple-leaf branches in our hands, which we waved about when we sang.

There is only one other girl here who was here at that time.

Grace (aged 13).

(When the King was Duke of Cornwall, he came to visit All Hallows in the West, on October 3rd, 1901. The Royal Train stopped in front of the school, and the Duke and Duchess, with some members of their suite, graciously came in to the school garden, where a maple-leaf pavilion had been erected for them. The children sang a song of welcome specially written for the occasion. Grace was only 3½ years old at the time.)
ABOUT CHRISTMAS (1909).

On Christmas Eve some of us went to Midnight Celebration. We got up at twelve o'clock. When we came downstairs the old people were singing in the schoolroom—they were learning some Christmas Hymns and Carols.

When it was time to go in the Chapel the other people went in first and then we went in last.

It was a very nice Service. We had one Hymn—it was, "O come! all ye faithful," the other people sang it in Indian, and we sang it in English. One of the little babies was crying in the middle of the Service.

When the Service was finished we came out and stayed in the Schoolroom, and one of the Sisters gave us one card each. The card was very nice.

The Indians had some tea before they went to their homes. When the people went away we went to bed.

Elsie Histko.

OUR CLOSING.

I will tell you about our Closing. We had our closing on June the thirtieth, and it was very nice. Some people from the village came to see it. The room was decorated with roses and syringa, and other flowers. The people thought it looked very nice when they saw it.

We had eighteen kinds of drilling and a play. The play was called "Grannie's Birthday." There were twenty-four girls in it. Eva was the oldest, so she was to be the Grannie. Eva was dressed in a grey skirt, with a white shawl around her, and she had a lace cap on with ribbons on it.

All her grandchildren were singing to her. There were about seventeen songs, and Grannie sang one song to us. I think the prettiest song was the song Grannie sang to us.

All the people said it was very nice when it was finished.

After that the prizes were given. There were twenty-five prizes. All the girls never got prizes, but some of them got two or three prizes.

May (aged 13).

A FLOOD.

I will tell you about the Flood at Spence's Bridge.

One day, about twelve o'clock, there was an old man sitting by the fire, and there was a kettle on the stove. It was boiling. It would make the lid go up—it made it go up three times—and the old said he knew what it meant. This old man lived in the house next to us.

There were lots of people bathing in the river, and little children. Some were sitting by the river, and this old man came and told them there was going to be a flood, but they would not believe him. He kept telling them to come away from there, but they would not go.

So he left them alone, and went away. After a while there was a great noise, because all the side of the hills fell down and fell into the river, and stopped the river from running. The water rose over the houses, but it never came to our house because it was on a hill.

Lots of people ran for their lives, but many of them were killed. Some men were on horses and they snatched up the children and ran up the hill.

After the water went down, they all went down again. Lots of people left that place.

After a while some men went down the river, and they found ever so many dead people, and they took them to their people.

That is all I know about it.

Edith (aged 12).

ABOUT A BEAR.

One day my little brother and I went for a walk at our field near Lytton, and we saw a bear. We ran as fast as we could, and it nearly bit our little dog, and Bob was barking at it, and it ran fast too until we shut the door and ran to our beds; and we wouldn't come out until we were going to cook our tea.

My little brother and I were scared, and we wouldn't go out at all, until we went to sleep.
MY GARDEN.

My garden is in our living-room and a big garden too. It has pretty flowers in it. Two of my gardens are square, and wood around them. I have lots of roses in them, they are all colours. My sweet peas are out now. All the other girls have gardens too, they are bigger than mine. My sunflowers are all getting to be very big. My garden is not very big. One of my plants are dead from root to the end, and so I pulled it up.

FLOWERS.

Flowers are very beautiful. They teach us many things. Violets teach us to be humble—they hide their heads under their leaves: so we shouldn't talk about our good done—we should hide them deep in our hearts. The lily of the valley teaches us to be humble too.

The white water-lily has her roots way deep in the mud under the water and yet she keeps herself pure and white. Whenever we are, even if the people around us are bad and won't fear God, we must keep our souls pure and clean.

If our bundies are not washed or mended properly, Sister sends them back to be washed or mended over again.

Sometimes we lose care of our clothes, and sometimes we put them on the pipe by the stove and they get burnt.

Sometimes we lose care of our stockings, and sometimes we lose care by losing in our stockings.

If our bundies are not washed or mended properly, Sister sends them back to be washed or mended over again.

VERNON.

There is lots of Indians in Vernon. When we go to pick hops they painted themselves red, and they wore feathers on their heads. They wore a blanket around themselves, and they sat us to go and catch little fish in the creek.

We went out singing one day with Elizabeth, we caught eight altogether, and we divided it between us.

Every night we go to the store to buy some nights we don't.

When the month was ended we all went to Salmon Arm again, we went home in a wagon.

Jana (aged 11).

Hilda (aged 10).
CHRISTMAS HOLIDAYS (1910).

The first part of our holidays we had no snow, not till after Christmas this year.

We all had a lovely time on Christmas Eve, and we all went to bed early. About half-past eleven some of us got up to go to Midnight Celebration.

The Chapel was beautifully decorated, especially the Altar. On each side of the Aisle there were evergreens, and everything looked so bright.

After we came out of Celebration it was a quarter past one, then we had supper and went to bed.

Next morning, as you may suppose, we were all busy with our stockings, and at ten minutes to seven we were all singing Carols.

We had breakfast at half past eight, we all got such a lot of presents too.

After Mattins we all went down to the dining hall and had our Christmas dinner there. We had two turkeys, and after that came the pudding which was very nice.

We had a still more lovely time on Monday afternoon, when we had our Christmas Tree in the Schoolroom.

We all got such nice useful things, the tree looked so lovely when lighted.

And after Christmas we had such a lovely time sleighriding after the snow fell, although we had some very cold weather for some days.

Isabel (aged 15).

CHRISTMAS TREE.

We were longing to look at the Christmas Tree. We were singing when we were going to get our presents off the Christmas Tree. Some of the dolls looked very nice. Lizzie got a nice doll with a brown hair and a blue ribbon and a pink dress.

Lots of the girls got small little dollys, they were the ones that Miss Flower dressed and she gave them to the girls. Canada and Celia got a nice scrap book off the Christmas tree, and some of the girls got a nice skipping rope.

There was a nice Santa Claus on top of the Christmas tree.

Susan (aged 10).

A SNOW STORM.

It was Sunday when it began snowing so hard. When we went to bed it was still snowing, but we went to sleep without hardly thinking of the snow. When most of us were asleep the snow was coming in at the windows, for they are usually open at night. A little while after that Sister came in and brushed the snow off the beds and dried the clothes that were wet.

The next day it was very cold, and the windows were frozen over, and such pretty patterns that Jack Frost had drawn in the night. The snow was quite deep by then, so that it was too deep for the ditch on the hill, the water came pouring down the hill, right down into the back kitchen, at first we thought it was mud coming down the hill, it was so muddy. And the river was frozen.

And after the snowstorm was over we went for a lovely walk, we saw big pieces of ice. They looked so pretty.

Janet (aged 11).

SPRING.

When Spring comes all the things seem to wake up, everything is asleep in winter, and the snow is the blanket. When the snow begins to melt, all the flowers begin to wake, the trees put on their green leaves, the birds begin building their nests, even the people seem to wake up for they walk about more. Everything is green, as if the whole earth had put on a green dress, the grass comes up nice and fresh.

Springtime is when we begin digging our gardens, and put in our seeds.

Jennie.
ST. PATRICK'S PRAYER

There were Grace and Nellie, little lass when I left, now they had grown into big girls that I hardly recognised them, and saw so many strange faces; the music also was changed in Chapel, I almost expected to hear the same tunes that we used to sing.

I don't think we were idle during the week we stayed at the old School; we were either out for walks, enjoying our favourite haunts, or helping to pick cherries, or helping to take care of the little ones, as it was a few days before the Closing and everybody was too busy. We were often invited to stay to Lunch by an old school friend who now had a house in town, which we always gladly accepted.

All holidays must end; the week I spent at Yale seemed to me to be the shortest I have ever spent; we would dearly have loved to have stayed longer; and what lovely bouquets Sister gave us before we left, the bouquets were nearly as large as ourselves. So the week ended at Yale, never to be forgotten.

Emma Chiltonen.

NEWS OF "OLD GIRLS"

Cristina (Mrs. F. Gladwin) has two little children and is very busy at her home at Dedroche, but finds time to write us interes-

ting letters now and then. Mail we saw at Lytton last autumn,

where she was staying with Sarah (Mrs. F. Seaward) for a change after coming out of the hospital where she had rheumatic fever very badly. Sarah's garden was a great credit to her, her vegetables were very large.

Samantha (Mrs. Dunstan) has a large family of little boys and girls is very glad of Lisa's help at home. Lisa had been very busy in the garden, especially in her strawberry patch.

We were so glad to hear from Marion Walker, now Mrs. Hinzlauer, she seems very happy and busy in her home at Monte Creek, but it seems to be a very lonely part of the country.

Flora (Mrs. Comyn) is now living at Skeetches.

Rhoda (Mrs. Kim) had a great sorrow in the death of her husband, since then she has often come to stay with Clara.

A feast we had again before we left.

One evening at Yale to visit the old school.

What a glorious time we had, we (three of us old girls) arrived one evening at Yale to visit the old school.

It was about seven years since I had left school and oh! what memories it brought back of the good old school days, as the school was just like a home to me. There was the same old book that we used to pore over, and I saw the places where we often had picnics, and it sounded like the same little birds that used to have their homes there, where they were just simply changed anything, there were the cherry trees that we used to climb, what leaves we used to have! they were just simply loaded with cherries now, as they were seven years ago, and what a feast we had again before we left.

COPY
Clara (Mrs. Clare), had another dear little boy last summer; they have moved to the Section-house near Yale Creek.

Esther (Mrs. Lynes) has a large family of boys and girls, she was living at Okanagan Landing.

Rosie (Mrs. Mitchell) was staying with Dora (Mrs. Walters) near Savonas last summer with her little children; Dora has a sturdy little boy and a dear little baby girl.

Lizzie Kirkpatrick is staying with her aunt on the Cariboo Road, and leads a very busy life indeed, but likes to hear from the old School.

Cassie, or Katie, Fowler is still keeping house for her father, and writes very interesting letters about all her doings from time to time.

Phyllis (Mrs. Joe) has been to see us each summer with some of her little children.

Elizabeth is still in service in Caulford, she sent a large sum for the Missionary Box last year.

Josephine, who is living at Chilliwack, also helped with the Missionary Box, so did Elsie, who is in Taconia, and Bee and Ada, who are both in service at Ashcroft, and very happy to be together. Gina seems to be doing very well at Aspen Grove, and hopes that that part of the country may be going to open up soon.

Merese (Mrs. Simons) lost her little boy this winter, he was a delicate little child.

Lottie had not been at all well, and Eva was going to stay at home for a while with her and her mother.

Agnes came down in the winter to see us, and had grown so tall and strong, we hardly knew her.

SCHOOL SONG—"ANGELS' GREETING."

See now, see now, stars, the dark gloom piercing,
O'er thee shed their silv'ry light, their silv'ry light:
Though the boundless ethereal space divide thee,
They will guide thee all through the dreary night.

See now, see how yon star is twinkling!
On its beams so soft and clear, so soft and clear,
Guardian angels send thee holy greetings,
Thy sad heart and thy trembling soul to cheer.

See now, see now how the stars are flashing!
Angels beckon thee away, far, far away:
And their beacons bright they'll still keep burning,
Till o'er thee breaketh the long'd for dawn of day.

Fanz Abt.

In a recent visit to the Schools of Inspector Ditchburn he advised our asking you for a new "Scale Shewing Grants to Boarding Schools at the rate of $100.00 per capita per annum"—as our present Scale is only for $60.00. (Taken from Department's Letter of Nov. 20th 1894, file no.: 120, 050)

Madam,

In reply to your letter of the 2nd instant I beg to inform you that under the new agreement regarding the maintenance and management of the All Hallows boarding school the per capita grant will be paid from April 1st last on the average attendance of the authorized number of pupils in residence at the school each quarter. The per capita grant will therefore not be calculated for each pupil individually and a scale of payment will not be required.

I also beg to acknowledge with thanks the copy of the school magazine "All Hallows in the West."

Your obedient servant

Asst Deputy and Secretary

Constance Sister Superior
All Hallows Boarding School
Yale, B.C.
Dear Sir,

Many thanks for your letter of May 26th regarding school holidays.

As the summers are generally so hot here we have usually had about 2 months' holiday from classroom work, but have gone on with industrial work, & such classes as Scripture. Sometimes piping etc., or when many young children were here, with reading & writing for them.

During this time some of the pupils were sent home for 3 weeks with leave from the Department.

We are glad to see they may go home for a month this year, but at whose discretion may they go? Do we still have them in their names & numbers & by Department? Or is it at our discretion to send home those whom we think fit?

Also would you please tell us whether they must have classroom work all the summer, except for that one month, or whether we may do as in former years.

We propose having their School closin
on Coronation Day, if possible, (June 22nd)
and sending home all who can go on
July 5th till August 5th.

We shall be much obliged if you
will please inform us as to whether
this course would be approved by the
Department.

Yours truly,

Constance, Sister Superior C.H.
I herewith enclose a letter from Constance, Sister Superior of the All Hallows Indian Boarding School at Yale, B.C., asking for certain information with respect to Boarding Schools, which I must ask you to supply direct to her, as I will be absent from this city for at least two weeks. The opening paragraph refers to Clauses 14 and 15 of the Contract, which I forwarded to her. I would suggest that the Department should furnish all principals of Boarding Schools with a copy of the Contract; also a copy of the Department's letter mailed to representatives of religious bodies interested in Indian education.

A copy of the amended scale of payment should also be forwarded to all principals of Boarding Schools as well as to the various Indian Agents.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector.

Ottawa, June 15, 1911.

Madam,

Mr. Inspector Ditchburn has forwarded to the Department your letter to him of the 2nd instant with the request that a reply be sent you direct. I, therefore, beg to inform you that under the terms of the new agreement relating to the future maintenance and management of boarding schools Clause 15 of the said agreement, which deals with the annual vacation, class-room work and the discretionary powers granted in allowing pupils to visit their homes, is as follows: "To have school-room exercises on five and industrial exercises on six days in each week, legal holidays excepted; and excepting also a vacation day not to exceed one month between the first of July and the first day of October in each year, unless some other course is expressly sanctioned by the Superintendent General. During the vacation the pupils may, in the discretion of the Management be permitted to visit their homes, but the Superintendent General will not pay any part of the cost of transportation either going or returning."

It is thought that the above clause quoted from the agreement fully covers the matters dealt with in your letter to Inspector Ditchburn, excepting the time on which you wish to close the school for the annual vacation and the sending to their homes of all pupils whom you allow to go. The Department will allow you to close the school for the annual vacation on the 22nd instant, as you have arranged, but the full grant can only be paid for one month from that date.

Rev. Sister Constance,
Sister Superior,
All Hallows Boarding School,
Yale, B.C.

April 1st, 1912

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

We are today forwarding to the Indian Agent at Lytton our Annual Report, with Financial Statement, also list of employees, and the Quarterly Register, list of Admissions and Discharges. We have not been asked this year for any further returns, so these are all we have sent.

We have been in serious difficulty over the non-arrival of the grant for the December Quarter. Our papers were filed in on, or just after, January 1st, but we have had no money yet. The same thing happened last year.

We applied last autumn, through our Indian Agent, for a new floor for the Children's Playroom, and two new flush-tanks for the two bathrooms, but, though we wrote again in December, we have had no reply at all about this.

The floor is badly worn, and the toilet in one of the bathrooms cannot be used, we have not had it in use for months. This has occasioned very great inconvenience all the while.

It is no use our writing to the Agent, we can get no answer to our
letters. He has not been once to visit the school since he was appointed. About a year and a half ago (I think) he came down for a few minutes late one evening to speak about something, but did not wish to see the schools.

Mr. A. E. Green, the School Inspector, who visited us in January, promised to do something in the matter of our floor, and flush tanks, as well as some other things, but, though we wrote him in the meantime on another matter, we have had no word from him since we were promised a sewing machine for pupil No. 110, etc., on her leaving school nearly two years ago. March 11th, 1914.

Dear Mr. Taylor -

Referring to our conversation in regard to the status of the Yale (All Hallows) Indian Boarding School, I could state that this matter has been before the Department on previous occasions but I have now looked into it carefully myself and for your information I wish to give in detail a statement of the circumstances.

On the 1st of April, 1911, the Department entered into a contract with the various churches and bodies interested for the maintenance and management of boarding schools. All these institutions were divided into three classes:

A.- First-class buildings owned by the churches or societies.

B.- Buildings owned by the Government.

C.- Buildings of a lower grade than A owned by the Churches.

J. D. Taylor, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ont.
In the best schools under Grade A are to receive $125.00 per capita and schools under B and C $100.00 per capita.

The requirements for Grade A call for a substantial building on a stone foundation, with a pure water supply, sanitary closets and drainage, hospital accommodation, modern system of ventilation and sufficient air space in dormitories and class rooms, modern heating apparatus and sufficient area of land for farms and gardens.

Class C calls for buildings which must be sanitary and in good repair, with hospital accommodation, modern system of ventilation and sufficient area of land for farms and gardens; you will note that they are not required to have a foundation, modern heating, sanitary water closets and drainage nor a modern heating apparatus.

Information before the Department tends to show very clearly that the All Hallows could not qualify for Grade A, and in some respects it is doubtful whether it could qualify strictly for Grade C notwithstanding this the grant was at once raised in 1911 from $60.00 to $100.00 and has been paid at that rate since. They have not sufficient dormitory accommodation for the pupilage provided although they have for the number of children at present in attendance, nor have they a modern system of
of ventilation, and as a matter of fact the building is in such bad repair that it is said to be very cold in the stormy winter months. The authorities themselves were so impressed with the need of new buildings that in a letter from the Principal, dated January 24th, 1911, it was stated that the main building was old, erected in 1890, with no basement, kitchen or laundry and that they wished to build a new school to qualify under Class A. Unfortunately, however, they were not able to arrange for the necessary finances and the matter was dropped.

I would like very much to do something in the direction asked for by the Principal but I am sure you will appreciate the difficulty when it is remembered that we have a number of institutions throughout the country in the same category and it could hardly be considered politic to make an exception in favour of any particular school. I may say that in all cases we have rigidly adhered to our classification and I wish also to emphasize the substantial increase in the per capita grant above referred to, which was made without any restrictions.

I hope, in the not far distant future, to have one of our architects visit the Province of British Columbia with a view to inspecting and reporting upon conditions at
at all our residential schools and I shall await with interest the result of his inspection of this institution.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

It appears that he bought the five acres, and paid over the money for the same, and only obtained a deed for one acre, that upon which the School now stands; the other five acres were not surveyed at the time so no deed could be given.

Bishop Sillitoe died in 1894, and presumably nothing more was done in the matter, the Sisters always taking for granted that the land belonged to them, as they have had the use of it eversince, but the man who pre-empted died without ever setting his deeds upon it, and now the land reverted to the Crown, and it has now been applied for by another man.

SPUZZUM, B. C.

Feb. 28th, 1909

The Minister of Education,
Ottawa Ont.

Hon. Sir,

We are trying to get a teacher for our school here and I wish to appeal to you for any help or information you can give me.

My own children are the only white children in the vicinity but there are several Indian children which I am sure would take advantage of a school if a teacher was provided. Here is a good school house, well furnished. We have four children of school age.

I took the matter of procuring a teacher up with the Dept. of Education at Victoria some time ago but was advised that a teacher could not be sup-
plied unless an average of at least ten white pupils could be guaranteed.

I understand however that the Dominion Government is responsible for the education of the Indian children. Is there no way therefore in which terms can be concluded whereby a teacher can be furnished?

Our children have been here now nearly a year and a half with no school facilities and as before stated there are several Indian children whom I think would be glad to avail themselves of the opportunity of attending school. He would gladly pay $10.00 or $15.00 per month towards a teacher's salary if that would be any inducement or help out of the difficulty.

Please let me know at your earliest convenience what can be done.

Sincerely,

P.H. Duffer

I shall make a full report after I have carefully looked into the various conditions affecting those Indians. In the meantime I might be allowed to express the opinion from such knowledge as I have that the conditions do not appear favorable. The band is somewhat scattered, and divided religiously. Either denomination would prefer no school to one controlled by the other; and we could only hope to carry on a school in so small and sparsely settled a community in conjunction with missionary work, as the inducements otherwise would preclude the probability of securing a teacher. Last Sunday March 8th inst., all of the Spuzzum Indians and all around here gathered together with Chief James Paul, wanted me to write to you that they want to open the school house here at Spuzzum if possible. Sir:-

Sir:

In reply to departmental letter dated April 8th, I beg to state that in company with Mr. Inspector Cairns I went to Spuzzum to investigate the application made by the Spuzzum Indians for a school.

We went into the whole matter with the Indians and they gave us their assurance that they would guarantee an attendance of fourteen children.

We inspected the old building, which was previously built and used as a schoolhouse, and which is still available, but which will require a certain amount of repairs, although it is at the present time being used as a dwelling. The desks have been all stowed away in the loft, so we could not quite see the exact number, but we think that there will be sufficient of them.

As the winter is now approaching, and the children all have to travel a considerable distance, besides some having to cross the river, we came to the conclusion that we would recommend that the school be given a trial, starting on the 1st of April, next, and that it should be run for five months until the last of September, when the children go with their parents to the hopfields, and by the end of that time we would be in a position to see whether we considered the Indians were sincere, and anxious enough to keep this school open. The Indians promised to provide fuel.

Under the circumstances I would like to recommend that the Department give this their favorable consideration, and make provision to provide a teacher. This school would be nondenominational, as there are both Protestant and Roman Catholic children.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I should have written to you sometime ago, but have been away so much lately that I have been unable to attend to my correspondence. Since Mr. Eteson left the Nicola we have not yet put in another Clergyman there and so I have been a lot in the Nicola Valley myself, and then again my assistant at Lytton has gone to the Front.

First of all in regard to the Shulus Day School. Apparently Mr. Eteson must have asked for Miss Williams' resignation, and then applied to the Department for the appointment for himself although he had been told by the Bishop and myself we would not consider such an arrangement, as Miss Williams had told the Bishop she would stay on for some time, when I found she had left and was going to the Old Country. In a hurry I found a young man named Harwood who was a scholar at a Grammar School in the Old Country and in recognition of his scholarship had to teach one of the Junior Classes every day, I asked him to take on the work temporarily. When Dr. Cairnes visited the School I told him how things were and asked his opinion, he said "I think you have a real live man and am pleased with him." I told Harwood this, and also asked one of the Nurses at the Hospital to go to the School and teach the girls sewing! Suddenly while Harwood was away on his holidays The Indian Agent at Kamloops writes saying Dr. Cairnes is dissatisfied with the appointment. If Dr. Cairnes thinks it would be better to have someone else there I would be glad if he would write to me saying so then I can show the letter to Harwood and will try and get him other work, at present I cannot do that when I told the man how pleased Dr. Cairnes was with him as a teacher, and too when he had more children this term than there were there last term.

The only natural construction Harwood can put on my conduct would be that I personally wished to get rid of him; while I like the man.

And now in regard to the Lytton Day School. This School is in a curious position as owing to the C.P.R. intending to "double track" I advised the Indians to look out for land and settle on it, and again as it was uncertain as to where the best place for a new School would be asked the Indian Agent - Mr. Graham - not to build a new School as the Government had proposed as it was so uncertain as to where the best centre would be, furthermore as you know so many people seize any
opportunity of further exciting the opinion of our Indians against the present Agent that I could not ask him to insist upon a better attendance, both The Inspector of Indian Affairs for the Agency and he are agreed that it would be unfair at the present juncture. So that it had to be left, while it is really useless to tell the Chief he has to do so, the poor unfortunate Chief is only suspected when his actions meet with the approval of the Indian Agent of his particular district at any other time he is let down and consequently he has very little power today. The Ordinary policy of the Department has been rather to undermine the authority of the Chief, so that to say to him you must see that the attendance at the Schools improves is to insist that he attends to a duty which is just as difficult among the Indians as it is among White people. To my mind the only fair way to do this is to ask the Inspector of Schools to call a meeting of the Indians and then for him as representing the Department to tell them they must send their children to the Schools just as the White people have to and in their presence to tell the Indian Agent he wants a monthly report of the children who stay away from School and then to send the boys to the Industrial School and the girls to the Boarding School for girls, then when once the Indians realise that the Department mean to take a strong course they will soon settle down and recognise it.

One more fact in regard to Miss Hobden, she came out from England at the request of Mr Green, it cost her about £50 = to pay her passage and get all fixed up. I know this because I had to lend her the money, Mr Green also assured her the Day Schools would be kept open without any doubt, so she came out on that understanding. Mr Green, as I believe in Day Schools, Dr. Cairnes does not, to his mind the only place is the Industrial School, as he was a Principal of an Indian Boarding this is natural, but what about the great majority of the Indian children whom the Industrial Schools do not reach? They are by far the greater number.

I must ask you please to keep Miss Hobden on, and when I am in Ottawa sometime towards the end of September or early in October I hope you will give me an opportunity of discussing the Indian Day School question with you. I would like to suggest some radical changes, which I think would meet with your approval. In regard to the Lytton Day School I may say that Dr. McKenna, and the Chairman of the Indian Commission together with Major Megraw and Mr Graham all think it a mistake to close it.

[Signature]

Edward Hugh
Archdeacon of Lytton.

I should have answered your letter before this but have been away from home so much that I have had little opportunity. In regard to Miss Hobden—as I wrote to Mr. Scott—the first intimation I had that she was returning was a cable from London saying she was starting. I had asked her to stop off at Ottawa and call but she was unable to do this as her ticket would not allow it.

You have been misinformed as to the numbers of children attending the Lytton Indian Day School, the daily average has been seven and not three. Mr. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Day Schools told us before Miss Hobden applied for leave there would be no question of closing the School if the average did not fall below six. Seven was the number average before Dr. Fort suggested the School being closed on account of the heat. Miss Hobden started immediately on her return, and kept the School open for one month. There is no doubt there would be many more children attend School if a School was opened across the river, there are twenty-seven children of school age in the vicinity, the difficulty is the bridge, it is only a railway one and certainly not safe for children to cross as apart from the danger of trains we have often a very strong wind blowing, the Indians across the river are willing to build a school between the Nikaia and Nehomin Reserves. But even here if the Indian School Act was enforced there should be a better average, and as you know from your long experience Indians, any more than white people, will make their children come to School unless they are compelled.

In view of the fact that the average is higher than the Inspector laid down and also that Miss Hobden returned at a considerable expense to take up her work again I do not think it is fair to close the School, and I am sure you do not. So please let it go on for the present, I shall be in Ottawa in Sept. and will come in and we can talk the whole thing over. I may as well tell you that the Indian Agent so far from suggesting that he was going to recommend the closing of the School actually asked what new supplies were needed.
This neighbourhood is one where there should be a big Day School, but certainly the better place is the other side of the river, if the Government could put a foot-way on one side of the bridge, having railings and wire netting on account of the wind, I have no doubt if any serious attempt was made to enforce the attendance it would be possible to have a daily average of 18. If the Department should desire I will willingly ask either Senator Boastock or Mr. H. Barnard—the member for Victoria—to come and see things and send in their Report to the Department. Also I am willing in the event of the daily average being below six to forward to the Department quarterly when the Returns are made up a cheque for half of Miss Hobden's salary. I am quite certain Mr. Scott and yourself are anxious to do what is right, but you naturally must act on information, unfortunately that information does not always tally with facts.

One more thing I sent in with my last quarters Hospital Returns a C.P.R. receipt for the train fare of a destitute Indian woman bringing her child to Hospital for an operation on the knee—on Jan. 14th last—The Indian Agent says it was sent in. I often do things myself but did not have my instruments with me at the time and as well rather funked the job at the house as the knee is such an easy place to infect, the boy had run in a long sliver quite deep near the cartilage holding the knee-cap down, the sliver was quite two inches long, and there was no time to wait so I brought him along; when this sort of thing has happened with Mr. Smith I have always had the cheque for the amount returned with the cheque for the Hospital Returns.

With kindest regards, Believe me,

Yours very sincerely

E. W. B. Pugle
Archdeacon of Lytton.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,

Sir:

In response to your letter of Aug. 17, numbered 319651/1 re the Day School at Lytton, I went to Lytton August the 28th. I also had a letter from the Agent, Mr. H. Graham, urging me to come as he expected the Inspector of Indian Agencies, Mr. A. Megraw, in Lytton on the 28th of August.

We fully discussed the school problems with special reference to the Day School at Lytton. The difficulty here is that the Fraser River divides the Indian people at Lytton, part live on one side and part on the other. On the side on which the school building is located there are five pupils of school age in attendance. There are three others who belong to this side of the river but they have been away with their parents for some time. On the other side of the river there are some twelve to fifteen of school age.

After this I saw Archdeacon Pugh and the teacher Miss Hobden. The Archdeacon informed me that the school had not been opened on account of the extremely hot weather. The holidays of the Public schools had been extended for a week. Then I was informed that a number of the Indians were at the present time away from home.
Archdeacon suggested that the matter of the Day School at Lytton be left till November, and that a meeting of the Indians be held at which the Indian Agent and myself be present. The Indians will all be home at that time. Perhaps some arrangement could be made in which all parties would concur that would settle the question for some time.

In the afternoon I visited St. George's Industrial School. The new building under construction is going ahead slowly. Mr. Dawson has found difficulty in procuring material. The boys had not all returned from their holidays. There were some 40 present. I did not go into the class-rooms to give an examination. I thought it would be better to leave it till later when the building was complete and the girls brought here from Yale. Conditions would then be normal and a report then would give a better idea of what was being accomplished.

On my way back to Vancouver I called at Yale. Here I found 21 girls who had returned early in August. They were in charge of three of the Sisters. The fourth Sister was away for holidays. The sister Superior had engaged a School teacher but she was not able to come at once. The Sisters were carrying on the work. The girls became restless and gave more or less trouble. The Sisters came to the conclusion that they would not carry on the school work any longer.
They sent a telegram to Archdeacon Pugh informing him of their decision. They explained to me that the arrangement which they made with the Rev. L. Dawson, Principal of the Industrial School, was that he would take over the girls when they returned after the holidays. They wanted this arrangement carried out as they did not feel able to stand the stress and strain of the responsibility of caring for the girls any longer and especially as the girls were so restless. Unless Mr. Dawson acts at once the Sisters intend to send the girls home.

I sent a telegram to Mr. Dawson advising him to come to Yale at once. I informed him of the decision of the Sisters. I remained at Yale till the evening of the 30th., hoping Mr. Dawson would arrive. However he did not come. The problem is his. I did not feel called on to remain any longer.

For the information of the Department, I wish to say that there is a lack of harmony and co-operation on the part of those carrying on educational work here that is detrimental to the best interests concerned.

In conclusion, I wish to say that on my return from the north, I will visit these schools and hope by that time everything will be running smoothly, and that results will be attained in the class-room.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

T.P.H. Cairns

REPORT OF INSPECTOR CAIRNS ON THE LYTTON DAY SCHOOL.

I held a meeting with the Indians Feb. 16. Archdeacon Pugh, Mr Agent Graham, and twenty four Indians including two Indian women were present.

There are about twenty children of school age on the Reserve across the Fraser river. A number of Indians from this reserve were present. The problem is how to get these children across to the school. The most feasible way is to construct a foot bridge in connection with the C.N.Railway bridge which crosses the river at the point. The Agent has this matter in hand and is corresponding with the Department.

If these children could be brought across the river a good school would then be possible.

We had a very harmonious conference. There is now a better understanding of the policy of the Indian Department on the part of the Indians.

Date of Inspection,-Feb. 20th, 1916.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Graham, in his report on the Lytton Day School for the month of February, last, states that the attendance is very unsatisfactory, there being only six children available, and, with the Lytton Industrial School so near, he thinks that that is the proper place for all these children. He also states that as soon as spring starts the parents will be taking their children with them out to the ranches, and the attendance will be even less satisfactory than at present.

The Lytton Day school is held in a rented building, which is in a very dilapidated condition.

The following is an extract from the report of Miss Hoaden, the teacher, for the year ended December 31st, last, which bears out Mr. Graham's statements regarding this school:— "Now the local industrial school is open to girls as well as boys some parents prefer to send their children there. The Indians are spending much more time cultivating their outlying ranches and of course the children accompany their parents, and for months together are unable to attend school regularly. This makes progress slow and discouraging."

Provision is made for one hundred pupils at the Lytton Industrial School and there is now an enrolment there of ninety-one, and they would have ample accommodation for all the children who have been attending the day school.

Dear Mr Hawksley,

I wish to acknowledge yours of Oct 27th in which you refer to the need of Day Schools at Rampart House and Forty Mile. I have given the matter considerable thought, and am deeply interested in the question of doing all that is possible in the way of providing schools for the Indians at both these two places and elsewhere. For a number of years we had a teacher at Forty Mile in fact school has been kept by our Church at this place since about 1891. A few years ago the Indians all practically left there, and made their headquarters at Eagle and Moosehide and elsewhere. For several years our School was continued on expecting that the Indians might return to Forty Mile, but year after year passed by without any material change in the situation, till at last we felt we were not justified in keeping a teacher there any longer, and he was accordingly removed to Selkirk. Recently some of the Indians have come back, and if they continue to remain there in any numbers, I shall be glad to do what I can in the way of opening up a school. It is rather expensive to keep a man there continuously. If school could be held regularly with a fair number of pupils, the Government grant given in such cases would be considerable help, but the movements of the Indian population are so uncertain that there is a certain amount of financial responsibility that is not easy to meet. I hope to visit Forty Mile before long, and will be glad again to consult with you on the matter.

With reference to Rampart House, the difficulties are somewhat similar. The Church of England has now a native clergyman, the Rev Amos Njootli in charge of the Mission. He does all he can in teaching the Indians to read and write in their own tongue, and with considerable success. He travels with the Indians to their hunting grounds, and holds school
regularly. He does not however teach in the English language, and I know it would be a great advantage if we could have a regular teacher in English for the Indian children. Here again financial difficulties have been in the way. The Indians at Rampart House spend most of their time in hunting and trapping and are scattered all over the country. For a short time some of them gather together at one place, and during this period school could be held, but when the parents go off to hunt again, their children must accompany them, unless someone is prepared to keep them, and this would require a Boarding School of some kind. The Government grant for Day Schools is now given according to the number of days school is held. I am afraid under the circumstances at Rampart House, the grant would go only a very small way towards the expense of keeping a teacher. Because of the remoteness of the place it would be impossible for a man to come and go very frequently, and he would have to settle down for the year. The cost of salary and travelling expense would be considerable, and thus again financial difficulties are hard to overcome. However, I hope we may be able to do something in the course of time to provide a regular school at Rampart House, and I shall be glad to discuss the question with you again at any time.

I remain,

Reverend and dear Father:

I beg to draw your attention on the Squamish Indian School.

This school was built in 1878 by late Bishop Murray, on the property of the Sisters of the Child Jesus, in the city of North Vancouver, close to the Indian Reservation. Of course, at that time the said city did not exist and the taxes on land were almost insignificant. But since the city has grown up, and at the present time the taxes are so high that it has been impossible for the school to meet the entire bill for the years 1870-1871. All what the school has been able to do, with the help of the other members of the Community, was to pay for the taxes on the 4 acres on which the school buildings are located; this amounted to $277.50. As for the 5 acres adjoining the school which are used for pasture for the cows, this bill the school could not possibly meet, so the property will be sold this coming summer for "unpaid taxes", and the poor Sisters, after having worked like slaves among the Indians for twenty-three years, will be left penniless.

As a result we shall not be able to keep our cows—for want of grazing ground—and consequently the pupils shall be deprived of milk, for though we should buy milk (and that we will) we could never afford to buy quantity supplied by our three good milk cows.

The Government, it is true, has raised the grant for Indians who need to provide their children with food, hardly supply anything now. But the number of expense is great.
