Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Inspector Ditchburn has reported on the taxation difficulties at the St. Mary's and Squamish Boarding Schools, B.C.

St. Mary's Boarding School:

The property at Mission, B.C., consists of 5 blocks of land and 3 town lots. Only one block of 165 acres, known as Sec. Gp. 3, Tp. 17, D.L. 2, is used solely for church and mission purposes. The rest of the property is leased to Japanese and white tenants and is not necessary to the management of the boarding school. 15 acres of the plot mentioned above is exempt from taxation and the tax on the remaining 140 acres of school property amounts to about $470.00 per annum.

I wish to recommend, following the correspondence between Father Welch and yourself, that this Department pay the taxes on the block of 140 acres used exclusively for school purposes. This year, the amount is $468.60, and the Principal of the school is prepared to submit to Mr. Ditchburn a receipted bill for this amount.

Squamish Boarding School:

The property at North Vancouver, held under title by Miss Marie Champlain, consists of Block 69 (4 acres) on which are the school building and garden, and Block 123 (5 acres) used as a pasturage and potato field. These two blocks are within the city of North Vancouver and are assessed on the same basis as surrounding residential property. The total valuation is $68,500.00. The annual taxes on Block 69, on which the school stands, amount roughly to $1,000.00, and have been paid from year to year. The unpaid taxes on Block 123 - the 5 acres used as pasturage - amount with penalties to $3,666.54. If Block 123 is to remain school property, this amount will have to be paid before the 30th of September, next. The Principal was prepared to allow Block 123 sold for arrears. I believe that both Blocks 69 and 123 (a total of 9 acres) are needed for school purposes.

You will remember that we discussed taking over this property at a nominal sum, until such time as it was not required for Indian educational purposes. The intention was to be relieved of the taxation and then return it to the present title holders. However, Section 208 of the Municipal Act at the 1919 session of the Provincial Legislature precludes such a procedure. It is stated that lands which are held or occupied other than by, or on behalf of, the Crown shall be liable to taxation, even when the fee of which lands is in the Crown.
Two possible courses of action remain:

1. The Department could purchase at the tax sale Block 123, at a price which, I believe, would be much under the present valuation of $42,500.00. The Sisters at the school would probably sell us Block 69, on which the school stands, for about $20,000.00. We should remember, however, that we would never use the property if we built an Indian residential school. 9 acres is insufficient for this purpose and we would be forced to put the property on the market when the Squamish Boarding school is replaced by a modern building elsewhere.

2. Block 123 could be sold for taxes and this Department pay taxes amounting to, roughly, $1,000.00 per annum on Block 69. This procedure would, of course, leave the institution with but 4 acres. They might be able to rent a pasture and potato patch from the new owners of Block 123, or elsewhere.

I think that this second suggestion concerning the Squamish Boarding School property is far from what is desired, but, under the circumstances, I recommend that we give a grant to the school, of $1,000.00 per year, to pay the taxation on Block 69, on which the school stands. They will have to make arrangements for their potato and milk supply.

I might state that funds are provided in the 1921-22 Supplementary Estimates for the payment, if you concur with my recommendations in connection with the St. Mary's and Squamish Boarding Schools.

R.J.F.
Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum:

Honorable Charles Stewart:

Some months ago the attention of the Department was drawn to the fact that the St. Mary's and Squamish Boarding Schools, in British Columbia, were subjected to heavy municipal taxation. These institutions are situated on the outskirts of Mission City and North Vancouver and, as the properties are owned by Roman Catholic Church Orders, they have not been exempt from municipal taxation.

I beg to recommend that authority be given to reimburse the management of the Squamish and St. Mary's Boarding Schools.

At the Squamish Boarding School the property consists of two blocks - one of 4 acres, on which the taxes mentioned above amounted to $977.91. This amount the Department proposes to pay. The school is situated on this block of land in the City of North Vancouver. Immediately across the street from the school, the Sisters in charge own Block 123 - a 5 acre parcel used for pasturage and for a potato patch. Sir,

With further reference to your letter of November 2nd last, No.122050/1, having reference to the desire on the part of the Department to have the Municipal Authorities in North Vancouver assess a portion of Block 64, which is being used for school purposes at the agricultural rate, I beg to advise you that I attended two sittings of the Court of Revision at North Vancouver, in connection with the above.

In the first place, the Court functions only to assess values, in which connection a letter of the Assessor received at the conclusion of the Court sittings is sent you herewith.

I asked the Court to consider any possible reduction that might be made under the Municipal Act, by way of eliminating the actual improvements, that is the actual site of school and out-buildings, or improvements, but the City Solicitor advised the Court that there was nothing in the Municipal Act to give authority for immunity from taxation in respect of property such as referred to. I then asked the Court if it thought the school portion of the taxes could be eliminated if the matter were brought to the Council's attention. The Court's reply was that as the school in question is not a city school it would have to pay taxes as other schools not being city schools in the vicinity were paying.

Reference was made smilingly by the Court Chairman to the purchase by the Department of Block 122, under which purchase the land being vested in the Crown became immune from taxation, detrimental to the best interests of the Municipality from a financial standpoint, and it was thought there would be no disposition on the part of the City Council to make any arrangement for tax reduction below assessed values in view of this.

In accordance with your letter numbered above, and dated January 2nd ultimo, I beg to inform you that I attended two sittings of the Municipal Court of Revision at North Vancouver, with a view to obtaining a reduction of assessed values in connection with the Squamish Mission Indian Boarding School property. In the first place, the Court functions only to assess values, in which connection a letter of the Assessor received at the conclusion of the Court sittings is sent you herewith.

I then asked the Court to consider any possible reduction that can be made under the Municipal Act, by way of eliminating the actual improvements, that is the actual site of school and outbuildings, or improvements, but the City Solicitor advised the Court that there was nothing in the Municipal Act to give authority for immunity from taxation in respect of property such as referred to. I then asked the Court if it thought the school portion of the taxes could be eliminated if the matter were brought to the Council's attention. The Court's reply was that as the school in question is not a city school it would have to pay taxes as other schools, not being city schools in the vicinity, were paying.

Reference was made smilingly by the Court Chairman to the purchase by the Department of block 123, under which purchase the land, being vested in the Crown, became immune from taxation, detrimental to the best interests of the Municipality from a financial standpoint, and it was thought there would be no disposition on the part of the City Council to make any arrangement for tax reduction below assessed values in view of this.

Dear Mr. Kearns:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to certain payments made by this Department in connection with the Squamish Indian Boarding School in North Vancouver.

In reply I wish to state that this school is situated within the Municipality of North Vancouver, on property not owned by the Government. It is maintained by a per capita grant paid from parliamentary appropriation. Representations were made to the Department that owing to the situation of the school the financial aid so derived was inadequate. I decided, therefore, to relieve them of taxation, which would place this school in the same position as an institution located on an Indian reserve. We therefore purchased Block 123, District Lot 271, North Vancouver, from the Reverend Sisters, and as it is now Government property, it is non-taxable, and we have assumed the payment of the taxes on Lot 69, on which the school buildings are situated.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

Re: Block 123, D.L.271, City of North Vancouver  
Your file B.5312.

Your letter to the Corporation of the City of North Vancouver has been referred to me for reply.

The City does not for a moment contend that it can assess and levy taxes on property the fee of which is in the Crown nor had the block in question been assessed since its transference to the Crown.

The facts are that up until July, 1922 the property in question was registered in the name of Marie Chaminade of North Vancouver. Block 122 adjoining was also assessed in her name. There are various buildings consisting of a school, priest's house etc. erected on Block 122; Block 123 being a vacant piece of ground. The school referred to is not one for the education of Indian children, but receives any child of the Catholic faith.

On the 27th of July, 1922, taxes due were as follows:

Under the provisions of our Municipal act the 1922 taxes had been assessed some months before the Crown acquired title. The Crown therefore acquired the property with taxes properly assessed against it, and the Municipality is simply exercising its rights to sell the lands for taxes assessed prior to the Crown acquiring the property. You will observe that under Sec. 233 our Municipal act (R.S.B.C. 1924, Chap. 179) taxes are considered to have been imposed on and from the 1st day of January in each year. When you have considered the matter in this light, I have no doubt that you will appreciate and agree with the viewpoint of the City.

The Council has no desire to indulge in litigation and feels sure that, with the facts as outlined herein before you, you will agree that the Corporation is entitled to taxes due prior to the acquisition of the land by the Crown and amounting to $781.01 with interest thereon.

The Council further regrets that the remarks of my predecessor have given umbrage. It would be idle to deny that the transaction did not at the time of its completion seem curious to the citizens of North Vancouver. At no time however has the Council suggested that the Crown was party to any colourable transaction, but at time it was felt that the Crown might have been made an innocent party to a transaction detrimental to the City's interests owing to all facts not having been put before the proper Ministers.

The facts as I am advised are that in 1922, the Council was approached by a party other than the Crown with a view to having said Block 123 exempted from taxation. Apart from there being no authority under the Municipal act...
for so doing, the Council in any case could see no valid reason for complying. The statement was then made by the applicant that the owners could get exemption in some other way. Shortly after, the Block was transferred to the Crown and has ever since been left undeveloped and unused with the local improvements charged against it payable by the City, in addition to the loss of revenue from taxes. I take it however from your letter that you are satisfied that the Crown was not made use of by the former owners of the land without being made aware of all the facts. There is, as you no doubt know, an Indian Reserve within the City Boundaries.

I shall be glad to hear from you and if you agree that the City is rightly entitled under the circumstances to $781.01 with interest thereon, the whole situation will be cleared up.

Yours truly,

"A. AITKEN GRAY"

City Solicitor.

AAG/ALJ

P.S. I shall be glad to give you any further information you desire either as to taxes or as to conditions when the Crown took over.
I have the honour to refer to your letter of May 20th, 1925, and to pass you here-with copy of letter just received from the City Solicitor, North Vancouver and your departmental file and Certificate of Title No. 77653-I covering Block 123, D.L.271. I should be glad of any remarks or further instructions you may have to give us herein and would ask for return of your file and papers should such instructions call for further consideration of this material.

So far as taxes attaching as of January 1st of the year of assessment are concerned, I might say that in 1922 this department was in correspondence with the Municipality of Point Grey upon a similar question, which eventually became the subject of suit. The case did not come to trial, having been settled as a result of negotiations. The point involved was whether, under the circumstances of that case, the taxes accrued January 1st of the year of assessment or later as of the date of notice to the land owner, the Crown having purchased in the interim and being inclined to contend that taxes should be adjusted as of the date of purchase. Our agents advised us at the time that...
the Government had a reasonable prospect of success in the litigation, but the officers of the municipality during their presence in Ottawa represented very strongly what they considered to be the injustice of the Government's contention, pointing out that the municipality put in extensive water works, sewers, streets, sidewalks etc., improving the neighbourhood with the expectation that the cost would be covered by rateable taxation over all the property affected by the improvements; that in the absence of these improvements the property would not have been suitable for the Government purposes and therefore would not have been taken, and that it came as a surprise to the municipality that the Government should in the circumstances repudiate liability for its proportion of the taxes for the year in which the property was acquired. While these people realized that for the future there would be no legal liability and therefore no claim they considered that for the single year in question, seeing that the law of the case was doubtful and the merits of their claim, from their point of view, so well established, the Government should admit and pay the claim to the extent of the principal amount, the municipality agreeing to remit the balance and pay its own costs of the litigation. This department, on that occasion, felt that we had an arguable case with a fair chance to succeed, but that in the case of most lawsuits it was impossible to predict the ultimate result.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

Dear Sir:

I wish to refer to your notice, No. 6634, dated the 26th of March, last, which is relative to Block 123, D. L. 271, North Vancouver. I referred this matter to the Department of Justice and they have been in correspondence with Mr. A. Aitken Gray, City Solicitor. This gentleman's letter to the Deputy Minister of Justice, dated the 18th of June, last, explains the viewpoint of the City of North Vancouver. I now understand that the 1922 taxes had been assessed some months before the Crown acquired title and that you are asking payment of the taxes in full for that year. I am advised that the law in this case is doubtful and, although I consider we have a reasonable prospect of success in the event of litigation, the Department of Indian Affairs will be willing, in view of the representations of your City Solicitor, to pay the balance of taxes for the year 1922, amounting to $761.01. If this is satisfactory to the corporation, I should be pleased if you would let me have an account in duplicate for this amount.

In the light of the fact that this Department received a few weeks ago for the first time information that the City of North Vancouver considered the balance of taxes for 1922 should be paid, I cannot agree to pay interest on the principal amount.

Yours truly,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

re Block 123, D.L. 271, North Vancouver—Your file 167-1-9.

With reference to your letter of August 1st last to the City Treasurer, I have in the meantime been making enquiries as to the attitude of the Dominion Government with reference to local improvements charged in other cities on the Coast on property acquired by the Government after the local improvements had been done. I find that both in Vancouver and Victoria the Government has always commuted the local improvements and paid the City. This would seem to be only fair and equitable.

For your information I am enclosing herewith particulars of local improvements charged against the above property under by-laws 49, 61, 171, and 204, together with a summary. All statements are sent to you in quadruplicate. I believe that the Government has some special form which it desires to be completed in such cases, these being, I believe, supplied by the Department of Public Works. If you wish these completed and will send me a supply, I shall be glad to arrange for their proper completion.
I feel sure that you will agree that the City of North Vancouver should be treated in exactly the same way as other Cities and Municipalities in British Columbia, and that therefore the Local Improvement rates should be settled by the Government through your department.

Awaiting the favour of your reply,

I remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

City Solicitor.
